# Source Definitions: (AS) = Abbott Smith - from https://github.com/translatable-exegetical-tools/Abbott-Smith, with corrections and adapted by Tyndale Scholars. 
# Source Definitions: (ML) = Middle Liddell - from Perseus - used for Meaning in the Brief lexicon when there is no entry by (AS)

# COLUMNS
#	STRONGS
#		Strong's number with extensions
#		G0001  - G5624,  Strongs numbers from original set made by Strong for Greek behind the KJV  
#		G3203  - G3302,  Not used for some reason
#		G5627  - G5799,  Greek morphology codes  (these numbers aren't used in this lexicon) 
#		G5800  - G5893,  Greek Synonyms - see http://studybible.info/strongs/G5800  (these numbers aren't used in this lexicon) 
#		G6000  - G6090,  Extra Strongs Numbers in NASB mainly for variants not known to Strong. (they remain the same so it is backward-compatible with NASB) 
#		G6100  - G9979,  Extra Greek from Apostolic Bible Project mainly for LXX words not found in NT (including Greek names that don't occur in the Hebrew) 
#		G6091  - G6099,  G9980 - G9999, Extra Greek for variants which are not included in NASB or Apostolic Bible  
#		G10000 - G19999, Greek equivalent of Strongs Hebrew numbers for names and transliterated words eg  Abagtha (H0005) = G10005. When there is a NT equivalent, this is the STEP_LexicalTag
#		G20000 - G20199, Words where  the Full LSJ entry refers to the LXX, but they are not referred to in the AB tagging because they only occur in non-Protestant canons or in MSS other than Vaticanus (used by AB)
#	WORD
#		Greek word in unicode lexical form. Based on LSJ but conforming to BADG when the difference may be confusing.
#	TRANS
#		Transliteration
#	GLOSS
#		A meaning in one word or as few as possible (by Tyndale scholars)
#	MORPH
#		Simple gramatical value of the main word represented as Language:Type-Gender-Extra
#		Language is A=Aramaic, H=Hebrew, G=Greek and N=Name (which is not language specific).
#		Type is A=Adjective, Adv=Adverb, Art=Article, Cond=Conditional, Conj=Conjunction, Cor=Correlative, DemP=Demonstrative Pn, ImpP=Impersonal Pn, Intg=Interogative,
#			Intj=Interjection, N=Noun, Neg=Negative, Part=Particle, Prep=Preposition, PerP=Personal Pn, PosP=Possessive Pn, RefP=Reflexive Pn, RelP=Relative Pn, V=Verb.
#		Gender is F=Female, M=Male, N=Neuter, C=Common and P or S is optionally added for Plural Singular
#		Extra for Names is L=Location, P=Person, LG/PG=Gentilic, T=Title (i.e. any other capitalised nouns such as titles, months, gods, planets etc)
#	DEF
#		Definition, lexical entry.
#		The Brief lexicon uses Abbot-Smith or MiddleLiddel or Mounce's Teknia when entries are missing.
#		(AS) = Abbott Smith - from https://github.com/translatable-exegetical-tools/Abbott-Smith, with corrections and adapted by Tyndale Scholars. 
#		(ML) = Middle Liddell - from Perseus - used for Meaning in the Brief lexicon when there is no entry by (AS)
#		(MT) = Mounce's Teknia Greek dictionary - from www.billmounce.com/greek-dictionary (with permission) -  used for Meaning in the Brief lexicon when there is no entry by (AS) or (ML)
#
STRONGS	WORD	TRANS	GLOSS	MORPH	DEF
G1	Ἀλφα	Alpha	alpha	G:N	<b>Α, α, ἄλφα</b> (which see), τό, indecl, <b>alpha</b>, the first letter of the Greek alphabet. As a numeral, ά = 1, α = 1000. As a prefix, it appears to have at least two and perhaps three distinct senses: 1) ἀ- (before a vowel, ἀν-) <b>negative</b>, as in ἄ-γνωστος, ἄ-δικος. 2) ἀ, ἁ- <b>copulative</b>, indicating community and fellowship, as in ἁ-πλοῦς, ἀ-κολουθέω, ἀ-δελφός. 3) An <b>intensive</b> force (LS, s. α), as in ἀ-τενίζω is sometimes assumed (but see Boisacq, see word). (AS)
G2	Ἀαρών	Aarōn	Aaron	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀαρών</b> (Heb. אַהֲרוֹן), indecl. (in FlJ, -ῶνος), <b>Aaron</b> (Exo.4:14, al.): Luk.1:5, Act.7:40, Heb.5:4, 7:11, 9:4. (AS)
G3	Ἀβαδδών	Abaddōn	Abaddon	N:N--T	<b>Ἀβαδδών</b> (Heb. אֲבַדּוֹן, <b>destruction</b>; LXX, ἀπώλεια, only in Wisdom Lit, of the place of the ruined dead: Job.26:6, 28:22, 31:12, Psa.88:12, Pro.15:11 *), indecl; in NT, <b>Abaddon</b>, the angel of the Abyss: Rev.9:11. (AS)
G4	ἀβαρής	abarēs	not burdensome	G:A	<b>αβαρής</b>, -ές (&lt; βαρός), <b>without weight</b>; metaph. (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word) <b>not burdensome</b>: 2Co.11:9. (AS)
G5	ἀββά	abba	Father	G:N-M	<b>Ἀββά</b> (T, -ᾶ), indecl. (Aram, אַבָּא, emphatic form of אַב = Heb. אָב, <b>father</b>), used in the phrase Ἀ. ὁ παήρ, <b>Abba, Father</b> (see Swete on Mk, I.with): Mrk.14:36, Rom.8:15, Gal.4:6. (AS)
G6	Ἄβελ	Abel	Abel	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἄβελ</b>, (WH, Ἅ-), ὁ, indecl. (הֶבֶל), <b>Abel</b> (Gen.4:2-10): Heb.11:4, 12:24; αἵμα Ἄ, Mat.23:35, Luk.11:51. (AS)
G7	Ἀβιά	Abia	Abijah	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀβιά</b> (Heb. אֲבִיָּה, אֲבִיָּהוּ), ὁ, indecl. (in FlJ, Ἀβίας, -α), <b>Abia, Abijah</b>. 1) Son of Rehoboam (3Ki.14:1): Mat.1:7. 2) A priest of the line of Eleazar (1Ch.24:3, 10): Luk.1:5. (AS)
G8	Ἀβιαθάρ	Abiathar	Abiathar	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀβιάθαρ</b>, ὁ, indecl. (Heb. אֶבְיָתָר), <b>Abiathar</b> (1Ki.21:1): Mrk.2:26. (AS)
G9	Ἀβιληνή	Abilēnē	Abilene	N:N-F-L	<b>Ἀβειληνή</b> (T, Rec. Ἀβι-), -ῆς, ἡ, (sc. χώρα), <b>Abilene</b>, <b>a district in the Anti-Lebanon</b>: Luk.3:1. (AS)
G10	Ἀβιούδ	Abioud	Abiud	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀβιούδ</b>, ὁ, indecl. (Heb. אֲבִיָּהוּד), <b>Abiud, Abihud</b>: Mat.1:13. (AS)
G11	Ἀβραάμ	Abraam	Abraham	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀβραάμ</b> (Heb. אַבְרָהָם), ὁ, indecl. (in FlJ, Ἄβραμος, -ου; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), <b>Abraham</b> (Gen.17:5 al.): Mat.1:1, 2 al. (AS)
G12	ἄβυσσος	abussos	abyss	G:N-F	<b>ἄ-βυσσος</b>, -ον (Ion. βυσσός = βυθός), 1) in cl, <b>boundless, bottomless</b> (e.g. ἄ. πέλαγος, ἄ. πλοῦτος Æsch.). 2) [In LXX (for תְּהוֹם, Gen.1:2, al; exc. Isa.44:27, Job.41:22 for צוּלָה, מְצוּלָה, Job.36:16 for רַחַב) and] NT, as subst. (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), ἡ ἄ. (sc. χώρα), <b>the abyss</b>; (a) of the sea (Gen.1:2); (b) <b>of the underworld, as the abode of the dead</b>: Rom.10:7 (a paraphrase of Deu.30:13 LXX); as the abode of demons, Luk.8:31, Rev.9:1, 2, 11, 11:7, 17:8, 20:1, 3 (Cremer, 2). (AS)
G13	Ἄγαβος	Agabos	Agabus	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἄγαβος</b>, -ου, ὁ <b>Agabus</b>: Act.11:28, 21:10. (AS)
G14	ἀγαθοεργέω	agathoergeō	to do good	G:V	<b>ἀγαθοεργέω</b>, -ῶ, <b>to do good, show kindness</b>: 1 Ti 6:18 (Cremer, 8). <b>ἀγαθουργέω</b>, -ῶ, contracted form (rare, see WH, <i>App</i>, 145) of ἀγαθοερ- (which see), <b>to do good</b>: Act.14:17. (AS)
G15	ἀγαθοποιέω	agathopoieō	to do good	G:V	<b>ἀγαθὀ-ποιέω</b>, -ῶ (= cl. ἀγαθὸν ποιεῖν, εὐεργετεῖν), [in LXX: Num.10:32, Jdg.17:13 A, Zep.1:12 (יטב hi.), Tob.12:13 B, 1Ma.11:33, 2Ma.1:2 *;] <b>to do good</b>; (a) univ: 1Pe.2:15, 20, 3:6, 17, 3 Jo.11; (b) <b>for another's benefit</b>: Mrk.3:4 (T, ἀγαθὸν ποιῆσαι), Luk.6:9; (with) accusative of person(s), Luk.6:33, 35 (Cremer, 8). (AS)
G16	ἀγαθοποιΐα	agathopoiia	doing good	G:N-F	<b>ἀγαθοποιία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἀγαθοποιός), <b>well-doing</b>: 1Pe.4:19. (AS)
G17	ἀγαθοποιός	agathopoios	doing good	G:N-M	<b>ἀγαθοποιός</b>, -όν = cl. ἀγαθουργός, [in LXX, of a woman who deals pleasantly in order to corrupt, Sir.42:14 *;] <b>doing well, acting rightly</b> (Plut.): 1Pe.2:14 (Cremer, 8; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G18	ἀγαθός	agathos	good-doer	G:A	<b>ἀγαθός</b>, -ή, -όν, [in LXX chiefly for טוֹב;] in general, <b>good</b>, in physical and in moral sense, used of persons, things, acts, conditions, etc, applied to that which is regarded as "perfect in its kind, so as to produce pleasure and satisfaction. that which, in itself good, is also at once for the good and the advantage of him who comes in contact with it" (Cremer, 3): γῆ, Luk.8:8; δένδρον, Mat.7:18; καρδία, Luk.8:15; δόσις, Jas.1:17; μέρις, Luk.10:42; ἔργον (freq. in Pl.), Php.1:6; ἐλπίς, 2Th.2:16; θησαυρός, Mat.12:35; μνεία, 1Th.3:6 (cf. 2Ma.7:20); as subst, τὸ ἀ, that which is morally good, beneficial, acceptable to God, Rom.12:2; ἐργάζεσθαι τὸ ἀ, Rom.2:10, Eph.4:28; πράσσειν, Rom.9:11, 2Co.5:10; διώκειν, 1Th.5:15; μιμεῖσθαι, III Jo 11; κολλᾶσθαι τῷ ἀ, Rom.12:9; ερωτᾶν περὶ τοῦ ἀ, Mat.19:17; διάκονος εἰς τὸ ἀ, Rom.13:4; τὸ ἀ. σου, <b>thy favour, benefit</b>, Phm 14; pl, τὰ ἀ, of goods, possessions, Luk.12:18; of spiritual benefits, Rom.10:15, Heb.9:11, 10:1. ἀ is opp. to πονηρός, Mat.5:45, 20:5; κακός, Rom.7:19; φαῦλος, Rom.9:11, 2Co.5:10 (cf. MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G19	ἀγαθωσύνη	agathōsunē	goodness	G:N-F	<b>ἀγαθωσύνη</b> (on the termination, see: ἁγιότης, and cf. WH, <i>App</i>, 152; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), -ης, ἡ (&lt; ἀγαθός), [in LXX for טוֹבָה, טוֹב, טוּב, only in Heb. bks;] <b>goodness</b> (representing "the kindlier, as δικαιοσύνη, the sterner element in the ideal character," AE, <i>Eph</i>, 5:9; on its relation to χρηστότης, see Tr, <i>Syn</i>, §lxiii): Rom.15:14, Gal.5:22, 2Th.1:11. (AS)
G20	ἀγαλλίασις	agalliasis	joy	G:N-F	<b>ἀγαλλίασις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀγαλλιάω), [in LXX (most freq. in Pss. and often coupled with εὐφροσύνη, as Ps 44(45):15) chiefly for גִּיל;] <b>exultation, exuberant joy</b>: Luk.1:44, Act.2:46, Heb.1:9, Ju 24; χαρὰ καὶ ἀ, Luk.1:14 (Cremer, 592). (AS)
G21	ἀγαλλιάω	agalliaō	to rejoice	G:V	<b>ἀγαλλιάω</b>, -ῶ, Hellenistic form of cl. ἀγάλλω, <b>to glorify</b>, mid. -ομαι, <b>to exult in</b>; [in LXX (most freq. in Pss.) chiefly for גיל, רנן pi;] <b>to exult, rejoice greatly</b>: before ἐπί, with dative, Luk.1:47; with dative mod, 1Pe.1:8, Rev.19:7. Mid, with same sense: Mat.5:12, Luk.10:21, Act.2:26, 16:34, 1Pe.4:13; before ἵνα, Jhn.8:56; ἐν, Jhn.5:35 (1 aor. pass. perh. as mid; but see Mozley, <i>Psalter</i>, 5), 1Pe.1:6 (Cremer, 590). (AS)
G22	ἄγαμος	agamos	unmarried	G:N-B	<b>ἄ-γαμος</b>, -ον [in LXX: 4Ma.16:9 *;] <b>unmarried</b>: 1Co.7:8, 32; fem. (= cl. ἄνανδρος), ib. 11, 34. (AS)
G23	ἀγανακτέω	aganakteō	be indignant	G:V	<b>ἀγανακτέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt;ἄγαν, <b>much</b>, ἄχομαι, <b>to grieve</b>), [in LXX: Wis.5:22, 12:27, Da TH Bel 28, 4Ma.4:21 *;] <b>to be indignant</b>: Mat.21:15, 26:8, Mrk.10:14, 14:4; before περί, Mat.20:24, Mrk.10:41; before ὅτι, Luk.13:14 (see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G24	ἀγανάκτησις	aganaktēsis	indignation	G:N-F	<b>ἀγανάκτησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀγανακτέω), [in LXX: Est.18:3 א 1 *;] <b>indignation</b>: 2Co.7:11 (see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G25	ἀγαπάω	agapaō	to love	G:V	<b>ἀγαπάω</b>, -ῶ, [in LXX chiefly for אהב;] <b>to love</b>, to feel and exhibit esteem and goodwill to a person, to prize and delight in a thing. 1) <b>Of human affection, to men</b>: τ. πλησίον, Mat.5:43; τ. ἐχθρούς, ib. 44; to Christ, Jhn.8:42; to God, Mat.22:37; with accusative of thing(s), Luk.11:43, Jhn.12:43, Eph.5:25, II Tim 4:8, 10, Heb.1:9, 1Pe.2:17, 3:10, 2Pe.2:15, 1Jn.2:15, Rev.12:11. 2) <b>Of divine love</b>; (a) <b>God's love</b>: to men, Rom.8:37; to Christ, Jhn.3:35; (b) <b>Christ's love</b>: to men, Mrk.10:21; to God, Jhn.14:31; with cogn. accusative, Jhn.17:26, Eph.2:4. (AS)
G26	ἀγάπη	agapē	love	G:N-F	<b>ἀγάπη</b>, -ης, ἡ [in LXX for אַהֲבָה, which is also rendered by ἀγάπησις and φιλία;] <b>love, goodwill, esteem</b>. Outside of bibl. and eccl. books, there is no clear instance (with Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 18:4, 70:2, cf. the same writer in <i>Constr. Quar.</i>, ii, 4; and with MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word, cf. Dr. Moulton in <i>Exp. Times</i>, xxvi, 3, 139). In NT, like ἀγαπάω, -ῶ, 1) <b>Of men's love</b>: (a) to one another, Jhn.13:35; (b) to God, 1Jn.2:5. 2) <b>Of divine love</b>; (a) <b>God's love</b>: to men, Rom.5:8; to Christ, Jhn.17:26; (b) <b>Christ's love to men</b>: Rom.8:35. 3) In pl, <b>love feasts</b>: Ju 12 (<i>DB</i>, iii, 157). (AS)
G27	ἀγαπητός	agapētos	beloved	G:A	<b>ἀγαπητός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; ἀγαπάω), [in LXX chiefly for יָתִיד, יָדִיד;] <b>beloved</b> (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 221); (a) <b>by God</b>: of Christ, Mat.3:17; of men, Rom.1:7; (b) <b>by Christians, of one another</b>: 1Co.4:14; freq. as form of address, ib. 10:14; opp. to ἐχθρός, Rom.11:28 (see AR, <i>Eph.</i>, 229; Cremer, 17; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G28	Ἄγαρ	Agar	Hagar	N:N-F-P	<b>Ἅγαρ</b> (Rec. Ἄ-), ἡ, indecl. (in FlJ, Ἀγάρα, -ης, Heb. הָגָר), <b>Hagar</b> (Gen.16): Gal.4:24,25. (AS)
G29	ἀγγαρεύω	aggareuō	to force	G:V	<b>ἀγγαρεύω</b> (from the Persian; cf. Vg. angiare, and the Heb. אִגֶרֶת; on the orthogr, see Bl, §6, 1; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), <b>to impress</b> into public service, employ a courier; hence, <b>to compel</b> to perform a service (prob. common in the vernac; cf. Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 86f, MM, <i>Exp.</i>, iv; <i>VGT</i>, see word): Mat.5:41, 27:32, Mrk.15:21. (AS)
G30	ἀγγεῖον	aggeion	jar	G:N-N	<b>ἀγγεῖον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; ἄγγος), [in LXX chiefly for כְּלִי;] <b>a vessel</b> (see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Mat.25:4. (AS)
G31	ἀγγελία	aggelia	message	G:N-F	<b>ἀγγελία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἄγγελος), [in LXX chiefly for שְׁמוּעָה;] <b>a message</b>: 1Jo.1:5, 3:11 (Cremer, 18; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G32	ἄγγελος	aggelos	angel	G:N-M	<b>ἄγγελος</b>, -ου, ὁ, [in LXX chiefly for מַלְאָךְ;] 1) <b>a messenger</b>, <b>one sent</b>: Mat.11:10, Jas.22:25. 2) As in LXX, in the special sense of <b>angel</b>, a spiritual, heavenly being, attendant upon God and employed as his messenger to men, to make known his purposes, as Luk.1:11, or to execute them, as Mat.4:6. The ἄ. in Rev.1:20-2:1, al, is variously understood as (1) <b>a messenger or delegate, </b> (2) <b>a bishop or ruler, </b> (3) <b>a guardian angel, </b> (4) the prevailing spirit of each church, i.e. the Church itself. (Cf. Swete, <i>Ap</i>), in l; DB, iv, 991; Thayer, see word; Cremer, 18; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word) (AS)
G33	ἄγε	age	to lead	G:V	<b>ἄγε</b>, prop. imperat. of ἄγω, <b>come!</b> used as <i>adv.</i> and addressed, like φέρε, <b>to one or more persons</b>: Jas.4:13, 5:1. (AS)
G34	ἀγέλη	agelē	herd	G:N-F	<b>ἀγέλη</b>, -ης, ἡ (&lt; ἄγω), [in LXX chiefly for עֵ֫דֶר;] <b>a herd</b>: Mat.8:30-32, Mrk.5:11, 13, Luk.8:32,33. (AS)
G35	ἀγενεαλόγητος	agenealogētos	without genealogy	G:A	<b>ἀγενεαλόγητος</b>, -ον (&lt; γενεαλογέω), <b>without genealogy</b>, i.e. without recorded pedigree (cf. Neh.7:64): Heb.7:3 (Cremer, 152; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G36	ἀγενής	agenēs	lowly	G:A	<b>ἀγενής</b>, -ές (&lt; γένος), 1) <b>unborn</b> (Plat.); 2) <b>of no family, ignoble, base</b> (opp. to ἀγαθός, Soph, Fr, 105): opp. to εὐγενής, 1Co.1:28 (for exx. from π, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G37	ἁγιάζω	hagiazō	to sanctify	G:V	<b>ἁγιάζω</b>, Hellenistic form of ἁγίζω (&lt; ἅγιος), <b>to make holy, consecrate, sanctify</b>; [in LXX chiefly for קדשׁ pi, hi;] 1) <b>to dedicate, separate, set apart for God</b>; of things: Mat.23:17,19, 2Ti.2:21; of persons: Christ, Jhn.10:36, 17:19. 2) <b>to purify</b>, <b>make conformable in character to such dedication</b>: forensically, to free from guilt, 1Co.6:11, Eph.5:26, Heb.2:11, 10:10, 14, 29, 13:12; internally, by actual sanctification of life, Jhn.17:17, 19, Act.20:32, 26:18, Rom.15:16, 1Co.1:2, 7:14, 1Th.5:23, Rev.22:11; of a nonbeliever influenced by marriage with a Christian, 1Co.7:14. 3) <b>In the intermediate sense of ceremonial or levitical purification</b>: (a) of things, 2Ti.2:21; (b) of persons, Heb.9:13. 4) <b>to treat as holy</b>: Mat.6:9, Luk.11:2, 1Pe.3:16 (Cremer, 53, 602; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G38	ἁγιασμός	hagiasmos	holiness	G:N-M	<b>ἁγιασμός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; ἁγιάζω), [in LXX: Eze.45:4 (מִקְדָּשׁ), Sir.7:31, etc;] as an active verbal noun in -μός, it signifies properly the process τὸ ἁγιάζειν, rather than the resultant state, ἁγιωσύνη, hence, 1) <b>consecration</b>; 2) <b>sanctification</b>: so strictly in Rom.6:19,22 (but see Meyer), 1Co.1:30, 1Th.4:3,7, 2Th.2:13, Heb.12:14, 1Pe.1:2. Elsewhere it perhaps (Ellic; but see Milligan, <i>Th.</i>, 48) inclines to the resultant state: 1Th.4:4, 1Ti.2:15 (Cremer, 55, 602). (AS)
G39	ἅγιον	hagion	holy	G:A	<b>ἅγιος</b>, -α, ον (&lt; τό ἅγός, <b>religious awe</b>; ἅζω, <b>to venerate</b>), [in LXX chiefly for קֹ֫דֶשׁ;] primarily, <b>dedicated to the gods, sacred</b> (Hdt; rare in Att, never in Hom, Hes. and Trag, who use ἁγνός), hence, <b>holy</b>, characteristic of God, separated to God, worthy of veneration. 1) <b> Its highest application is to God himself, in his purity, majesty, and glory</b>: Luk.1:49, Jhn.17:11, Rev.4:8. Hence (a) of things and places which have a claim to reverence as sacred to God, e.g. the Temple: Mat.24:15, Heb.9:1; (b) <b>of persons employed by him, as angels</b>: 1Th.3:13; prophets, Luk.1:70; apostles, Eph.3:5. 2) <b>Applied to persons as separated to God's service</b>: (a) of Christ, Mrk.1:24, Jhn.6:69, Act.4:30; (b) of Christians, Act.9:13, Rom.1:7, Heb.6:10, Rev.5:8. 3) <b>In the moral sense of sharing God's purity</b>: Mrk.6:20, Jhn.17:11, Act.3:14, Rev.3:7. 4) <b>Of pure, clean sacrifices and offerings</b>: 1Co.7:14, Eph.1:4. (AS)
G40	ἅγιος	hagios	holy	G:A	<b>ἅγιος</b>, -α, ον (&lt; τό ἅγός, <b>religious awe</b>; ἅζω, <b>to venerate</b>), [in LXX chiefly for קֹ֫דֶשׁ;] primarily, <b>dedicated to the gods, sacred</b> (Hdt; rare in Att, never in Hom, Hes. and Trag, who use ἁγνός), hence, <b>holy</b>, characteristic of God, separated to God, worthy of veneration. 1) <b> Its highest application is to God himself, in his purity, majesty, and glory</b>: Luk.1:49, Jhn.17:11, Rev.4:8. Hence (a) of things and places which have a claim to reverence as sacred to God, e.g. the Temple: Mat.24:15, Heb.9:1; (b) <b>of persons employed by him, as angels</b>: 1Th.3:13; prophets, Luk.1:70; apostles, Eph.3:5. 2) <b>Applied to persons as separated to God's service</b>: (a) of Christ, Mrk.1:24, Jhn.6:69, Act.4:30; (b) of Christians, Act.9:13, Rom.1:7, Heb.6:10, Rev.5:8. 3) <b>In the moral sense of sharing God's purity</b>: Mrk.6:20, Jhn.17:11, Act.3:14, Rev.3:7. 4) <b>Of pure, clean sacrifices and offerings</b>: 1Co.7:14, Eph.1:4. (AS)
G41	ἁγιότης	hagiotēs	holiness	G:N-F	<b>ἁγιότης</b>, -ητος, ἡ (&lt; ἅγιος), [in LXX: 2Ma.15:2 *;] <b>sanctity</b>, <b>holiness</b>, <b>regarded, properly, as an abstract quality </b>(see next word, and cf. Lft. Notes, 49; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): 2Co.1:12, Heb.12:10. (AS)
G42	ἁγιωσύνη	hagiōsunē	holiness	G:N-F	<b>ἁγιωσύνη</b> (cf. ἀγαθωσύνη), -ης, ἡ (&lt; ἅγιος), [in LXX: Psa.29 (30):4 96(97):12 (קֹדֶשׁ), 95(96):6 (עֹז), 144(145):5 (הוֹד), 2Ma.3:12 *;] <b>holiness</b>, the state in man resulting from ἁγιασμός, which see: Rom.1:4, 2Co.7:1, 1Th.3:13 (Cremer, 52; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G43	ἀγκάλη	agkalē	arm	G:N-F	<b>ἀγκάλη,-ης, ἡ</b> (&lt; ἄγκος, <b>a bend</b>), [in LXX for אַצִּיל, חֵיק;] <b>the bent arm</b>: Luk.2:28 (cf. ἐναγκαλίζομαι). (AS)
G44	ἄγκιστρον	agkistron	fishhook	G:N-N	<b>ἄγκιστρον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; ἄγκος, a bend), [in LXX חַכָּה, etc;] <b>a fish-hook</b>: Mat.17:27. (AS)
G45	ἄγκυρα	agkura	anchor	G:N-F	<b>ἄγκυρα</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἄγκος, a bend), [in Sm: Jer.52:18 *;] <b>an anchor</b>: Act.27:29, 30 40; figuratively (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), Heb.6:19. (AS)
G46	ἄγναφος	agnaphos	unshrunk	G:A	<b>ἄγναφος</b>, -ον (= ἄγναπτος, &lt; γνάπτω, late form of κνάπτω, <b>to card wool</b>), <b>uncarded, undressed</b>, i.e. new (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Mat.92:6, Mrk.2:21. (AS)
G47	ἁγνεία	hagneia	purity	G:N-F	<b>ἁγνεία</b> (WH, ἁγνία), [in LXX for טָהֳרָה, נָזִיר, נֶזֶר, etc;] <b>purity</b>: 1Ti.4:12, 5:2 (Cremer, 58. For exx. of ceremonial use in π, see MM, <i>Exp.</i>, iv). (AS)
G48	ἁγνίζω	hagnizō	to purify	G:V	<b>ἁγνίζω</b> (&gt; ἁγνός), [in LXX always ceremonially, chiefly for קָדַשׁ;] <b>to purify</b>, <b>cleanse from defilement</b>; (a) <b>ceremonially</b>: Jhn.11:55, Act.21:24, 26 24:18; (b) <b>morally</b>: Jas.4:8, 1Pe.1:22, 1Jn.3:3. (AS)
G49	ἁγνισμός	hagnismos	purification	G:N-M	<b>ἁγνισμός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&gt; ἁγνίζω), [in LXX: Num.6:5 (נֵזֶר) 8:7 19:17 (חַטָּאָה), etc;] <b>purification</b>: in ceremonial sense, Act.21:26 (LXX). (AS)
G50	ἀγνοέω	agnoeō	be ignorant	G:V	<b>ἀγνοέω</b>, -ῶ (&gt; ἁγνίζω), [in LXX for שָׁגָה, שָׁגַג, אָשַׁם, etc;] 1) <b>to be ignorant</b>, <b>not to know</b>: absol, Ι Ti 1:13, Heb.5:2; with accusative, Act.13:27 17:23, Rom.10:3, 2Co.2:11; ἐν οἷς, 2Pe.2:12; before ὅτι, Rom.2:4 6:3 7:1, 1Co.14:38; οὐ θέλω ὑμᾶς ἀγνοεῖν, <b>a Pauline phrase</b>: with accusative, Rom.11:25; before ὑπέρ, 2Co.1:8; περί, 1Co.12:1, 1Th.4:13. ὅτι, Rom.1:13, 1Co.10:1 (for similar usage in π, V. MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). Pass: 1Co.14:38, 2Co.6:9, Gal.1:22. 2) <b>not to understand</b>: with accusative, Mrk.9:32, Luk.9:45. (AS)
G51	ἀγνόημα	agnoēma	error	G:N-N	<b>ἀγνόημα</b>, -τός, τό (&lt; ἀγνοέω), [in LXX: Gen.43:12 (מִשְׁגֶּה), Tob.3:3, Jdth.5:20, Sir.23:2 51:19, 1Ma.13:39 *;] <b>a sin of ignorance</b> (so in π; see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Heb.9:7. (AS)
G52	ἄγνοια	agnoia	ignorance	G:N-F	<b>ἄγνοια</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἀγνοέω), [in LXX chiefly for אָשָׁם, שְׁגָגָה;] <b>ignorance</b>: Act.3:17 17:30, Eph.4:18 (with sense of wilful blindness; cf. MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), 1Pe.1:14. (AS)
G53	ἁγνός	hagnos	pure	G:A	<b>ἁγνός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; ἅγος, see: ἅγιος), [in LXX chiefly for טָהוֹר (Pss, and Pr. only), also 2Ma.13:8, 4Ma.18:7, al;] 1) <b>free from ceremonial defilement</b>, in a condition prepared for worship (for exx. of pagan usage, V. G56	ἀγνωσία	agnōsia	ignorance	G:N-F	<b>ἀγνωσία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; γινώσκω), [in LXX: Job.35:16 (בִּבְלִי־דַּעַת), Wis.13:1, 3Ma.5:27 *;] <b>ignorance</b> (opp. to γνῶσις): 1Co.15:34, 1Pe.2:15 (see Hort in l; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)

G58	ἀγορά	agora	marketplace	G:N-F	<b>ἀγορά</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἀγείρω, <b>to bring together</b>) [in LXX for עִזָּבוֹן, שׁוּק;] 1) <b>an assembly</b> (Hom, Xen, al.). 2) <b>a place of assembly</b>, <b>a public place</b> or <b>forum</b>, <b>a market-place</b> (Hom, Thuc, al; LXX): Mat.11:16 20:2 23:7, Mrk.6:56 (cf. G59	ἀγοράζω	agorazō	to buy	G:V	<b>ἀγοράζω</b> (&lt; ἀγορά), [in LXX chiefly for שׁבר, קנה;] 1) <b>to frequent the ἀγορά </b> (Hdt, al.). 2) <b>to buy in the market</b>, <b>purchase</b> (Xen, al; LXX; in π. very common in deeds of sale, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): absol, Mat.21:12, Mrk.11:15; with accusative of thing(s), Mat.13:44, 46, al; before παρά, with genitive of person(s), Rev.3:18 (LXX, Polyb.); ἐκ, Mat.27:7; with genitive pret, Mrk.6:37, al; metaph, 1Co.6:20 7:23, 2Pe.2:1, Rev.5:9 14:3, 4. (AS)
G60	ἀγοραῖος	agoraios	of the marketplace	G:A	<b>ἀγοραῖος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἀγορά), 1) <b>frequenting the ἀγορά </b>, <b>a lounger in the ἀγορά </b> (Xen, al.): Act.17:5. 2) In late writers (Strab, al.), <b>proper to the ἀγορά </b>: ἀγοραῖοι (sc. ἥμεραι) ἀγονται (cf. Lat. conventus agere), <b>court-days are kept</b>, Act.19:38 (for exx. of both usages, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)

G68	ἀγρός	agros	field	G:N-M	<b>ἀγρός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ, [in LXX chiefly for שָׂדֶה]; 1) <b>a field</b>: Mat.6:28, al. 2) <b>the country</b>: Mrk.15:21, al; pl, <b>country places, farms</b>: Mrk.5:14 6:36 56, Luk.8:34 9:12. 3) = χωρίον <b>a piece of ground</b>: Mrk.10:29, Act.4:27, al. G73	ἀγών	agōn	fight	G:N-M	<b>ἀγών</b>, -ῶνος, ὁ (&lt; ἄγω), [in LXX: Isa.7:13 (לאה), Est.4:17, Wis.4:2 10:12, II Mac.6, 4Mac.5 *;] 1) <b>a gathering</b>, esp. for games. 2) <b>a place of assembly</b>. 3) <b>a contest, struggle, trial</b>; metaph. G79	ἀδελφή	adelphē	sister	G:N-F	<b>ἀδελφή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; ἀδελφός), [in LXX for אָהוֹת;] <b>a sister</b>: Mat.19:29, al; metaph. (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), of a member of the Christian community: Rom.16:1, 1Co.7:15 Jas.21:15, al. (AS)
G80	ἀδελφός	adelphos	brother	G:N-M	<b>ἀδελφός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; ἀ- copul, δελφύς, womb), in cl, <b>a brother</b>, born of the same parent or parents. [In LXX (Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, 102f.), for אָח;] 1) lit. of a brother (Gen.4:2, al.). 2) Of a neighbour (Lev.19:17). 3) Of a member of the same nation (Exo.2:14, Deu.15:3). In NT in each of these senses (1. Mat.1:2, al; 2. Mat.7:3; 3. Rom.9:3) and also, 4) <b>of a fellow-Christian</b>: 1Co.1:1, Act.9:30. This usage finds illustration in π, where ἀ. is used of members of a pagan religious community (M, <i>Th.</i>, I, 1:4; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). The ἀδελφοὶ τ. Κυρίου (Mat.12:46-49 13:55 28:10, Mrk.3:31-34, Luk.8:19-21, Jhn.2:12 7:3, 5 10 20:17, Act.1:14, 1Co.9:5) may have been sons of Joseph and Mary (Mayor, <i>Ja.</i>, Intr. viff; <i>DB</i>, i, 320ff.) or of Joseph by a former marriage (Lft, <i>Gal.</i>, 252ff; <i>DCG</i>, i, 232ff.), but the view of Jerome, which makes ἀ. equivalent to ἀνεψιός, is inconsistent with Greek usage. (Cremer, 66.) (AS)
G81	ἀδελφότης	adelphotēs	brotherhood	G:N-F	<b>ἀδελφότης</b>, -ητος, ἡ (&lt; ἀδελφός), [in LXX: 1Ma.12:10,17, 4Mac.5 *;] 1) abstract, <b>brotherhood, brotherly affection</b> (LXX). 2) Concrete, <b>the brotherhood</b>, <b>the Christian community</b>: 1Pe.2:17 5:9 (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G82	ἄδηλος	adēlos	unclear	G:A	<b>ἄ-δηλος</b>, -ον (&lt; δῆλος), [in LXX: Ps 50 (51):6 (בַּטֻחוֹת);] 1) <b>unseen, unobserved, not manifest</b> (Ps, l.with): Luk.11:44. 2) <b>uncertain, indistinct</b>: 1Co.14:8. (AS)
G83	ἀδηλότης	adēlotēs	uncertainty	G:N-F	<b>ἀδηλότης</b>, -ητος, ἡ (&lt; ἄδηλος), <b>uncertainty</b>: 1Ti.6:17. (AS)
G84	ἀδήλως	adēlōs	uncertainly	G:Adv	<b>ἀδήλως</b> (&lt; ἄδηλος), <i>adv.</i> <b>uncertainly</b>: of direction, 1Co.9:26. (AS)
G85	ἀδημονέω	adēmoneō	be distressed	G:V	<b>ἀδημονέω</b>, -ῶ (on the derivation, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), [in Aq: Job.18:20; Sm: Psa.60 (61):3 115:2 (116:11), Ecc.7:17 (16), Eze.3:15 *;] <b>to be troubled, distressed</b> (MM, l.with): Mat.26:37, Mrk.14:33, Php.2:26. (AS)
G86	ᾍδης	Hadēs	Hades	G:N-M	<b>ᾅδης</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX ehiefly for שְׁאוֹל, also for דּוּמָה, מָוֶת, etc;] 1) in Hom, <b>Hades</b> (Pluto), the god of the underworld. 2) <b>the abode of Hades, the underivorld</b>; in NT, the abode of departed spirits, <b>Hades</b>: ἐν τ. ᾅ, Luk.16:23; εἰς ᾅ, Act.2:27,31; πύλαι ᾅδου, Mat.16:18; κλεῖς τοῦ ᾅ, Rev.1:18; metaph, ἕως ᾅ, Mat.11:23, Luk.10:15; personified, Rev.6:8 20:13,14 (Cremer, 67, 610; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G87	ἀδιάκριτος	adiakritos	impartial	G:A	<b>ἀ-διά-κριτος</b>, -ον (&lt; διακρίνω), [in LXX: Pro.25:1 *;] 1) <b>not to be parted, mixed, undistinguishable</b> (cf. Pr, l.with, and see Lft, <i>Ignat. Eph.</i>, §3). 2) <b>without uncertainty</b> (Hort, in l, but see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Jas.3:17. (AS)
G88	ἀδιάλειπτος	adialeiptos	continuous	G:A	<b>ἀδιάλειπτος</b>, -ον (&lt; διαλείπω), <b>unremitting, incessant</b>: Rom.9:2, 2Ti.1:3. (For exx, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word) (AS)
G89	ἀδιαλείπτως	adialeiptōs	unceasingly	G:Adv	<b>ἀδιαλείπτως</b> (see supr.), adv, [in LXX: 1Ma.12:11, II Mac.4, 3Ma.6:33 *;] <b>unremittingly, incessantly</b>: Rom.1:9, 1Th.1:3 2:13 5:17. (AS)
G90	ἀδιαφθορία	adiaphthoria	unspoilable	G:N-F	<b>incorruption, uprightness </b>, (New Testament) (ML)
G91	ἀδικέω	adikeō	to harm	G:V	<b>ἀδικέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἄδικος), [in LXX for עשׁק, עוה, etc;] 1) intrans, to be ἄδικος, <b>do wrong, act wickedly</b> or <b>criminally</b>: Act.25:11, 1Co.6:8, 2Co.7:12, Col.3:25, Rev.22:11; <b>to do hurt</b>, Rev.9:19. 2) Trans. (a) <b>to do</b> some <b>wrong</b>: ὃ ἠδίκησεν, Col.3:25; <b>to wrong</b> some one, Mat.20:13, Act.7:26, 27 25:10, 2Co.7:2, Gal.4:12, Phm 18, 2Pe.2:13; pass, Act.7:24, 2Co.7:12; mid, 1Co.6:7 (<b>suffer. to be wronged</b>; WM, §38, 3; but see Bl, §54, 5; and cf. ἀποστερέω); (b) <b>to injure, hurt</b>: Luk.10:19 Rev.2:11 6:6 7:2, 3 9:4,10 11:5. (AS)
G92	ἀδίκημα	adikēma	crime	G:N-N	<b>ἀδίκημα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; ἀδικέω), [in LXX for עָוֹן, פֶּשַׁע, etc;] <b>a wrong, injury, misdeed</b> (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Act.18:14 24:20, Rev.18:5. (AS)
G93	ἀδικία	adikia	unrighteousness	G:N-F	<b>ἀδικία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἄδικος), [in LXX for עָוֹן, פֶּשַׁע, עָוֶל, etc;] 1) <b>injustice</b>: Luk.18:6, Rom.9:14. 2) <b>unrighteousness, iniquity</b>: Jhn.7:18, Act.8:23, Rom.1:18, 29 2:8 6:13, 2Ti.2:19, 1Jn.1:9 5:17; opp. to ἀλήθεια, 1Co.13:6, 2Th.2:12; to δικαιοσύνη], Rom.3:5; ἀπάτη τῆς ἀ, 2Th.2:10; μισθὸς ἀδικίας, Act.1:18, 2Pe.2:13,15; ἐγράται τῆς ἀ, Luk.13:27; μαμωνᾶς τῆς ἀ, Luk.16:9; κόσμος τῆς ἀ, Jas.3:6; οἰκονόμος τῆς ἀ, Luk.16:8. 3) = ἀδίκημα, <b>an unrighteous act</b>: ironically, a favour, 2Co.12:13; pl, Heb.8:12 (Cremer, 261; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G94	ἄδικος	adikos	unjust	G:A	<b>ἄδικος</b>, -ον (&lt; δίκη), [in LXX for שׁקר, עול, etc;] 1) <b>unjust</b>: Rom.3:5, Heb.6:10. 2) <b>unrighteous, wicked</b>: Luk.16:11 18:11, Act.24:15, 1Co.6:1,9 1Pe.3:18; opp. to δίκαιος, Mat.5:45; to εὐσεβής, 2Pe.2:9; to πιστός, Luk.16:10 (Cremer, 200). (AS)
G95	ἀδίκως	adikōs	unjustly	G:Adv	<b>ἀδίκως</b>, <i>adv.</i> (&lt; ἄδικος), [in LXX for שׁקר, עול, etc;] <b>unjustly, undeservedly</b>: 1Pe.2:19. (AS)
G96	ἀδόκιμος	adokimos	failing	G:A	<b>ἀ-δόκιμος</b>, -ον, [in LXX: Pro.25:4, Isa.1:22 (סִיג) *;] 1) of things (prop. of metals: LXX, ll. with), <b>not standing the test, rejected</b>: γῆ, Heb.6:8. 2) Of persons, <b>rejected after testing, reprobate</b>: Rom.1:28, 1Co.9:27, 2Co.13:5-7, 2Ti.3:8, Tit.1:16 (Cremer, 212). (AS)
G97	ἄδολος	adolos	pure	G:A	<b>ἄδολος</b>, -ον, 1) <b>guileless</b> (Pind, Thuc). 2) Of liquids (Æsch, Eur, and late prose writers), <b>genuine, pure</b> (in π. and in MGr. of wine, also of corn: MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word; Milligan, NTD, 77): of milk, metaph, 1Pe.2:2. (AS)
G98	Ἀδραμυττηνός	Adramuttēnos	Adramyttene	N:N--LG	<b>Ἁδραμυντηνός</b> (T, Rec. Ἀδραμυττηνός), -ή,-όν, of <b>Adramyttium</b>, a seaport of Mysia: Act.27:2. (AS)
G99	Ἀδρίας	Adrias	Adriatic Sea	N:N-M-L	<b>Ἁδρίας</b> (T, Rec. Ἀδρίας), -ου, ὁ, <b>the Adriatic</b> sea, <b>in later Greek usage extended to take in all the waters between Greece and Italy</b>: Act.27:27. (AS)
G100	ἁδρότης	hadrotēs	abundance	G:N-F	<b>ἁδρότης</b>, -τος, ἡ (&lt; ἁδρός, <b>thick, well-grown</b>), 1) <b>thickness, vigour</b>. 2) <b>abundance, bounty</b>: 2Co.8:20. (AS)
G101	ἀδυνατέω	adunateō	be impossible	G:V	<b>ἀδυνατέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἀδύνατος), [in LXX: Deu.17:8, Zec.8:6 (פּלא ni.), Job.42:2 (בּצר ni.), al;] 1) Abbott-Smith omits this number <b>to be unable</b> (cl, Philo; π, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). 2) In LXX and NT (Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 124; Hatch, <i>Essays</i>, 4; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 46 f.), <b>to be impossible</b>: Mat.17:20, Luk.1:37. (AS)
G102	ἀδύνατος	adunatos	unable	G:A	<b>ἀ-δύνατος</b>, -ον, [in LXX for אֶבְיוֹן, דַּל, etc;] 1) of persons, <b>unable, powerless</b>: Act.14:8; figuratively Rom.15:1 (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). 2) Of things, <b>impossible</b>: Mat.19:26, Mrk.10:27, Luk.18:27, Rom.8:3, Heb.6:4,18 10:4 11:6. (AS)
G103	ᾄδω	adō	to sing	G:V	<b>ᾄδω</b> (Attic form of Ion. and poët. ἀείδω), [in LXX chiefly for שִׁיר;] <b>to sing</b>, (a) intrans, with dative (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), of praise to God: Eph.5:19, Col.3:16; (b) trans, with cogn. accusative: ᾠδὴν, Rev.5:9 14:3 15:3. (AS)
G104	ἀεί	aei	always	G:Adv	<b>ἀεί</b>, <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX: Isa.42:14 (מֵעוֹלָם) 51:13 (תָּמִיד), Ps 94(95):10, al;] <b>ever</b>; 1) of continuous time, <b>unceasingly, perpetually</b>: Act.7:51, 2 Co.4.11; 6:10, Tit.1:12, Heb.3:10. 2) Of successive occurrences, <b>on every occasion</b> (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): 1Pe.3:15, 2Pe.1:12. (AS)
G105	ἀετός	aetos	eagle	G:N-M	<b>ἀετός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ, [in LXX for נֶשֶׁר;] <b>an eagle</b>: Rev.4:7 8:13 (Rec. ἀγγέλου) 12:14. Where carrion is referred to, ἀ. is probably a <b>vulture</b> (cf. Job.39:30, Pro.30:17): Mat.24:28, Luk.17:37 (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G106	ἄζυμος	azumos	unleavened	G:A	<b>ἄζυμος</b>, -ον (&lt; ζύμη), [in LXX for מָצָּה; τὰ ἄ. (sc. λάγανα, <b>cakes</b>) = הַמָצָּה;] <b>unleavened</b>: ἡ ἑορτὴ τῶν ἄ. (הַג הַמָצָּה), <b>the paschal feast</b> (also called τὰ ἄ, Mrk.14:1), Luk.22:1; ἡμέρα τῶν ἄ, Mat.26:17, Mrk.14:12, Luk.22:7; ἡμέραι, Act.12:3 20:6. Fig, of Christians, <b>free from corruption</b>: 1Co.5:7; exhorted to keep festival, ἐν ἀζύμοις (sc. ἄρτοις, λάγανοις, or, indefinitely, "unleavened elements"), ib. 8 (Cremer, 724). (AS)

G109	ἀήρ	aēr	air	G:N-M	<b>ἀήρ</b>, ἀέρος, ὁ, [in LXX: 2Ki.22:12 (= Psa.17(18):11 שׁחק), Wi.8;] in Hom, Hes, the lower air which surrounds the earth, as opp. to the purer αἰθήρ of the higher regions; generally, <b>air</b> (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Act.22:23, 1Th.4:17, Rev.9:2 16:17; of the air as the realm of demons, Eph.2:2; ἀ. δέρειν, of striving to no purpose, 1Co.9:26; εἰς ἀ. λαλεῖν, of speaking without effect, not being understood, 1Co.14:9. G114	ἀθετέω	atheteō	to reject	G:V	<b>ἀθετέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; τίθημι), [in LXX for seventeen different words, פּשׁע, מרד, בּגד, מעל, etc, often meaning, as 1Ki.13:3 (Heb, al.), <b>to revolt</b>; properly, <b>to make ἄθετον </b>, or <b>do away with what has been laid down</b> (see <i>DCG</i>, i, 453 f.)]. 1) <b>to set aside, disregard</b> (in Gramm, <b>to reject as spurious</b>): <b>διαθήκην </b>, Gal.3:16; <b>ἐντολήν </b>, Mrk.7:9; <b>νόμον </b>. Heb.10:28; <b>πίστιν </b>, 1Ti.5:12. 2) <b>to nullify, make void</b>: Luk.7:30 (see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 59), 1Co.1:19, Gal.2:21. 3) <b>to reject</b>: Mrk.6:26 (Field, op. cit, 30), Lk 10:16, Jhn.12:48, I Th 48, Ju 8 (for exx. in π, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). G129	αἷμα	ahima	blood	G:N-N	<b>αἷμα</b>, ατος, τό, [in LXX for דָּם;] <b>blood.</b> 1) <b>In the ordinary sense</b>: Mrk.5:25, Luk.8:43,44 22:44, Jhn.19:34, Act.15:20,29 21:25, Rev.8:7,8 11:6 16:3,4,6 19:13. 2) <b>In special senses</b>: (a) <b>of generation, origin, kinship </b>(cl.): Jhn.1:13 (see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word); (b) as in OT (AR on <i>Eph</i>, l.with), in the phrase σάρξ καὶ αἷ. (αἷ. κ. σ.), to indicate human nature as opp. to God and created spirits: Mat.16:17, 1Co.15:50, Gal.1:16, Eph.6:12, Heb.2:14; (with) <b>of things in colour resembling blood</b>: Act.2:19,20, Rev.6:12 14:18-20. (d) <b>of bloodshed, a bloody death </b>(cl.): Mat.23:30,35 27:4,6,8,24,25, Luk.11:50,51 13:1, Act.1:19 5:28 18:6 20:26 22:20, Heb.12:4, Rev.6:10 17:6 18:24 19:2; αἷ. ἐκχέειν (Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 428; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word, αἷ.), Rom.3:15, Rev.16:6; (e) <b>of sacrificial blood, as an expiation</b>: Heb.9:7,12,13,18-22,25 10:4 11:28 13:11; of the blood of Christ, Mat.26:28, Mrk.14:24, Luk.22:20, Jhn.6:53,54,56, Act.20:28, Rom.3:25 5:9, 1Co.10:16 11:25,27, Eph.1:7 2:13, Col.1:20, Heb.9:12,14 10:19,29 12:24 13:20, 1Pe.1:2,19, 1Jn.1:7 (cf. 5:6,8), Rev.1:5 5:9 7:14 12:11. (Cremer, 69 f, 612 f.) (AS)
G130	αἱματεκχυσία	ahimatekchusia	bloodshed	G:N-F	<b>αἱματεκχυσία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; αἷμα, ἐκ, χέω), <b>shedding of blood</b> (Eccl; Cremer, 71): Heb.9:22. (AS)

G133	αἴνεσις	ainesis	praise	G:N-F	<b>αἴνεσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; αἰνέω), [in LXX chiefly for תּוֹדָה, תְּהִלָּה;] <b>praise</b> (Eccl.): θυσία αἰνέσεως (Lev.7:12, זֶבַח תּוֹדָה), Heb.13:15. (AS)
G134	αἰνέω	aineō	to praise	G:V	<b>αἰνέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; αἶνος), poët, Ion. and late prose (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word) for cl. ἐπαινέω, [in LXX chiefly for הלל, ידה;] <b>to praise</b>: with accusative, τ. θεόν, Luk.2:13,20 19:37 24:53, Act.2:47 3:8,9, Rom.15:11; with dative, τ. Θεῷ (Jer.20:13, al. for הִלֵּל לְ; see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 245), Rev.19:5. (AS)
G135	αἴνιγμα	ainigma	obscure thing	G:N-N	<b>αἴνιγμα</b>, -ατος, τό (&lt; αἰνίσσομαι, <b>to speak in riddles</b>; &lt; αἰνός = δεινός, <b>dread, strange</b>), [in LXX for חִידָה, Num.12:8 and always exc. Deu.28:37 (שַׁמָּה);] <b>a dark saying, riddle</b>: 1Co.13:12 (cf. Nu, l.with). (AS)
G136	αἶνος	ainos	praise	G:N-M	<b>αἶνος</b>, ου, ὁ, [in LXX for הלל pi, עֹז;] poët, and Ion, 1) = μῦθος, <b>a tale</b> (Horn, al.). 2) = Att. ἔπαινος, <b>praise</b> (Horn, al.): Mat.21:16 (LXX), Luk.18:43. 3) In π, <b>a decree</b> (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G137	Αἰνών	Ainōn	Aenon	N:N--L	<b>Αἰνών</b>, ἡ, indecl. (cf. Heb.עַיִן, <b>a spring</b>), <b>Aenon</b>: Jhn.3:23. (AS)
G138	αἱρέω	ahireō	to choose	G:V	<b>αἱρέω</b>, [in LXX for אמר hi, בּחר, etc;] <b>to take</b>; Mid, -ομαι (M, <i>Pr</i>, 158 f; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), <b>to choose</b>: Php.1:22, 2Th.2:13, Heb.11:25. (Cf. ἀν, ἀφ, δι, ἐξ, καθ, περι, προ-αιρέω.) (AS)
G139	αἵρεσις	ahiresis	sect	G:N-F	<b>αἵρεσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; αἱρέω, -ομαι), [in LXX for נְדָבָה,] 1) <b>capture</b>. 2) <b>choosing, choice</b> (see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). 3) <b>that which is chosen</b>, hence, <b>opinion</b>; esp. <b>a peculiar opinion, heresy</b>: 1Co.11:19, Gal.5:20, 2Pe.2:1 R, txt. 4) In late writers (MM, <i>VGT</i>), of a set of persons professing particular principles or opinions, <b>a school, sect, party, faction</b>: Act.5:17 15:5 24:5,14 26:5 28:22, I Co, Ga, II Pe, l.with, R, mg. (Cremer, 614). (AS)
G140	αἱρετίζω	ahiretizō	to choose	G:V	<b>αἱρετίζω</b>, [in LXX chiefly for בּחר (see Cremer, 615);] = αἱρέομαι (Hipp, Inscr.), <b>to choose</b>: Mat.12:18 (LXX, ἀντιλήμψομαι). (AS)
G141	αἱρετικός	ahiretikos	schismatic	G:A	<b>αἱρετικός</b>, -ή, όν (&lt; αἱρέομαι), 1) <b>capable of choosing</b> (Plat.). 2) <b>causing division, heretical, factious</b> (Cremer, 614): as subst, Tit.3:10. (AS)

G165	αἰών	aiōn	an age	G:N-M	<b>αἰών</b>, -ῶνος, ὁ, [in LXX chiefly for עַד,עוֹלָם;] 1) in cl, like Lat. aevum (LS, MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), <b>a space of time</b>, as, a lifetime, generation, period of history, an indefinitely long period; in NT of an indefinitely long period, <b>an age, eternity</b>, usually with prep. (MM, <i>VGT</i>); (a) <b>of the past</b>: ἀπ᾽ αἰ. (cf. Heb. מֵעוֹלָם), Luk.1:70; (b) <b>of the future</b>: εἰς τ. αἰ. (cf. לְעוֹלָם), <b>forever</b>, Mat.21:19; id, with neg, <b>never</b>, Jhn.4:14; more strongly, εἰς τὸν αἰ. τοῦ αἰ, Heb.1:8 (LXX); εἰς τοὺς αἰ, Mat.6:13; εἰς τοὺς αἰ. τῶν αἰ. (cf. Isa.45:17, עַד־עוֹלְמֵי עַד), Rom.16:27, LT; cf. also Eph.3:21, 2Pe.3:18, Ju 25, Rev.14:11. 2) οἱ αἰ, <b>the worlds, the universe</b>, "the sum of the periods of time, including all that is manifested in them": He:12 11:3 (cf. 1Ti.1:17, where τῶν αἰ. are prob. "the ages or world-periods which when summed up make eternity". 3) <b>the present age</b> (Heb. הָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה): ὁ αἰ, Mat.13:22; ὁ αἰ. οὗτος, Mat.12:32; ὁ νῦν αἰ, 1Ti.6:17; ὁ ἐνεστὼς αἰ, Gal.1:4; similarly, of the time after Christ's second coming (הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא), ὁ αἰ. ἐκεῖνος, Luk.20:35; ὁ αἰ. μέλλων, Mat.12:32; ὁ αἰ. ὁ ἐρχόμενος, Mrk.10:30. (AS)

G181	ἀκαταστασία	akatastasia	disorder	G:N-F	<b>ἀκαταστασία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἀκατάστατος), [in LXX: Pro.26:28 (מִדְחֶה), Tob.4:13 *;] <b>instability</b> (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word); hence, <b>confusion</b>, <b>tumult</b>: 1Co.14:33, Jas.3:16; pl. G231	ἁλιεύς	halieus	fisherman	G:N-M	<b>ἁλεεύς</b> (Rec. ἁλιεύς, the older form; WH, <i>App.</i>, 151, -έως, ὁ (&lt; ἅλς, <b>the sea</b>) [in LXX for דָּג, דַּוָּג;] <b>a fisherman</b>: Mat.4:18, 19, Mrk.1:16, 17, Luk.5:2 (AS)
G232	ἁλιεύω	halieuō	to fish	G:V	<b>ἁλιεύω</b> (&lt; ἁλιεύς), [in LXX: Jer.16:16 (דִּיג)*;] <b>to fish</b>: Jhn.21:3 (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G233	ἁλίζω	halizō	to salt	G:V	<b>ἁλίζω</b> (&lt; ἅλς), [in LXX for מָלַח;] <b>to salt, season with salt</b>: Mat.5:13, Mrk.9:49. (AS)
G234	ἀλίσγημα	alisgēma	defilement	G:N-N	<b>ἀλίσγημα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; late ἀλισγέω, to pollute) <b>pollution</b>: Act.15:20. (AS)
G235	ἀλλά	alla	but	G:Conj	<b>ἀλλά</b> (ἀλλ᾽ usually bef. α and υ, often bef. ε and η, rarely bef. ο and ω, never bef. ι; Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, 93 f; WH, <i>App.</i>, 146), <i>adversative particle</i>, <b>stronger than δέ</b>; prop. neuter pl. of ἄλλος, used adverbially, with changed accent; hence prop. <b>otherwise, on the other hand</b> (cf. Rom.3:31); 1) opposing a previous negation, <b>but</b>: οὐ (μὴ). ἀ, Mat.5:15, 17 Mrk.5:39, Jhn.7:16, al; rhetorically subordinating but not entirely negativing what precedes, οὐ. ἀ, <b>not so much. as</b>, Mrk.9:37, Mat.10:20, Jhn.12:44, al; with ellipse of the negation, Mat.11:7-9, Act.19:2, 1Co.3:6 6:11 7:7, 2Co.7:1, Gal.2:3, al; in opposition to a foregoing pos. sentence, ἀ. οὐ, Mat.24:6, 1Co.10:23; οὐ μόνον. ἀ. καί, Jhn.5:18, Rom.1:32, al; elliptically, after a negation, ἀ. ἵνα, Mrk.14:49, Jhn.1:8 9:3, al; = εἰ μή (Bl, §77, 13; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 241; but cf. WM, §iii, 10), Mat.20:23, Mrk.4:22. 2) Without previous negation, to express opposition, interruption, transition, etc, <b>but</b>: Jhn.16:20 12:27, Gal.2:14; before commands or requests, Act.10:20 26:16, Mat.9:18, Mrk.9:22, al; to introduce an accessory idea, 2Co.7:11; in the apodosis after a condition or concession with εἰ, ἐάν, εἴπερ, <b>yet, still, at least</b>, Mrk.14:29, 1Co.9:2, 2Co.4:16, Col.2:5, al; after μέν, Act.4:17, Rom.14:20, 1Co.14:17; giving emphasis to the following clause, ἀλλ᾽ ἔρχεται ὥρα, <b>yea</b>, etc, Jhn.16:2; so with neg, ἀλλ᾽ οὐδέ, <b>nay, nor yet</b>, Luk.23:15. 3) Joined with other particles (a practice which increases in late writers; Simcox, <i>LNT</i>, 166), ἀ. γε, <b>yet at least</b>, Luk.24:21, 1Co.9:2; ἄ ἤ, <b>save only, except</b>, Luk.12:51, 2Co.1:13; ἀ. μὲν οὖν, Php.3:8 (on this usage, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G236	ἀλλάσσω	allassō	to change	G:V	<b>ἀλλάσσω</b> (&lt; ἄλλος), [in LXX chiefly for חָלַף, מוּר hi, etc;] 1) <b>to change</b>: Act.6:14, Gal.4:20. 2) <b>to transform</b>: 1Co.15:51-52, Heb.1:12. 3) <b>to exchange</b>: with accusative, before ἐν (= בְּ, Psa.106:20) instead of simple genitive (Bl, § 36, 8), Rom.1:23 (AS)

G264	ἁμαρτάνω	hamartanō	to sin	G:V	<b>ἁμαρτάνω</b> (pres. formed from aor. ἁμαρτεῖν), [in LXX for חָטָא, also for אָשַׁם, רָשַׁע, etc;] 1) to miss the mark (Hom, Æsch, al.), hence metaph. (Hom, al.), to err, do wrong 2) <b>In LXX and NT, to violate God's law, to sin </b>(for non-Christian exx, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): absol, Mat.18:25 27:4, Luk.17:3, Jhn.5:14 8:11 9:2-3 Rom.2:12 3:23 5:12, 14 5:16 6:15, 1Co.7:28 7:36 15:34, Eph.4:26, 1Ti.5:20, Tit.3:11, Heb.3:17 10:26, 1Pe.2:20, 2Pe.2:4 2:4 1Jn.1:10 Jn 2:1 Jn 3:6-9 Jn 5:18; with cogn. accusative, ἁ. ἁμαρτίαν (cf. G266	ἁμαρτία	hamartia	sin	G:N-F	<b>ἁμαρτία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἁμαρτάνω, which see), [in LXX chiefly for חַטָּאת and cogn. forms, also for פֶּשַׁע,עָוֹן, etc;] prop. <b>a missing the mark</b>; in cl. (see reff. to <i>CR</i> in MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word); (a) <b>guilt, sin</b> (Plat, Arist, al.); (b) more freq, from Æsch. down, <b>a fault, failure</b>. In NT (as LXX) always in ethical sense; 1) as a principle and quality of action, = τὸ ἁμαρτάνειν, <b>a sinning, sin</b>: Rom.5:12, 13 20; ὑφ᾽ ἁμαρτίαν εἶναι, Rom.3:9; ἐπιμένειν, Rom.6:1; ἀποθνήσκειν, νεκρὸν εἶναι τῇ ἁ, Rom.6:2, 11; τὴν ἀ. γινώσκειν, Rom.7:7; σῶμα τῆς ἁ, Rom.6:6; ἀπάτη τῆς ἁ, Heb.3:13; personified as a ruling principle, ἁ. βασιλεύει, κυριεύει, etc, Rom.5:21 6:12, 14 7:17, 20; δουλεύειν, Rom.6:6; δοῦλος τῆς ἁ, ib. 17; νόμος τῆς ἁ, Rom.7:23 8:2; δύναμις τῆς ἁ, 1Co.15:56 (cf. Gen.4:7). 2) As a generic term (disting. fr. the specific terms ἁμάρτημα, which see, etc.) for concrete wrongdoing, violation of the divine law, <b>sin</b>: Jhn.8:46, Jas.1:15, al; ποιεῖν (τὴν) ἁ, Jhn.8:34, 2Co.11:7, 1Jn.3:8; εἴχειν ἁ, Jhn.9:41 15:22, 24 19:11, 1Jn.1:8; in pl. ἁμαρτίαι, sin in the aggregate, 1Th.2:16 (see Milligan, in l.); ποιεῖν ἁμαρτίας, Jas.5:15; πλῆθος ἁμαρτιῶν, Jas.5:20, 1Pe.4:8; ἄφεσις ἁμαρτιῶν, Mat.26:28, Mrk.1:4, al; ἐν ἁμαρτίαις εἶναι, 1Co.15:17; collectively, αἴρειν τὴν ἁ. τ. κόσμου, Jhn.1:29; ἀποθνήσκειν ἐν τῇ ἁ, Jhn.8:21. 3) = ἁμάρτημα, <b>a sinful deed, a sin</b>: Mat.12:31, Act.7:60, 1Jn.5:16. (AS)

G281	ἀμήν	amēn	amen	H:A	<b>ἀμήν</b>, indecl. Is, l.with), ὁ ἀ, Rev.3:14. 2) As <i>adv.</i>, (a) <b>in solemn assent to the statements or prayers of another </b>(Nu, Ne, etc, ll. with): ὁ ἀ, 1Co.14:16; (b) <b>similarly, at the end of one's own prayer or ascription of praise</b>: Rom.1:25 15:33, Gal.1:5, 1Ti.1:17; (with) in the Gospels, exclusively, introducing solemn statements of our Lord, <b>truly, verily</b>: Mat.5:18, 26 Mrk.3:28 (see Swete, in l.), Luk.4:24, al; ἀ. ἀ, always in Jhn.1:52 3:3 5:19, al; τὸ ναί, καὶ. τὸ ἀ, 2Co.1:20 (on usage in π, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). G301	Ἀμώς	Amōs	Amos	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀμώς</b>, ὁ indecl. (Heb. אָמוֹץ, Isa.1:1; עָמוֹס, Amo.1:1; אָמוֹן, 4Ki.21:18 ff. B) 1) as in 2Ki, Lc. B (Α. Ἀμμών; Jos, Ἀμμών, "Αμωσσς), <b>Amon</b>: Mat.1:10. 2) <b>Amos</b>: Luk.3:25. (AS)
G302	ἄν	an	if	G:Cond	<b>ἄν</b>, <i>conditional particle</i>, which cannot usually be separately translated in English, its force depending on the constructions which contain it (see further, LS, see word; WM, §xlii; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 165 ff; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). 1) In apodosis, (i) with indic, impf. or aor, expressing what would be or would have been if (εἰ with impf, aor. or plpf.) some condition were or had been fulfilled: Luk.7:39 17:6, Jhn.5:46, Gal.1:10, Mat.12:7 24:43, 1Co.2:8, Act.18:14, 1Jn.2:19, al. The protasis is sometimes understood (as also in cl.): Mat.25:27, Luk.19:23. In hypothetical sentences, expressing unreality, ἄν (as often in late writers, more rarely in cl.) is omitted: Jhn.8:39 15:24 19:11, Rom.7:7, Gal.4:15; (ii) with opt, inf, ptcp. (cl; see LS, see word; M, <i>Int.</i>, §275; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 167:4). 2) In combination with conditional, relative, temporal, and final words; (i) as in cl, with subj, (a) in protasis with εἰ, in Attic contr. ἐάν, which see; (b) in conditional, relative, and temporal clauses (coalescing with ὅτε, ἐπεί, etc; see: ὅταν, ἐπάν, etc.), <b>ever, soever</b>; (α) with pres, ἡνίκα, 2Co.3:15; ὃς ἄν, Rom.9:15 (LXX) 16:2, al; ὅσοι ἄν, Luk.9:5; ὡς ἄν, Rom.15:24 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 167); (β) with aor, ὃς ἄν, Mat.5:21, 22, 31; ἕως ἄν, <b>until</b>, Mat.2:13, Mrk.6:10, al; ὡς ἄν, <b>as soon as</b> (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 167), 1Co.11:34, Php.2:23. On the freq. use of ἐάν for ἄν with the foregoing words, see: ἐάν; (ii) in late Gk, when some actual fact is spoken of, with indic: ὅταν (which see); ὅπου ἄν, Mrk.6:56 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 168); καθότι ἄν, Act.2:45 4:35; ὡς ἄν, 1Co.12:2. 3) in iterative construction, with impf. and aor. indic. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 167): Act.2:45 4:35, 1Co.12:2. 4) with optative, giving a potential sense to a question or wish: Act.8:31 26:29. 5) <b>Elliptical constructions</b>: εἰ μή τι ἄν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 169), 1Co.7:5; ὡς ἄν, with inf, <b>as it were</b> (op. cit. 167), 2Co.10:9. (AS)
G303	ἀνά	ana	each	G:Prep	<b>ἀνά </b> prep. (the rarest in NT; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 98; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), prop, upwards, up, always with accusative 1) <b>In phrases</b>: ἀ. μέσον, among, between, with genitive, Mat.13:1-58 25:1-46, Mrk.7:31, 1Co.6:5 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 99), Rev.7:17 [so in LXX for בְּתוׄך׃]; ἀ. μέρος, in turn, 1Co.14:27 (both found in Polyb; cf. M<i>Gr.</i> ἀνάμεσα). 2) Distrib, <b>apiece, by</b>: Mat.20:9-10, Luk.9:3 (WH om.), Luk.9:14 Luk.10:1, Jhn.2:6, Rev.4:8. 3) Adverbially ("a vulgarism," B1, § 51, 5; cf. Deiss, BS, 139 f.), ἀ. εἷς ἕκαστος, Rev.21:21. As prefix, ἀ. signifies (a) <b>up</b>: ἀναβαίνειν; (b) <b>to</b>: ἀναγγέλλειν; (with) <b>anew</b>: ἀναγεννᾶν; (d) <b>back</b>: ἀνακάμπτειν. (AS)

G323	ἀνάδειξις	anadeixis	public appearance	G:N-F	<b>ἀνά-δειξις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀναδείκνυμι), [in LXX: Sir.43:6 *;] <b>a sheaving forth, announcement</b>: Luk.1:80. (AS)
G324	ἀναδέχομαι	anadechomai	to receive	G:V	<b>ἀνα-δέχομαι </b> [in LXX: 2Ma.6:19 2Mac 8:36 *;] 1) to assume, undertake (in π. freq. as legal term: MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): ἐπαγγελίας, Heb.11:17. 2) = cl. ὑποδέχομαι, <b>to receive</b>: of guests, Act.28:7. (AS)
G325	ἀναδίδωμι	anadidōmi	to deliver	G:V	<b>ἀνα-δίδωμι </b> [in LXX: Sir.1:22, 2Ma.13:15 *;] 1) to give forth, send up, as of plants (Hdt, al.). 2) <b>to give up, yield, hand over </b>(MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Act.23:33. (AS)
G326	ἀναζάω	anazaō	to revive	G:V	<b>ἀνα-ζάω</b>, -ῶ [in Al: Gen.45:27 *;] <b>to live again, regain life </b>(cf. cl. ἀναβιόω; Cremer, 722; and for other exx, v MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): metaph. of moral revival, Luk.15:24 (WH, mg, ἔζησεν); of sin, Rom.7:9. (AS)
G327	ἀναζητέω	anazēteō	to search	G:V	<b>ἀνα-ζητέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: Job.3:4 (דָּרַשׁ), Job.10:6 (בָּקַשׁ pi.), 2Ma.13:21 *;] to look for or seek carefully ("specially of searching for human beings, with an implication of difficulty": MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Luk.2:44-45 Act.11:25. (AS)
G328	ἀναζώννυμι	anazōnnumi	to gird	G:V	<b>ἀνα-ζώννυμι </b> [in LXX: Jdg.18:16, Pro.31:17 (חָגַר)*;] <b>to gird up</b>: figuratively, τ. ὀσφύας τ. διανοίας, 1Pe.1:13. (AS)
G329	ἀναζωπυρέω	anazōpureō	to rekindle	G:V	<b>ἀνα-ζωπυργέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ζωός, πῦρ), [in LXX: 1Ma.13:7 *;] <b>to kindle afresh</b>: metaph, 2Ti.1:6 (for vernac. exx, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G330	ἀναθάλλω	anathallō	to renew	G:V	<b>ἀνα-θάλλω</b> (&lt; θάλλω, to flourish), [in LXX: Psa.28:7 (עָלַז), Eze.17:24 (פָּרַח hi.), Hos.8:9, Wis.4:4, Sir.5:1-15 *;] <b>to revive</b>: Php.4:10 (of MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G331	ἀνάθεμα	anathema	devoted	G:N-N	<b>ἀνάθεμα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; ἀνατίθημι), Hellenistic for Attic ἀνάθημα (Bl, § 27, 2); 1) prop. = τὸ ἀνατιθέμένον, that which is laid by to be kept, a votive offering (as ἀνάθημα in 2Ma.2:13, Luk.21:5 —where LT read -θεμα, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46). 2) [As equiv. in LXX for חֵרֶם,] devoted, a thing devoted to God (see Driver, De, 98 f, and cf. Lev.27:28-29), hence; (a) of the sentence pronounced (Deu.13:15), <b>a curse</b>: Act.23:14; (b) of the object on which the curse is laid, accursed (Deu.7:26): Rom.9:3, 1Co.12:3 16:22, Gal.1:8-9 (see <i>ICC</i> on Ro; Lft, <i>Ga.</i>, ll. with; Cremer, 547; Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, § v; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G332	ἀναθεματίζω	anathematizō	to take an oath	G:V	<b>ἀνα-θεματίζω</b> (&lt; ἀνίθεμα), [in LXX chiefly for חָרַם hi. (Num.21:2, 1Ki.15:3, al.), 1Ma.5:5;] <b>to devote to destruction, declare or invoke ana­thema</b>: absol, Mrk.14:71; ἐαντόν, <b>to bind oneself under a curse</b>: Act.23:12, 14 23:21 (cf. καταναθεματίζω, and on the occurrence of the word in π, see Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 92 f; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). G378	ἀναπληρόω	anaplēroō	to fulfil	G:V	<b>ἀνα-πληρόω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX chiefly for מָלֵא, Lev.12:6, al; also שָׁלַם (Gen.15:16, 3Ki.7:51, Isa.60:20), etc;] 1) <b>to fill up, make full </b>(in π. of com­pleting contracts and making up rent; cf. MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): τόπον, take one's place (cf. <i>Heb.</i> מָקוֹם שָׁלַם), 1Co.14:16; άμαρτίας, complete the number, 1Th.2:16; τ. νόμον, observe perfectly, Gal.6:2; pass, προφητεία, fulfilled, Mat.13:14. 2) <b>to supply</b>: τό ὑστέρημα, 1Co.16:17, Php.2:30 (Cremer, 838). (AS)
G379	ἀναπολόγητος	anapologētos	inexcusable	G:A	<b>ἀναπολόγητος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἀπολογεόμαι), <b>without excuse, inexcusable </b>(in Polyb, al, as a forensic term; see Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 252): Rom.1:20 2:1. (AS)
G380	ἀναπτύσσω	anaptussō	to unroll	G:V	<b>ἀνα-πτύσσω </b> [in LXX for פָּרַשׂ,etc;] <b>to unroll</b>: τ. βιβλίον, Luk.4:17 (WH, R, ἀνοίξας). (AS)

G382	ἀναρίθμητος	anarithmētos	countless	G:A	<b>ἀν-αρίθμητος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἀριθμέω), [Job.31:25, al.], <b>innumerable</b>: Heb.11:12. (AS)

G384	ἀνασκευάζω	anaskeuazō	to upset	G:V	<b>ἀνα-σκευάζω</b> (&lt; σκεῦος, a vessel), prop, <b>to pack up baggage, hence, to dismantle, ravage, destroy</b>; metaph, <b>to unsettle, subvert </b>(MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): ψυχάς, Act.15:24. (AS)
G385	ἀνασπάω	anaspaō	to pull up	G:V	<b>ἀνα-σπάω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX for לָקַח, עָלָה hi;] <b>to draw up</b>: Luk.14:5, Act.11:10 (in π. of pulling up barley; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)
G386	ἀνάστασις	anastasis	resurrection	G:N-F	<b>ἀνά-στασις</b>, -εως, ή (&lt; ἀνίστημι), [in LXX: Zep.3:8 (קוּם), La 3:63 (קִימָה), קִימָה), Psa.66:1-20 title, Dan LXX 11:20, 2Ma.7:14 2Mac 12:43 *;] 1) <b>a raising up, awakening, rising </b>(in Inscr. of the erection of a monument, see MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word): Luk.2:34. 2) <b>a rising from the dead </b>(see <i>DCG</i>, ii, 605b); (a) <b>of Christ</b>: Act.1:22 2:31 4:33 Rom.6:5, Php.3:10, 1Pe.3:21; ἐξ ἀ. νεκρῶν, Rom.1:4 (<i>ICC</i>, in l); ἐκ νεκρῶν, 1Pe.1:3; (b) of persons in OT hist. (e.g. 3Ki.17:17 ff.): Heb.11:35; (with) <b>of the general resurrection</b>: Mat.22:23, 28 22:30 Mrk.12:18, 23 Luk.20:27, 33 20:36, Jhn.11:24, Act.17:18 23:8 24:15, 2Ti.2:18; ἀ. ἐκ νεκρῶν, Luk.20:35, Act.4:2; τῶν νεκρῶν, Mat.22:31, Act.17:32 23:6 24:21 26:23, 1Co.15:12-13 15:21 15:42, Heb.6:2; ἀ. ζωῆς, resurrection to life (cf. 2Ma.7:14, ἀ. εἰς ζωήν) and ἀ. τ. κρίσεως, τ. to judgment, Jhn.5:29; ἀ. τ. δικαίων, Luk.14:14; κρείττων ἀ, Heb.11:35; on ἡ ἀ. ἡ πρώτη, Rev.20:5-8, see Swete, in l, Weste. on Jhn.5:1-47, but see also Thayer, see word; by meton. of Christ as Author of ἀ, Jhn.11:25 (see <i>DB</i>, iv, 231; Cremer, 307). (AS)
G387	ἀναστατόω	anastatoō	to cause trouble	G:V	<b>ἀνα-στατόω</b>, ῶ (&lt; ἀνάστατος, driven from home; &lt; ἀνίστημι), [in LXX: Dan.7:23 (דּוּשׁ;* also in Aq, and in π. (see Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 80 f; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word),] <b>to stir up, excite, unsettle</b>: with accusative; (a) <b>to tumult and sedition</b>: Act.17:6 21:38; (b) <b>by false teaching</b>: Gal.5:12 (see Milligan, <i>NTD</i>, 73 f.). G433	ἀνήκω	anēkō	be fitting	G:V	<b>ἀν-ήκω</b> (ἀνά, ἥκω), [in LXX: Jos.23:14 (בּוֹא), 1Ki.27:8, Sir. prol.10, 1, 2 Mac6*;] prop, to have come up to; in later writers, impers. it is due, <b>it is befitting</b>: in ethical sense (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), Eph.5:4, Col.3:18; τὸ ἀνῆκον, Phm 8. (AS)

G435	ἀνήρ	anēr	man	G:N-M	<b>ἀνήρ</b>, ἀνδρός, ὁ, [in LXX chiefly for אִישׁ, freq. אֱנוֹשׁ, also אָדָם, etc;] <b>a man</b>, Lat. vir. 1) As opp. to a woman, Act.8:12, 1Ti.2:12; as a <b>husband</b>, Mat.1:16, Jhn.4:16, Rom.7:2, Tit.1:6. 2) As opp. to a boy or infant, 1Co.13:11, Eph.4:13, Jas.3:2. 3) In appos. with a noun or adj, as ἀ. ἁμαρτωλός, Luk.5:8; ἀ. προφήτης, 24:19; freq. in terms of address, as ἀ. ἀδελφοί, Act.1:16; and esp. with gentilic names, as ἀ. Ἰουδαῖος, Act.22:3; ἀ. Ἐφέσιοι, 19:35. 4) In general, <b>a man, a male person</b>: = τις, Luk.8:41, Act.6:11. (AS)

G471	ἀντεῖπον	anteipon	to contradict	G:V	<b>ἀντ-εῖπον</b> (άντί, εἶτον), [in LXX for H7725 hi, דָבַר pi, עָנָה, etc;] 2 2 aor, without present in use, <b>to speak against, gainsay</b>: Luk.21:15, Act.4:14. (AS)
G472	ἀντέχω	antechō	to cling to	G:V	<b>ἀντ-ὲχω</b> (ἀντί, ἔχω), [in LXX for חָזַק hi, etc;] 1) trans, to hold against. 2) Intrans, to withstand. Mid. 1. in cl, to hold out against. 3) (cf. MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), <b>to hold firmly to, cleave to</b>: with genitive (see Bl, § 36, 2), Mat.6:24, Luk.16:13, 1Th.5:14 (see M, <i>Th.</i>, in l), Tit.1:9. (AS)
G473	ἀντί	anti	for	G:Prep	<b>ἀντί</b> (the ι is elided only in ἀνθ᾽ ὧν), prep. with genitive (cf. MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word); 1) prop, in local sense, over against, opposite, hence 2) <b>instead of, in place of, for </b>(Hom, etc.): Mat.5:38 17:27, Luk.11:11, 1Co.11:15, Heb.12:2; with artic. inf. (cl.), Jas.4:15; of succession, Mat.2:22; χάριν ἀ. χάριτος, Jhn.1:16 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 100); of price in exchange, Heb.12:16; λύτρον ἀ. πολλῶν, Mat.20:28, Mrk.10:45 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 105); of requital, Rom.12:17, 1Th.5:16, 1Pe.3:9 (cf. Wis.11:15); ἀνθ᾽ ὧν, because, Luk.1:20 19:44, Act.12:23, 2Th.2:10 (cl, LXX for אֲשֶׁר תַּחַת); id. therefore (cl, LXX), Luk.12:3; ἀ. τούτου (LXX for כֵּן נַעֲרָה) Eph.5:31. As a prefix, ἀντι- (before vowels ἀντ, ἀνθ᾽-), denotes (a) <b>over against</b>, ἀντιπέραν; (b) <b>co-operation</b>, ἀντιβάλλειν; (with) <b>requital</b>, ἀντιμισθία; (d) <b>opposition</b>, ἀντίχριστος; (e) <b>substitution</b>, ἀνθύπατος. Compounds of ἀ. usually govern dative (B1, § 37, 7). (AS)
G474	ἀντιβάλλω	antiballō	to discuss	G:V	<b>ἀντι-βάλλω </b> [in LXX: 2Ma.11:13 *;] <b>to throw in turn, exchange</b>: metaph, λόγους (cf. Lat. conferre sermons; see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 81), Luk.24:17. (AS)

G529	ἀπάντησις	apantēsis	meeting	G:N-F	<b>ἀπάντησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀπαντάω), [in LXX chiefly for קָרָא;] usually with seel, ὑπ; a meeting; εἰς ἀ, with genitive or dative, <b>to meet</b>: Mat.25:6 27:32 (WH, txt, omits), Act.28:15, 1Th.4:17 (see M, <i>Th.</i>, in l; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 14, 242; MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 69). G530	ἅπαξ	hapax	once	G:Adv	<b>ἅπαξ </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX for אֶחָד, פַּעַם;] (a) <b>once</b>: 2Co.11:25, Heb_9:26-27; ἔτι ἅ, Heb.12:26-27; ἅ. τ. ἐνιαυτοῦ, Heb.9:7; καί ἅ. κ. δίς, <b>twice</b>: Php.4:16, 1Th.2:18; (b) <b>once for all</b>: Heb.6:4 9:28 10:2, 1Pe.3:18, Ju 3 5 (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word). (AS)

G533	ἀπαρνέομαι	aparneomai	to deny	G:V	<b>ἀπ-αρνέομαι</b> (-οῦμαι) depon, [in LXX: Isa.31:7 (מָאַס) *;] to deny, i.e. to refuse to recognize, <b>to ignore</b>: with accusative, of oneself (<i>DCG</i>, ii, 598 f.), Mat.16:24, Mrk.8:34 (MM, <i>VGT</i>, see word), Luk.9:23 (WH, mg, txt, ἀρν-) of Peter's denials of Christ, Mat.26:34-35, 75, Mrk.14:30-31, 72, Luk.22:34, 61; pass, Luk.12:9 (Cremer, 111). G536	ἀπαρχή	aparchē	firstfruits	G:N-F	<b>ἀπ-αρχή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; ἀπάρχομαι, to make a beginning in sacrifice, offer first fruits) [in LXX chiefly for תְּרוּמָה, רֵאשִׁית;] 1) the beginning of a sacrifice. 2) <b>first fruits</b>: τοῦ φυράματος (cf. Num.15:20), Rom.11:16. G537	ἅπας	hapas	all	G:A	<b>ἅπας</b>, -ασα, -αν (strengthened form of πᾶς, see: ἅ-), <b>all, the whole, altogether</b>: bef. subst. with art, as Luk.3:21; or after, as Mrk.16:15]; absol, in masc, as Luk.5:26; in neut, as Act.2:44; ἅ. οὗτοι, Act.2:7 (LT); ἅ. ὑμεῖς, Gal.3:28 (TTr.). G565	ἀπέρχομαι	aperchomai	to go away	G:V	<b>ἀπέρχομαι</b>, [in LXX chiefly for הלךְ;] 1) <b>to go away, depart</b> (also, in late writers, with "perfective" force, <b>to arrive</b> at a destination, the thought being carried on to the goal; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 111f, 247; MM, see word); (a) absol: Mat.13:25, al; ptcp, ἀπελθών, used pleonastically with other verbs as in Heb. G566	ἀπέχει	apechei	to receive/be far	G:V	to receive (in full); to be distant; (<i>middle</i>) to abstain, avoid trans. <b>to have in full</b> what is due or is sought, Mt. 6:2, 5, 16; Lk. 6:24; Phil. 4:18; <b>to have altogether,</b> Phlm. 15; hence, <b>it is enough,</b> Mk. 14:41; <i>intransitive</i> <b>to be distant,</b> Lk. 7:6; <b>to be estranged,</b> Mt. 15:8; Mk. 7:6, <i>middle</i> <b>to abstain from,</b> Acts 14:20 (MT)

G568	ἀπέχω	apechō	to have in full	G:V	<b>ἀπ-έχω </b> [in LXX chiefly for רָחַק;] 1) trans, (a) <b>to hold back, keep off</b>; (b) <b>to have in full, to have received </b>(on the " punctiliar " force of the compound, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 109, 247): with accusative, Mat.6:2, 5 6:16, Luk.6:24, Php.4:18, Phm 15 (for illustr. from π, where it is used in receipts, see Deiss, BS, 229; <i>LAE</i>, 110 f; MM, see word); impers, ἀπέχει (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 39), <b>it is enough</b>: Mrk.14:41. 2) Intrans, <b>to be away, distant</b>: absol, Luk.15:20; before ἀπό, Mat.14:24 15:8, Mrk.7:6, Luk.7:6 15:20 24:13. G573	ἁπλοῦς	haplous	sound	G:A	<b>ἁπλοῦς</b>, -ῆ, -οῦν (contr. fr. -όος; &lt; ἁ.- cop, πλόος), [in LXX: Pro.11:25 *;] <b>simple, single</b>: in a moral sense (<i>DCG</i>, ii, 628 f.), ἀφθαλμός, Mat.6:22, Luk.11:34. (In π. of a marriage dowry, see MM, see word). ἁπλόος, see: ἁπλοῦς (AS)

("Later writers comprehend under the one word the whole magnanimous and honour­able type of character in which. singleness of mind is the central feature "-Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, l.with) (AS)
G575	ἀπό	apo	away from	G:Prep	<b>ἀπό</b> (on the freq. neglect of elision bef. vowels, see Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, 94, WH, <i>App.</i>, 146), <i>prep.</i> with genitive (WM, 462ff; on its relation to ἐκ, παρά, ὑπό, ib. 456f.), [in LXX for לְ,בְּ,מִן;] <b>from</b> (i.e. from the exterior). 1) <b>Of separation and cessation</b>; (1) <b>of motion from a place</b>: Mat.5:29, 30 7:23, Luk.5:2 22:41, al; (2) in partitive sense (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 72, 102, 245; MM, see word; Bl, §40, 2), Mat.9:16 27:21, Jhn.21:10, Act.5:2, al; also after verbs of eating, etc; (3) of alienation (cl. genitive of separation), after such verbs as λούω (Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 227), λύω, σώζω, παύω, etc; ἀνάθεμα ἀ, Rom.9:3; ἀποθνήσκειν ἀ, Col.2:20; σαλευθῆναι, 2Th.2:2, καθαρός, -ίζειν, ἀ. (Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 196, 216), Act.20:26, 2Co.7:1, Heb.9:14; (4) of position, Mat.23:34 24:31, al; after μακράν, Mat.8:30; transposed before measures of distance, Jhn.10:18 21:8, Rev.14:20 (Abbott, <i>JG</i>, 227); (5) of time, ἀπὸ τ. ὥρας, ἡμέρας, etc, Mat.9:22, Jhn.19:27, Act.20:18, Php.1:5, al; ἀπ᾽ αἰῶνος, Luk.1:70, al; ἀπ᾽ ἀρχῆς, etc, Mat.19:4, Rom.1:20; ἀπὸ βρέφους, 2Ti.3:15; ἀφ᾽ ἧς, <b>since</b>, Luk.7:45, al; ἀπὸ τ. νῦν, Luk.1:48, al; ἀπὸ τότε, Mat.4:17, al; ἀπὸ πέρυσι, <b>a year ago</b>, 2Co.8:10 9:2; ἀπὸ πρωΐ, Act.28:23; (6) of order or rank, ἀπὸ διετοῦς, Mat.2:16; ἀπὸ Ἀβραάμ, Mat.1:17; ἐβδομος ἀπὸ Ἀδάμ, Ju 14; ἀπὸ μικροῦ ἕως μεγάλου, Act.8:10, Heb.8:11; ἄρχεσθαι ἀπό, Mat.20:8, Jhn.8:9, Act.8:35, al. 2) <b>Of origin</b>; (1) of birth, extraction, and hence, in late writers, (a) of local extraction (cl. ἐξ; Abbott, <i>JG</i>, 227ff.), Mat.21:11, Mrk.15:43, Jhn.1:45, Act.10:38, al; οἱ ἀπὸ Ἰταλίας (WM, §66, 6; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 237; Westc, Rendall, in l.), Heb.13:24; (b) of membership in a community or society (BL, §40, 2), Act.12:1, al; (with) of material (= cl. genitive; Bl. l.with; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 102), Mat.3:4 27:21; (d) after verbs of asking, seeking, etc, Luk.11:50, 51 1Th.2:6 (Milligan, in l.); (2) of the cause, instrument, means or occasion (freq. = ὑπό, παρά, and after verbs of learning, hearing, knowing, etc; Bl, §40, 3), Mat.7:16 11:29, Luk.22:45, Act.2:22 4:36 9:13 12:14, 1Co.11:23, Gal.3:2, al; ἀπὸ τ. ὄχλου, Luk.19:3 (cf. Jhn.21:6, Act.22:11); ἀπὸ τ. φόβου, Mat.14:26, al. (cf. Mat.10:26 13:44). 3) <b>Noteworthy Hellenistic phrases</b>: φοβεῖσθαι ἀπό (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 102, 107); προσέχειν ἀπό (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 11. with; Milligan, <i>NTD</i>, 50); ἀπὸ νότου (Heb. מִגֶּנֶב), Rev.21:13; ἀπὸ προσώπου (מִפְּנֵי), 2Th.1:9 (Bl, §40, 9); ἀπὸ τ. καρδιῶν (בְּלֵב), Mat.18:35; ἀπὸ ὁ ὤν (WM, §10, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 9), Rev.1:4. 4) In composition, ἀπό denotes separation, departure, origin, etc. (ἀπολύω, ἀπέρχομαι, ἀπογράφω); it also has a perfective force (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 112, 247), as in ἀφικνεῖσθαι, which see (AS)
G576	ἀποβαίνω	apobainō	to get out	G:V	<b>ἀπο-βαίνω </b> [in LXX for הָיָה, etc;] <b>to step off, disembark</b>: Luk.5:2, Jhn.21:9; metaph, of events, <b>to issue, turn out </b>(Field, <i>Notes</i>, 74): Luk.21:13, Php.1:19 (MM, see word). (AS)

Metaph: Rom.7:11; τ. ἔχθραν, Eph.2:16; τὸ γράμμα ἀποκτείνει 2Co.3:6 (on the perfective force of this verb, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 114) (AS)
G616	ἀποκυέω	apokueō	to generate	G:V	<b>ἀπο-κυέω</b> (Rec. -κύω), -ῶ (&lt; ἀπό, κυέω or κύω, to be pregnant), [in LXX: 4Ma.15:17 *;] prop, "the medical word for birth as the close of pregnancy" (Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, 26 f.). In κοιν, "an ordinary syn. of τίκτω, but definitely 'perfectivised' (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 111 ff; MM, see word) by the ἀπό, and so implying <b>safe delivery," to bring forth, give birth to</b>: Jas.1:15, 18. (AS)
G617	ἀποκυλίω	apokuliō	to roll away	G:V	<b>ἀπο-κυλίω</b> (see: κυλίω), [in LXX: Gen.29:3, 8 29:10 (גָּלַל) Jdth.13:9 *;] <b>to roll away</b>: Mat.28:2, Mrk.16:3, Luk.24:2. (AS)
G618	ἀπολαμβάνω	apolambanō	to get back	G:V	<b>ἀπο-λαμβάνω </b> [in LXX: Num.34:14 (לָקַח (Deu.25:5 A, Isa.5:17, 2Ma.4:46 2Mac 6:21 2Mac 8:6, 4Ma.18:23 *;] 1) <b>to receive from another</b>; absol, <b>to receive as one's due</b>: Luk.16:25 18:30 (seel. λάβῃ) Luk.23:41, Rom.1:27, Gal.4:5, Col.3:24, 2Jn.8. 2) <b>to receive back</b>: Luk.6:34 15:27. 3) <b>to take apart or aside</b>: Mrk.7:33 (cf. use in π. of the recluses of the Serapeum; MM, see word). (AS)
G619	ἀπόλαυσις	apolausis	enjoyment	G:N-F	<b>ἀπόλαυσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀπολαύω, to take of, enjoy a thing) [in LXX: 3Ma.7:16 *;] <b>enjoyment</b>: 1Ti.6:17, Heb.11:26 (for late exx, see MM, see word). (AS)
G620	ἀπολείπω	apoleipō	to leave	G:V	<b>ἀπο-λείπω </b> [in LXX for H2308 יָתַר, etc;] 1) <b>to leave, leave behind </b>(in π. a term. techn. in wills; see MM, see word): 2Ti.4:13 4:20, Tit.1:5; pass, <b>to be reserved, remain</b>: Heb.4:6, 9 10:26. 2) <b>to desert, abandon</b>: Ju 6. (AS)
G621	ἀπολείχω	apoleichō	to lick	G:V	<b>ἀπο-λείχω</b> (for ἐπιλ, which see), <b>to lick up</b>: Luk.16:21, Rec. (AS)
G622	ἀπολλύω	apolluō	to destroy	G:V	<b>ἀπ-όλλυμι and ἀπολλύω </b> [in LXX for אָבַד, etc. (38 words in all)]. 1) Act, 1 <b>to destroy utterly, destroy, kill</b>: Mk 124, 922, al; τ. ψνχήν, Mat.10:28, al; 2 <b>to lose utterly</b>: Mat.10:42, al; metaph, of failing to save, Jhn.6:39 18:9. 2) Mid, 1 <b>to perish</b>; (a) <b>of things</b>: Mat.5:29, Jhn.6:12, Heb.1:11 (LXX, al; (b) <b>of persons</b>: Mat.8:26, al. Metaph, of loss of eternal life, Jhn.3:15-16 10:28 17:12, Rom.2:12, 1Co.8:11 15:18, 2Pe.3:9. In οἱ ἀπολλὺμενοι, the perishing, contrasted in 1Co.1:18, al, with οἱ σωζόμενοι, the "perfective" force of the verb, WH. " implies the completion of the process of destruction," is illustrated (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 114 f; M, <i>Th.</i>, ii, 2:10); 2 <b>to be lost</b>: Luk.15:4 21:18. Metaph, on the basis of the relation between shepherd and flock, of spiritual destitution and alienation from God: Mat.10:6 15:24, Luk.19:10 (MM, see word; <i>DCG</i>, i, 191 f, ii, 76, 554; Cremer, 451) (AS)
G623	Ἀπολλύων	Apolluōn	Apollyon	N:N--T	<b>Ἀπολλύων</b>, -οντος, ὁ (pres. ptcp. of ἀπολλύω), Apollyon, i.e. the Destroyer: Rev.9:11 (cf. Ἀβάδδων). (Cremer, 453; <i>DB</i>, i, 125, 172.) (AS)
G624	Ἀπολλωνία	Apollōnia	Apollonia	N:N-F-L	<b>Ἀπολλωνία</b>, -ας, ἡ <b>Apollonia, a city of Macedonia</b>: Act.17:1. (AS)
G625	Ἀπολλῶς	Apollōs	Apollos	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀπολλώς</b>, -ώ, ὁ (perh. contr. from Ἀπολλώνιος, Act.18:24 D) <b>Apollos</b>: Act.18:24 19:1, 1Co.1:12 3:4-6 3:22 4:6 16:12, Tit.3:13. (AS)
G626	ἀπολογέομαι	apologeomai	to defend oneself	G:V	<b>ἀπολογέομαι</b>, -οῦμαι (&lt; ἀπό, λόγος), [in LXX: Jer.12:1 (רִיב) Jer.31:6, 2Ma.13:26 *;] 1) <b>to defend</b>: with accusative, Rom.2:15. 2) <b>to defend one's self</b>: absol, Luk.21:14, Act.26:1; before ὅτι, Act.25:8; τί, to adduce something in one's defence, Luk.12:11, Act.26:24 (ταῦτα) Act.24:10 (τὰ περὶ ἐμαυτοῦ); περί, with genitive of thing(s), and ἐπί, with genitive of person(s), Act.26:2; with dative of person(s), Act.19:33, 2Co.12:19. G628	ἀπολούω	apolouō	to wash off	G:V	<b>ἀπο-λούω </b> [in LXX: Job.9:30 (רָחַץ)*;] <b>to wash off, wash away</b>; mid, metaph, with accusative of thing(s), <b>to wash off oneself</b>: ἀμαρτίας, Act.22:16; absol, ἀπελούσασθε, ye washed yourselves clean (cf. Cremer, 406), 1Co.6:11. (AS)
G629	ἀπολύτρωσις	apolutrōsis	redemption	G:N-F	<b>ἀπο-λύτρωσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀπολυτρόω, to release on payment of ransom, cf. λύτρον), [in LXX: Da (LXX) Dan.4:30 with *;] <b>release effected by pay­ment of ransom, redemption, deliverance</b>; metaph, Heb.11:35; of deliverance thr. Christ from evil and the consequences of sin: Luk.21:28, Rom.3:24 (Vau, in l) 8:23, 1Co.1:30, Eph.1:7, 14 4:30, Col.1:14, Heb.9:15. (On the extent to WH. the word retains the sense of ransom, see <i>ICC</i>, Rom.3:24, Westc, He, 297 ff; see also <i>ICC</i>, <i>Eph.</i>, 11; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 605; Cremer, 410; Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 331; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 271, 316; Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, § 77.) (AS)

G649	ἀποστέλλω	apostellō	to send	G:V	<b>ἀπο-στέλλω</b>, [in LXX very freq, almost always for שׁלח;] prop, <b>to send away, to dispatch</b> on service; 1) <b>to send</b> with a commission, or on service; (a) <b>of persons</b>: Christ, Mat.10:40; the apostles, 10:16; servants, Mrk.12:2; angels, 13:27; (b) <b>of things</b>: ὄνος, Mat.21:3; τὸ δρέπανον, Mrk.4:29; τ. λόγον, Act.10:36; τ. ἐπαγγελίαν (i.e. the promised Holy Spirit), Luk.24:49, Rec; before εἰς, Mat.20:2, Luk.11:49, Jhn.3:17; ὀπίσω, Luk.19:14; ἔμπροσθεν, Jhn.3:28; πρὸ προσώπου, Mat.11:10; πρός, Mat.21:34; with ref. to sender or place of departure: ἀπό, Luk.1:26 (Rec. ὑπό); παρά, Jhn.1:6; ἐκ, ib. 1:19; ὑπό, Act.10:17 (Rec. ἀπό); before inf, Mrk.3:14, al; ἵνα, Mrk.12:2, al; εἰς (of purpose), Heb.1:14; without direct obj: before πρός, Jhn.5:33; λέγων, Jhn.11:3; ἀποστείλας, with indic, Mat.2:16, Act.7:14, Rev.1:1. 2) <b>to send away, dismiss</b>: Luk.4:18, Mrk.5:10 8:26 12:3 (cf. ἐξ, συν-αποστέλλω). G650	ἀποστερέω	apostereō	to defraud	G:V	<b>ἀπο-στερέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; στερέω, to rob), [in LXX: Exo.21:10 (גָּרַע), Deu.24:14 (עָשַׁק), Mal.3:5, Sir.4:1 29:6-7 31:21-22 *;] <b>to defraud, deprive of, despoil </b>(in cl. chiefly of the misappropriation of trust funds, Field, <i>Notes</i>, 33; cf. G651	ἀποστολή	apostolē	apostleship	G:N-F	<b>ἀπο-στολή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; ἀποστέλλω), [in LXX: Deu.22:7, 3Ki.4:34 9:16 Psa.78:49, Ecc.8:8, Sng.4:13 (for שָׁלַח and its cognates), 1Es.9:51 Est.9:54, Jer.32:36, Bar.2:25, 1Ma.2:18, 2Ma.3:2 *.] 1) In cl, a sending away (MM, see word), as, an expedition (Hdt.). 2) In LXX (a) discharge, dis­missal (Ecc.8:8); (b) a gift (3Ki.9:16, 1Ma.2:13). 3) <b>In NT, the office of an Apostle of Christ, apostleship</b>: Act.1:25, Rom.1:5, 1Co.9:2, Gal.2:8 (Cremer, 530). (AS)
G652	ἀπόστολος	apostolos	apostle	G:N-M	<b>ἀπόστολος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ἀοστέλλω), [in LXX; 3Ki.14:6 A (שָׁלַח) *;] 1) a fleet, an expedition (Dem.). 2) a messenger, one sent on a mission (Hdt, LXX, l.with, and π; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 37 f; MM, see word; M, <i>Th.</i>, i, 2:7 and reff.): Jhn.13:16, 2Co.8:23 Php.2:25. 3) In NT, an Apostle of Christ (a) with special ref. to the Twelve: Mat.10:2, Mrk.3:14, Luk.11:49, Eph.3:5, Rev.18:20, al, equality with whom is claimed by St. Paul, Gal.1:1, 11 ff, 1Ti.2:7, a1; (b) in a wider sense of prominent Christian teachers, as Barnabas, Act.14:14, apparently also Silvanus and Timothy, 1Th.2:6, and perhaps Andronicus and Junias (Junia?), Rom.16:7 (see <i>ICC</i>, in l); of false teachers, <b>claiming apostleship</b>: 2Co.11:5 11:13, Rev.2:2. (On the different uses of the term in NT, see Lit, <i>Gal.</i>, 92-101; Cremer, 530; <i>DB</i>, i, 126; <i>DCG</i>, i, 105; Enc. Br, ii, 196 ff.) (AS)

G663	ἀποτομία	apotomia	severity	G:N-F	<b>ἀποτομία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἀποτέμνω, <b>to cut of</b>), [in Sm: Jer.51:35, Nam.3:1 *;] <b>steepness, sharpness</b>; metaph, <b>severity</b> (MM, see word): Rom.11:22. (AS)
G664	ἀποτόμως	apotomōs	severely	G:Adv	<b>ἀποτόμως </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX: Wis.5:22 *;] <b>abruptly, curtly, hence sharply, severely</b>: 2Co.13:10, Tit.1:13 (MM, see word). (AS)
G665	ἀποτρέπω	apotrepō	to avoid	G:V	<b>ἀπο-τρέπω </b> [in LXX: Sir.20:29 48:18, 3Ma.1:23, 4Ma.1:33 4Mac 16:12 *;] <b>to turn away</b>; mid, <b>to turn oneself away from</b>: with accusative, 2Ti.3:5. (AS)
G666	ἀπουσία	apousia	absence	G:N-F	<b>ἀπουσία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἄπειμι); 1) <b>absence </b>(Æsch, Thuc.): Php.2:12, 2) deficiency, waste (MM, s.v). (AS)
G667	ἀποφέρω	apopherō	to carry off	G:V	<b>ἀπο-φέρω </b> [in LXX for הָלַךְ, etc;] <b>to carry off, bear, or lead away</b>: with accusative, Mrk.15:1, 1Co.16:3, Rev.17:3 21:10. Pass, Luk.16:22, Act.19:12. (AS)
G668	ἀποφεύγω	apopheugō	to escape	G:V	<b>ἀπο-φεύγω </b> [in LXX: Sir.22:22 *;] <b>to flee from, escape</b>: with accusative, 2Pe.2:18 2:20; with genitive, 2Pe.1:4. (AS)
G669	ἀποφθέγγομαι	apophtheggomai	to declare	G:V	<b>ἀπο-φθέγγομαι </b> [in LXX for נָבָא, etc;] <b>to speak forth, give utterance</b>: Act.2:4, 14 26:25 (MM, s. see). (AS)
G670	ἀποφορτίζομαι	apophortizomai	to unload	G:V	<b>ἀπο-φορτίζομαι</b> (&lt; φορτίζω, to load), to discharge a cargo (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 134), <b>to unlade</b>: with accusative, τ. γόμον, Act.21:3. (AS)
G671	ἀπόχρησις	apochrēsis	using up	G:N-F	<b>ἀπό-χρησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἀποχράομαι, to use to the full, abuse) <b>abuse, misuse</b>: Col.2:22 (MM, see word). (AS)
G672	ἀποχωρέω	apochōreō	to leave	G:V	<b>ἀπο-χωρέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: Jer.46:5 (סוּג), 2Ma.4:33, 3Ma.2:33 *;] <b>to go away, depart, withdraw</b>: before ἀπό, Mat.7:23, Luk.9:39, Act.13:13 (absol, Luk.20:20, Tr, mg.). (AS)
G673	ἀποχωρίζω	apochōrizō	to separate from	G:V	<b>ἀπο-χωρίζω </b> [in LXX: Eze.43:21 (מִפְקָד)*;] <b>to separate, part asunder</b>: pass, Rev.6:14; reflexively, <b>to separate oneself</b>: Act.15:39. (AS)
G674	ἀποψύχω	apopsuchō	to faint	G:V	<b>ἀπο-ψύχω </b> [in LXX: 4Ma.15:18 *;] 1) to breathe out life, expire (Thue; LXX, l.with). 2) <b>to leave off breathing, faint </b>(Hom, Od, xxiv, 348): before ἀπό, Luk.21:26. (AS)
G675	Ἄππιος	Appios	Appius	N:N-M-L	<b>Ἀππιος</b>, -ου, ὁ <b>Appius</b>; Ἀππίου Φόρον, Appii Forum (Market of Appius), <b>a town in Italy</b>: Act.28:15. (AS)
G676	ἀπρόσιτος	aprositos	unapproachable	G:A	<b>ἀ-πρόσ-ιτος</b>, -ον (&lt; πρόσειμι, to go to), <b>unapproachable</b>: φῶς, 1Ti.6:16. (AS)
G677	ἀπρόσκοπος	aproskopos	not giving offence	G:A	<b>ἀπρόσκοπος</b>, -ον (&lt; προσκόπτω), [in LXX: Sir.32:21, 3Ma.3:8 *;] 1) act, <b>not causing to stumble</b>: metaph, of not leading others into sin, 1Co.10:32. 2) Pass, <b>not stumbling, without offence, blameless</b>: Act.24:16, Php.1:10 (for exx, see MM, see word). (AS)
G678	ἀπροσωπολήπτως	aprosōpolēptōs	impartially	G:Adv	<b>ἀπροσωπολήμπτως</b> (Rec. -λήπτως, cl.), adv. (&lt; α- neg, προσωπολήμπτης), <b>without respect of persons, impartially</b>: 1Pe.1:17. (AS)
G679	ἄπταιστος	aptaistos	without falling	G:A	<b>ἄ-πταιστος</b>, -ον (&lt; πταίω), [in LXX: 3Ma.6:39 *;] <b>without stumbling, sure-footed</b>: metaph. (MM, see word), Ju 24. (AS)
G680	ἅπτω	haptō	to touch	G:V	to touch, hold, handle; (act.) to start a fire; "to touch a woman" means "to get married" <i>primarily</i> <b>to bring in contact, fit, fasten; to light, kindle,</b> Mk. 4:21; Lk. 8:16; <b>to touch,</b> Mt. 8:3; <b>to meddle, venture to partake,</b> Col. 2:21; <b>to have intercourse with, to know carnally,</b> 1Cor. 7:1; by <i>implication</i> <b>to harm,</b> 1Jn. 5:18 (MT)
G681	ἅπτω	haptō	to kindle	G:V	<b>ἅπτω </b> [in LXX chiefly for נָגַע;] prop, to fasten to; hence, of fire, <b>to kindle, light</b>: Luk.8:16 11:33 15:8, Act.28:2. Mid, with genitive, to fasten oneself to, cling to, lay hold of (so in π; MM, see word): Mat.8:3, 15, Jhn.20:17, al; of carnal intercourse, 1Co.7:1; with reference to levitical and ceremonial prohibitions, 2Co.6:17, Col.2:21; of hostile action, 1Jn.5:18 (cf. ἀν, καθ, περι- άπτω) (AS)
G682	Ἀπφία	Apphia	Apphia	N:N-F-P	<b>Ἀπφία</b>, -ας, ἡ <b>Apphia</b>: Phm 2 (MM, see word). (AS)
G683	ἀπωθέω	apōtheō	to reject	G:V	<b>ἀπ-ωθέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX for זָנַח, מָאַס, etc;] to thrust away. Mid, <b>to thrust away from oneself, refuse, reject</b>: with accusative of person(s) (MM, see word), Act.7:27, 39 13:46, Rom.11:1-2, 1Ti.1:19. (AS)
G684	ἀπώλεια	apōleia	destruction	G:N-F	<b>ἀπώλεια</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἀπόλλυμι), [in LXX (Cremer, 797) for אָבַד, אֵיד, etc;] <b>destruction, waste, loss, perishing </b>(in π, of money, see MM, see word): Mat.26:8, Mrk.14:4, Act.8:20, Rom.9:22, 1Ti.6:9, 2Pe.2:1; in special sense of the loss of eternal life, perdition, the antithesis of σωτηρία: Mat.7:13, Jhn.17:12, Php.1:28 3:19, 2Th.2:3, Heb.10:39, 2Pe.2:3 3:7 3:16, Rev.17:8, 11 (<i>DB</i>, iii, 744). (AS)
G685	ἀρά	ara	curse	G:N-F	<b>ἀρά</b>, -ᾶς, ἡ [in LXX chiefly for אָלָה]; 1) a prayer (MM, see word). 2) (as in Homer) a curse, <b>malediction</b>: Rom.3:14 (LXX), (AS)
G686	ἄρα	ara	therefore	G:Conj	<b>ἄρα</b>, <i>illative particle</i>, expressing a more subjective or informal inference than οὖν, <b>then</b>: prop. (as in cl.), the second word in the sentence, Rom.7:21 8:1, Gal.3:7; ἐπεὶ ἄρα, 1Co.7:14 (with another word between) 5:10; as the first word, Luk.11:48, Act.11:18, Rom.10:17, 1Co.15:18, 2Co.5:15 7:12, Heb.4:9; so prop. in apodosis after protasis with εἰ, Mat.12:28, Luk.11:20, Gal.2:21 3:29 5:11, Heb.12:8 (κενὸν ἄρα), 1Co.15:14; often in interrogations, direct and indirect, τίς (τί) ἄρα, Mat.18:1 19:25, 27 24:45, Mrk.4:41, Luk.1:66 8:25 12:42 22:23, Act.12:18; εἰ ἄρα, Mrk.11:13, Act.8:22; εἴπερ ἄρα, 1Co.15:15; οὐκ ἄρα, Act.21:38; μήτι ἄρα, 2Co.1:17; in strengthened forms, ἄρα γε, ἄραγε, Mat.7:20 17:26, Act.17:27, and more freq. ἄρα οὖν (Epp. Paul.), <b>so then</b>, Rom.5:18 7:3, 25 8:12 9:16, 18 14:19, Gal.6:10, Eph.2:19, 1Th.5:6, 2Th.2:15 (Bl, §77, 2; 78, 5; MM, see word). (AS)
G687	ἆρα	ara	no?	G:Intg+G:Neg	<b>ἆρα</b>, <i>interrog. particle</i>, implying anxiety or impatience, "quite rare and only in Luke and Paul, therefore a literary word" (Bl, §77, 2). 1) (num igitur) expecting a neg. reply, Luk.18:8; ἆρά γε, Act.8:30. 2) (ergone) in apodosis, expecting an affirm. reply, Gal.2:17 (Bl, l.with; Lft, <i>Ga.</i>, in l; MM, see word). (AS)

G691	ἀργέω	argeō	be idle	G:V	<b>ἀργέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἀργός), [in LXX: Est.4:24, Ecc.12:3 (בָּטֵל), I Est.2:30, Sir.33:27), 2Ma.5:25 *;] <b>to be idle</b>; τὸ κρίμα. ἀ, lingers (cf. M<i>Gr.</i> ἀργά, <b>late</b>: MM, see word): 2Pe.2:3. (AS)

G693	ἀργύρεος	argureos	silver	G:A	<b>ἀργύρεος</b> (see MM, see word), -οῦς, -ᾶ, -οῦν (&lt; ἄργυρος), [in LXX for כֶּסֶף;] <b>of silver</b>: Act.19:24 (WH, br.), 2Ti.2:20, Rev.9:20. (AS)
G694	ἀργύριον	argurion	money	G:N-N	<b>ἀργύριον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; ἄργυρος), [in LXX for כֶּסֶף (Gen.13:2, al.), exc. G695	ἀργυροκόπος	argurokopos	silversmith	G:N-M	<b>ἀργυροκόπος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ἄργυρος, κόπτω, to beat) [in LXX: Jdg.17:4, Jer.6:29 (צָרַף) *;] <b>a silversmith</b>: Act.19:24 (Plut; 77, see MM, see word). (AS)
G696	ἄργυρος	arguros	silver	G:N-M	<b>ἄργυρος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ἀργός, shining), [in LXX for כֶּסֶף;] <b>silver </b>(on its relation to ἀργύριον, see MM, see word): Mat.10:9, Act.17:29, Jas.5:5, Rev.18:12. (AS)

G700	ἀρέσκω	areskō	to please	G:V	<b>ἀρέσκω </b> [in LXX chiefly for טוֹב;] 1) <b>to please </b>(Hom, Hdt, al.): with dative of person(s), Mat.14:6, Mrk.6:22, Rom.8:8 15:2, 1Th.2:15 4:1, 1Co.7:32-34 Gal.1:10, 2Ti.2:4; before ἐνώπισν (= <i>Heb.</i> בּעֵנֵי, Bl, § 37, 1; 40, 7), Ac 65. 2) In late Gk, esp. in Inscr, to render service to (see M, <i>Th.</i>, <i>ICC</i>, 1 Co, ll with; Cremer, 640 f.); Rom.15:1, 3, 1Co.10:33, 1Th.2:4. G701	ἀρεστός	arestos	pleasing	G:A	<b>ἀρεστός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; ἀρέσκω), [in LXX for יָשָׁר, etc;] <b>pleasing, agreeable </b>(Hdt, Xen, and later writers; see Cremer, 641 f; MM, see word): with dative of person(s), Jhn.8:29, Act.12:3; before ἐνώπιον, with genitive (Bl, § 37, 1; 40, 7), 1Jn.3:22; ἀρεστόν ἐστιν, with accusative and inf (El, § 69, 5; 72, 5), Act.6:2. (AS)
G702	Ἀρέτας	Aretas	Aretas	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀρέτας</b> (WH, Ἀρ; <i>Intr.</i>, 313), -α, ὁ, <b>Aretas, an Arabian king</b>: 2Co.11:32 (Deiss, BS, 183 f, thinks the proper spelling Ἀρέθας was changed, as Schürer suggests, "by desire to Hellenise a barbaric name by assimilation to ἀρετή"). (AS)
G703	ἀρετή	aretē	virtue	G:N-F	<b>ἀρετή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ [in LXX, in sing: Hab.3:3, Zec.6:13 (הוֹד), in pl: Isa.42:8, 12 43:21 63:7 (תְּהִלָּה), Wis.4:1 5:13 8:7 2:1-24; 4Mac.2.2 *;] prop, whatever procures pre-eminent estimation for a person or thing, in Hom. any kind of conspicuous advantage. Later confined by philos. writers to intrinsic eminence-moral goodness, virtue; (a) <b>of God</b>: 2Pe.1:3; (b) <b>of men</b>: Php.4:8, 2Pe.1:5; pl. (Isa, Es, ll. with), <b>excellencies</b>: 1Pe.2:9 (the usage appears to be a survival of an early comprehensive sense in which the original idea is blended with the impression which it makes on others, i.e. praise, renown; see Hort, 1 Pe, 129. Deiss, BS, 95 f, thinks it means manifestations of divine power, as in current Gk. speech; cf. also MM, see word) (AS)

G711	Ἀριστόβουλος	Aristoboulos	Aristobulus	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἀριστόβουλος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ἄριστος, βουλή, i.e. best-counselling) <b>Aristobulus, a Christian</b>: Rom.16:10. (AS)
G712	ἄριστον	ariston	early meal	G:N-N	<b>ἄριστον</b>, -ου, τό [in LXX: 3Ki.3:1 (לֶחֶם), Tob.2:1, 4, al;] 1 1, prop, breakfast. 2) In late Gk. = cl. δεῖτνον, <b>dinner</b>: Mat.22:4, Luk.11:38 14:12. (AS)
G713	ἀρκετός	arketos	sufficient	G:A	<b>ἀρκετός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; ἀρκέω), [in Aq: Deu.25:2 *;] <b>sufficient</b>: Mat.6:34 (on the neut, see B1, § 31, 2); before ἵνα (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 210), Mat.10:25; with inf, 1Pe.4:3 (for exx, see Deiss, BS, 257; MM, see word). (AS)
G714	ἀρκέω	arkeō	be sufficient	G:V	<b>ἀρκέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX for הוֹן, etc;] 1) <b>to keep off</b>; with dative, to assist. 2) <b>to suffice</b>: with dative of person(s), Jo 67, 2Co.12:9; impers, Mat.25:9, Jhn.14:8 (MM, see word). G717	Ἀρμαγεδδών	Armageddōn	Armageddon	N:N--L	<b>Ἁρμαγεδών</b> (WH, Ἃρ Μαγεδών; Rec. Ἀρμαγεδδών, prop. = הַר מְגִדּוֹן), cf.
