G1341	δικαιοκρισία	dikaiokrisia	justice	G:N-F	<b>δικαιοκρισία</b>, -ας, ἡ <b>righteous judgment</b>: Rom.2:5 (cf. τ. δικαίας κρίσεως, 2Th.1:5; τὴν δ. κ, Jhn.7:24. For use in π, see Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 89 f.). (AS)
G1342	δίκαιος	dikaios	just	G:A	<b>δίκαιος</b>, -α, -ον (&lt; δίκη), [in LXX chiefly for צַדִּיק (for rendering of צַדִּיק in sense of correct, see Deiss, BS, 115 f.); sometimes for נָקִי as Pro.1:11, al;] in early Gk. writers (a) of persons, observant of δίκη, custom, rule, right, <b>righteous</b> in performing duties to gods and men; (b) of things, <b>righteous</b>, in accordance with right. In NT 1) <b>righteous</b>, chiefly in the broad sense, as above, of the person or thing corresponding to the Divine standard of right (a) <b>of persons</b>: of God, Rom.3:26, 1Jn.2:29 Jn 3:7; of Christ, Act.3:14 7:52 22:14, 1Pe.3:18, 1Jn.2:1; of men, Mat.1:19 (Abbott, <i>Essays</i>, 75 f.) Mat.10:41 13:17, 43 13:49, Luk.1:6, 17, Rom.5:7, 1Ti.1:9, Jas.5:6, 1Pe.3:12, 1Jn.3:7, Rev.22:11, al; δ. καὶ εὐλαβής, Luk.2:25; ἅγιος, Mrk.6:20; ἀγαθός, Luk.23:50; φοβούμενος τ. θεόν, Act.10:22; opp. to ἀμαρτωλοὶ καὶ ἀσεβεῖς, 1Pe.4:18; ἄδικοι, Mat.5:45, Act.24:15; δ. ἐκ πίστεως, Rom.1:17, Gal.3:11, Heb.10:38 " (LXX); δ. παρὰ τ. θεῷ, Rom.2:13 (b) <b>of things</b>: ἔργα δ, opp. to πονηρὰ, 1Jn.3:12; ἐντολή, Rom.7:12; metaph, αἷμα, Mat.23:35; τὸ δ, Luk.12:57; δ. ἐστιν, Act.4:19, Eph.6:1, Php.1:7; ὅ, Mat.20:4; ὅσα, Php.4:8 2) In narrower sense (a) of persons, as in later cl. writers, <b>just</b>, <b>rendering to each his due</b>: Tit.1:8, 1Jn.1:9; δ. κριτής, 2Ti.4:8 (b) <b>of things</b>: τὸ δ, Col.4:1; δ, sc. ἐστιν, 2Th.1:6; κρίσις δ, Jhn.5:30; ὁδοί, Rev.15:3 (AS)
G1343	δικαιοσύνη	dikaiosunē	righteousness	G:N-F	<b>δικαιοσύνη</b>, -ης, ἡ (&lt; δίκαιος), [in LXX chiefly for צֶדֶק, and cognates, Gen.15:6, al, rarely for חֶסֶד, Gen.19:19;] the character of ὁ δίκαιος (which see) 1) in broad sense, <b>righteousness</b>, <b>conformity to the Divine will in purpose, thought and action</b>: Mat.5:6, Jhn.16:8, Act.13:10, Rom.4:3; λόγος δικαιοσύνης, teaching of r, Heb.5:13; βασιλεὺς δ. (cf. FlJ, BJ, vi, 10, β. δίκαιος), Heb.7:2; ὅπλα δ, Rom.6:13; ὁδὸς δ, Mat.21:32; θώραξ τῆς δ, Eph.6:14; διὰκονοι δ, 2Co.11:15; ὁσιότης καὶ δ, Luk.1:75, cf. Eph.4:24; ἀγαθωσύνῃ καὶ δ, Eph.5:9; δ. κ. εἰρήνη κ. χαρά, Rom.14:17; δ. κ. ἁγιασμός, 1Co.1:30; opp. to ἁμαρτία, Rom.8:10; ἀνομία, 2Co.6:14; άδικία, Rom.3:5; ποιεῖν τὴν δ, 1Jn.2:29 Jn 3:7; id. as an inclusive term for the active duties of the religious life (<i>ICC</i>, in l; Abbott, <i>Essays</i>, 73 ff), Mat.6:1; ἐργάζεσθαι δ, Act.10:35; διώκειν δ, 1Ti.6:11; πληροῦν πᾶσαν δ, Mat.3:15; ζῆν τῇ δ, 1Pe.2:24; δ. θεοῦ, a righteousness divine in its character and origin, Mat.6:33, Jas.1:20, (where it also includes the idea of God's personal r; see <i>ICC</i>, on Rom.1:17) Rom.1:17 3:5, 21-26 10:3, 2Co.5:21, Php.3:9; ἡ δ. τ. πίσιεως, Rom.4:11; ἡ ἐκ π. δ, Rom.9:30; ἡ κατὰ π. δ, Heb.11:7; opp. to this is ἡ ἐκ νόμου δ, Rom.10:5; ἡ δ. ἐν ν, Php.3:6; ἡ ἰδία δ, Rom.10:3, cf. Php.3:9 2) In narrower sense (cf. δίκαιος), <b>justice</b>: Act.17:31, 2Pe.1:1, Rev.19:11 (<i>DCG</i>, ii, 529 ff; Cremer, 190, 690). (AS)
G1344	δικαιόω	dikaioō	to justify	G:V	<b>δικαιόω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; δίκαιος), [in LXX chiefly for צָדַק pi, hi, (1) as Eze.16:51, Jer.3:11 (cf. NT usage); (2) as Deu.25:1; Exo.23:7, Isa.50:8;] 1) in cl, (a) with accusative of thing(s), <b>to deem right</b>; (b) with accusative of person(s), <b>to do one justice</b>; pass, δικαιοῦσθαι, <b>to be treated rightly</b>, opp. to ἀδικεῖσθαι. 2) In NT, as in LXX, and as usual with verbs in -όω from adjectives of moral meaning; (1) <b>to show to be righteous</b>: Mat.11:19, Luk.7:35, Rom.3:4 " (LXX), 1Ti.3:16; (2) <b>to declare, pronounce righteous</b>: Luk.7:29 10:29 16:15 18:14, Rom.2:13 3:24, 26 3:28 4:5 8:30, 33, Tit.3:7; before ἀπό, Mat.11:19, Luk.7:35, Act.13:39, Rom.6:7; ἐκ πίστεως, Rom.3:30 5:1, Gal.2:16 3:8, 24; ἐξ ἔργων, Rom.3:20 (LXX) Rom.4:2, Gal.2:16, Jas.2:21, 24-25; ἐκ τ. λόγων, Mat.12:37; διὰ τ. πίστεως, Rom.3:30; with dative, Rom.3:24, 28, Tit.3:7; before ἐν, Act.13:39, Rom.3:4 5:9, 1Co.4:4 6:11, Gal.2:17 3:11 5:4, 1Ti.3:16 (see Cremer, 193, 693; <i>DB</i>, ii, 826 ff.). (AS)
G1345	δικαίωμα	dikaiōma	righteous act	G:N-N	<b>δικαίωμα</b>, -τος, τ (&lt; δικαιόω), [in LXX most freq. for חֹק, in Ez, chiefly for מִשְׁפָּט, in Pss, τὰ δ, freq. for פִּקּוּד;] a concrete expression of righteousness, the expression and result of the act of δικαίωσις, "a declaration that a thing is δίκαιον, or that a person is δίκαιος," hence, (a) <b>an ordinance</b>: δ. τ. θεοῦ, Rom.1:32; τ. κυρίου, Luk.1:6; τ. νόμου, Rom.2:26 8:4; λατρείας, Heb.9:1; σαρκός, Heb.9:10; (b) <b>a sentence</b>: <i>of acquittal</i>, Rom.5:16 (also Rom.5:18; <i>ICC</i>, in l), or <i>of condemnation</i>; (with) <b>a righteous act</b>: Rom.5:18 (RV), Rev.15:4 19:8 (on the usage of π, see MM, <i>Exp.</i>, iii, xi). (AS)
G1346	δικαίως	dikaiōs	rightly	G:Adv	<b>δικαίως </b> <i>adv.</i> (&lt; δίκαιος, which see), [in LXX for צֶדֶק, etc;] 1) <b>righteously</b>: 1Co.15:34, 1Th.2:10, Tit.2:12. 2) <b>justly</b>: Luk.23:41, 1Pe.2:23. (AS)
G1347	δικαίωσις	dikaiōsis	justification	G:N-F	<b>δικαίωσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; δικαιόω), [in LXX for מִשְׁפָּט, Lev.24:22 *;] <b>the act of pronouncing righteous, justification, acquittal</b>: Rom.4:25 5:18 (Cremer, 199). (AS)

G1349	δίκη	dikē	condemnation	G:N-F	<b>δίκη</b>, -ης, ἡ [in LXX for נָקָם, רִיב, etc;] 1) <b>custom</b>. 2) <b>right</b>. 3) <b>a judicial hearing</b>; hence its result, <b>the execution of a sentence, punishment</b>: δ. τίνειν, 2Th.1:9; δ. υπεχειν, Ju 7. 4) Personified (cf. Lat. Justitia), <b>justice, vengeance</b>: Act.28:4. (AS)
G1350	δίκτυον	diktuon	net	G:N-N	<b>δίκτυον</b>, -ον, τό [in LXX chiefly for רֶשֶׁת, שְׂבָכָה;] general term for a <b>net</b>: Mat.4:20-21, Mrk.1:18-19, Luk.5:2, 4-6, Jhn.21:6, 8 21:11 (AS)
G1351	δίλογος	dilogos	insincere	G:A	<b>διλογος</b>, -ον (&lt; δίς, λέγω), 1) in sense of διλογεῖν, -ία (Xen.), <b>given to repetition</b>. 2) In NT, prob. (cf. δίγλωσσος, Pro.11:13, Sir.5:9) <b>double-tongued</b>: 1Ti.3:8. (AS)

G1360	διότι	dioti	because	G:Conj	<b>δι-ότι </b>, <i>conjunct.</i>, for διὰ τοῦτο, ὅτι (Lat. propterea quod), <b>because</b>: Luk.1:13 2:7 21:28, Act.13:35 18:10 20:26 22:18, Rom.1:19, 21 3:20 8:7, 21, 1Co.15:9, Php.2:26, 1Th.2:8, 18 (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 37) 1Th.4:6, Heb.11:5, 23, Jas.4:3, 1Pe.1:16 1:24 2:6. G1391	δόξα	doxa	glory	G:N-F	<b>δόξα</b>, -ης, ἡ (&lt; δοκέω), [in LXX very freq. for כָּבוֹד, also for הוֹד,פִּפְאֶרֶת, etc, 25 words in all;] in cl, 1) <b>expectation, judgment, opinion</b> (4Ma.5:18). 2) <b>opinion, estimation</b> in which one is held, <b>repute</b>; in NT, always <b>good opinion</b>, hence <b>reputation, praise, honour, glory</b>: Luk.14:10, Jhn.12:43, Heb.3:3; opp. to αἰσχύνη, Php.3:19; to ἀτιμία, 2Co.6:8; δ. κ. τιμή, Rom.2:7, 10 1Pe.1:7, 2Pe.1:17; ζητεῖν, Jhn.5:44 7:18 8:50, 1Th.2:6; λαμβάνειν, Jhn.5:41, 2Pe.1:17, Rev.5:12; διδόναι δ. τ. θεῷ (cf. נָתַן כָּבוֹד לַיהוָֹה, Jer.13:16, al.), Luk.17:18, Jhn.9:24, Act.12:23, Rom.4:20, Rev.4:9; εἰς (τ.) δ. θεοῦ, Rom.3:7 15:7, Php.1:11, al; in doxologies, τ. θεῷ (ᾧ) ἡ δ, Luk.2:14, Rom.11:36 16:27, Gal.1:5, Eph.3:21, al. 3) Later also (not cl.) as in LXX (= הוֹד, Job.39:20, 1Ch.29:25; כָּבוֹד, Job.19:9, Est.5:11, al.), visible <b>brightness, splendour, glory</b>: of light, Act.22:11; of heavenly bodies, 1Co.15:40 ff; esp. that wh. radiates from God's presence, as manifested in the pillar of cloud and in the Holy of Holies (= כָּבוֹד, Exo.16:10 25:22 40:34, al; and new Heb. שְׁכִינָה, 2Ma.2:8; see <i>DB</i>, iv, 489b), Rom.9:4, Jas.2:1 (see Hort, Mayor, in l.); hence of the manifested glory of God, Rom.1:23, Col.1:11 Eph.1:6, 12 17 3:16; of the same as communicated to man through Christ, 2Co.3:18 4:6; and of the glorious condition into which Christians shall enter hereafter, Rom.8:18, 21 9:23, 2Ti.2:10, al. (AS)
G1392	δοξάζω	doxazō	to glorify	G:V	<b>δοξάζω</b> (&lt; δόξα), [in LXX chiefly for כָּבַד ni, pi, also for פָּאַר, etc;] 1) to think, suppose, hold an opinion (Æsch, Plat, al.). 2) To bestow δόξα (which see) on, <b>to magnify, extol, praise </b>(Thuc, iii, 45; Plut, al.): with accusative, Mat.5:16, Mrk.2:12, Jhn.8:54, Rom.15:6, 1Pe.2:12, al; id. before ἐπί Luk.2:20; ἐν, Gal.1:24, 1Pe.4:16. 3) In LXX and NT (see: δόξα, 3), to clothe with splendour, glorify (Exo.34:29-30, Psa.37:20, Isa.44:23, Est.3:1, al): Rom.8:30, 2Co.3:10, 2Th.3:1, 1Pe.1:8, al; of Christ, Jhn.7:39 8:54, al. (on the Johannine use, see Cremer, 211; Westc, Jo, <i>Intr.</i>); of the Father, Jhn.13:31-32, 1Pe.4:11, al. (cf. ἐν, συν-δοξάζω). (AS)

G1400	δοῦλον	doulon	slave	G:N-N	servant, slave; in the NT a person owned as a possession for various lengths of times (Hebrew slaves no more than seven years, Gentile slaves without time limit), of lower social status than free persons or masters; slaves could earn or purchase their freedom <b>a male slave,</b> or <b>servant,</b> of various degrees, Mt. 8:9, and frequently; <b>a servitor, person of mean condition,</b> Phil. 2:7; <i>feminine</i> δούλη, <b>a female slave; a handmaiden,</b> Lk. 1:38, 48; Acts 2:18; δοῦλος, used figuratively, in a bad sense, <b>one involved in</b> moral or spiritual <b>thraldom,</b> Jn. 8:34; Rom. 6:17, 20; 1Cor. 7:23; 2Pet. 2:19; in a good sense, <b>a</b> devoted <b>servant</b> or <b>minister,</b> Acts 16:17; Rom. 1:1; <b>one pledged</b> or <b>bound to serve,</b> 1Cor. 7:22; 2Cor. 4:5 (MT)

G1438	ἑαυτοῦ	heautou	my/your/him-self	G:RefP	<b>ἑαυτοῦ</b>, -ῆς, -οῦ, dative -ῷ, etc, accusative -όν, etc, pi. -ῶν, etc. (Att. contr. αὑτοῦ, etc); <i>reflex pron.</i>; 1) prop, of 3rd person (Lat. sui, sibi, se), <b>of himself, herself, itself</b>, etc: Mat.27:42, Mrk.15:31, Luk.23:35, al; added to a middle verb, διεμερίσαντο ἑαυτοῖς, Jhn.19:24; to an active verb, Act.14:14 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 157); ἀφ᾽ ἑαυτοῦ, Luk.12:57 21:30, Jhn.5:19, al. G1444	Ἑβραϊκός	Hebraikos	Hebrew	N:N--LG	<b>Ἑβραϊκός</b>, -ή, -όν, <b>Hebrew</b>: Luk.23:38, Rec. (AS)
G1445	Ἑβραῖος	Hebraios	a Hebrew	N:N--PG	<b>Ἑβραῖος</b> (WH, Ἐβ-), -α, -ον (Aram, עִבְרַי), as subst, ὁ Ἑ, [in LXX for עֵבֶר, עִבְרִי;] <b>a Hebrew</b>. 1) In OT, of Israelites in contrast with those of another race (Gen.14:13, Exo.1:15, Deu.15:12, al.). 2) In NT as the correlative of Ἑλληνιστής, a Jew who had adopted, in greater or less degree, Greek culture and Greek language. The distinction was not merely linguistic (<i>DB</i>, ii, 325); as far as it was so, Συριστής would be a more correct Greek term for the Jew of Semitic speech (see: Ἑβραΐς, and cf. Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 7): Act.6:1, 2Co.11:22, Php.3:5. (AS)

G1453	ἐγείρω	egeirō	to arise	G:V	<b>ἐγείρω</b>, [in LXX for קוּם, etc;] trans. SYN: αἰτιάομαι (which see), διαβάλλω, ἐπικαλέω, κατηγορέω. (AS)
G1459	ἐγκαταλείπω	egkataleipō	to leave behind	G:V	<b>ἐγκαταλείπω</b>, [in LXX chiefly for עזב;] 1) <b>to leave behind</b>: ἡμῖν σπέρμα, Rom.9:29 (LXX). 2) <b>to abandon, desert, forsake</b>: with accusative of person(s), Mat.27:46 (LXX), Mrk.15:34 (ib.), Act.2:27 (LXX) (WH, ἐνκ-), 2Ti.4:10, 16 Heb.13:5 " (LXX); τ. ἐπισυναγωγήν (cf. MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xi), Heb.10:25. Pass, Act.2:31 (WH, ἐνκ-), 2Co.4:9. (AS)
G1460	ἐγκατοικέω	egkatoikeō	to live among	G:V	<b>ἐγκατοικέω</b>, see: ἐνκ. <b>ἐν-κατοικέω</b>, -ῶ (Rec. ἐγκ, see: ἐν), <b>to dwell among</b>: before ἐν, 2Pe.2:8. (AS)
G1461	ἐγκεντρίζω	egkentrizō	to ingraft	G:V	<b>ἐγκεντρίζω</b>, see: ἐνκ. <b>ἐν-κεντρίζω</b> (Rec. ἐγρ, see: ἐν; &lt; κεντρίζω, to graft), [in LXX: Wis.16:11 *;] to ingraft, graft in. figuratively, with accusative of person(s), Rom.11:17,19,23,24. (AS)
G1462	ἔγκλημα	egklēma	accusation	G:N-N	<b>ἔγκλημα -τος</b>, τό (&lt; ἐγκαλέω), <b>an accusation, charge</b>: Act.23:29 25:16 (Cremer, 743). (AS)
G1463	ἐγκομβόομαι	egkomboomai	to clothe oneself	G:V	<b>ἐγκομβόομαι</b>, -οῦμαι (&lt; κόμβος, a knot, whence ἐγκόμβωμα, a garment tied on over others, used especially of a frock or apron worn by slaves), <b>to put on oneself</b>, as a garment, <b>gird on</b>: ἀλλήλοις τ. ταπεινοφροσύνην (as for service, RV, cf. Thayer, see word, but cf. also <i>ICC</i>, in l.), 1Pe.5:5. (AS)
G1464	ἐγκοπή	egkopē	hindrance	G:N-F	<b>ἐγκοπή</b>, see: ἐνκ. <b>ἐν-κοπή</b> (Rec. ἐγκ, see: ἐν; T, ἐκκ-), -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; ἐγκόπτω); 1. an incision, a cutting, break. 2. Metaph, <b>an interruption, a hindrance</b>: 1Co.9:12. (AS)
G1465	ἐγκόπτω	egkoptō	to impede	G:V	<b>ἐγκόπτω</b>, see: ἐνκ. <b>ἐν-κόπτω</b> (Rec. ἐγκ, see: ἐν; and in I Pe, l.with, ἐκκ-); 1. to cut into (as in breaking up a road), hence, 2. to hinder: with accusative Act.24:4, 1Th.2:18. inf, Gal.5:7; before τοῦ, with inf, Rom.15:22; εἰς τό, with inf, 1Pe.3:7. (AS)
G1466	ἐγκράτεια	egkrateia	self-control	G:N-F	<b>ἐγκράτεια</b>, -ας, ἡ (-&lt; ἐγκρατής), [in LXX: Sir.18:15, 30 4Ma.5:34 *;] 1) prop, <b>mastery, control</b>. 2) (sc. ἑαθτοῦ) <b>self-control</b>: Act.24:25, Gal.5:23, 2Pe.1:6 (see <i>DB</i>, iv, 558b 695a; Page on Ac, l.with). (AS)
G1467	ἐγκρατεύομαι	egkrateuomai	to self-control	G:V	<b>ἐγκρατεύομαι</b>, depon, [in LXX for אפק, Gen.43:31, 1Ki.13:12, Est.5:10 א 3 *;] <b>to exercise self-control:</b> 1Co.7:9; with accusative, πάντα (see Bl, 91), 1Co.9:25. (AS)
G1468	ἐγκρατής	egkratēs	self-controlled	G:A	<b>ἐγκρατής</b>, -ές (&lt; κράτος), [in LXX: Wis.8:20, Sir.6:27 15:1 26:15 27:30, al;] 1) <b>strong, powerful</b>. 2) C. genitive of thing(s), <b>master of</b>, hence, 3) (sc. ἑαυτοῦ), <b>self -controlled, exercising self-control</b>: Tit.1:8. (AS)
G1469	ἐγκρίνω	egkrinō	to classify	G:V	<b>ἐγ-κρίνω</b>, see: ἐνκ. <b>ἐν-κρίνω</b> (Rec. ἐγκ, see: ἐν), <b>to reckon among </b>: ἑαυτούς, 2Co.10:12. (AS)
G1470	ἐγκρύπτω	egkruptō	to mix	G:V	<b>ἐγ-κρύπτω</b>, [in LXX for טמן, etc;] <b>to conceal in</b>: with accusative, before εἰς, Mat.13:33. (AS)
G1471	ἔγκυος	egkuos	pregnant	G:A	<b>ἔγκυος</b>, see: ἐνκ. ἔνκυoς (Rec. ἐγκ, see: ἐν), -ον (&lt; κύω, to conceive), [in LXX: Sir.42:10 *;] <b>pregnant, big with child </b>: Luk.2:5. (AS)
G1472	ἐγχρίω	egchriō	to rub on	G:V	<b>ἐγχρίω</b>, [in LXX: Jer.4:30 (קרע). Tob.2:10 6:8 11:7 *;] <b>to rub in, anoint</b>: mid, with dupl. accusative, Rev.3:18. (AS)
G1473	ἐγώ	egō	I/we	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)
G1474	ἐδαφίζω	edaphizō	to raze	G:V	<b>ἐδαφίζω</b> (&lt; ἔδαφος) [in LXX chiefly for רטשׁ pu;] 1) <b>to beat level like a threshing floor</b> (Theophr.). 2) <b>to dash to the ground</b> (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 74): Luk.19:44 (cf. Psa.136(137):9, Hos.14:1). (AS)
G1475	ἔδαφος	edaphos	ground	G:N-N	<b>ἔδαφος</b>, -εος (-ους), τό, [in LXX for עָפָר, קַרְקע, etc;] <b>bottom, pavement, ground</b>: Act.22:7. (AS)
G1476	ἑδραῖος	hedraios	steadfast	G:A	<b>ἑδραῖος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἕδρα, <i>a seat</i>), [in Sm: Ps 32 (33):14, al;] 1) <b>sitting, seated</b>. 2) <b>steadfast, firm</b>; metaph, of moral fixity: 1Co.7:37 15:58, Col.1:23. (AS)
G1477	ἑδραίωμα	hedraiōma	foundation	G:N-N	<b>ἑδραίωμα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; ἑδραῖος), <b>a support, bulwark, stay</b> (Vg. fermamentum): 1Ti.3:15 (eccl.). (AS)
G1478	Ἐζεκίας	Ezekias	Hezekiah	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἑζεκίας</b> (Rec. Ἐζ-), -ου, ὁ (Heb. חִזְקִיָּה, <i>strength of Jehovah</i>), <b>Hezekiah</b>, King of Judah: Mat.1:9, 10. (AS)
G1479	ἐθελοθρησκεία	ethelothrēskeia	self-made religion	G:N-F	<b>ἐθελο-θρησκία</b> (Rec. -εία), -ας, ἡ, <b>self-imposed worship</b>: Col.2:23 (eccl; cf. <i>DB</i>, iv, 923a; Cremer, 733). (AS)
G1480	ἐθίζω	ethizō	be accustomed	G:V	<b>ἐθίζω</b>, [in LXX: Sir.23:9, 13 2Ma.14:30;] <b>to accustom</b>: pass. pf. ptcp, τὸ εἰθισμένον, <b>the established custom</b>, Luk.2:27. (AS)
G1481	ἐθνάρχης	ethnarchēs	governor	G:N-M	<b>ἐθνάρχης</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ἔθνος, ἄρχω), [in LXX: 1Ma.14:47 15:1, 2 *;] <b>an ethnarch, a provincial governor</b> (cf. I Mac, ll. with; FlJ, <i>Ant.</i>, xiii, 6, 6; Dalman, 332): 2Co.11:32. (AS)
G1482	ἐθνικός	ethnikos	Gentile-like	G:A	<b>ἐθνικός</b>, -ή, -όν, [in Al: Lev.21:7 *;] 1) <b>national</b> (Polyb.). 2) <b>foreign</b> (gramm.); in NT, as subst, ὁ ἐ, <b>the Gentile </b>(the adj. "describes character rather than mere position"; cf. ἔθνος, and see Cremer, 228): Mat.5:47 6:7 18:17, 3Jo.7. (AS)
G1483	ἐθνικῶς	ethnikōs	Gentile-way	G:Adv	<b>ἐθνικῶς</b>, <i>adv.</i>, <b>in Gentile fashion</b>: Gal.2:14. (AS)
G1484	ἔθνος	ethnos	Gentile nation	G:N-N	<b>ἔθνος</b>, -ους, τό, [in LXX chiefly for עַם,גּוֹי;] 1) <b>a multitude, a company</b>, whether of beasts or men (Hom.). 2) <b>a nation, people</b>: Mat.21:43 24:7, Mrk.13:8, Luk.22:25, Act.10:35, al; in sing, of the Jewish people, Luk.7:5 23:2, Jhn.11:48, 50-53 18:35, Act.10:22 24:3, 10 26:4 28:19. 3) In pl, as in OT, τὰ ἔ. (like Heb. הַגּוֹיִם), <b>the nations</b>, as distinct from Israel, <b>Gentiles</b>: Mat.4:15 6:32, Act.26:17, Rom.3:29 11:11 15:10, Gal.2:8, al; of Gentile Christians, Rom.11:13 15:27 16:4, Gal.2:12, 14, Eph.3:1. (AS)
G1485	ἔθος	ethos	custom	G:N-N	<b>ἔθος</b>, -εος (-ους), τό (&lt; ἔθω), [in LXX: Wis.14:16, Da TH Bel 15, 1Ma.10:89, 2Ma.11:25 13:4, 4Ma.18:5 א R*;] <b>habit, custom</b>; Luk.22:39, Jhn.19:40, Act.16:21 25:16, Heb.10:25; in Luk.1:9 Act.6:14 15:1 21:21 26:3 28:17, almost in the narrower sense of law (Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 251 f.). (AS)
G1486	ἔθω	ethō	to have a custom	G:V	<b>ἔθω</b>, pf. with pres. sense εἴωθα, [in LXX: Num.24:1 (כְּפַעַם־בְּפַעַם), Dan LXX Su 13, Sir.37:14, 4Ma.1:12 *;] <b>to be accustomed, wont</b>: Mat.27:15, Mrk.10:1; ptcp, τὸ εἰθός, <b>custom</b>: κατὰ τὸ εἰ. (Nu, l.with), Luk.4:16, Act.17:2. (AS)
G1487	εἰ	ei	if	G:Cond	<b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)
G1488	εἶ	ei	you are	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G1489	εἴγε	eige	if indeed/otherwise	G:Cond	<b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)
G1490	εἰ δὲ μή(γε)	ei de mē(ge)	but if not	G:Part	<b>μήγε</b>, see: γε. <b>γε</b>, <i>enclitic postpositive particle</i>, rarer in κοινή than in cl, giving special prominence to the word to which it is attached, distinguishing it as the least or the most important (Thayer, see word), <b>indeed, at least, even</b> (but not always translatable into English); 1) <b>used alone</b>: Luk.11:8 18:5 Rom.8:32. 2) More freq. with other particles: αλλά γε, Luk.24:21, 1Co.9:2; ἄρα γε, Mat.7:20 17:26, Act.17:27; ἆρά γε, Act.8:30; εἴ γε (Rec. εἴγε), 2Co.5:3, Gal.3:4, Eph.3:2 4:21, Col.1:23 (see Meyer, Ellic, on Ga, Eph, ll. with; Lft, on Ga, Col, ll. with); εἰ δὲ μήγε, following an affirmation, Mat.6:1, Luk.10:6 13:9; a negation, Mat.9:17, Luk.5:36, 37 14:32, 2Co.11:16; καί γε (Rec. καίγε, cl. καὶ. γε), Luk.19:42 (WH om.), Act.2:18 17:27; καίτοιγε (L καίτοι γε, Tr. καί τοι γε), Jhn.4:2; μενοῦνγε (see see word); μήτι γε, see: μήτι; ὄφελόν, 1Co.4:8. (AS)
G1491	εἶδος	eidos	appearance	G:N-N	<b>εἶδος</b>, -ους, τό, [in LXX for מַרְאֶה, etc;] 1) <b>that which is seen, appearance, external form</b>: Luk.3:22 9:29, Jhn.5:37, 2Co.5:7 (<i>ICC</i> in l.). 2) <b>form, sort, kind</b>: 1Th.5:22. (AS)
G1492	εἴδω	eidō	to perceive	G:V	<b>οἶδα</b>, (from same root as εἶδον, which see), [in LXX chiefly for ידע;] pf. with pres. meaning (plpf. as impf; on irregular tense-forms, see App.), <b>to have seen or perceived</b>, hence, <b>to know, have knowledge of</b>: with accusative of thing(s), Mat.25:13, Mrk.10:19, Jhn.10:4, Rom.7:7, al; with accusative of person(s), Mat.26:72, Jhn.1:31, Act.3:16, al; τ. θεόν, 1Th.4:5, Tit.1:16, al; with accusative and inf, Luk.4:41, al; before ὅτι, Mat.9:6, Luk.20:21, Jhn.3:2, Rom.2:2 11:2, al; before quaest. indir, Mat.26:70, Jhn.9:21, Eph.1:18, al; with inf, <b>to know how</b> (cl.), Mat.7:11, Luk.11:13, Php.4:12, 1Th.4:4, al; in unique sense of <b>respect, appreciate</b>: 1Th.5:12 (but see also <i>ICC</i> on 1Th.4:4). G1497	εἴδωλον	eidōlon	idol	G:N-N	<b>εἴδωλον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; εἶδος), [in LXX for אֱלוֹהָּ, גְּלוּלִים, etc;] 1) in cl. (a) <b>a phantom, image, likeness</b>; (b) <b>an image in the mind, an idea, fancy</b>. 2) In LXX and NT, (a) <b>an image of a god, an idol</b> (cf. Polyb, xxxi, 3, 13): Act.7:41, 1Co.12:2, Rev.9:20; (b) <b>the false god</b> or <b>idol worshipped in an image</b> (<i>ICC</i>, on I Th, l.with): Act.15:20, Rom.2:22, 1Co.8:4, 7 10:19 2Co.6:18, 1Th.1:9, 1Jn.5:21. (AS)
G1498	εἴην	eiēn	may be	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G1499	εἰ καί	ei kai	if also	G:Conj	<b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)

G1509	εἰ μή τι	ei mē ti	except what	G:Cond+G:Neg+G:Conj	<b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)
G1510	εἰμί	eimi	to be	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G1511	εἶναι	einai	to exist	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G1512	εἴπερ	eiper	if so/since	G:Cond/G:Conj	<b>εἴ-περ</b>, see: εἰ. <b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)

G1515	εἰρήνη	eirēnē	peace	G:N-F	<b>εἰρήνη</b>, -ης, ἡ, [in LXX chiefly for שָׁלוֹם;] <b>peace</b>; 1) <b>of public peace, freedom from war</b>: Luk.14:32, Act.12:20 24:2; of the church, Ac 9:31. 2) <b>Of peace between persons, concord, agreement </b>: Mat.10:34, Luk.12:51, Rom.14:17, 1Co.7:15, Gal.5:22, Jas.3:18; ζητεῖν εἰ, 1Pe.3:11; διώκειν, 2Ti.2:22; ib. before μετὰ πάντων, Heb.12:14; by meton, of him who brings peace, Eph.2:14. 3) As in LXX (= Heb. שָׁלוֹם, Aram. שְׁלָם), of a state of security and safety: Jhn.16:33, Rom.2:10, 1Th.5:3,́ whence the formulae, ὕπαγε (πορεύου) εἰς εἰ, Mrk.5:34, Luk.7:50 (cf. 1Ki.1:17, al; לְכִי לְשָׁלוֹם); εἰ. ὑμῖν (שָׁלוֹם לָכֶם), Jhn.20:19, 21, 26; ἀπολύειν ἐν εἰ, Luk.2:29, cf. 1Co.16:11; ἡ εἰ. ὑμῶν, Mat.10:13, Luk.10:6; υἱὸς εἰρήνης, ib. 4) <b>Of spiritual peace, the peace of Christ's kingdom </b>(<i>DCG</i>, ii, 330f.): Luk.1:79 2:14 Jhn.16:33, Rom.2:10 5:1 8:6, al; ὁ κύριος τῆς εἰ, 2Th.3:16; ὁ θεὸς τῆς εἰ, Rom.15:33 16:20, 2Co.13:11, al; in epistolary salutations, Rom.1:7, 1Co.1:3, Gal.1:3, 1Th.1:1, 1Pe.1:2, 2Jo.3, Rev.1:4, al. G1518	εἰρηνοποιός	eirēnopoios	peacemaker	G:A	<b>εἰρηνοποιός</b>, -όν <b>peace-making, a peacemaker</b>: Mat.5:9 (AS)
G1519	εἰς	eis	toward	G:Prep	<b>εἰς</b>, <i>prep. with accusative, </i> expressing entrance, direction, limit, <b>into, unto, to, upon, towards, for, among</b> (Lat. in, with accusative). I. Of place. 1) After verbs of motion; (a) <b>of entrance into</b>: Mat.8:23, 9:7, Mrk.1:45, Luk.2:15, 8:31, al; (b) of approach, <b>to</b> or <b>towards</b>: Mrk.11:1, Luk.6:8, 19:28, Jhn.11:31, 21:6, al; (with) before pl. and collective nouns, <b>among</b>: Mrk.4:7, 8:19, 20, Luk.11:49, Jhn.21:23, al; (d) Of a limit reached, <b>unto, on, upon</b>: Mat.8:18, 21:1, Mrk.11:1, 13:16, Luk.14:10, Jhn.6:3, 11:32, al; with accusative of person(s) (as in Ep. and Ion.), Act.23:15, Rom.5:12, 16:19, 2Co.10:14; (e) <b>elliptical</b>: ἐπιστολαὶ εἰς Δαμασκόν, Act.9:2; ἡ διακονία μου ἡ εἰς Ἱ, Rom.15:31; metaph, of entrance into a certain state or condition, or of approach or direction towards some end (Thayer, B, i, 1; ii, 1), εἰς τ. ὄνομα, M, <i>Pr.</i>, 200. 2) Of direction; (a) <b>after verbs of seeing</b>: Mat.6:26, Mrk.6:41, Luk.9:16, 62, Jhn.13:22, al; metaph, of the mind, Heb.11:26, 12:2, al; (b) <b>after verbs of speaking</b>: Mat.13:10, 14:9, 1Th.2:9, al. 3) After verbs of rest; (a) <b>in "pregnant" construction, implying previous motion </b>(cl; see WM, 516; Bl, §39, 3; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 234f.): Mat.2:23, 4:13, 2Th.2:4, 2Ti.1:11, Heb.11:9, al; (b) by an assimilation general in late Gk (see Bl, M, <i>Pr.</i>, ll. with) = ἐν: Luk.1:44, 4:23, Act.20:16, 21:17, Jhn.1:18 (but see Westc, in l.), al. II. Of time, <b>for, unto</b>; 1) accentuating the duration expressed by the accusative: εἰς τ. αἰῶνα, Mat.21:19; εἰς γενεὰς καὶ γ, Luk.1:50; εἰς τ. διηνεκές, Heb.7:3, al. 2) Of a point or limit of time, <b>unto, up to, until</b>: Mat.6:34, Act.4:3, 25:21, Php.1:10, 2:16, 1Th.4:15, 2Ti.1:12; of entrance into a future period, σεις τὸ μέλλον (see: μέλλω), <b>next (year)</b>, Luk.13:9 (but with <i>ICC</i>, in l.); εἰς τ. μεταξὺ σάββατον, <b>on the next Sabbath</b>, Act.13:42; εἰς τὸ πάλιν (see: πάλιν, 2Co.13:2. III. Of result, after verbs of changing, joining, dividing, etc: στρέφειν εἰς, Rev.11:6; μετας, Act.2:20, Jas.4:9; μεταλλάσσειν, Rom.1:26; σχίζειν εἰς δύο, Mat.27:51, al; predicatively with εἴναι, Act.8:23. IV. Of relation, <b>to, towards, for, in regard to</b> (so in cl, but more freq. in late Gk, εἰς encroaching on the simple dative, which it has wholly displaced in MGr; Jannaris, <i>Gr.</i>, §1541; Robertson, <i>Gr.</i>, 594; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 117f.): Luk.7:30, Rom.4:20, 15:2, 26, 1Co.16:1, Eph.3:16, al; ἀγάπη εἰς, Rom.5:8, al; χρηστός, Eph.4:32; φρονεῖν εἰς, Rom.12:16; θαρρεῖν, 2Co.10:1. V. <b>Of the end or object</b>: εὔθετος εἰς, Luk.14:34; σόφος, Rom.16:19; ἰσχύειν, Mat.5:13; εἰς τοῦτο, Mrk.1:38, al; ἀφορίζειν εἰς, Rom.1:1; indicating purpose, εἰς φόβον, Rom.8:15; εἰς ἔνδειξιν, Rom.3:25; εἰς τό, with inf. (= ἵνα or ὥστε; Bl, §71, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 218ff.): Mat.20:19, Rom.1:11, 1Co.9:18, al. VI. <b>Adverbial phrases</b>: εἰς τέλος, εἰς τὸ πάλιν, etc (see: τέλος, πάλιν, etc.). (AS)
G1520	εἷς	ehis	one	G:A	<b>εἷς </b> ιά, ἕν, genitive ἑνός, μιᾶς, ἑνός, cardinal numeral, <b>one</b>; 1) <b>one</b>, as opp. to many: Mat.25:15, Rom.5:12, 1Co.10:8, al; as subst, Rom.5:15, Eph.2:14; id. with genitive partit, Mat.5:19, al; before ἐκ (ἐξ), Mrk.14:18, Jhn.6:8, al; metaph, of union and concord, Jhn.10:30 17:11, Rom.12:4-5, Php.1:27; ἀπὸ μιᾶς (B1, § 44, 1), Luk.14:18; with neg, εἷς. οὐ (μή), more emphatic than οὐδείς, no one, none (cl.), Mat.5:18 10:29, Luk.11:46 12:6. 2) Emphatically, to the exclusion of others; (a) <b>a single (one)</b>: Mat.21:24, Mrk.8:14; absol, 1Co.9:24, al; οὐδὲ εἷς, Mat.27:14, Jhn.1:3, Rom.3:10, al; (b) <b>one, alone</b>: Mrk.2:7 10:18, Luk.18:19; (with) <b>one and the same</b>: Rom.3:30, 1Co.3:8 11:5 12:11, 1Jn.5:8. 3) In late Gk, with weakened force, = τις or indef. art. (of. <i>Heb.</i> אֶחָד, Gen.22:13, al; see B1, § 45, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 96 f.): Mat.8:19 19:6, Rev.8:13, al; εἷς τις (Bl, l.with), Luk.22:50, Jhn.11:49 4) <b>Distributively</b>: εἷς καστος (cl.), Luk.4:40, Act.2:6, al; εἷς. καὶ εἷς (cl, εἷς μὲν. εἷς δέ), Mat.17:4, Mrk.9:5, Jhn.20:12, al. (cf. LXX and use of <i>Heb.</i> אֶחָד, Exo.17:12, al); ὁ εἷς. ὁ ἕτερος (ἄλλος) = cl. ὁ μὲν (ἕτερος). ὁ δέ (ἕτερος), Mat.6:24, Luk.7:41, Rev.17:10; καθ᾽ εἷς, εἷς κ. είς (in which καθ᾽ is adverbial, or the expression formed from the analogy of ἕν καθ᾽ ἔν; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 105), <b>one by one, severally</b>: Mrk.14:19, Rom.12:5, al; εἷς τὸν ἕνα = ἀλλήλους (B1, 45, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 246), 1Th.5:11. 5) As ordinal = πρῶτος (like <i>Heb.</i> אֶחָד; Bl, § 45, 1; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 95 f.), <b>first</b>: Mat.28:1, Mrk.16:2, al (AS)
G1521	εἰσάγω	eisagō	to bring in	G:V	<b>εἰσ-άγω </b> [in LXX chiefly for בּוֹא, hi;] <b>to bring in</b>: with accusative, Luk.2:27, Jhn.18:16, Act.7:45; before εἰς, Luk.22:54, Act.9:8 21:28-29, 37 22:24, Heb.1:6; ὧδε, Luk.14:21. (AS)

G1525	εἰσέρχομαι	eiserchomai	to enter	G:V	<b>εἰσ-έρχομαι</b>, [in LXX chiefly for בּוֹא;] <b>to go in</b> or <b>into, enter</b>: Mat.9:25, Luk.7:45, al; before εἰς, Mat.10:12, Mrk.2:1, al; before διά (πύλης, θύρας, etc.), Mat.7:13, Jhn.10:1, al; ὑπὸ τ. στέγην, Mat.8:8; with adv: ὅπου, Mrk.14:14, Heb.6:20; ὧδε, Mat.22:12; ἔσω, Mat.26:58; before πρός, with accusative of person(s), Mrk.15:43, Luk.1:28, Act.10:3 11:3 16:40 17:2 28:8, Rev.3:20; of demons taking possession, Mrk.9:25, Luk.8:30 22:3, Jhn.13:27; of food, Mat.15:11, Act.11:8. (see: βασιλεία); εἰς τ. κατάπαυσιν, Heb.3:11, 18 4:1 ff; εἰς τ. δόξαν, Luk.24:26; εἰσ. καὶ ἐξερχ, <b>to go in and out</b> (like Heb. בוֹא וְצֵאת, Deu.28:6, etc.), of familiar intercourse, Act.1:21; figuratively, of moral freedom, Jhn.10:9 (cf. ἐπ, παρ, συν-εισέρχομαι). (AS)
G1526	εἰσί	eisi	they are	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)

G1534	εἶτα	eita	then	G:Adv	<b>εἶτα </b> <i>adv.</i>, <b>denoting sequence</b>; 1) <b>of time</b>; <b>then, next</b>: Mrk.8:25, Luk.8:12, Jhn.13:5 19:27 20:27, 1Ti.3:10, Jas.1:15; before genitive abs, Mrk.4:17; in enumerations, 1Co.15:5 15:7 15:24, 1Ti.2:13. 2) <b>In argument</b>; (a) <b>therefore, then</b>, (b) <b>furthermore</b>: Heb.12:9 (cf. εἶτεν). (AS)
G1535	εἴτε	eite	whether	G:Conj	<b>εἴτε</b>, see: εἰ. <b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)
G1536	εἴ τις	ei tis	if any	G:Cond	if any, if everny, if ever (MT)
G1537	ἐκ	ek	out from	G:Prep	<b>ἐκ</b> (ἐξ), <i>prep. with genitive, </i> <b>from out of, from</b> (<i>see</i> Addendum, p. 492). This entry is included here, but in the print version the entry is found on p. 492. <b>ἐκ</b>, before a vowel ἐξ, <i>prep. with genitive, </i> of motion outwards, separation from (opp. to εἰς; = Lat. e, ex), <b>from out of, from among, from</b>. I. Of Place, 1) <b>of motion, out of, forth from, off from</b>: Jhn.6:31, Act.9:3, Gal.1:8, al; esp. after verbs of motion, Mat.8:28 17:9, Mrk.1:25 7:28, Jhn.1:33 20:1, Act.12:7, 17 27:30, al; constr. praeg, σώζειν (διας) ἐκ, Ju 5, Act.28:4. Metaph, Mat.7:4, 5, 1Pe.2:9; ἐκ τ. χειρός (-ῶν), before genitive of person(s), Luk.1:74, Jhn.10:28, 29, 39, Act.12:4 24:7, Rev.19:2; πίνειν (which see) ἐκ; of the place from which an action proceeds, Luk.5:3 (cf. 12:36, Jhn.13:4, 2Co.2:4). 2) <b>Of change from one place or condition to another</b>: Jhn.8:42, Rom.6:13 13:11, Rev.7:14, al; with ellips. of verb of motion, 2Ti.2:26, 2Pe.2:21, Rev.2:21, al. 3) Of separation or distinction from a number, before collective or pl. nouns: Mat.13:47, 49, Jhn.12:1, Act.3:15, 1Pe.1:3, al; after εἷς, Mat.10:29 Luk.17:15, al; οὐδείς, Jhn.7:19, al; πολλοί, Jhn.11:19, al; τις, Luk.11:15, al; τίς, Mat.6:27, al; in partitive phrase as subject of sentence, Jhn.16:17; Hebraistically, ἐκ μέσου before genitive, = ἐκ (Heb. מִתּוֹךְ), Mat.13:49, al. 4) <b>Of position or direction </b>(so in cl. = ἔξω): ἐκ δεξιῶν (see: δεξιός); ἐξ ἐναντίας, Mrk.15:39 (metaph, Tit.2:8); ἐκ ῥιζῶν (i.e, <b>utterly</b>), Mat.11:20. II. Of Time, 1) of the point of time from which, <b>from, since</b>: ἐκ γενετῆς, Jhn.9:1, cf. Mrk.10:20, Luk.23:8, Act.24:10, al. 2) <b>Of succession in time</b>: ἐκ δευτέρου, <b>a second time</b>, Mrk.14:72, al, cf. Mat.26:44; ἡμέραν ἐξ ἡμέρας, <b>from day to day</b>, 2Pe.2:8. III. Of Origin, 1) <b>of nativity, lineage, race</b>: κοίτην (ἐν γαστρί) ἔχειν, Rom.9:10, Mat.1:18; γεννᾶν ἐκ, Mat.1:3 ff; γεννᾶσθαι (γίνεσθαι) ἐκ, Jhn.3:6 8:41, Gal.4:4; ἐκ πνεύματος (θεοῦ), Jhn.1:13 3:5ff, al. ἔρχεσθαι, εἶναι, etc, ἐκ τ. πολέως, Jhn.1:44; φυλῆς, Luk.2:36, al; τ. ἐξουσίας Ἡρῴδου, Luk.23:7; ὁ ὢν ἐκ τ. γῆς, Jhn.3:31. 2) <b>Of the author, occasion or source</b>: Mat.5:37, Jhn.2:16, Rom.2:29, 1Co.8:6, Gal.5:8, al; ἐκ (τ. θεοῦ, 1Co.7:7, 2Co.5:1, 1Jn.4:7; ἐκ τ. πατρός, Jhn.6:65, al; ἐκ τ. γῆς ἐστιν, λαλεῖ, Jhn.3:31; εκ καρδίας, Rom.6:17, cf. Mrk.12:30, 1Ti.1:5; ἐκ ψυχῆς, Eph.6:6, Col.3:23; ἐκ πίστεως, Rom.14:23; κρίνειν ἐκ, Luk.19:22, Rev.20:12. 3) <b>Of the agent, after passive verbs</b>: Mat.15:5, Mrk.7:11, 2Co.2:2, al; freq. in Re after αδικεῖσθαι (2:11), etc. 4) <b>Of cause, dependence, source of supply</b>: τ. πόνου (των), Rev.16:10, 11; τ. φωνῶν, Rev.8:13; ἐκ τούτου, Jhn.6:66 19:12 (but see Meyer, in ll.); ἐκ θεοῦ λαλεῖν, 2Co.2:17; ἐκ τ. ἀληθείας, Jhn.18:37, 1Jn.3:19; ὁ ἐκ πίστεως, Rom.3:26 4:16; οἱ (ὄντες) ἐκ περιτομῆς, Act.11:2, Rom.4:12, Gal.2:12, Col.4:11; πίνειν ἐκ, Mat.26:29, Mrk.14:25, Jhn.4:13, al; θερίζειν, Gal.6:8; μετέχειν ἐκ (= partit. genitive), 1Co.10:13; with inf, ἐκ τοῦ ἔχειν, 2Co.8:11. 5) <b>Of material</b>: Mat.27:29, Jhn.2:15 19:2, Rom.9:21, 1Co.11:12, Rev.18:12, al; allied to which is its use of price (= cl. genitive): Mat.27:7, cf. ib. 20:2, Act.1:18. IV. <b>By attraction = ἐν </b>(cl.): τὰ ἐκ τ. οἰκιας, Mat.24:17; τ. ἐξ αὐτοῦ δύναμιν, Mrk.5:30 (see Field, in l.); ὁ πατὴρ ὁ ἐξ οὐρανοῦ, Luk.11:13. V. <b>Adverbial phrases</b>: ἐξ ἀνάγκης, 2Co.9:7, Heb.7:12; ἐξ ἰσότητος, 2Co.8:13; ἐκ μέρους, 1Co.12:27 13:9-12; ἐκ μέτρου, Jhn.3:34; ἐκ συμφώνου, 1Co.7:5. VI. in composition, ἐκ signifies, 1) <b>procession, removal</b>: ἐκβαίνω, ἐκβάλλω. 2) <b>Opening out, unfolding</b>: ἐκτείνω; metaph, ἐξαγγάλλω. 3) <b>Origin</b>: ἔκγονος. 4) <b>Completeness</b>: ἐξαπορέω (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 237), ἐκπληρόω, ἐκτελέω. (AS)
G1538	ἕκαστος	hekastos	each	G:A	1. <b>every, every one, each, each one </b>, Lat. <i>quisque</i>, (Homer), etc; the <i>singular</i> is often joined with a pl. Verb, ἔβαν οἴκονδε ἕκαστος they went home <b>every one of them </b>, (Iliad by Homer); ἕκαστος ἐπίστασθε (Xenophon Historicus);the <i>singular</i> is also put in apposition with a pl. Noun, Τρῶας ἕκαστον ὑπήλυθε τρόμος (for Τρώων ἕκαστον)) fear seized them <b>every one </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 2. in <i>plural</i> <b>all and each one </b>, (Homer) 3. more definitely, εἷς ἕκαστος, Lat. <i>unusquisque</i>, every single one, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; καθ᾽ ἕκαστον <b>singly, by itself </b>, Lat. <i>singulatim</i>, (Plato Philosophus), etc. 4. ὡς ἕκαστοι <b>each by himself </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. (ML)
G1539	ἑκάστοτε	hekastote	always	G:Adv	<b>ἑκάστοτε </b> <i>adv.</i>, <b>each time, always</b>: 2Pe.1:15. (AS)
G1540	ἑκατόν	hekaton	hundred	G:A	<b>ἑκατόν</b>, οἱ, αἱ, τά indecl, <b>a hundred</b>: Mat.13:8, 23 Luk.15:4, al; κατὰ ἑ, Mrk.6:40; εἰς, ἐν ἑ, Mrk.4:8, 20 (AS)
G1541	ἑκατονταέτης	hekatontaetēs	a hundred years old	G:A	<b>ἑκατονταετής</b> (Rec. έτης), <b>-ές </b> (&lt; ἑκατόν, ἔτης) [in LXX for שָׁנֶה מֵאָה בֵּן, Gen.17:17 *;] <b>a hundred years old</b>: Rom.4:19. (AS)
G1542	ἑκατονταπλασίων	hekatontaplasiōn	a hundred times	G:A	<b>a hundred times as much </b> or <b>many </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
G1543	ἑκατόνταρχος	hekatontarchos	centurion	G:N-M	<b>ἑκατοντάρχης</b> (-άρχος, Mat.8:5, 8 27:54, Luk.7:2, Act.22:25 28:16; cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 48); <b>-ου</b> (&lt; ἑκατόν, ἄρχω,), [in LXX for מֵאָה שַׂר;] <b>a centurion</b>: Mat.8:13, Luk.7:6 23:47, Act.10:1, 22 21:32 22:26 23:17, 23 24:23 27:1, 6 27:11, 31 27:43 (cf. κεντυρίως). (AS)
G1544	ἐκβάλλω	ekballō	to expel	G:V	<b>ἐκ-βάλλω </b> [in LXX chiefly for גָּרַשׁ pi, also for שָׁלַךְ hi, יָצָא hi, יָרַשׁ hi, etc;] 1) <b>to drive, cast</b> or <b>send out, to expel</b>: with accusative of thing(s), mid. (σῖτον), before εἰς, Act.27:38; pass, Mat.15:17; with accusative of person(s), Mat.21:12, Mrk.11:15, al; δαιμόνια, Mat.7:22, Mrk.1:34, al; id. before ἐκ, Mrk.7:26; παρά, Mrk.16:9; ἐν, Mrk.3:22; (ἐν) τ. ὀνόματι, Mat.7:22, Mrk.9:38; λόγῳ, Mat.8:16; before ἔξω, Jhn.6:37; id. with genitive, Mrk.12:8, al; of expulsion from home, Gal.4:30; from the Church, III Jn 10. 2) In LXX and NT (like <i>Heb.</i> יָצָא and Aram. הַנְפֵּק), <b>to command</b> or <b>cause to depart</b>: Mat.9:38, Mrk.1:12 (see Swete, in l.), ib. Mrk.1:43 5:40, Luk.10:2, Jas.2:25; τ. κρίσιν εἰς νῖκος (<i>to cause to proceed to its goal</i>), Mat.12:20 (LXX). 3) <b>to reject</b> (cl.): τ. ὄνομα ὑμῶς ὡς πονηρόν (cf. Deu.25:14), Luk.6:22; <b>to leave out</b>, Rev.11:2. 4) <b>to take, draw</b> or <b>pluck out</b>; (a) <b>with violence</b>: Mat.7:5, Mrk.9:47, Luk.6:42; (b) <b>to bring forth</b> or <b>out of</b>: Mat.12:35, Luk.10:35. (AS)
G1545	ἔκβασις	ekbasis	way out	G:N-F	<b>ἔκ-βασις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἐκβαίνω), [in LXX: Wis.2:17 8:8 11:14 *;] 1) <b>a way out</b> (Hom, Xen.): 1Co.10:13. 2) <b>the issue</b> (Menand.) Heb.13:7. (AS)
G1546	ἐκβολή	ekbolē	jettisoning	G:N-F	<b>ἐκ-βολή</b>, -ῆς (&lt; ἐκβάλλω), [in LXX: Exo.11:1 (גָּרַשׁ), Jos.1:5 (ἐκβολὴν ποιεῖσθαι, טול hi.), Eze.47:8 (יָצָא)*;] 1) <b>a throwing out</b>. 2) <b>a jettison, a throwing overboard of cargo</b>: Act.27:18 (cf. Jos, l.with; and see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 144 f.). (AS)
G1547	ἐκγαμίζω	ekgamizō	to marry	G:V	<b>ἐκ-γαμίζω </b> Rec. for γαμίζω, which see: Mat.22:30 24:38, Luk.17:27, 1Co.7:38. Not elsewhere. (AS)
G1548	ἐκγαμίσκω	ekgamiskō	to give in marriage	G:V	<b>ἐκ-γαμίσκω </b> Rec. for γαμίσκω, which see: Luk.20:34-35. Not elsewhere. <b>γαμίζω</b> (&lt; γάμος), <b>to give in marriage</b>, <b>a daughter</b>: 1Co.7:38. Pass, Mat.22:30 24:38, Mrk.12:25, Luk.17:27 20:35 (WH, mg, γαμίσκονται; cf. γαμίζω). (AS)
G1549	ἔκγονος	ekgonos	descendant	G:A	<b>ἔκ-γονος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἐκγίγνομαι, to be born of), [in LXX for פְּרִי (neut.), בֵּן, etc;] 1) with genitive, <b>born of</b>. 2) As subst, ὁ, ἡ ἔ, <b>a child, son or daughter</b>; in pl, <b>descendants</b>: τέκνα ἢ ἔ, <b>children or grand-children</b>, 1Ti.5:4. (AS)
G1550	ἐκδαπανάω	ekdapanaō	to expend	G:V	<b>εκ-δαπανάω</b>, -ῶ strengthened form of δαπανάω, <b>to spend wholly</b>; pass, with reflexive force, <b>to spend oneself wholly</b>: before ὑπέρ, 2Co.12:15. (AS)
G1551	ἐκδέχομαι	ekdechomai	to wait for	G:V	<b>ἐκ-δέχομαι </b> [in LXX for עֶרֶב, קָבַץ, etc;] 1) <b>to take</b> or <b>receive from</b> (Hom, Hdt, a1.). 2) (Rare in cl.), <b>to expect, await</b>: with accusative of thing(s), Jhn.5:3, Heb.11:10, Jas.5:7; with accusative of person(s), Act.17:16, 1Co.11:33 16:11; before ἕως, Heb.10:13 (Cremer, 687). (AS)
G1552	ἔκδηλος	ekdēlos	clearly evident	G:A	<b>ἔκ-δηλος</b>, -ον (&lt; δῆλος), [in LXX: 3Ma.3:19 3Mac 6:5 *;] strengthened form of δῆλος, which see, <b>quite clear, evident</b>: 2Ti.3:9. (AS)
G1553	ἐκδημέω	ekdēmeō	be away	G:V	<b>ἐκ-δημέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἔκδημος, <i>from home</i>; cf. -ία, 3Ma.4:11)*; <b>to be from home, absent</b>: 2Co.5:6; before ἀπό, 2Co.5:8; before ἐκ, 2Co.5:9 (cf. ἀπο, ἐνδημέω). (AS)
G1554	ἐκδίδωμι	ekdidōmi	to lease	G:V	<b>ἐκ-δίδωμι </b> [in LXX for נָתַן, etc;] 1) <b>to surrender, give up, give out</b>. 2) <b>to let out for hire</b> (Hdt.); mid. (as freq. in π; see MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xii); <b>to let out to one's advantage</b>, Mat.21:33, 41, Mrk.12:1, Luk.20:9. (AS)
G1555	ἐκδιηγέομαι	ekdiēgeomai	to tell in detail	G:V	<b>ἐκ-δι-ηγέομαι</b>, -οῦμαι depon, [in LXX chiefly for סָפַר, pi;] <b>to tell in detail, relate, declare</b>: Act.13:41 (LXX) Act.15:3. (AS)
G1556	ἐκδικέω	ekdikeō	to avenge	G:V	<b>ἐκδικέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἔκδικος), [in LXX for פָּקַד, נָקַם, שָׁפַט, etc;] 1) <b>to vindicate</b>: with accusative of person(s), Luk.18:3, 5. 2) <b>to avenge</b>: with accusative of person(s), ἑαυτούς, Rom.12:19; with accusative of thing(s), παρακοήν, 2Co.10:6; αἷμα, Rev.6:10 19:2 (Cremer, 203; for exx. from π. in both senses, see MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xii). (AS)
G1557	ἐκδίκησις	ekdikēsis	vengeance	G:N-F	<b>ἐκ-δίκησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἐκδικέω), [in LXX chiefly for נָקָם;] <b>vengeance, vindication</b>: Luk.21:22, Rom.12:19 (see MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xii), Heb.10:30 (LXX), 2Co.7:11; of the injured person, with genitive, Luk.18:7-8; with dative, Act.7:24; of the offender, with genitive obj, 1Pe.2:14; with dative, 2Th.1:8 (cf. Sir.12:6). (AS)
G1558	ἔκδικος	ekdikos	avenging	G:A	<b>ἔκδικος</b>, -ον (&lt; δίκη), [in LXX: Wis.12:12, Sir.30:6, 4Ma.15:29 *;] 1) <b>without law, unjust</b>. 2) <b>exacting penalty from</b>; as subst, <b>an avenger</b>: Rom.13:4; before περί, 1Th.4:6 (in π, <i>a legal representative</i>; Milligan, <i>Th.</i>, l.with). (AS)
G1559	ἐκδιώκω	ekdiōkō	to persecute	G:V	<b>ἐκ-διώκω </b> [in LXX for בָּרַח hi, צָמַת, הָדַף, etc;] <b>to chase away, drive out</b>: 1Th.2:15 (cf. Deu.6:19, Jol.2:20). (AS)
G1560	ἔκδοτος	ekdotos	handed over	G:A	<b>ἔκ-δοτος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἐκδίδωμι), [in LXX: Da TH Bel 1:22 *;] <b>given up, delivered over</b>: Act.2:23 (for construction, see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 111 f.). (AS)
G1561	ἐκδοχή	ekdochē	expectation	G:N-F	<b>ἐκ-δοχή ῆς</b>, ἡ (&lt; ἐκδέχομαι); 1) in cl, (a) <b>a receiving from, succession</b>; (b) <b>an interpretation</b>. 2) In NT, = προσδοκία, <b>expectation</b>: Heb.10:27 (cf. Field, <i>Notes</i>, 231; Cremer, 688). (AS)
G1562	ἐκδύω	ekduō	to strip	G:V	<b>ἐκ-δύω </b> [in LXX chiefly for פָּשַׁט;] <b>to take of, strip of, strip</b>: with accusative of person(s) (sc. clothing), Mat.27:28; with accusative of person(s) and of thing(s), Mat.27:31, Mrk.15:20, Luk.10:30; mid, <b>to put off</b>: figuratively, of the body, 2Co.5:4. (AS)
G1563	ἐκεῖ	ekei	there	G:Adv	<b>ἐκεῖ </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX chiefly for שָׁם;] 1) properly, of place, <b>there</b>: Mat.2:13 5:24, al; οἱ ἐ, Mat.26:71; οὗ. ἐ, Mat.6:21 18:20 24:28, Mrk.6:10, Luk.12:34; pleonastic, ὅπου. ἐ. (= שָׁם אֲשֶׁר, Deu.4:5, al.), Rev.12:6, 14 (cf. Bl, § 50, 4). 2) As often in cl. (Hdt, Thuc, al.), with verbs of motion, for ἐκεῖσε, <b>thither</b>: Mat.2:22 17:20 24:28 26:36, Mrk.6:33, Luk.12:18 17:37 21:2, Jhn.11:8 18:2-3, Rom.15:24 (AS)
G1564	ἐκεῖθεν	ekeithen	from there	G:Adv	<b>ἐκεῖθεν </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX chiefly for שָׁם;] 1) of place, <b>thence</b>: Mat.4:21, Mrk.6:1, al. 2) Of time, <b>thereafter</b> (see: κἀκεῖθεν). (AS)
G1565	ἐκεῖνος	ekeinos	that	G:DemP	<b>ἐκεῖνος</b>, -η, -ο (&lt; ἐκεῖ), [in LXX chiefly for הַהוּא,הוּא, and cogn. forms;] <i>demonstr. pron.</i>, <b>that</b> person or thing (<i>ille</i>), implying remoteness as compared with οὗτος (<i>hic</i>); 1) absol, emphatic <b>he, she, it</b>: opp. to οὗτος, Luk.18:14, Jas.4:15; ἡμεῖς, Heb.12:25; ὑμεῖς, Mrk.4:11; ἄλλοι, Jhn.9:9; ἐγώ, Jhn.3:30; to persons named, Mk 16:[10, 13, 20], Jhn.2:21; of one (absent) who is not named, contemptuously (Abbott, <i>JG</i>, §§2385, 2732), Jhn.7:11 9:28; with respect, of Christ, 1Jo.2:6 3:3, al; referring to a preceding noun, Mrk.16:[10], Jhn.7:45; resumption of a participial subject, Jhn.1:33 9:37 10:1, Rom.14:14, al. (on its reference in Jhn.19:35, see Westc, in l; Moffatt, <i>Intr.</i>, 568; Sanday, <i>Fourth Gospel</i>, 77ff.). 2) As <i>adj.</i>, joined, like οὗτος, to a noun with the article: Mat.7:25, Mrk.3:24, Jhn.18:15, al; esp. of time, past or future: ἐν τ. ἡμέραις ἐ, Mat.3:1, Mrk.1:9, Act.2:18 " (LXX), al; ἐν ἐ. τ. ἡμέρᾳ, esp of the Parousia, Mat.7:22, Luk.6:23, 2Th.1:10, 2Ti.1:12; adverbially, ἐκεινής (sc. ὁδοῦ) = cl. ἐκεινῇ (Bl, §36, 13), <b>that way</b>, Luk.19:4. (AS)
G1566	ἐκεῖσε	ekeise	there	G:Adv	<b>ἐκεῖσε </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX: Job.39:29 שָׁם *;] <b>thither</b>: Act.21:3; constr. pregn. (MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xii; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 134), τοὺς ἐ. ὄντας, Act.22:5. (AS)
G1567	ἐκζητέω	ekzēteō	to seek out	G:V	<b>ἐκ-ζητέω, -ῶ</b> [in LXX chiefly for דָּרַשׁ, also for נָצַר, בָּקַשׁ, etc;] 1) <b>to seek out </b>or <b>after, search for</b>: with accusative of person(s) (1Ma.9:26); figuratively, τ. κύριον, θεόν (cf. Psa.14:2, Amo.5:4, al.), Act.15:17, Rom.3:11, Heb.11:6; εὐλογίαν, Heb.12:17; ἐξεζήτησαν κ. ἐξηραύνησαν (as in 1Ma.9:26), <b>sought and searched out</b>: 1Pe.1:10. 2) As in 2Ki.4:11, Eze.3:18, 20 al. (דָּרַשׁ), <b>to demand, require</b>: Luk.11:50-51 (AS)
G1568	ἐκθαμβέω	ekthambeō	be awe-struck	G:V	<b>ἐκ-θαμβέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἔκθαμβος), [in LXX: Sir.30:9 *;] 1) <b>to be amazed</b>. 2) <b>to amaze, terrify</b> (Sir.30:9). Pass, <b>to be amazed, terrified</b>: Mrk.9:15 14:33 16:5-6. (AS)
G1569	ἔκθαμβος	ekthambos	astonished	G:A	<b>ἔκ-θαμβος</b>, -ον (&lt; θάμβος), [in LXX: Wis.10:19, Da TH Dan.7:7 (<b>dreadful, terrible</b>: אֵמְתָּנִי) *;] <b>amazed</b> (cf. Polyb, xx, 10, 9): Act.3:11. (AS)
G1570	ἔκθετος	ekthetos	exposed	G:A	<b>ἔκ-θετος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἐκτίθημι), [in Al: Eze.42:3 *;] <b>cast out</b>: ποιεῖν ἔ. = ἐκτιθέναι, Act.7:19. (AS)
G1571	ἐκκαθαίρω	ekkathairō	to cleanse	G:V	<b>ἐκ-καθαίρω </b> [in LXX for בָּעַר, etc;] 1) <b>to cleanse thoroughly, cleanse out</b>: with accusative, ἑαυτόν, 2Ti.2:21; of the impurity removed, ζυμήν, 1Co.5:7. (AS)
G1572	ἐκκαίω	ekkaiō	be enflamed	G:V	<b>ἐκ-καίω </b> [in LXX chiefly for בָּעַר;] 1) <b>to burn up</b>. 2) <b>to kindle</b>. Pass, <b>to burn</b>: metaph, of the passions (cf. Sir.16:6, Job.3:17), Rom.1:27. (AS)
G1573	ἐκκακέω	ekkakeō	to lose heart	G:V	<b>ἐκκακέω, -ῶ</b>, see: ἐνκακέω. <b>ἐν-κακέω</b>, -ῶ (LTr, ἐγκ; Rec. ἐκκ; cf. WH, Notes, 157 f; &lt; κακός, cowardly), [in Sm: Gen.27:46, Num.21:5, Pro.3:11, Isa.7:16 *;] <b>to lose heart </b>: Luk.18:1, 2Co.4:1,16, Gal.6:9, Eph.3:13, 2Th.3:13 (Cremer, 330). (AS)
G1574	ἐκκεντέω	ekkenteō	to pierce	G:V	<b>ἐκ-κεντέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX chiefly for דָּקַר;] 1) <b>to prick out, put out</b> (Arist.). 2) <b>to pierce</b> (Polyb, LXX): with accusative of person(s), Jhn.19:37 (LXX), Rev.1:7. (AS)

G1577	ἐκκλησία	ekklēsia	assembly	G:N-F	<b>ἐκκλησία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἐκ-καλέω), [in LXX chiefly for קָהָל, otherwise for one of its cogn. forms;] 1) prop, <b>an assembly</b> of citizens regularly convened (in Thuc, ii, 22, opp. to σύλλογος, <i>a concourse</i>): Act.19:32, 39 41. 2) In LXX of <b>the assembly, congregation, community</b> of Israel (Deu.4:10 23:2, al.): Act.7:38, Heb.2:12 " (LXX). 3) NT, esp. of an assembly or company of Christians, a <b>(the) church</b>; (a) <b>of gatherings for worship</b>: 1Co.11:18 14:19, 34 35; (b) <b>of local communities</b>: Act.8:3, 1Co.4:17; with name added, Act.8:1, Rom.16:1, 1Th.1:1, al; pl, Act.15:41, 1Co.7:17; τ. Χριστοῦ, Rom.16:16; τ. Ἀσίας, 1Co.16:19; τ. ἁγίων, 1Co.14:33; εἰπο]ν τ. ἐκκλησίᾳ, Mat.18:17 (but see Hort, <i>Ecclesia</i>, 10); of a house-congregation (<i>DB</i>, i, 431a), Rom.16:5, 1Co.16:19, Col.4:15, Phm 2; (with) <b>of the whole body of Christians</b>: Mat.16:18, 1Co.12:28, Eph.1:22, Php.3:6, al; τ. θεοῦ, Act.20:28 (Κυρίου, T, R, mg.), 1Co.15:9, Gal.1:13, 1Ti.3:15; ἐ. προτοτόκων ἀπογεγραμμένων ἐν οὐρανοῖς, Heb.12:23. G1588	ἐκλεκτός	eklektos	select	G:A	<b>ἐκ-λεκτός, -ή, -όν</b> (&lt; ἐκλέγω), [in LXX for בָּחַר (so prob. in Isa.28:16, Pro.17:3, for MT בָּחַן), בָּרִיא, etc;] 1) <b>choice, select</b> (cl, rarely; Thuc, Plat, al.), hence, <b>eminent</b>: Rom.16:13 (cf. G1622	ἐκτός	ektos	outside/except	G:Prep	1. <b>outside </b>, opp. to ἐντός: 2. as <i>preposition</i> with <i>genitive</i> <b>outside, out of, far from </b>, with <i>genitive</i>, (Homer): <b>outside of, free from </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), attic; ἐκτὸς ἐλπίδος <b>beyond </b> hope, Lat. <i>praeter spem</i>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 3. of Time, <b>beyond </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 4. <b>except </b>, ἐκτὸς ὀλίγων (Xenophon Historicus) 5. <i>absolute</i>, τὰ ἐκτός <b>external things </b>, (Euripides) 6. with Verbs of motion, ῥίπτειν ἐκτός to throw <b>out </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. (ML)
G1623	ἕκτος	hektos	sixth	G:A	<b>ἐκτός</b>, <i> adv.</i> [in LXX Jdg.8:26 20:15, 3Ki.10:13, al. (בַּד, Jdg.5:28 (בַּד), בַּד), Sng.4:1-3 (בַּד), al;] 1) as adv, <b>outside, beyond</b>: τὸ ἐ, with poss. genitive, the outside, Mat.23:26; in late Gk. (see Deiss, BS, 118), pleonastic, ἐκτός εἰ μή, 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 2) With force of prep, with genitive; (a) <b>outside of</b>: 1Co.6:18, 2Co.12:2; (b) <b>beyond, besides, except</b>: Act.26:22, 1Co.15:27. (AS)
G1624	ἐκτρέπω	ektrepō	to turn/wander away	G:V	<b>ἐκ-τρέπω </b> [in LXX for הָפַךְ, Amo.5:8 *;] to turn out of the course, turn aside, with accusative Pass, with middle sense, intrans, <b>to turn aside</b>: Heb.12:13 (R, txt, for be put out of joint, R, mg, see Thayer, see word Westc, in l); figuratively, before εἰς, 1Ti.1:6; ἐπί, 2Ti.4:4; ὀπίσω, 1Ti.5:15; with accusative, <b>to shun, avoid</b>: 1Ti.6:20. G1670	ἕλκω	helkuō, helkō	to draw/persuade	G:V	<b>ἕλκω </b> (Hellenistic form ἑλκύω in Jhn.11:1-57. with, Act.16:19), [in LXX for מָשַׁךְ, etc;] <b>to draw</b>: with accusative of thing(s), Jhn.18:10 21:6; with accusative of person(s), before ἔξω, Act.21:30; εἰς, Act.16:19, Jas.2:6. G1671	Ἑλλάς	Hellas	Greece	N:N-F-L	<b>Ἑλλάς</b>, -άδος, ἡ [in LXX: Isa.66:19, Eze.27:13 (יָוָן), 1Ma.1:1 1Mac 8:9 *;] with varying usage as to geographical limits; in NT = 'Αχαία (cf. Act.18:12), <b>Greece</b>: Act.20:2. (AS)
G1672	Ἕλλην	Hellēn	a Greek	N:N--LG	<b>Ἕλλην</b>, -ηνος, ὁ [in LXX: Jol.3:6, Zec.9:13 (יָוָן), etc; 1Ma.1:19, al. *;] <b>a Greek</b>; opp. to βάρβαρος, Rom.1:14; usually in ΝΤ of Greek Gentiles, opp. to Ἰουδαῖοι: Jhn.7:35, Act.11:29 14:1 16:1, 3 18:4 19:19, 17 20:21 21:28 Rom.1:16 2:9-10 3:9 10:12, 1Co.1:22 1:24 10:32 12:13, Gal.2:3 3:28, Col.3:11; of proselytes, Jhn.12:29, Act.17:4. G1679	ἐλπίζω	elpizō	to hope/expect	G:V	<b>ἐλπίζω </b> [in LXX chiefly for בָּטַח, also for חָסָה, יָחַל pi, hi, etc;] <b>to look for, expect, hope </b>(for): with accusative of thing(s), Rom.8:24-25, 1Co.13:7, Heb.11:1; with dative of thing(s) (τ. τύχῃ, Thuc, iii, 97, 2), Mat.12:21; before καθώς, 2Co.8:5; with inf, Luk.6:34 23:8, Act.26:7, Rom.15:24, 1Co.16:7, 2Co.5:11, Php.2:19, 23, 1Ti.3:14, II Jn 12, 3Jn.14; before ὅτι, with pres, Luk.24:21; with fut, Act.24:26, 2Co.1:13 13:6, Phm 22. (AS)
G1680	ἐλπίς	elpis	hope	G:N-F	<b>ἐλπίς </b> (ἑλ, Rom.8:20, WH, see Bl, § 4, 3; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 44), -ίδος, ἡ [in LXX for בָּטַח and its derivatives, תִּקְוָה (freq. in Jb), etc;] expectation (in cl, rarely of evil, mostly of good, and so always in NT), hope; 1) <b>of hope in general</b>: 2Co.1:6; with genitive obj, Act.16:19; art. inf, Act.27:20, 1Co.9:10; παρ᾽ ἐλπίδα, Rom.4:18; ἐπ᾽ ἐλπίδι, 1Co.9:10. 2) <b>Of religious hope</b>: ἐπ᾽ ἐλπίδι, Act.2:26 26:6, Rom.4:18 8:20, Tit.1:2; τῇ ἐ. ἐσώθημεν, Rom.8:24; κατ᾽ ἐλπίδα ζωῆς αἰωνίου, Tit.3:7; of the Messianic hope of Israel, Act.23:6 26:6-7 28:20; of Christian hope, Rom.5:2-5 12:12 15:4, 13, 1Co.13:13, 2Th.2:16, Heb.3:6 6:11 7:19 10:23, 1Pe.1:3 1:21 3:15; with genitive obj, Rom.5:2, Col.1:27, 1Th.1:3 5:8, Tit.1:2; with genitive of that on which the hope is based, Act.26:6, Eph.1:18 4:4, Col.1:23; ὁ θεὸς τῆς ἐ, Rom.15:13; ἔχειν ἐ. (= cl. ἐλπίζειν), Act.24:15, Rom.15:4, 2Co.3:12 10:15, Eph.2:12, 1Th.4:13; before ἐπί, with dative, 1Jn.3:3; εἰς, Act.24:15; ὅτι, Rom.8:20, Php.1:20-21. Meton, (a) <b>of the author or ground of hope </b>(cl.): 1Th.2:19, 1Ti.1:1; with genitive obj, Col.1:27; (b) <b>of the thing hoped for</b>: Gal.5:5, Col.1:5, Tit.2:13, Heb.6:18 (Cremer, 252, 712). G1687	ἐμβατεύω	embateuō	to investigate	G:V	<b>ἐμβατεύω </b> [in LXX: with accusative, Jos.19:49 (נָחַל, Jos.19:51 (חָלַק pi.); before εἰς, 1Ma.12:25 1Mac 13:20 1Mac 14:31 1Mac 15:40; metaph, 2Ma.2:30 *;] (&lt; ἐμβάτης &lt; ἐμβαίνω) 1) to step in or on (Soph.), hence (a) <b>to frequent, haunt, dwell in </b>(Æsch, Eur.); metaph, Col.2:18 (dwelling in, R, txt; taking, R, mg.); (b) to invade (1Mac, ll with; metaph, Col, Lc.). 2) <b>to enter on, come into possession of </b>(Eur, Dem; LXX, Jos, H. with); on the difficulties of reading and interpretation in this passage, see Lft, Col, 194 f, 252; <i>ICC</i>, 268 ff; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 197; Milligan, <i>NTD</i>, 177; and for exx. from π, MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xii (cf. κενεμβ.).
