G1690	ἐμβριμάομαι	embrimaomai	be agitated	G:V	<b>ἐμ-βριμάομαι</b> (T, -έομαι; Bl, § 22, 1), -ῶμαι (&lt; βρίμη, strength, bulk, whence βριμάομαι, to snort with anger), depon, with aor. mid. and pass, [in LXX (Hatch, <i>Essays</i>, 25): Dan LXX 11:30 (also Aq, Psa.7:12; Sm, Isa.17:13) *;] to snort in (of horses, Æsch.), hence, to speak or act with deep feeling (<i>DCG</i>, i, 62b); (a) to be moved with anger (cf. ἐμβρίμημα, La 2:6): with dative, Mrk.14:5, Jhn.11:33; ἐν ἑαυτῷ, Jhn.11:38; (b) <b>to admonish sternly</b>: with dative, Mat.9:30, Mrk.1:43. (AS)
G1691	ἐμέ	eme	me	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)
G1692	ἐμέω	emeō	to vomit	G:V	<b>ἐμέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: Isa.19:14 (קֵא)*;] <b>to vomit</b>: figuratively, Rev.3:16. (AS)
G1693	ἐμμαίνομαι	emmainomai	be enraged	G:V	<b>ἐμ-μαίνομαι </b> depon, <b>to rage against</b>: with dative, Act.26:11. (AS)

Deiss, BS, 248; MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xii): Gal.3:10 (LXX). (AS)

G1698	ἐμοί	emoi	I	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. G1699	ἐμός	emos	mine	G:PosP	<b>ἐμός</b>, -ή, -όν poss. prop. of first of person(s), representing the em­phasized genitive ἐμοῦ, mine, subjectively and objectively, i.e. belonging to, <b>proceeding from or related to me</b>: Mat.18:20, Mrk.8:38, Jhn.3:29 (most freq. in this gospel), al; absol, τὸ ἐμόν, τὰ ἐμά, Mat.20:15 25:27, Luk.15:31, Jhn.10:14 16:14-15 17:10; = genitive obj. (cl.), εἰς τ. ἐμὴν ἀvάμνησιν, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24-25; with genitive expl, τ. ἐμῇ χειρὶ Παύλου, 1Co.16:21, Col.4:18, 2Th.3:17 (AS)
G1700	ἐμοῦ	emou	of me	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)

G1705	ἐμπίμπλημι	empimplēmi	to fill up	G:V	<b>ἐμ-πίπλημι</b> (on ἐμπίμπ, see LS, see word, Bl, § 6, 8), and ἐμπιπλάω (Act.14:17), [in LXX chiefly for מָלֵא, שָׂבַע;] <b>to fill full, fill up, satisfy</b>: with accusative of person(s) and genitive of thing(s), Luk.1:53, Act.14:17; pass, Luk.6:25, Jhn.6:12; metaph, with genitive of person(s), <b>to take one's fill of</b>: Rom.15:24 (cf. Dan LXX Su 32). (AS)
G1706	ἐμπίπτω	empiptō	to fall into	G:V	<b>ἐμ-πίπτω </b> [in LXX chiefly for נָפַל;] <b>to fall into</b>: before εἰς, Mat.12:11, Luk.6:39 10:36; metaph, εἰς κρίμα, 1Ti.3:6; ὀνειδισμόν 1Ti.3:7; πειρασμόν, 1Ti.6:9; εἰς χεῖρας θεοῦ (cf. 2Ki.24:14, 1Ch.21:13, Sir.2:18), Heb.10:31. (AS)
G1707	ἐμπλέκω	emplekō	to entangle/involve	G:V	<b>ἐμ-πλέκω </b> [in LXX: Pro.28:18 (נָפַל), 2Ma.15:17 *;] <b>to weave in, entwine</b>; pass, metaph, <b>to be involved, entangled in</b>: 2Ti.2:4, 2Pe.2:20. (AS)

G1709	ἐμπνέω	empneō	to breath into	G:V	<b>ἐν-πνέω</b>, -ῶ (Rec. ἐμπ, see: ἐν) [in LXX: Deu.20:16, Jos.10:28 ff. Jos.11:11, 14 (ptcp. neut, for נֶפֶשׁ, נְשָׁמָה), Wis.15:11 *;] 1) to breathe on. 2) <b>to breathe</b>; (a) absol; (b) with genitive part: figuratively, ἀπειλῆς κ. φόνου, Act.9:1. (AS)
G1710	ἐμπορεύομαι	emporeuomai	to traffic in	G:V	<b>ἐμ-πορεύομαι </b> depon. (&lt; ἔμπορος), [in LXX chiefly for סָחַר;] 1) to travel, esp. for business. 2) <b>to traffc, trade</b>: Jas.4:13. 3) C. accusative of thing(s) (a) <b>to traffic in</b>; (b) <b>to import</b>: (Hos.12:1, for יָבַל hoph.). 4) C. accusative of person(s), <b>to make a gain of</b>: 2Pe.2:3. (AS)
G1711	ἐμπορία	emporia	trade/business	G:N-F	<b>ἐμπορία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἔμπορος), [in LXX for סָחַר, רָכַל etc;] <b>commerce, business, trade</b>: Mat.22:5. (AS)
G1712	ἐμπόριον	emporion	marketplace/trade	G:N-N	<b>ἐμπόριον</b>, -ον, τό (ἔμπορος) [in LXX: Deu.33:19 (סָפַן), Eze.27:3 (רָכַל); ἐ. εἶναι, Isa.23:17 (זָנָה)*;] <b>a trading place, exchange</b>: οἶκος ἐμπορίου, Jhn.2:16. (AS)
G1713	ἔμπορος	emporos	trader/merchant	G:N-M	<b>ἔμ-πορος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; πόρος, a journey), [in LXX chiefly for סָחַר, רָכַל;] 1) a passenger on shipboard, one on a journey. 2) <b>a merchant</b>: Mat.13:45, Rev.18:3, 11 18:15, 23. (AS)
G1714	ἐμπρήθω	emprēthō	to burn	G:V	<b>ἐμ-πίπρημι</b>, ἐμπρήθω (for the form, see: ἐμπίπλημι, and cf. Veitch, see word πίμπρημι), [in LXX chiefly for שָׂרַף;] <b>to set on fire</b>: πόλιν, Mat.22:7; pass, of the body, <b>to become inflamed</b>: Act.28:6 (T; πίμπρημι WH, which see). (AS)
G1715	ἔμπροσθεν	emprosthen	before	G:Prep	<b>ἔμ-προσθεν </b> <i>adv.</i> of place (in cl. also of time), [in LXX chiefly for עֳנִי;] 1) <b>adverbially, before, in front</b>: Luk.19:28; εἰς τὸ ἔ, Luk.19:4; opp. to ὄπισθεν, Rev.4:6; opp. to τὰ ὀπίσω, τὰ ἔ, Php.3:13. 2) As prep, before; (a) <b>in front of</b>: Mat.5:24 6:2 7:6 11:10 27:29, Luk.5:19 7:27 14:2, Jhn.3:28 10:4, Rev.19:10 22:8; (b) <b>in the presence of</b>: Mat.27:11, Gal.2:14, 1Th.1:3 2:19 3:9 3:13; ὁμολουεῖν, ἀρνεῖσθαι (Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 210), Mat.10:32, 36 26:70, Luk.12:8; in forensic sense, Mat.25:32 27:11, Luk.21:36, Act.18:17, 2Co.5:10, 1Th.2:19, I Jn 3:19; εὐδοκία (θέλημά) ἐστι ἔ. θεοῦ (a targumic formula; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 211), Mat.11:26 18:14, Luk.10:21; (with) <b>in the sight of</b>: Mat.5:16 6:1 17:2 23:14, Mrk.2:12 9:2, Luk.19:27, Jhn.12:37, Act.10:4; (d) of rank and dignity (Dem, Plat, al; LXX, Gen.48:20): Jhn.1:15, 30. (AS)
G1716	ἐμπτύω	emptuō	to spit on/at	G:V	<b>ἐμ-πτύω </b> [in LXX: before εἰς, Num.12:14 A, Deu.25:9 (יָרָק)*;] = cl, καταπτύω (Ruth, <i>NPhr.</i>, 66), <b>to spit upon</b>: with dative, Mrk.10:34 14:65 15:19; before εἰς, Mat.26:67 27:30. Pass, Luk.18:32. (AS)
G1717	ἐμφανής	emphanēs	revealed	G:A	<b>ἐμφανής</b>, -ές (&lt; ἐμφαίνω, to show in, exhibit), [in LXX: Mic.4:1, Isa.2:2 (כּוּן ni.), Wis.6:22 7:21 14:17; ἐ. γίνεσθαι, Exo.2:14 (יָדַע ni.), Isa.65:1 (דָּרַשׁ ni.)*;] <b>manifest</b>: Act.10:40; metaph, Rom.10:20 (LXX) (see: ἐπιφανής). (AS)
G1718	ἐμφανίζω	emphanizō	to show	G:V	<b>ἐμφανίζω </b> [in LXX for יָדַע hi, etc;] 1) <b>to manifest, exhibit</b>: ἐαυτόν, with dative of person(s), Jhn.14:21-22 (<i>DCG</i>, ii, 112b). (AS)

G1720	ἐμφυσάω	emphusaō	to breathe into	G:V	<b>ἐμ-φυσάω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; φυσάω, to blow), [in LXX for נָפַח, etc;] to breathe into (cf. Gen.2:7, Wis.15:11, a1.), <b>breathe upon</b>: Jhn.20:22. (AS)
G1721	ἔμφυτος	emphutos	implanted/ingrafted	G:A	<b>ἔμ-φυτος</b>, -ον (&lt; ἐμφύω, to implant), [in LXX: ἔ. ἡ κακία αὐτῶν, Wis.12:10 *;] 1) innate (Wis.12:10). 2) <b>rooted, implanted</b>: Jas.1:21 (see Mayor, in l). (AS)
G1722	ἐν	en	in/on/among	G:Prep	<b>ἐν</b>, <i>prep</i>, (the most freq. of all in NT), with dative (= Heb. בְּ, Lat. in, with <i>abl.). </i> I. Of place, with dative of thing(s), of person(s), <b>in, within, on, at, by, among</b>: ἐν τ. πόλει, Luk.7:37; τ. οφθαλμῷ, Mat.7:3; τ. κοιλίᾳ, Mat.12:40; τ. ὄρει, 2Pe.1:18; τ. θρόνῳ, Rev.3:21; τ. δεξιᾷ τ. θεοῦ, Rom.8:34; ἐν ἡμῖν Abbott-Smith has ὑμῖν, Luk.1:1; of books, ἐν τ. βιβλίῳ, Gal.3:10; τ. νόμῳ, Mat.12:5, al; ἐν τοῖς τ. Πατρός, <b>in my Father's house</b> (RV; cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 103), Luk.2:49; trop, of the region of thought or feeling, ἐν τ. καρδίᾳ (-αις), Mat.5:28, 2Co.4:6, al; τ. συνειδήσεσιν, 2Co.5:11; after verbs of motion, instead of εἰς (constructio praegnans, a usage extended in late Gk. beyond the limits observed in cl; cf. Bl, §41, 1; M, <i>Th.</i>, 12), ἀποστέλλω. ἐν, Mat.10:16. δέδωκεν ἐν τ. χειρί (cf. τιθέναι ἐν χερσί, Hom, <i>Il.</i>, i, 441, al.), Jhn.3:35; id. after verbs of coming and going (not in cl.), εἰσῆλθε, Luk.9:46; ἐξῆλθεν, Luk.7:17. II. Of state, condition, form, occupation, etc: ἐν ζωῇ, Rom.5:10; ἐν τ. θανάτῳ, 1Jn.3:14; ἐν πειρασμοῖς, 1Pe.1:6; ἐν εἰρήνῃ, Mrk.5:25; ἐν δόξῃ, Php.4:19; ἐν πραΰτητι, Jas.3:13; ἐν μυστηρίῳ, 1Co.2:7; ἐν τ. διδαχῇ, Mrk.4:2; of a part as contained in a whole, ἐν τ. ἀμπέλῳ, Jhn.15:4; ἐν ἑνὶ σώματι, Rom.12:4; of accompanying objects or persons (simple dative in cl.), <b>with</b>, ἐν αἵματι, Heb.9:25; ἐν δέκα χιλιάσιν, Luk.14:31 (cf. Ju 14, Act.7:14); similarly (cl.), of clothing, armour, arms, ἐν στολαῖς, Mrk.12:38; ἐν ἐσθῆτι λαμπρᾷ, Jas.2:2; ἐν μαξαίρῃ, Luk.22:49; ἐν ῥάβδῳ, 1Co.4:21 (cf. ἐν τόξοις, Xen, <i>Mem.</i>, 3, 9, 2); of manner (cl.), ἐν τάχει (= ταχέως), Luk.18:8 (cf. Bl, §41, 1); of spiritual influence, ἐν πνεύματι, Rom.8:9; ἐν π. ἀκαθάρτῳ, Mrk.1:23; of the mystical relation of the Christian life and the believer himself, <b>to God and Christ </b>(cf. <i>ICC</i>, <i>Ro.</i>, 160f; Mayor on Ju 1; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 103): ἐν Χριστῷ, Rom.3:24, 6:11, 1Co.3:1, 4:10, 2Co.12:2, Gal.2:17, Eph.6:21, Col.4:7, 1Th.4:16, al. III. Of the agent, instrument or means (an extension of cl. ἐν of instr.—see LS, see word Ill—corresponding to similar use of Heb. בְּ), <b>by, with</b>: ἐν ὑμῖν κρίνεται ὁ κόσμος (= cl. παρά, C. dative), 1Co.6:2; ἐν τ. ἄρχοντι τ. δαιμονίων, Mat.9:34; ἐν αἵματι, Heb.9:22; ἐν ὕδατι, Mat.3:11, al; ἐν μαχαίρᾳ ἀποκτενεῖ (cf. the absol. ἐν μ, ἐν ῥάβδῳ, supr, II, which some would classify here), Rev.13:10 (cf. 6:8). Allied to this usage and distinctly Semitic are the following: ἠγόρασας. ἐν τ. αἵματι σου (cf. <i>BDB</i>, see word בְּ, III, 3), Rev.5:9; ὁμολογεῖν ἐν (= Aram. אודי בּ; cf. McNeile on Mt, I.with; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 104), Mat.10:32, Luk.12:8; ὀμνύναι ἐν (= cl. accusative, so Jas.5:12), Mat.5:34, al; also <b>at the rate of, amounting to</b>, Mrk.4:8 (WH; vv. ll, εἰς, ἒν), Act.7:14 (LXX). IV. Of time, (a) <b>in</b> or <b>during</b> a period: ἐν τ. ἡμέρᾳ (νυκτί), Jhn.11:9, al; ἐν σαββάτῳ, Mat.12:2, al; ἐν τῷ μεταξύ, <b>meanwhile</b>, Jhn.4:31; (b) <b>at the time of an event</b>: ἐν τ. παρουσίᾳ, 1Co.15:23; ἐν τ. ἀναστάσει, Mat.22:28; (with) with art. inf, (α) pres. (so sometimes in cl, but not as in NT = ἕως; V. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 215), <b>while</b>: Mat.13:4, Mrk.6:48, Gal.4:18, al; (β) aor, <b>when, after</b>: Luk.9:36, al; (d) <b>within</b> (cl.): Mat.27:40, V. <b>In composition</b>: (1) meaning: (a) with adjectives, it signifies usually the possession of a quality, as ἐνάλιος, ἐν́δοξος; (b) with verbs, continuance in (before ἐν) or motion into (before εἰς), as ἐμμένω, ἐμβαίνω. (ii) Assimilation: ἐν becomes ἐμ- before β, μ, π, φ, ψ; ἐγ- before γ, κ, ξ, χ; ἐλ- before λ. But in the older MSS of NT, followed by modern editions, assimilation is sometimes neglected, as in ἐνγράφω, ἐγκαινίζω, etc. (AS)

G1736	ἐνδημέω	endēmeō	be home	G:V	<b>ἐνδημέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ἔνδημος, living in a place), <b>to live in a place, be at home</b>: ἐν τ. σώματι, 2Co.5:6 5:9; πρὸς τ. Kύριον, 2Co.5:8. (AS)

G1743	ἐνδυναμόω	endunamoō	to strengthen	G:V	<b>ἐν-δυναμόω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: Jdg.6:34, 1Ch.12:18 A (לָבַשׁ), Psa.52:7 (עָזַז)*;] <b>to make strong, strengthen</b>: with accusative, of person(s), Php.4:13, 1Ti.1:12, 2Ti.4:17. G1787	ἐντός	entos	inside	G:Prep	<b>ἐντός</b> (&lt; ἐν), <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX: Job.18:20, Psa.39:3 109:22, Sng.3:10; ὁ, τὸ, τὰ ἐ, Psa.103:1, Isa.16:11, Da TH Dan.10:16, Sir.19:26, 1Ma.4:48 *;] <b>within</b>: with genitive, ἐ. ὑμῶν, within you (i.e. in your hearts, R, txt.), or among you (R, mg.), Luk.17:21 (cf. Field, <i>Notes</i>, 71; Thayer, see word; <i>ICC</i>, Lk, l.with; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 145 ff.); τὸ ἐ, Mat.23:26. (AS)

G1793	ἐντυγχάνω	entugchanō	to call on	G:V	<b>ἐν-τυγχάνω </b> [in LXX: Da TH Dan.6:12-13 (קֶרֶב) Wis.8:20 16:28, 2Ma.2:25 2Mac 4:36 2Mac 6:12 2Mac 15:39, 3Ma.6:37; before κατά, 1Ma.8:32 1Mac 10:61-64 1Mac 11:25 *;] 1) to fall in with. 2) to meet with in order to converse. 3) <b>to petition, make petition</b>: with dative of person(s), before ὑπέρ with genitive of person(s), Act.25:24 (cf. G1908	ἐπηρεάζω	epēreazō	to mistreat	G:V	<b>ἐπηρεάζω</b> (&lt; ἐπήρεια, spiteful abuse), <b>to revile</b>: with accusative of person(s), Luk.6:28; with accusative of thing(s) (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l), 1Pe.3:16. (AS)
G1909	ἐπί	epi	upon/to/against	G:Prep	<b>ἐπί</b> (before a smooth breathing ἐπ᾽, before a rough breathing ἐφ᾽), <i>prep.</i> with genitive, dative, accusative (accusative most freq. in NT), with primary sense of superposition, <b>on, upon</b>. I. C. genitive, 1) of place, answering the question, where? (a) of the place on which, <b>on, upon</b>: ἐπὶ (τ.) γῆς, Mat.6:10, 19, al; τ. κεφαλῆς, 1Co.11:10; τ. νεφελῶν, Mat.24:3 o, al; like ἐν, in constr. praegn. after verbs of motion: βάλλειν, Mrk.4:26; σπείρειν, ib. 31; ἔρχεσθαι, Heb.6:7, al; figuratively, ἐπ᾽ ἀληθείας (MM, see word ἀ.); of the subject of thought or speech, Gal.3:16; of power or authority, <b>over</b>, πάντων, Rom.9:5: τ. γάζης, Act.8:27; ἐξουσία, Rev.2:26 20:6; (b) of vicinity, <b>at, by</b>: τ. θαλάσσης, Jhn.6:9; τ. ὁδοῦ, Mat.21:19; τοῦ βάτου, Mrk.12:26 (see Swete, in l.); with genitive of person(s), <b>in the presence of, before</b>, Mat.28:14, Act.23:30, 1Co.6:1, al. 2) Of time, (a) with genitive of person(s), <b>in the time of</b>: ἐπὶ Ἐλισαίου, Luk.4:27; ἐπὶ Κλαυδίου, Act.11:28; ἐπὶ Ἀβιάθαρ ἀρχιερέως, <b>when A. was high priest</b>, Mrk.2:26; (b) with genitive of thing(s), <b>at, at the time of</b>: Mat.1:11, Heb.1:2, 2Pe.3:3; ἐπὶ τ. προσευχῶν, Rom.1:10, Eph.1:16, 1Th.1:2, Phm 4. II. C. dative, of place, answering the question, where? (a) lit, <b>on, upon</b>: Mat.9:16, 14:8, al; after verbs of motion (see supr, I, 1, (<i>a</i>)), Mat.9:16 Act.8:16; <b>above</b>, Luk.23:38; <b>at, by</b>, Mrk.13:29, Jhn.5:2, Act.5:9, al; (b) metaph, <b>upon, on the ground of</b>, Luk.4:4 (LXX); <b>in the matter of</b>, Mrk.6:52 (see Swete, in l.); <b>upon, of, concerning</b>, Act.5:35, 40; of the ground, reason or motive (Bl, §38, 2; 43, 3), Mat.18:3 19:9, Rom.12:12, al; ἐφ᾽ ᾧ, <b>for the reason that, because</b>, Rom.5:12 2Co.5:4; after verbs of motion, <b>over</b>, Mat.18:13, Rom.16:19, al; of a condition (cl.), Rom.8:20, 1Co.9:10; ἐπὶ δυσὶ μάρτυσιν (see Westc. on Heb.9:10), Heb.10:28; of purpose or aim, Eph.2:10, Php.4:10; of authority, <b>over</b>, Mat.24:47 Luk.12:44; of hostility, with dative of person(s) (cl.), <b>against</b>, Luk.12:52; <b>in addition to</b> (cl.), 2Co.7:13; of an adjunct, <b>in, at, on</b>, Php.1:3 2:17. III. C. accusative, 1) of place of motion upon or over, answering the question, whither? (a) lit, <b>upon, over</b>: Mat.14:28, 29, Luk.5:19, al. mult; in NT also, answering the question, where? (as with genitive, dative), Mrk.4:38 11:2, Luk.2:25, Jhn.1:32; ἐπὶ τ. αὐτό, Act.1:15 2:1, al; of motion to a vicinity, <b>to</b>, Mrk.16:2, Act.8:36, al; (b) metaph. (in wh. "the accusative is more widely prevalent than it strictly should be," Bl, §43, 1); of blessings, evils, etc, coming upon one, with accusative of person(s), Mat.10:13 12:28, Act.2:17, Jhn.18:4, Eph.5:6, al; of addition (dative in cl.), λύπη ἐπὶ λύπην, Php.2:27; ἐπικαλεῖν ὄνομα ἐπί (see: ἐπικαλέω), Act.15:17, Jas.2:7; καλεῖν ἐπί, <b>to call after</b>, Luk.1:59; of number or degree: ἐπὶ τρίς (cl. εἰς τ.), <b>thrice</b>, Act.10:16 11:10; ἐπὶ πλεῖον, <b>the more, further</b>, Act.4:17 2Ti.2:16 3:9 (see also infr, 2, (<i>a</i>)); ἐφ᾽ ὅσον (see infr, ib.), <b>forasmuch as</b>, Mat.25:40, 45, Rom.11:13; of power, authority, control, Luk.1:33, Act.7:10 Rom.5:14, Heb.3:6, al; of the direction of thoughts and feelings, <b>unto, towards</b>, Luk.1:17 23:28, Act.9:35, 42, Rom.11:22, Gal.4:9, Eph.2:7, 1Ti.5:5, al; of purpose, <b>for</b>, Mat.3:7, Luk.23:48; ἐφ᾽ ὅ πάρει (Rec. ἐφ᾽ ᾧ, Mat.26:50; of hostility, <b>against</b>, Mat.24:7, Mrk.3:24-26 10:11 13:8, Luk.9:5, Jhn.13:18, Act.7:54, 1Co.7:36, 2Co.1:23; Of reference, <b>concerning, for</b> (cl. usually dative), Mrk.9:12 15:24, Jhn.19:24, Rom.4:9. 2) Of time, (a) <b>during, for</b>: Luk.4:25 (WH, txt, omits ἐπί), Act.13:31 16:18, Heb.11:30, al; ἐφ᾽ ὅσον (χρόνον), <b>as long as, for so long time as</b>, Mrk.9:15 Rom.7:1, al. (for ἐφ᾽ ὅ in another sense, see supr, 1, (<i>b</i>)); ἐφ᾽ ἱκανόν (see: ἱ), Act.20:11; ἐπὶ πλεῖον (see supr, 1, (b)), <b>yet longer, further</b>, Act.20:9 24:4; (b) <b>on, about, towards</b> (cl. εἰς): Luk.10:35 Act.3:1 4:5. IV. <b>In composition, ἐπί signifies</b>: <b>up</b>, ἐπαίρω; <b>upon</b>, ἐπίγειος, ἐπιδημέω, ὠπικαθίζω; <b>towards</b>, επιβλέπω, ὠπεκτείνω; <b>over</b> (of superintendence), ἐπιστάτης; <b>again, in addition</b>, ἐπαιτέω; <b>against</b>, ἐπιορκέω, ἐπιβουλή. (AS)

G1966	ἐπιοῦσα	epiousa	to come later	G:V	<b>ἔπ-ειμι </b> [in LXX: Exo.8:22 (עָמַד), Sir.42:19, etc;] 1) <b>to come upon, approach </b> 2) <b>Of time, to come on or after</b>; mostly as ptcp, ἐπιών, -οῦσα, όν, <b>next, following</b>: τῇ- ἔ. (sc.ἡμέρᾳ, as freq. in late Gk.), Act.16:11 20:15 21:18; ἡμέρᾳ (as usual in cl.), Act.7:26; νυκτί, Act.23:11. (AS)
G1967	ἐπιούσιος	epiousios	daily	G:A	<b>ἐπιούσιος</b>, -ον (cf. περιούσιος, [in LXX for סְגֻלָּה, etc.]), found only in the phrase ἄρτος ἐ, EV, daily; R, mg, <b>for the coming day</b>: Mat.6:11, Luk.11:3. (Several derivations find support, each pointing to a different meaning. 1) &lt; ἐπιοῦσα (sc. ἡμέρα) (or, &lt; ἐπὶ τὴν ἰοῦσαν (sc. ήμέραν), Zorell, see word), hence, for the morrow or for the coming day (R, mg.). 2) (a) &lt; ἐπί + οὐσία, hence, for subsistence, needful (Am. R, mg.); (b) &lt; ἐπί + εἶναι in fern. ptcp. form, hence, pertaining to (the day). For renderings of versions and views of various writers, see reff. in <i>DB</i>, <i>ext.</i>, 36 f; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 58 f, 62a; <i>ICC</i> on Lk, l.with The EV, daily, is based on the Vg. (Lk; OL, Mt, Lk, quotidianus). "It is difficult not to think that τὸν ἐ. rests upon misunderstanding of an original Aramaic phrase, or upon a Greek corruption" (<i>ICC</i> on Mt, l.with; cf. also Cremer, 239). (AS)

Metaph, φόβος, Luk.1:12, Act.19:17, Rev.11:11; ὀνειδισμοί, Rom.15:3 (LXX); of the Holy Spirit: before ἐπί, with dative, Act.8:16; ἐπί, with accusative, Act.10:44 11:15; absol, Act.23:7. (AS)

G2070	ἐσμέν	esmen	we are	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G2071	ἔσομαι	esomai	will be	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. G2072	ἔσοπτρον	esoptron	mirror	G:N-N	<b>ἔσ-οπτρον</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX: Wis.7:26, Sir.12:11 *;] <b>a mirror</b>: 1Co.13:12, Jas.1:23. (AS)
G2073	ἑσπέρα	hespera	evening	G:N-F	<b>ἑσπέρα</b>, -ας, ἡ (prop, fem, of ἕσπερος), [in LXX chiefly for עָרַב;] (a) (sc. ὥρα), <b>evening</b>: Luk.24:29, Act.4:3 20:15 28:23; (b) (so. χώρα), the west. (AS)
G2074	Ἐσρώμ	Esrōm	Hezron	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἑσρώμ </b> (Ἑσρών, Lk, l.with; Rec. Ἑσρ-), ὁ (Heb. חֶצְרוֹן, Gen.46:12, Num.26:21, 1Ch.25:1-31, al.), [in LXX both forms, ut supr. (cf. <i>ICC</i>, on Mt, l.with; WH, § 408);] Esrom (AV), Hezron (RV), an ancestor of Jesus: Mat.13:1-58, Luk.3:35. (AS)
G2075	ἐστέ	este	you are	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G2076	ἐστί	esti	he is	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G2077	ἔστω	estō	to be	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). G2078	ἔσχατος	eschatos	last/least	G:A	<b>ἔσχατος</b>, -η, -ον [in LXX chiefly for אַחֲרִית אַחֲרוֹן;] <b>last, utmost, extreme</b>; (a) <b>of place</b>: of the lowest or least honoured place, Luk.14:9-10; τ. ἔσχατον, with genitive part, Act.1:8 13:47; (b) <b>of time</b>: Mat.20:12, 14, Mrk.12:6, 22, opp. to πρῶτος, Mat.20:8, 1Co.15:45, Rev.2:19, al; τὰ ἔ. καὶ T. πρῶτα, Mat.12:45, Luk.11:26, 2Pe.2:20; of the Eternal, ὁ πρῶτος καὶ ὁ ἔ, Rev.1:17 2:8 22:13; in phrases relating to the Messianic age and the consummation of the Kingdom of God: ἐπ᾽ ἐσχάτου (-ων) τ. ἡμερῶν, Heb.1:2, 2Pe.3:3; τ. χρόνων, 1Pe.1:20; ἔ. ὥρα, 1Jn.2:18; ἐπ᾽ ἐ. χόνου, Ju 18; ἐν ἐ. ἡμέραις, Act.2:17, Jas.5:3, 2Ti.3:1; neut, ἔσχατον, as adv, Mrk.12:22, 1Co.15:8; (with) <b>of rank</b>: Mrk.9:35, 1Co.4:9 (AS)
G2079	ἐσχάτως	eschatōs	extremely	G:Adv	<b>ἐσχάτως </b> <i>adv.</i>, <b>extremely, utterly</b>; ἐ. ἔχειν (= Lat. in extremis esse), only in late writers (cf. ἐν ἐσχάτοις εἶναι, FlJ, <i>Ant.</i>, ix, 8, 6), to be at the point of death: Mrk.5:28. (AS)

G2087	ἕτερος	heteros	other	G:A	<b>ἕτερος</b>, -α, -ον, [in LXX chiefly for אַחֵר;] <i>distributive pron.</i>, prop. dual (BL, §13, 5; 51, 6), denoting the second of a pair, but in late Gk. encroaching on ἄλλος (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 79f.); 1) of number, <b>other</b>; with art, <b>the other</b>; (a) of two, Luk.5:7 9:56, al; opp. to ὁ πρῶτος, Mat.21:30; ὁ εἷς, Mat.6:24, Luk.7:41, Act.23:6, al; ἕ. μὲν. ἕ. δέ, <b>the one. the other</b>: 1Co.15:40; <b>the next</b>: Luk.6:6 9:56 (sc. ἡμέρα, Xen.), Act.20:15 27:3; = ὁ πλησίον, <b>one's neighbour</b>: Rom.2:1 13:8, 1Co.6:1, al; (b) of more than two, <b>another</b>: Mat.8:21 11:3, Luk.6:6 22:65, Jhn.19:37, Rom.8:39, al; pl, Act.2:13; οἱ μὲν. ἄλλοι δὲ. ἕ. δέ, Mat.16:14; τινὲς. ἕ. δέ, Luk.11:16. 2) Of kind or quality, <b>other, another, different</b> (Plat, Dem, al.): Mrk.16:[12], Luk.9:29, Act.2:4, 1Co.14:21, 2Co.11:4, Gal.1:6, al. G2091	ἑτοιμασία	hetoimasia	readiness	G:N-F	<b>ἑτοιμασία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἑτοιμάζω, which see), [in LXX for כּוּן hi, כֵּן, מָכוֹן, and cognate forms, Est.2:68 3:3, Psa.10:17 65:9 89:14, Nam.2:4, Zec.5:11, Eze.43:11, Da TH Dan.11:7, 20-21, Wis.13:12 *;] 1) = ἑτοιμότης, (a) <b>readiness </b>(Hipp.); (b) preparation (LXX; e.g. ἑ. τ. καρδίας, Psa.10:17): Eph.6:15, EV. 2) foundation, firm footing (Psa.89:14): Eph, l.with (Hatch, <i>Essays</i>, 55; <i>Exp.</i> Times, ix, 38; but see also Abbott, <i>Essays</i>, 95). G2092	ἕτοιμος	hetoimos	ready	G:A	<b>ἕτοιμος</b>, -ον also (in cl. after Thuc.) -η (2Co.9:5, 1Pe.1:5), -ον, [in LXX chiefly for כּוּן, מָכוֹן (cf. G2192	ἔχω	echō	to have/be	G:V	<b>ἔχω</b>, [in LXX for אָצֵל (ἐχόμενος), יֵשׁ,בַּעַל, etc, 59 words in all;] (on the <i>Aktionsart</i> of the various tenses, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 110, 145, 150, 183), <b>to have</b>, as in cl, in various senses and constructions. I. Trans; 1) 1. <b>to have, hold, hold fast</b>, etc; (a) <b>to hold</b>, <b>as, in the hand</b>: Rev.5:8 14:6, al; ἐν τ. χειρί, Rev.1:16 10:2, al; (b) of arms and clothing, = φέρω, φορέω, <b>to bear, wear</b>: Mat.3:4 22:12, al; so freq. pres. ptcp. (LS, see word, A, I, 6; Bl, 74, 2), Mrk.11:13, Jhn.18:10, Rev.9:17, al; (with) of a woman, ἐν γαστρὶ ἔ, <b>to be with child</b>: Mrk.13:17, Rom.9:10; (d) <b>to hold fast, keep</b>: Luk.19:20; metaph, of the mind and conduct, Mrk.16:8 (cf. Job.21:6, Isa.13:8; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 293; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 44f.), Jhn.14:21, Rom.1:28, 1Ti.3:9, 2Ti.1:13, Rev.6:9, al; (e) <b>to involve</b>: Heb.10:35 (LXX), Jas.1:4, 1Jn.4:18; (<i>f</i>) = Lat. habere (Bl, §34, 5; 73, 5), <b>to hold, consider</b>: with accusative and predic. ptcp, Luk.14:18; with accusative, before ὡς, Mat.14:5; εἰς (Hebraism), Mat.21:46; on (Bl, §70, 2), Mrk.11:32. 2) <b>to have, possess</b>; (a) in general, with accusative of thing(s): Mat.19:22, Mrk.10:22, Luk.12:19, Jhn.10:16, 1Co.11:22, al; of wealth or poverty, absol, ἔχειν (neg. οὐκ, μή), Mat.13:12 25:29, 2Co.8:12; ἐκ τ. ἔχειν, <b>according to your means</b>, 2Co.8:11; (b) of relationship, association, and: πατέρα, Jhn.8:41; γυναῖκα (MM, xiv), 1Co.7:2; φίλον, Luk.11:5; βασιλέα, Jhn.19:15; ποιμένα, Mat.9:36; with dupl. accusative, Mat.3:9, al; (with) <b>of parts or members</b>: ὦτα, Mat.19:15; μέλη, Rom.12:4; θεμελίους, (d) with accusative, as periphrasis of verb: μνεῖαν ἔ. (= μεμνῆσθαι), 1Th.3:6; ἀγάπην, Jhn.13:35; γνῶσιν, 1Co.8:1; πεποίθησιν, 2Co.3:4; θλίψιν, Jhn.16:33, etc. (Thayer, see word, I, 2, f, g.); (e) of duty, necessity, etc: ἀνάγκην, 1Co.7:37; νόμον, Jhn.19:7; ἐπιταγήν, 1Co.7:25; ἀγῶνα, Php.1:30; κρίμα, 1Ti.5:12; (f) <b>of complaints and disputes</b>; κατά, with genitive of person(s), Mat.5:23, Mrk.11:25; id. before ὅτι, Rev.2:4, 20; with accusative before πρός, Act.24:19, al; (g) with inf, (α) (cl.) <b>to be able</b> (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 14): Mat.18:25, Mrk.14:8 (sc. ποιῆσαι), Luk.12:4, Act.4:14, al; (β) <b>of necessity </b>(BL, §69, 4): Luk.12:50, Act.23:17-19 28:19. II. Intrans. (BL, §53, 1), <b>to be in a certain condition</b>: ἑτοίμως ἔ, with inf, Act.21:13, 2Co.12:14; ἐσχάτως (which see), Mrk.5:23; κακῶς, <b>to be ill</b>, Mat.4:24, al; καλῶς, Mk 16:[18]; κομψότερον, Jhn.4:52; πῶς, Act.15:36; impers, ἄλλως εἴχει, <b>it is otherwise</b>, 1Ti.5:25; οὕτως, Act.7:1, al; τὸ νῦν ἔχον, <b>as things now are</b> (Tob.7:11), Act.24:25. III. Mid, -ομαι, <b>to hold oneself fast, hold on</b> or <b>cling to, be next to</b>: with genitive, τ. ἐχόμενα σωτηρίας, Heb.6:9 (Rendall, in l.); ptcp, ὁ ἐχόμενος, <b>near, next</b>: of place, Mrk.1:38; of time, τ. ἐχομένη (ἡμέρα, expressed or understood), Luk.13:33, Act.20:15 21:26; (σαββάτῳ), Act.13:44. (Cf. ἀν, προσ-αν, ἀντ, ἀπ, ἐν, ἐπ, κατ, μετ, παρ, περι, προ, προσ, συν, ὑπερ, ὑπ-έχω.) (AS)
G2193	ἕως	heōs	until	G:Prep	<b>ἕως</b>, <i>relative particle</i> (Lat. <i>donee, usque), </i> expressing the terminus ad quem (cf. Burton, §321ff.). I. As <i>conjunction</i>; 1) <b>till, until</b>; (a) of a fact in past time, with indic: Mat.2:9, al. (Wis.10:14, al.); (b) ἕως ἄν, with subjc. aor: Mat.2:13 5:18, Mrk.6:10, al; without ἄν (M. <i>Pr.</i>, 168f; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 115), Mrk.14:32 (Burton, §325), Luk.12:59, 2Th.2:7, al; (with) with indic, pres. (Burton, §328; BL, §65, 10): Mrk.6:45, Jhn.21:22, 23 1Ti.4:13. 2) C. indic, <b>as long as, while</b> (Burton, §327): Jhn.9:4 (Plat, Phaedo, 89c). II. As an <i>adverb</i> (chiefly in late writers). 1) Of time, <b>until, unto</b>; (a) as <i>prep.</i> with genitive (BL, §40, 6; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 99): τ. ἡμέρας, Mat.26:29, Luk.1:80, Rom.11:8, al; ὥρας, Mat.27:45, al; τέλους, 1Co.1:8, 2Co.1:13; τ. νῦν, Mat.24:21, Mrk.13:19 (1Ma.2:33); ἐτῶν ὀγ. (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 49f.), Luk.2:37; τ. ἐλθεῖν, Act.8:40; before names and events, Mat.1:17 2:15, Luk.11:51, Jas.5:7, al; (b) before οὗ, ὅτου, with the force of a <i>conjc.</i> (Burton, §330; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 91); (α) ἕ. οὗ (Hdt, ii, 143; Plut, al.): with indic, Mat.1:25 (WH br, οὗ) 13:33, al; with subjc. aor, Mat.14:22, al; (β) ἔ. ὅτου: with subjc, Luk.13:8; with indic, Mat.5:25 (<b>until</b>), Jhn.9:18; (with) with <i>adv.</i> (ἔ. ὀψέ, Thuc, iii, 108): ἄρτι, Mat.11:12, Jhn.2:10, 1Co.4:13, al; πότε (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 107), Mat.17:17, Mrk.9:19, Jhn.10:24, al. 2) Of place, <b>as far as, even to, unto</b> (Arist, al.); (a) as <i>prep.</i> with genitive (see supr.): Mt 1123, Lk 1015, al; (b) with <i>adv.</i> (BL, §40, 6): ἄνω, Jhn.2:7; ἔσω, Mrk.14:54; κάτω, Mat.27:51, Mrk.15:38; ὧδε, Luk.23:5; (with) with <i>prep.</i>: ἔξω, Act.21:5; πρός, Luk.24:50 (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 83). 3) Of quantity, measure, etc: Mat.18:21, Mrk.6:23, Luk.22:51, al. (AS)

G2228	ἤ	ē	or	G:Conj	<b>ἤ</b>, <i>disjunctive and comparative <i>particle</i> (Bl, §36, 12; 77, 11); </i> 1) disjunctive, <b>or</b>; (a) <b>between single words</b>: Mat.5:17 Mrk.6:56, Luk.2:24, Jhn.6:19, Rom.1:21, al; (b) before a sentence expressing a variation, denial or refutation of a previous statement, freq. in interrog. form: Mat.7:4, 9 Mrk.12:14, Luk.13:4, Rom.3:29 6:3 9:21, 1Co.6:9, 16 9:6, 2Co.11:7; ἤ. ἤ, <b>either. or</b>, Mat.6:24, Luk.16:13, 1Co.14:6; (with) <b>in a disjunctive question </b>(as Lat. an after utrum): Mat.9:5, Mrk.2:9, Luk.7:19, al; after πότερον, Jhn.7:17; μή, 1Co.9:8; μήτι, 2Co.1:17; ἤ. ἤ. ἤ, Mrk.13:35. 2) Comparative, <b>than</b>: after comparatives, Mat.10:15, Luk.9:13, Jhn.3:19, Rom.13:11, al; after ἕτερον, Act.17:21; θέλω (Khüner 3, iv, 303), 1Co.14:19; πρὶν ἤ, <b>before</b>, before accusative and inf, Mat.1:18 Mrk.14:30; after a positive adj. (Gen.49:12; cf. Robertson, <i>Gr.</i>, 661), Mat.18:8, 9 Mrk.9:43, 45 47. 3) <b>with other particles</b>: ἀλλ᾽ ἤ, see: ἀλλά; ἤ γάρ, see: γάρ; ἢ καί, <b>or even, or also</b>, Mat.7:10, Luk.11:11, 12 Rom.2:15 4:9, al; ἤτοι. ἤ, Rom.6:16 (cf. Wis.11:19). (AS)
G2229	ἦ	ē	surely	G:Adv	<b>ἦ (μήν)</b>, see: εἰ, iii, 7. <b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)

G2244	ἡλικία	hēlikia	age/height	G:N-F	<b>ἡλικία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἧλιξ, of the same age, mature), [in LXX: Eze.13:18 (קוֹמָה), Job.29:18, Wis.4:9, Sir.26:17, freq. in 2-4 Mac;] always of age or maturity; "a stage of growth whether measured by age or stature"; 1) (a) <b>age</b>: Mat.6:27, Luk.12:25 (R, mg.), Heb.11:11; (b) <b>full age, maturity</b>: Jhn.9:21, 23, Eph.4:13. 2) <b>stature</b>: Luk.19:3 (Mat.6:27, Luk.12:25, AV, R, txt; but the prevailing usage in LXX and π. favours the former meaning in these doubtful passages; cf, Ellic, <i>ICC</i>, AR, on Eph, l.with; Milligan, <i>NTD</i>, 74 f, and esp, MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xv; e contra, Field, <i>Notes</i>, 6). G2245	ἡλίκος	hēlikos	how great	G:Cor+G:Intg	<b>ἡλίκος</b>, -η, -ον 1) prop, as big as, as old as. 2) As indirect interrog, <b>what sized, what, how great, how small </b>(the sense to be determined by the context): Col.2:1, Jas.3:5, Gal.6:11 (WH, mg; πηλ, WH, txt, RV). (AS)
G2246	ἥλιος	hēlios	sun	G:N-M	<b>ἥλιος</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX chiefly for שֶׁמֶשׁ;] <b>the sun</b>: with art. (El, § 46, 5), Mat.5:45 13:43 17:2 24:29, Mrk.1:32 4:6 13:24 16:2, Luk.4:40, Act.2:20 " (LXX) Act.26:13, Eph.4:26, Jas.1:11, Rev.1:16 6:12 8:12 9:2 10:1 12:1 16:8 19:17 21:23; βλέπειν τὸν ἥ, Act.13:11; οὐδὲ μὴ πέσῃ ἐπ᾽ αὐτοὺς ὁ ἥ, Rev.7:16; without art, Mat.13:6, Luk.21:25 23:45, Act.27:20, 1Co.15:41, Rev.7:2 16:12 22:5. G2247	ἧλος	hēlos	nail	G:N-M	<b>ἧλος</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX: Isa.41:7 מַסְמֵר etc;] <b>a nail</b>: Jhn.20:25. (AS)
G2248	ἡμᾶς	hēmas	us	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)
G2249	ἡμεῖς	hēmeis	we	G:PerP	<b>ἡμεῖς</b>, see: ἐγώ. <b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. G2250	ἡμέρα	hēmera	day	G:N-F	<b>ἡμέρα</b>, -ας, ἡ, [in LXX chiefly (very freq.) for יוֹם;] <b>day</b>; 1) <b>as distinct from night</b>: genitive ἡμέρας, <b>by day</b> (WM, §30, 11), Rev.21:25; ἡ. κ. νυκτός (ν. κ. ̔ἡ.), Act.9:24, 1Th.2:9, 2Th.3:8, Rev.4:8 (BL, §36, 13); ἡμέρας μέσης, <b>at mid-day</b>, Act.26:13; accusative durat, τ. ἡμέρας, Luk.21:37; ὅλην τὴν ἡ, Rom.8:36; ἐν ἡμέρα, Jhn.11:9, Rom.13:13; ἡμέρας ὁδός, <b>a day's journey</b>, Luk.2:44; ἡ. γίνεται, Lk 4:42 22:66; κλίνει, Luk.9:12, al; metaph, Jhn.9:4, Rom.13:12, 1Th.5:4, 5 8, 2Pe.1:19. 2) Of a civil day of 24 hours, incl. night: Mat.6:34, Mrk.6:21, Luk.13:14, al; τρίτῃ ἡ, Mat.16:21; ἡμέρᾳ κ. ἡ. (cf. יוֹם בְּיוֹם, Est.3:4), 2Co.4:16; ὅλην τ. ἡ, Rom.8:36 10:21; pl, Jhn.2:12, Act.9:19, al; ἡ. τῶν ἀζύμων, Act.12:3; τ. σαββάτου, Luk.13:14, 16; ἡ κυριάκη ἡ, Rev.1:10. 3) <b>In Messianic sense, of the last day</b>: ἡ ἡ. (ἐκείνη, τ. κυρίου, etc.), Mat.7:22, Luk.6:23, Rom.13:12, 1Co.1:8, 1Th.5:2, 2Th.2:2, 2Pe.3:10, al; by meton, as compared with the divine judgment on that day, ἡ. ἀνθρωπίνη, of a human <b>tribunal</b>, 1Co.4:3 (EV, <b>man's judgment</b>). 4) As in Heb. (also in Gk. writers; Bl, §46, 9; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 81), of time in general: Jhn.8:56 14:20, 2Co.6:2, Eph.6:13, 2Pe.3:18; pl. Act.15:7, Eph.5:16, Heb.10:32; πᾶσας τὰς ἡ. (cf. כָּל הַיָּמִים, Deu.4:40, al; MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xv), Mat.28:20; ἐλεύσονται ἡ. ὅταν (ὅτε), Mat.9:15, Mrk.2:20, Luk.5:35 17:22; αἱ ἡ, with genitive of person(s) (Gen.26:1, al.), Mat.2:1, Luk.1:5, Act.7:45, 1Pe.3:20; ἀρχ̀ ἡμερῶν, Heb.7:3. (AS)

G2258	ἦν	ēn	was	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)

G2268	Ἡσαΐας	Hēsaias	Isaiah	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἠσαίας</b> (Rec. Ἠ, Mrk.1:2. (AS)
G2269	Ἠσαῦ	Ēsau	Esau	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἠσαῦ</b>, ὁ indecl. (Heb. עֵשָׂו, Gen.25:25), <b>Esau</b>: Rom.9:13 (LXX) Heb.11:20 12:16. (AS)
G2270	ἡσυχάζω	hēsuchazō	be quiet/give up	G:V	<b>ἡσυχάζω </b> [in LXX chiefly for שָׁקַט;] <b>to be still</b>; (a) <b>to rest from labour</b>: Luk.23:56; (b) <b>to live quietly</b>: 1Th.4:11; (with) <b>to be silent</b>: Luk.14:3, Act.11:18 21:14 (cf. Job.32:7, Neh.5:8). (AS)
G2271	ἡσυχία	hēsuchia	quietness	G:N-F	<b>ἡσυχία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; ἡσύχιος, which see), [in LXX for אִישׁוֹן, שָׁלֵו, etc;] 1) <b>quietness</b>: 2Th.3:12. 2) <b>stillness, silence</b>: Act.22:2, 1Ti.2:11-12 (AS)
G2272	ἡσύχιος	hēsuchios	quiet	G:A	<b>ἡσύχιος</b>, -α, -ον (= the more freq. ἥσυχος; cf. Wis.18:14, Sir.25:20), [in LXX: Isa.66:2 (רוּחַ נָכֶה)*;] <b>quiet, tranquil</b>: 1Ti.2:2, 1Pe.3:4. (AS)
G2273	ἤτοι	ētoi	whether	G:Conj	1. = ἦ τοι, <b>now surely, truly, verily </b>, (Iliad by Homer); after ἀλλ᾽ εἰ, <b>nevertheless </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 2. = ἤτοι, <b>either in truth </b>, followed by ἤ, <b>or </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. (ML)
G2274	ἡσσάομαι	hēssaomai	be lesser	G:V	<b>ἡττάω</b>, -ῶ (ἡσσ, 2Co.12:13, see: ἥσσων) [in LXX for חָתַת, etc;] pass, 1) <b>to be inferior</b>: before ὑπέρ, 2Co.12:13. 2) <b>to be overcome</b>: absol, 2Pe.2:20; with dative, 2Pe.2:19. (AS)
G2275	ἥττημα	hēttēma	loss	G:N-N	<b>ἥττημα</b>, -τος, τό [in LXX for מַס, Isa.31:8 *;] <b>defect, loss, defeat</b>: Rom.11:12 (cf. Isa, l.with), 1Co.6:7 (cf. Field, <i>Notes</i>, 160 f, 171 f; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 212). (AS)
G2276	ἥσσων	hētton, hēssōn	less/worse	G:A	<b>ἥσσων</b> (Rec. ἥττ, the Attic literary form), ἧσσων, <b>inferior, less</b>; neut, τὸ ἧ, adverbially, <b>less</b>: 2Co.12:15; εἰς τὸ ἧ, <b>for the worse </b>(opp. to κρεῖττον): 1Co.11:17. (AS)
G2277	ἤτω	ētō	let him/it be	G:V	1. as Substantive Verb, <b>to be, to exist </b>, οὐκ ἔσθ᾽ οὗτος ἀνήρ, οὐδ᾽ ἔσσεται (Odyssey by Homer); τεθνηῶτος, μηδ᾽ ἔτ᾽ ἐόντος (Odyssey by Homer); οὐκέτ᾽ ἔστι he <b>is no more </b>, (Euripides); θεοὶ αἰὲν ἐόντες (Iliad by Homer); ἐσσόμενοι posterity, (Iliad by Homer); ζώντων καὶ ὄντων Ἀθηναίων (Demosthenes Orator);so of cities, etc, ὄλωλεν, οὐδ᾽ ἔτ᾽ ἔστι Τροία (compare <b>Troja fuit) </b>, (Euripides) 2. of things, <b>to be, exist </b>, εἰ ἔστιν ἀληθέως [ἡ τράπεζα] (Herdotus Historicus); ἕως ἂν ὁ πόλεμος ἦι so long as it <b>last </b>, (Thucydides) 3. <b>to be </b>, opp. to <b>appearing to be </b>, as <b>esse </b> to <b>videri </b>, τὸν ἐόντα λόγον the <b>true </b> story, (Herdotus Historicus); τὰ ὄντα ἀπαγγέλλειν (Thucydides); τῶι ὄντι, Lat. <i>revera</i>, in reality, in fact, (Plato Philosophus) 4. followed by the Relative, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅς, <b>no one </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc; εἰσὶν οἵ, Lat. <i>sunt qui</i>, (Thucydides), etc; ἐστὶν ἅ <b>some things </b>, (Thucydides); also ἔστιν οἵ, for εἰσὶν οἵ, (Herdotus Historicus), etc;so withrelat. Particles, ἔστιν ἔνθα, Lat. <i>est ubi</i>, (Xenophon Historicus), etc; ἔστιν ὅπη, ἔσθ᾽ ὅπου, <b>somewhere </b>, or <b>somehow </b>, (Plato Philosophus), etc; ἔστιν ὅπως <b>in some manner </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; ἔστιν ὅτε, ἔσθ᾽ ὅτε, <b>sometimes </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 5. ἔστι <i>impersonal</i>, with <i>infinitive</i>, like πάρεστι, <b>it is possible </b>, (Homer), attic 6. <b>to be </b>, Copula connecting predicate with subject, both being in the same case, (Homer), etc. 7. sometimes εἶναι with Part. represents finite Verb, ἦν τεθνηκώς, for ἐτεθνήκει, (Aeschulus Tragicus); πεφυκός ἐστι = πέφυκε, (Aristophanes Comicus) 8. the Inf. is redundant in some phrases, ἑκὼν εἶναι (see. ἑκών II); τὸ ἐπ᾽ ἐκείνοις εἶναι <b>quantum in illis esset </b>, (Thucydides); τὸ σύμπαν εἶναι (Herdotus Historicus); τὸ νῦν εἶναι (Plato Philosophus), etc. (ML)

G2288	θάνατος	thanatos	death	G:N-M	<b>θάνατος</b>, -ου, ὁ (θνήσκω), [in LXX chiefly for מָוֶת,מוּת, sometimes דֶּבֶר;] <b>death</b>; 1) <b>of the death of the body, whether natural or violent</b>: Jhn.11:13, Php.2:27, Heb.7:23, al; opp. to ζωή, Rom.8:38, Php.1:20; of the death of Christ, Rom.5:10, Php.3:10, Heb.2:9; ῥυέσθαι (σώζειν) ἐκ θ, 2Co.1:10, Heb.5:7; περίλυπος ἕως θανάτου, Mat.26:38, Mrk.14:34; μέχρι (ἄχρι), Php.2:8, Rev.2:10; πληγὴ θανάτου, a deadly wound. G2308	θέλησις	thelēsis	will	G:N-F	<b>θέλησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (θέλω) [in LXX: 2Ch.15:15, Pro.8:35 (רָצוֹן), Eze.18:23 (חֵפֶץ), LXX Dan.11:45 (צְבִי), Tob.12:18, Wis.16:25, 2Ma.12:16, 3Ma.2:26 *;] in colloq. and M<i>Gr.</i> = τὸ θέλειν, <b>will</b>: Heb.2:4. (AS)
G2309	θέλω	thelō	to will/desire	G:V	<b>θέλω</b> (the strengthened form ἐθέλω is found in Hom, and is the more freq. in Attic; see Rutherford, <i>NPhr.</i>, 415f.), [in LXX for חפץ,אבה; with neg, מאן pi, etc;] <b>to will, be willing, wish, desire</b> (more freq. than βούλομαι, which see, in vernac. and late Gk, also in MGr; G2349	θνητός	thnētos	mortal	G:A	<b>θνητός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; θνήσκω), [in LXX: Pro.3:13 20:24 (אָדָם), Job.30:23 (חַי), Isa.51:12 (מוּת), Wis.9:14 15:17, 2Ma.9:12, 3Ma.3:29 *;] <b>subject to death, mortal</b>: Rom.6:12 8:11, 1Co.15:53-54, 2Co.4:11 5:4. (AS)
G2350	θορυβέω	thorubeō	to make commotion	G:V	<b>θορυβέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; θόρυβος), [in LXX: Nam.2:3 (רָעַל ho.), Dan LXX 8:17 (בָּעַת ni.), Jdg.3:26, Wis.18:19, Sir.40:6 *;] 1) <b>to make a noise or uproar</b>: mid, of loud and ostentatious lamentation, Mat.9:23, Mrk.5:39, Act.20:10. 2) Trans, <b>to trouble, throw into confusion</b>: τ. πόλιν, Act.17:5. (AS)

G2395	ἰατρός	iatros	physician	G:N-M	<b>ἰατρός</b>, -οὔ, ὁ (&lt; ἰάομαι), [in LXX for רָפָא;] <b>a physician</b>: Mat.9:12, Mrk.2:17 5:26, Luk.4:23 5:31 8:43 (om. WH, R, mg.), Col.4:14 (on the status of physicians, see MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xv.). (AS)
G2396	ἴδε	ide	look!	G:Intj	<b>ἴδε</b> (Attic ἰδέ; the "later" accentuation is also found in Hom; Veitch, 215) 1) prop, 2 aor. imperat. of ὁράω, which see 2) <b>As interjection, apart from the construction of the sentence, and used where one or many are addressed, see! behold! lo!</b>: Mat.25:20, 22 25:25, Mrk.2:24 3:34 11:21 13:1, 21 15:4, 35 16:6, Jhn.1:29, 36 1:48 3:26 5:14 7:26 11:3, 36 12:19 16:29 18:21 19:4, 14 19:26-27, Gal.5:2. (AS)

G2398	ἴδιος	idios	one's own/private	G:A	<b>ἴδιος</b>, -α, -ον (in Attic usually -ος, -ον), [in LXX chiefly for of person(s) suff, also for לָהֶם, etc; (τὰ ἴ.) בֵּיתוֹ;] 1) <b>one's own</b>; (a) <b>of that which is private and personal </b>(in cl. opp. to κοινός, δημόσιος; cf. infr. 3); (b) of property, friends, home, country, etc. (in cl. opp. to ἀλλότριος; in late writers often, like ἑαυτοῦ, with weakened sense, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 87ff; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 123f.): Luk.6:41, Jhn.1:42 5:43, Act.2:6 20:28, 1Co.11:21, Gal.6:5, 2Ti.1:9, Heb.7:27, Ju 6, al; πράσσειν τὰ ἴ, 1Th.4:11; κατὰ τὰς ἰ. ἐπιθυμίας, 2Ti.4:3; οἱ ἴδιοι, Jhn.1:11 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 90f; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 84) 13:1, Act.4:23, 1Ti.5:8; τὰ ἴδια, one's <i>home</i> (Field, <i>Notes</i>, l.with), Luk.18:28, Jhn.1:11 16:32 19:27. 2) <b>peculiar, distinct, appropriate, proper</b>: τὸ ἴ. σῶμα, 1Co.15:38; ἐν τ. ἰ. τάγματι, 1Co.15:23; εἰς τ. τόπον τ. ἴ, Act.1:25; = αὐτοῦ (see Deiss, ut. supr.), Mat.22:5, Jhn.1:42 (cf. Wis.10:1). 3) Adverbially (see supr, 1 (<i>a</i>); and cf. WM, 739:2); (a) ἰδίᾳ, <b>severally, separately</b>: 1Co.12:11; (b) κατ᾽ ἰδίαν, <b>apart, privately, in private</b>: Mat.14:13, 23 20:17, Mrk.4:34 7:33, Luk.10:23, Act.23:19, al. (AS)
G2399	ἰδιώτης	idiōtēs	unlearned	G:N-M	<b>ἰδιώτης</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ἴδιος), [in LXX: Pro.6:8 (no <i>Heb.</i>)*;] 1) a pri­vate person, as opp. to the State or an official (βασιλεῖς κ. ἰδιῶται, Pr, l.with; and cf. MM, <i>Exp.</i>, xv). 2) <b>one without professional knowledge, unskilled, uneducated, unlearned</b>: 1Co.14:16 14:23-24 (R, mg, without gifts); ἀγράμματοι κ. ἰ, Act.4:13; with dative (= cl. with genitive of thing(s)), λόγῳ, 2Co.11:6. G2400	ἰδού	idou	look! G2434	ἱλασμός	hilasmos	propitiation	G:N-M	<b>ἱλασμός</b>, -οῦ (&lt; ἱλάσκομαι), [in LXX: Lev.25:9, Num.5:8 (כִּפֻּר), Psa.130:4, Da TH Dan.9:9 (סְלִיחָה), Amo.8:14 (אַשְׁמָה), Eze.44:27 (חַטָּאָה), 1Ch.28:20, Sir.18:20 A, 2Ma.3:33 *;] 1) an appeasing (Plut.). 2) <b>a means of appeasing, propitiation </b>(Philo; Nu, Ez, ll.with): 1Jn.2:2 Jn 4:10. 3) In LXX also forgiveness (Ps, Da TH, ll.with). G2435	ἱλαστήριος	hilastērios	propitiation	G:N-N	<b>ἱλαστήριος</b>, -α, -ον (&lt; ἱλάσκομαι), [in LXX: 4Ma.17:22; neut, Exo.25:16 (17) ff. Exo.31:7 35:12 37:6 ff, Lev.16:2, 13 ff. G2443	ἵνα	hina	in order that/to	G:Conj	<b>ἵνα</b>, I. <i>adverb</i> (poët, Hom, al.), 1) of place, <b>where, whither</b>. 2) of circumstance, <b>when</b>. II. <i>Conjunction</i>, 1) prop, final, denoting purpose or end (cl.), <b>that, in order that</b>, usually the first word in the clause, but sometimes (cl. also) preceded by an emphatic word (Act.19:4, Rom.11:31, Gal.2:10, al.); (a) with optative (so in cl. after historic tenses): after a pres, Eph.1:17 (but WH, mg, subjc; see Burton, §225, Rem, 2); (b) with subjc: after a pres, Mrk.4:21, Luk.6:34, Jhn.3:15, Act.2:25, Rom.1:11, al; after a pf, Mat.1:22, Jhn.5:23 1Co.9:22, al; after an imperat. (pres. or aor.), Mat.7:1, Mrk.11:25, Jhn.10:38, 1Co.7:5, al; after a delib. subjc, Mrk.1:38, al; after a fut, Luk.16:4, Jhn.14:3, 1Co.15:28, al; after historic tenses (where optative in cl; WM, 359f; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 196f.), Mrk.6:41 (impf.), Jhn.4:8 (plpf.), Mrk.3:14 (aor.), al; (with) in late writers (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 35; Burton, §§198, 199), with indic, fut: Luk.20:10, 1Pe.3:1, al; (d) as often in eccl. writers (Thayer, see word), with indic. pres: 1Co.4:6, Gal.4:17, al. (; but V. Burton, §198, Rem.); (e) εἰς (διὰ) τοῦτο, ἵνα: Jhn.18:37, 1Ti.1:16, al; τούτου χάριν, Tit.1:5; (f) <b>elliptical constructions</b>: omission of the principal verb, Jhn.1:8, 2Th.3:9, 1Jn.2:19, al; of the final verb, Rom.4:16, 2Co.8:13, al. 2) In late writers, definitive, = inf. (WM, 420; Bl, §69, 1), <b>that</b>; (a) after verbs of wishing, caring, striving, etc: θέλω, Mat.7:12, al; ζητῶ, 1Co.4:2 14:12; ζηλόω, 1Co.14:1, al; (b) <b>after verbs of saying, asking, exhorting</b>: εἰπεῖν, Mat.4:3, al; ἐρωτῶ, Mrk.7:26, al; παρακαλῶ, Mat.14:36, 1Co.1:10, al, etc; (with) after words expressing expediency, etc: συμφέρει, Mat.18:6, Jhn.11:50, al; ἱκανός, Mat.8:8, Luk.7:6; χρείαν ἔχω, Jhn.2:25, al, etc; (d) <b>after substantives, adding further definition</b>: ὥρα, Jhn.12:23 13:1; χρόνος, Rev.2:21; συνήθεια, Jhn.18:39; μισθός, 1Co.9:18. 3) In late writers, ecbatic, denoting the result, = ὥστε, <b>that, so that</b> (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 206ff; WM, 572; Bl, §69, 3; Burton, §223): Rom.11:11, 1Co.7:29, 1Th.5:4, al. (but see Thayer, see word); so with the formula referring to the fulfilment of prophecy, ἵνα πληρωθῇ, Mat.1:22 2:14, Jhn.13:18, al. (AS)

G2468	ἴσθι	isthi	you should be	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G2469	Ἰσκαριώτης, Ἰσκαριώθ	Iskariōtēs, Iskariōth	Iscariot	N:N-M-P	<b>ἰσκαριώθ</b>, ὁ indecl. (Mrk.3:19 14:10, Luk.6:16, elsewhere -ιώτης; V. infr.) and Ἰσκαριώτης, -ου (Heb. prob. קִרְיָא אִישׁ; see Swete, <i>Mk.</i>, 319), <b>Iscariot</b>: surname of Judas, ll. with supr, also Mat.10:4 26:14, Mrk.14:43 (WH, R, omit), Luk.22:3, Jhn.12:4 13:2 14:22; of his father Simon, Jhn.6:71 13:26. G2470	ἴσος	isos	equal	G:A	<b>ἴσος</b> (epic ἶσος, so sometimes Rec.), -η, -ον, [in LXX for כְּ֜, Jb 5:14; Job.10:10, al; אֶחָד, Eze.40:5 ff; 2Ma.9:15, 4Ma.13:20-21, al;] equal, the same in size, number, quality, etc: δωρεά, Act.11:17; μαρτυρίαι, Mrk.14:56, 59; ἴ. ποιεῖν, with accusative and dative, Mat.20:12; ἑαυτὸν τ. θεῷ, Jhn.5:18; τὰ ἴ. ἀπολαβεῖν, Luk.6:34, n. pl, ἴσα, adverbially, Rev.21:16; τ. θεῷ, Php.2:6. G2502	Ἰωσίας	Iōsias	Josiah	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἰωσείας</b> (-σίας, Rec.), -ου, ὁ (Heb. יֹאשִׁיָּה), <b>Josiah</b>: Mat.1:10-11 (AS)
G2503	ἰῶτα	iōta	iota	G:N-N	<b>ἰῶτα</b>, τό, <b>iota </b>(Heb. י, i.e. the smallest letter): Mat.5:18. (AS)
G2504	κἀγώ	kagō	and I	G:Conj+G:PerP	<b>κἀγώ</b> see: ἐγώ. <b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)
G2505	καθά	katha	as/just as	G:Conj	<b>καθά</b> <i> adv.</i> (for καθ᾽ ἅ), [in LXX: Gen.7:9 19:8, al. (אֲשֶׁר, כְּ), Isa.58:11, Wis.3:10, al;] <b>just as, according as</b>: Mat.27:10 (LXX), Luk.1:2, D (cf. BL, § 78, 1; Phil. Gosp, 8 f.). (AS)

G2507	καθαιρέω	kathaireō	to take down	G:V	<b>καθ-αιρέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX for נָתַץ, פָּרַץ, יָרַד, etc;] 1) <b>to take down</b>: with accusative of person(s) (the technical term for removal after crucifixion, Field, <i>Notes</i>, 44), Mrk.15:36, 46, Luk.23:53, Act.13:29. 2) <b>to put down by force, pull down, destroy</b>: ἀποθήκας, Luk.12:18 (opp. to οἰκοδομεῖν); δυνάστας, Luk.1:52; ἔθνη, Act.13:19; pass, Act.19:27 (diminished, Field, <i>Notes</i>, 129 f.); figuratively, <b>to refute</b>: λογισμούς, 2Co.10:5. (AS)
G2508	καθαίρω	kathairō	to prune	G:V	<b>καθαίρω</b> (&lt; καθαρός), [in LXX: Isa.28:27 (דּוּשׁ ho.), 2Ki.4:6, Jer.51:39 א*;] <b>to cleanse</b>: of pruning, Jhn.15:2 (cf. καθαρίζω). (AS)
G2509	καθάπερ	kathaper	just as	G:Conj	<b>καθάπερ</b> (for καθ᾽ ἅπερ = καθά) <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX for אֲשֶׁר, Gen.12:4, Exo.7:6, al;] <b>just as, even as</b>: Rom.3:4 4:6 9:13 10:15 11:8 12:4, 1Co.10:10 12:12, 2Co.1:14 3:13 3:18 8:11, 1Th.2:11 3:6 3:12 4:6, Heb.4:2. (AS)
G2510	καθάπτω	kathaptō	to attach	G:V	<b>καθ-άπτω </b> [in Sm: Sng.1:6 *;] 1) to fasten on, put upon, with accusative 2) Act. for mid. (cf. Bl, § 53, 3), <b>to lay hold of, attack</b>: with genitive, χειρός, Act.28:3. (AS)
G2511	καθαρίζω	katharizō	to clean	G:V	<b>καθαρίζω</b> (Hellenistic-FlJ, Inscr.-for Attic καθαίρω, which see, on the vulgar -ερ, Mat.8:3, Mrk.1:42, see Bl, § 6, 1; Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 74) [in LXX chiefly for טָהֵר;] to cleanse, make clean. 1) <b>In physical sense</b>: with accusative of thing(s), figuratively, Mat.23:25-26, Luk.11:39; of disease (leprosy), with accusative of person(s), Mat.8:2-3 10:8 11:5, Mrk.1:40-42 Luk.4:27 5:12-13 7:22 17:14, 17; ἡ λέπρα ἐκαθερίσθη (on the spelling see supr.), Mat.8:3. 2) <b>In ethical sense</b>: τ. καρδίας, Act.15:9 (cf. Sir.38:10); τ. χεῖρας, Jas.4:8; λαὸν ἑαυτῷ, Tit.2:14; τ. ἐκκλησίαν, Eph.5:26; with accusative of person(s) (of thing(s)), before ἀπό (131, § 36, 9; Deiss, BS, 216 f.), 2Co.7:1, Heb.9:14, 1Jn.1:7 Jn 1:9. 3) <b>In ceremonial sense</b>: Mrk.7:19, Act.10:15 11:9, Heb.9:22-23 10:2 (cf. δια-καθαρίζω). (AS)

G2532	καί	kai	and	G:Conj	<b>καί</b>, <i>conj.</i>, <b>and</b> I. Copulative. 1) Connecting single words; (a) <b>in general</b>: Mat.2:18, 16:1, Mrk.2:15, Luk.8:15, Heb.1:1, al. mult; repeated before each of the terms in a series, Mat.23:23, Luk.14:21, Rom.7:12, 9:4, al. (b) <b>connecting numerals </b>(WM, §37, 4): Jhn.2:20, Act.13:20; (with) <b>joining terms which are not mutually exclusive, as the part with the whole</b>: Mat.8:33, 26:59, Mrk.16:17, Act.5:29, al. 2) <b>Connecting clauses and sentences</b>: Mat.3:12, Act.5:21, al. mult; esp. (a) <b>where, after the simplicity of the popular language, sentences are paratactically joined </b>(WM, §60, 3; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 12; Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 128ff.): Mat.1:21, 7:25, Mrk.9:5, Jhn.10:3, al; (b) <b>joining affirmative to negative sentences</b>: Luk.3:14, Jhn.4:11, IIIJhn.10; (with) consecutive, <b>and so</b>: Mat.5:1, 23:32, Heb.3:19, al; after imperatives, Mat.4:19, Luk.7:7, al; (d) = καίτοι, <b>and yet</b>: Mat.3:14, 6:26, Mrk.12:12, Luk.18:7 (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 72), 1Co.5:2, al; (e) beginning an apodosis (= Heb. וְ; so sometimes δέ in cl.), <b>then</b>: Luk.2:21, 7:12, Act.1:10; beginning a question (WM, §53, 3a): Mrk.10:26, Luk.10:29, Jhn.9:36. 3) Epexegetic, <b>and, and indeed, namely</b> (WM, §53, 3c): Luk.3:18, Jhn.1:16, Act.23:6, Rom.1:5, 1Co.3:5, al. 4) <b>In transition</b>: Mat.4:23, Mrk.5:1, 21, Jhn.1:19, al; so, Hebraistically, καὶ ἐγένετο (וַי:הִי; also ἐγένετο δέ), Mrk.1:9 (cf. Luk.5:1; V. Burton, §§357-60; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 14, 16). 5) καὶ. καί, <b>both. and</b> (for τε. καί, see: τε); (a) <b>connecting single words</b>: Mat.10:28, Mrk.4:41, Rom.11:33, al; (b) <b>clauses and sentences</b>: Mrk.9:13, Jhn.7:28, 1Co.1:22, al. II. Adjunctive, <b>also, even, still</b>: Mat.5:39, 40; Mrk.2:28, al. mult; esp. with pron, adv, etc, Mat.20:4, Jhn.7:47, al; ὡς κ, Act.11:17; καθὼς κ, Rom.15:7; οὑτω κ, Rom.6:11; διὸ κ, Luk.1:35; ὁ κ. (Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 313ff.), Act.13:9; pleonastically, μετὰ κ. (Bl, §77, 7; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 265f,), Php.4:3; τί κ, 1 Co 15:29; ἀλλὰ κ, Luk.14:22, Jhn.5:18, al; καίγε (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 230; Burton, §437), Act.17:27; καίπερ, Heb.5:8; κ. ἐάν, see: ἐάν. <b>ἐάν</b>, contr. fr. εἰ ἄν, <i>conditional particle</i>, representing something as "under certain circumstances actual or liable to happen," but not so definitely expected as in the case of εἰ with ind. (Bl, §65, 4; cf. Jhn.13:17, 1Co.7:36), <b>if haply, if</b>; 1) with subjc. (cl.); (a) pres: Mat.6:22, Luk.10:6, Jhn.7:17, Rom.2:25, 26 al; { (b) aor. (= Lat. fut. pf.): Mat.4:9 16:26 (cf. ptcp. in Luk.9:25; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 230), Mrk.3:24, Luk.14:34, Jhn.5:43, Rom.7:2, al; = cl. εἰ, with opt, Jhn.9:22 11:57, Act.9:2; as Heb. אִם = ὅταν, Jhn.12:32 14:3, I Jhn.2:28 3:2, Heb.3:7 " (LXX). 2) C. indic, (as in late writers, fr. Arist. on; see WH, <i>App.</i>, 171; VD, <i>MGr.</i> 2, <i>App.</i>, §77; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 201f, <i>LAE</i>, 155, 254; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 168, 187; Bl, §65, 4); (a) fut: Mat.18:19 T, Luk.19:40, Act.7:7; (b) pres: 1Th.3:8 (see Milligan, in l.). 3) <b>With other particles</b>: ἐ. καί (Bl, §65, 6), Gal.6:1; ἐ. μή (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 185, 187; Bl, l.with), with subjc. pres, Mat.10:13, 1Co.8:8, Jas.2:17, 1Jn.3:21; aor, Mat.6:15, Mrk.3:27, Jhn.3:3, Rom.10:15, Gal.1:8 2:16 (see Lft, Ellic, in ll.); ἐ. τε. ἐ. τε, [in LXX for אִם. אִם, Est.19:13, al,] Rom.14:8. 4) = cl. ἄν (which see) after relat. pronouns and adverbs (Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, 96; WH, <i>App.</i>, 173; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 42f; Bl, §26, 4; Mayser, 152f; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 202ff.): ὃς ἐ, Mat.5:19, Mrk.6:22, 23 Luk.17:32, 1Co.6:18, al; ὅπου ἐ, Mat.8:19; ὁσάκις ἐ, Rev.11:6; οὗ ἐ, 1Co.16:6; καθὸ ἐ, 2Co.8:12; ὅστις ἐ, Gal.5:10. G2588	καρδία	kardia	heart	G:N-F	<b>καρδία</b>, -ας, ἡ, [in LXX chiefly for לֵבָב,לֵב;] <b>the heart</b>, 1) the bodily organ which is regarded as the seat of life (2Ki.18:14, 4Ki.9:24, al.). 2) In a psychological sense, the seat of man's collective energies, the focus of personal life, the seat of the rational as well as the emotional and volitional elements in human life, hence that wherein lies the moral and religious condition of the man (<i>DB</i>, ii, 317f; <i>DGG</i>, ii, 344a); (a) of the seat of physical life (Jdg.19:5, Psa.101 (102):5 103 (104):15): Act.14:17, Jas.5:5; (b) <b>of the seat of spiritual life</b>: Mat.5:8, Mrk.7:19, Luk.1:51, Act.5:3, Rom.10:9, 10 Eph.6:5, al; pl, Mat.9:4, Mrk.2:6, al; opp. to στόμα, χείλεα, πρόσωπον, Mat.15:8, Mrk.7:6, Rom.10:8, 9 2Co.5:12; περιτομὴ καρδίας, Rom.2:29; ἐκ κ, Rom.6:17, 1Pe.1:22; ἀπὸ τῶν κ, Mat.18:35; ἐν ὅλῃ (ἐξ ὅλης), Mat.22:37, Mrk.12:30 " (LXX); γινώσκειν (ἐρευνᾶν, δοκιμάζειν) τὰς κ, Luk.16:15, Rom.8:27, 1Th.2:4; to think, etc, ἐν τ. κ, Mat.9:4, Mrk.2:6, Luk.12:45, Rom.10:6; συνιέναι (νοεῖν) τῇ κ, Mat.13:15, Jhn.12:40; ἐπαχύνθη ἡ κ, Mat.13:15 (LXX); πωροῦν τὴν κ, Jhn.12:40; κ. εὐθεῖα, Act.8:21; πονηρά, Heb.3:12; ἀμετανόητος, Rom.2:5; εἶναι (ἔχειν) ἐν τῇ κ, 2Co.7:3, Php.1:7; ὀδύνη τῇ κ, Rom.9:2. 3) <b>Of the central or innermost part of anything </b>(of the pith of wood, Arist.): τ. γῆς, Mat.12:40 (Cremer, 343ff.). G2596	κατά	kata	according to	G:Prep	<b>κατά</b> (bef. a vowel κατ᾽, καθ᾽; on the freq. neglect of elision, see Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, 95; WH, <i>App.</i>, 146a), <i>prep. with genitive, accusative, </i> <b>down, downwards</b>. I. C. genitive (WM, §47, k; Bl, §42, 2). 1) C. genitive of thing(s), in local sense; (a) <b>down, down from</b>: Mat.8:32, Mrk.5:13, Luk.8:33, 1Co.11:4; (b) <b>throughout</b> (late usage; Bl, l.with): κ. ὅλης κ.τ.λ, Luk.4:14 23:5, Act.9:31 10:37; (with) <b>in a peculiar adjectival phrase</b>: ἡ κ. βάθους, deep or extreme poverty, 2Co.8:2. 2) C. genitive of person(s), usually in hostile sense; (a) <b>against</b> (in cl. only after verbs of speaking, witnessing, etc.): opp. to ὑπέρ, Mrk.9:40; μετά, Mat.12:30; after ἐπιθυμεῖν, Gal.5:17; λαλεῖν, Act.6:13; διδάσκειν, Act.21:28; ψεύδεσθαι, Jas.3:14; after verbs of accusing, etc, Mat.5:23, Luk.23:14, Rom.8:33, al; verbs of fighting, prevailing, etc, Mat.10:35, Act.14:2, 1Co.4:6, al; (b) of swearing, <b>by</b>: όμνυμι κ. (BL, §34, 1), He 6:13,16, cf. Mat.26:63. II. C. accusative (WM, §49d; BL, §42, 2). 1) <b>Of motion or direction</b>; (a) <b>through, throughout</b>: Luk.8:39 9:6 10:4, Act.8:1, 36 al; (b) <b>to, towards, over against</b>: Luk.10:32 (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 62), Act.2:1 o 16:7, Gal.2:11, Php.3:14, al; (with) in adverbial phrases, <b>at, in, by, of</b>: κατ᾽ οἶκον, <b>at home</b>, Act.2:46; κατ᾽ ἰδίαν (see: ἴδιος); καθ᾽ ἑαυτόν, Act.28:16, Rom.14:22, Jas.2:17; with pron. of person(s), Act.17:28 18:15, Rom.1:15, Eph.1:15, al. 2) Of time, <b>at, during, about</b>: Act.8:26 12:1 19:23, Rom.9:9 Heb.1:10, al. 3) <b>Distributive</b>; (a) <b>of place</b>: κ. τόποὐς, Mat.24:7, al; κ. πόλιν, Luk.8:1, 4 al; κ. ἐκκλησίαν, Act.14:23. (b) <b>of time</b>: κ. ἔτος, Luk.2:41; ἑορτήν, Mat.27:15, al; (with) of numbers, etc: καθ᾽ ἕνα πάντες, 1Co.14:31 (on καθ᾽ εἷς, see: εἷς); κ. ἑκατόν, Mrk.6:40; κ. μέρος, Heb.9:5; κ. ὄνομα, Jhn.10:3. 4) Of fitness, reference, conformity, etc; (a) <b>in relation to, concerning</b>: Rom.1:3, 4 7:22 9:3, 5, 1Co.12:6 10:18, Php.1:12; κ. πάντα, Act.17:22, Col.3:20, 22 Heb.2:17 4:15; (b) <b>according to, after, like</b>: Mrk.7:5, Luk.2:27, 29 Jhn.7:24 Rom.8:4 14:15, Eph.2:2, Col.2:8, Jas.2:8, al. III. In composition, κ. denotes, 1) <b>down, down from</b> (καταβαίνω), etc.), hence, metaph; (a) <b>victory or rule over </b>(καταδουλόω, -κυριεύω, etc.); (b) "perfective" action (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 111ff.). 2) <b>under</b> (κατακαλύπτω), etc.). 3) <b>in succession</b> (καθεξῆς). 4) <b>after, behind</b> (καταλείπω). 5) Hostility, <b>against</b> (καταλαλέω). (AS)
G2597	καταβαίνω	katabainō	to come/go down	G:V	<b>κατα-βαίνω </b> [in LXX chiefly for יָרַד;] to go or come down, descend. 1) <b>Of persons</b>: Mat.3:16 24:17, Luk.2:51 6:17 10:31 17:31 19:5-6, Jhn.4:47, 49 4:51 5:7, Act.7:34 8:15 10:20 20:10 23:10 24:1, 22 Eph.4:10. before ἀπό, Mat.8:1 14:29 27:40, 42 Mrk.3:22 15:30, Luk.10:30, Jhn.6:38, Act.25:7, 1Th.4:16; ἐκ, Mat.17:9; ἐκ τ. οὐρανοῦ, Mat.28:2, Mrk.9:9, Jhn.1:32 3:13 6:33, 41-42 6:50-51, 58 Rev.10:1 18:1 20:1; εἰς, Mrk.1:10, Luk.10:30 18:14, Jhn.2:12, Act.7:15 8:38 14:25 16:8 18:22 25:6, Rom.10:7, Eph.4:9; ἐπί, with accusative loc, Jhn.6:16; with accusative of person(s), Luk.3:22, Jhn.1:33, 51; ἐν, Jhn.5:4; πρός, with accusative of person(s), Act.10:21 14:11, Rev.12:12. 2) <b>Of things</b>: σκεῦος, Act.10:11 11:5; βροχή, Mat.7:25, 27; λαῖλαψ, Luk.8:23; before ἀπό, Luk.9:54, Act.8:26, Jas.1:17; ἐπὶ τ. γῆν, Luk.22:44 (WH, R, mg, reject); ἐκ τ. οὐρανοῦ before ἀπό, Rev.3:12 21:2, 10; id. before εἰς, Rev.13:13; ἐπί, with accusative of person(s), Rev.16:21. G2613	καταδικάζω	katadikazō	to condemn	G:V	<b>κατα-δικάζω </b> [in LXX: Psa.94:21 (רָשַׁע hi.), La 3:36 (עָוַת pi.), Wis.2:20, al;] <b>to pass sentence upon, condemn</b>; in cl, with genitive of person(s) (accusative of thing(s)); in late writers (so LXX), with accusative of person(s) (θανάτῳ, Wis, l.with): Mat.12:7, Jas.5:6; absol. (as Plat, Legg, 958c), Luk.6:37; pass, Mat.12:37, Luk.6:37. δικάζω, <b>to judge</b>: Luk.6:37 (Tr, mg; see: καταδ; Cremer, 199). (AS)

G2660	κατανύσσω	katanussō	to pierce	G:V	<b>κατα-νύσσω </b> [in LXX: Gen.34:7 (עָצַב hith.), Lev.10:3, Psa.4:4, Psa 29:12, al.
