(AS)
G2661	καταξιόω	kataxioō	to consider worthy	G:V	<b>κατ-αξιόω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: 2Ma.13:12, 3Ma.3:21 3Mac 4:11, 4Ma.18:3 *;] <b>to deem worthy</b>: with accusative of person(s) and genitive of thing(s), 2Th.1:5; pass. before inf, Luk.20:35, Act.5:41. (AS)
G2662	καταπατέω	katapateō	to trample	G:V	<b>κατα-πατέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX for דָּרַךְ, רָמַס, שָׁאַף, etc;] <b>to tread down, trample under foot</b>: Mat.7:6, Luk.12:1; pass, Mat.5:13, Luk.8:5. Metaph, τ. υἱὸν τ. θεοῦ, Heb.10:29. (AS)
G2663	κατάπαυσις	katapausis	rest	G:N-F	<b>κατά-παυσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; καταπαύω), [in LXX chiefly for מְנוּחָה, Psa.95:11, Isa.66:1, al; ἡμέρα τῆς κ, 2Ma.15:1] 1) in cl, a putting to rest, causing to cease. 2) <b>In LXX and NT, rest, repose</b>: Act.7:49 (LXX), Heb.3:11, 18 4:1, 3 4:5, 10-11 (AS)
G2664	καταπαύω	katapauō	to keep from	G:V	<b>κατα-παύω </b> [in LXX for נוּחַ, שָׁבַת, etc;] 1) trans, (a) <b>to cause to cease, restrain</b>: Act.14:18; (b) <b>to cause to rest</b>: Heb.4:8. 2) Intrans, <b>to rest</b>: before ἀτό, Heb.4:4 (LXX), Heb.4:10. (AS)
G2665	καταπέτασμα	katapetasma	curtain	G:N-N	<b>κατα-πέτασμα</b>, -τος, τό (= cl. παραπέτασμα) [in LXX chiefly for פֹּרֶכֶת (the veil of the Holy of Holies), Exo.26:31, Lev.21:23, al; also for מָסָךְ (the outer veil), Exo.35:12, Num_3:26, al. (elsewhere κάλυμμα);] <b>in NT always the inner veil or curtain of the Temple </b>(or Tabernacle): Mat.27:51, Mrk.15:38, Luk.23:45, Heb.6:19 9:3; figuratively, ἡ σὰρξ αὐτοῦ Heb.10:20. (AS)

G2818	κληρονόμος	klēronomos	heir	G:N-M	<b>κληρο-νόμος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; κλῆρος, νέμομαι, to possess) [in LXX: Jdg.18:7, 2Ki.14:7, Mic.1:15, Jer.8:10 (יָרַשׁ), Sir.23:22 *;] 1) (as in cl.) an heir: Mat.21:38, Mrk.12:7, Luk.20:14, Gal.4:1; of those who as sons of God inherit the privileges of the Messianic Kingdom; of Christ himself, Heb.1:2; of Abraham, Rom.4:13-14; of Christians, Rom.8:17, Gal.3:29, Tit.3:7, Jas.2:5. 2) (As in LXX: Jg, Mi, Je, ll. with) a possessor: Heb.6:17 11:7 (Cremer, 359 f.). (AS)
G2819	κλῆρος	klēros	lot	G:N-M	<b>κλῆρος</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX chiefly for נַחֲלָה גּוֹרָל;] <b>a lot</b>; (a) <b>that which is cast or drawn</b>: Mat.27:35, Mrk.15:24, Luk.23:34, Jhn.19:24 " (LXX), Act.1:26; (b) <b>that which is obtained by casting</b>: Act.1:17 8:21; of a part in the Kingdom of God (cf. Wis 55), Act.26:18, Col.1:12; pl. of the "cure" of a presbyter, 1Pe.5:3 (see <i>ICC</i>, in l). (AS)
G2820	κληρόω	klēroō	to obtain	G:V	<b>κληρόω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: 1Ki.14:41 (לָכַד ni.), Est.4:11 A (קָרָא ni.), Isa.17:11 *;] 1) to cast lots. 2) to choose by lot. 3) <b>to assign by lot, assign a portion</b>: pass, ἐν ᾧ καὶ ἐκληρώθημεν, Eph.1:11 (on the various interpretations, see <i>ICC</i>; AR; Ellic, in l). G2871	κοπή	kopē	slaughter	G:N-F	<b>κοπή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; κόπτω), [in LXX: Gen.14:17, Jos.10:20 (נָכָה hi, מַכָּה), Deu.28:25 (נָגַף), Jdth.15:7 *;] 1) in cl, a stroke, a pounding (as in a mortar). 2) <b>In LXX, a smiting in battle</b>: Heb.7:1 (LXX). (AS)
G2872	κοπιάω	kopiaō	to labor	G:V	<b>κοπιάω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; κόπος), [in LXX chiefly for יָגַע;] 1) (as in cl.) to grow weary: Mat.11:28, Jhn.4:6, Rev.2:3 (cf. Isa.40:31). 2) <b>Hence, in LXX and NT, to work with effort, to toil</b>: absol, Mat.6:23, Luk.5:5 12:27, Jhn.4:38, Act.20:35, 1Co.4:12, Eph.4:28, 2Ti.2:5; with accusative of thing(s), Jhn.4:38; freq. in Paul. G2962	κύριος	kurios	lord	G:N-M	<b>κύριος</b>, -α, -ον (also -ος, -ον), [in LXX (subst.) chiefly for יהוה, also for בַּעַל,אָדוֹן, etc;] <b>having power</b> (κῦρος) or <b>authority</b>; as subst, ὁ κ, <b>lord, master</b>; 1) <b>in general</b>: with genitive of thing(s), Mat.9:38 20:8, Mrk.12:9 13:35, Luk.19:33; τ. σαββάτου, Mat.12:8, Mrk.2:28, Luk.6:5; with genitive of person(s), δούλου, etc, Mat.10:24, Luk.14:21, Act.16:16, al; absol, opp. to οἱ δοῦλοι, Eph.6:5, 9 al; of the Emperor (Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 161), Act.25:26; θεοὶ πολλοὶ καὶ κ. πολλοί, 1Co.8:5; of a husband, 1Pe.3:6; in voc, as a title of respect to masters, teachers, magistrates, etc, Mat.13:27 16:22 27:63, Mrk.7:28, Luk.5:12, Jhn.4:11, Act.9:5, al. 2) <b>As a divine title </b>(freq. in π; Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 353 ff.); in NT, (a) <b>of God</b>: ὁ κ, Mat.5:33, Mrk.5:19, Luk.1:6, Act.7:33, Heb.8:2, Jas.4:15, al; anarth. G3004	λέγω	legō	to speak	G:V	<b>λέγω</b>, [in LXX very freq, chiefly for אמר; λέγει for נְאֻם, Gen.22:16, al;] 1) in Hom, <b>to pick out, gather, reckon, recount</b>. 2) In Hdt. and Att, <b>to say, speak, affirm, declare</b>: absol, Act.13:15, 24:10; before orat. dir, Mat.9:34, Mrk.3:11, Jhn.1:29, al; before ὅτι recit, Mrk.3:21, Luk.1:24, Jhn.6:14, al; accusative and inf, Luk.11:18, Jhn.12:29, al; after another verb of speaking, προσφωνεῖν κ. λέγειν, Mat.11:17, al; ἀπεκρίθη (ἐλάλησεν) λέγων (καὶ λέγει; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 24 ff.), Mat.25:9, Mrk.3:33, 7:28, Luk.24:6, 7, al; of unspoken thought, λ. ἐν ἑαυτῷ, Mat.3:9, Luk.3:8, al; of writing, 2Co.8:8, Php.4:11, al; λέγει ἡ γραφή, Rom.4:3, Jas.2:23, al; with accusative of thing(s), Luk.8:8, 9:33, Jhn.5:34, al; σὺ λέγεις (a non-committal phrase; Swete, <i>Mk.</i>, 359, 369f.), Mat.27:11, Mrk.15:2, Luk.23:3, Jhn.18:37; with dative of person(s), before orat. dir, Mat.8:20, Mrk.2:17, al. mult; id. before ὅτι, Mat.3:9, al; with prep, πρός, μετά, περί, etc, Mrk.4:41, Jhn.11:56, Heb.9:5, al; <b>to mean</b> (cl.), Mrk.14:71, Jhn.6:71, 1Co.10:29, al; <b>to call, name</b>, Mrk.10:18; pass, Mat.9:9, Mrk.15:7, al (cf. ἀντι, δια- (-μαι), προ, συλ-λέγω). G3008	λειτουργέω	leitourgeō	to minister	G:V	<b>λειτουργέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; λειτουργός), [in LXX chiefly for שָׁרַת pi, also for עָבַד, צָבָא, etc;] 1) in cl, at Athens, to supply public offices at one's own cost, render public service to the State, hence, generally, 2) <b>to serve the State, do a service, serve </b>(of service to the Gods, Diod, i, 21): of the official service of priests and Levites (Exo.29:30, Num.16:9, Sir.4:14, 1Ma.10:42, al; cf. (chiefly of Athens), the discharge of a public office at one's own expense (see LS, see word), hence, 2) <b>a service, ministry</b>; in π. (Deiss, BS, 140 f.) and in LXX (though here also of secular service, 3Ki.1:4, al.), of religious service or ministration; and so in NT: of priestly ministrations, Luk.1:23, Heb.8:6 9:21; figuratively, θυσία καὶ λ. τῆς πίστεως ὑμῶν, Php.2:17; of Christian beneficence, 2Co.9:12, Php.2:30. G3044	Λίνος	Linos	Linus	N:N-M-P	1. <b>Linos </b>, a mythical minstrel, son of Apollo and Urania (Calliope), teacher of Orpheus, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus), etc. 2. as appellative, <b>the song </b> or <b>lay of Linos </b>, sung by a boy to the cithara while the vintagers are at work, Λίνον ὑπὸ καλὸν ἄειδεν sang <b>the </b> lovely <b>lay of Linos </b> in accompaniment, (Iliad by Homer);compare αἴλινος which is <b>a mournful song. </b> (ML)
G3045	λιπαρός	liparos	rich	G:A	<b>λιπαρός</b>, -ά, -όν (&lt; λίπος, fat), [in LXX: Jdg.3:29, Neh.9:35, Is 30:23 (שָׁמֵן)*;] <b>oily, fatty</b>; metaph, of living, <b>rich, dainty</b>: τὰ λ. καὶ τ. λαμπρά, Rev.18:14. (AS)
G3046	λίτρα	litra	pound	G:N-F	<b>λίτρα</b>, -ας, ἡ (cf. Lat. libra), 1) a Sicilian coin = Rom. libra or as. 2) <b>In weight, a pound</b>: Jhn.12:3 19:39. (AS)

G3049	λογίζομαι	logizomai	to count	G:V	<b>λογίζομαι</b> (&lt; λόγος), [in LXX chiefly for חָשַׁב;] 1) prop, of numerical calculation, <b>to count, reckon</b>: with accusative before μετά, Mrk.15:23 (LXX) (Rec, R, mg.), Luk.22:37. 2) Metaph, without reference to numbers, by a reckoning of characteristics or reasons; (a) <b>to reckon, take into account</b>: with accusative of thing(s), 1Co.13:5; id. before dative of person(s), Rom.4:3 (LXX), Rom.4:4, 6 4:8 " (LXX), 2Co.5:19, 2Ti.4:16; before εἰς (cf. <i>Heb.</i> ל חָשַׁב; Bl, § 33, 3), Act.19:27, Rom.2:26 4:3, 5 4:9-11, 22-24 9:8 Gal.3:6 " (LXX), Jas.2:23 (LXX); (b) <b>to consider, calculate</b>: with accusative of thing(s), Php.4:8; before ὅτι, Jhn.11:50, Heb.11:10; τοῦτο, ὅτι, 2Co.10:11; with accusative of person(s), with inf, Rom.6:11; before ὡς, Rom.8:36 (LXX); (with) <b>to suppose, judge, deem</b>: 1Co.13:11; ὡς, 1Pe.5:12; οὕτως, 1Co.4:1; with accusative of thing(s), 2Co.3:5; id. before εἰς, 2Co.12:6; ὅτι, Rom.8:18; τοῦτο, ὅτι, Rom.2:3, 2Co.10:7; with inf, 2Co.11:5; accusative and inf, Rom.3:28 14:14, Php.3:13; with accusative of person(s) before ὡς, 2Co.10:2; (d) <b>to purpose, decide</b>: with inf. (Eur, Or, 555), 2Co.10:2 (cf. ἀνα, δια, παρα, συλ-λογίζομαι). (AS)

G3056	λόγος	logos	word	G:N-M	<b>λόγος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; λέγω) [in LXX chiefly for דָּבָר, also for מִלָּה,אֵמֶר, etc;] I. Of that by which the inward thought is expressed, Lat. oratio, sermo, vox, verbum. 1) <b>a word</b>, not in the grammatical sense of a mere name (ἔπος, ὄνομα, ῥῆμα), but a word as embodying a conception or idea: Mat.8:8, Luk.7:7, 1Co.14:9, 19 Heb.12:19, al. 2) <b>a saying, statement, declaration</b>: Mat.19:22 (T om.), Mrk.5:36 7:29, Luk.1:29, Jhn.2:22 6:60, Act.7:29, al; with genitive attrib, Act.13:15, Rom.9:9, Heb.7:28, al; of the sayings, commands, promises, etc, of teachers, Mat.7:24 10:14, Mrk.8:38, Luk.9:4, Jhn.14:24, al; λ. κενοί, Eph.5:6; ἀληθινοί, Rev.19:9; πιστοί, Rev.22:6; esp. of the precepts, decrees and promises of God, ὁ λ. τ. θεοῦ, <b>the word of God</b>: Mrk.7:13, Jhn.10:35, Rom.13:9, 1Co.14:36, Php.1:14, al; absol, ὁ λ, Mat.13:21, 22 Mrk.16:[20], Luk.1:2, Act.6:4, Heb.4:12, al. 3) <b>speech, discourse</b>: Act.14:12, 2Co.10:10, Jas.3:2; opp. to ἐπιστολή, 2Th.2:15; disting, from σοφία, 1Co.2:1; ἀναστροφή, 1Ti.4:12; δύναμις, 1Co.4:19, 1Th.1:5; ἔργον, Rom.15:18; οὐδενὸς λ. τίμιον (<b>not worthy of mention</b>), Act.20:24; of the faculty of speech, Luk.24:19, 2Co.11:6; of the style of speech, Mat.5:37, 1Co.1:5; of instruction, Col.4:3, 1Pe.3:1; with genitive of person(s), Jhn.5:24 8:52, Act.2:41, al; ὁ λ. ὁ ἐμός, Jhn.8:31; with genitive obj. (τ.) ἀληθείας, 2Co.6:7, Col.1:5, Jas.1:18; τ. καταλλαγῆς, 2Co.5:19; τ. σταυροῦ, 1Co.1:18; of mere talk, 1Co.4:19, 2o, Col.2:23, 1Jn.3:18; of the talk which one occasions, hence, <b>repute</b>: Col.2:23. 4) subject-matter, hence, <b>teaching, doctrine</b>: Act.18:15, 2Ti.2:17, al; esp. of Christian doctrine: Mat.13:20-23, Mrk.4:14-20 8:32, Luk.1:2, Act.8:4, Gal.6:6, 1Th.1:6, al; with genitive of person(s), τ. θεοῦ, Luk.5:1, Jhn.17:6, Act.4:29, 1Co.14:36, I Jhn.1:10, Rev.6:9, al; τ. Κυρίου, Act.8:25, 1Th.1:8, al; τ. Χριστοῦ, Col.3:16, Rev.3:8; with genitive appos, Act.15:7; with genitive attrib, Heb.5:13. 5) <b>a story, tale, narrative</b>: Mat.28:15, Jhn.21:23, Act.1:1 11:22; before περί, Luk.5:15. 6) That which is spoken of (Plat, al; V. Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 124), <b>matter, affair, thing</b>: Mat.21:24, Mrk.1:45 11:29, Luk.20:3, Act.8:21; of a matter in dispute, as a case or suit at law, Act.19:38; pl. (1Ma.7:33, al.), Luk.1:4. II. Of the inward thought itself, Lat. ratio. 1) <b>reason</b>, (a) <b>of the mental faculty </b>(Hdt, Plat, al.): κατὰ λόγον, Act.18:14; (b) <b>a reason, cause</b>: τίνι λόγῳ, Act.10:29; παρεκτὸς λόγου πορνείας, Mat.5:32 19:9, WH, mg, R, mg. 2) <b>account</b>, (a) <b>regard</b>: Act.20:24, Rec; (b) <b>reckoning</b>: Php.4:15, 17; συναίρειν (which see) λ, Mat.18:23 25:19; in forensic sense, Rom.14:12, Heb.13:17, 1Pe.4:5; with genitive of thing(s), Luk.16:2; before περί, Mat.12:36, Act.19:40, 1Pe.3:15. 3) <b>proportion, analogy</b>: Php.2:16 (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 193 f.). III. ὁ λ, the Divine <b>Word</b> or <b>Logos</b>: Jhn.1:1, 14; τ. ζωῆς, 1Jn.1:1; τ. θεοῦ, Rev.19:13 (see Westc, Swete, <i>CGT</i>, in ll; reff. in Artt, <i>Logos</i>, <i>DB</i>, <i>DCG</i>). (AS)

G3083	λύτρον	lutron	ransom	G:N-N	<b>λύτρον</b>, -ον, τό (&lt; λύω), [in LXX (Pent.15 Pr.2, Isa.1) for פִּדְיוֹם and cogn. forms, גְּאֻלָּה, כֹּפֶר, מְחִיר;] a ransom (as for a life, Exo.21:30; for slaves, Lev.19:20; for captives, Isa.45:13): ἀντὶ πολλῶν, Mat.20:28, Mrk.10:45 (see Swete, in l, and for discussion of λ. and its cognates, Westc, He, 295 f; Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 331 f; cf. also ἀντί-λύτρον). G3084	λυτρόω	lutroō	to ransom	G:V	<b>λυτρόω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; λύτρον, which see), [in LXX chiefly for פָּדָה, גָּאַל;] <b>to release on receipt of ransom</b>; mid, <b>to release by paying ransom, to redeem</b>: in spiritual sense, Tit.2:14; pass, 1Pe.1:18; in general sense, to deliver (cf. G3122	μάλιστα	malista	especially	G:Adv	<b>μάλιστα</b>, see: μάλα. <b>μάλα </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX for אֲבָל, 3Ki.1:43, Dan LXX 10:21, al; compar. for מ, Num.13:32 (31), al; μᾶλλον ἠ (מ), Gen.19:9, al; superlat, 2Ma.8:7, 4Ma.4:22 12:9 15:4;] I. Compar, μᾶλλον. 1) Of increase, <b>more</b>; with qualifying words: πολλῷ, Mrk.10:48, Luk.18:39, Rom.5:15, 17, Php.2:12, al; πόσῳ, Luk.12:24, Rom.11:12, al; τοσούτῳ. ὅσῳ, Heb.10:25. 2) Of comparison, <b>the more</b>: Luk.5:15, Jhn.5:18, Act.5:14, 1Th.4:1, 10, 2Pe.1:10; ἔτι μ. καὶ μ, Php.1:9; with compar, Mrk.7:36, 2Co.7:13; πολλῴ μ. κρεῖσον, Php.1:23; μ. διαφέρειν, with genitive, Mat.6:26; μ. ἤ, Mat.18:13; with genitive, 1Co.14:18; as periphr. for compar, Act.20:35, 1Co.9:15, Gal.4:27; μ. δέ (EV, <b>yea rather</b>), Rom.8:34. 3) Of preference, <b>rather, the rather, sooner</b>: with qualifying words, πολλῷ, Mat.6:30, al; πολύ, Heb.12:25; πόσῳ, Mat.7:11, al; in a question, οὐ μ, 1Co.9:12; after a neg, Mat.10:6, al; θέλω (εὐδοκῶ) μ, 1Co.14:5, 2Co.5:8; ζηλῶ, 1Co.14:1; with subst, τ. σκότος ἢ τ. φῶς, Jhn.3:19; μ. δέ, Gal.4:9. G3303	μέν	men	on the other hand	G:Part	<b>μέν</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i> (originally a form of μήν), usually related to a following δέ or other adversative conjunction, and distinguishing the word or clause with which it stands from that which follows. It is generally untranslatable and is not nearly so frequent in NT as in cl. Like δέ, it never stands first in a clause. 1) <b>Answered by δέ or some other particle</b>: μὲν. δέ, <b>indeed. but</b>, Mat.3:11, Luk.3:16, al; with pronouns, ὃς μὲν. ὃς δέ, <b>one. another</b>, Mat.21:35, al; pl, Php.1:16, 17; ὃ μὲν. ὃ δὲ. ὃ δέ, some. some. some, Mat.13:8; τοῦτο μὲν. τοῦτο δέ, partly. partly, Heb.10:33; μὲν. ἔπειτα, Jhn.11:6; μὲν. καί, Luk.8:5. 2) <b>μέν solitarium, answered by no other particle</b>: πρῶτον μέν (Bl, l.with), Rom.1:8 3:2, 1Co.11:18; μὲν οὖν in narrative, summing up what precedes or introducing something further (Bl, §78, 5), <b>so then, rather, nay rather</b>: Luk.11:28 (WH, μενοῦν), Act.1:6 9:31, al; μὲν οὖν γε (Php.3:8, WH): see: μενοῦνγε. (AS)
G3304	μενοῦνγε	menounge	rather	G:Part	<b>μεν-οῦν-γε</b> = μὲν οὖν γε <b>nay rather</b>: Rom.9:20 10:18, Php.3:8. (AS)

(iii) <b>Of condition</b>: with pred, μόνος, Jhn.12:24; ἄγαμος, 1Co.7:11; πιστός, 2Ti.2:13; ἱερεύς, Heb.7:3; with adv, οὕτως, 1Co.7:40; ὡς κἀγώ, ib. 8; before ἐν, ib. 20, 24. 2) Trans. G3307	μερίζω	merizō	to divide	G:V	<b>μερίζω</b> (&lt; μέρος), [in LXX chiefly for חָלַק;] <b>to divide</b>; (a) <b>to divide into parts </b>: metaph, pass, 1Co.7:34 (WH, R, ing.), 1Co.7:34 (Rec, R, txt.) Polyb, xi, 28, 9), <b>to bestow</b>: Rom.12:3, 1Co.7:17, 2Co.10:13, Heb.7:2; mid, with accusative of thing(s) before μετά, Luk.12:13 (cf. δια, συμ-μερίζω). (AS)

G3326	μετά	meta	with/after	G:Prep	<b>μετά</b> (before vowel μετ᾽; on the neglect of elision in certain cases, V. WH, <i>App.</i>, 146 b), <i>prep.</i> with genitive, accusative (in poet, also with dative), [in LXX for אַחַד,עִם,אֵת, etc.]. I. C. genitive, 1) <b>among, amid</b>: Mrk.1:13, Luk.22:37 (LXX, ἐν) 24:5, Jhn.18:5, al; διωγμῶν, Mrk.10:30. 2) <b>Of association and companionship, with </b>(in which sense it gradually superseded σύν, than which it is much more freq. in NT; cf. Bl, §42, 3): with genitive of person(s), Mat.8:11 20:20 Mrk.1:29 3:7 Luk.5:30, Jhn.3:22, Gal.2:1, al. mult; εἶναι μετά, Mat.5:25, Mrk.3:14, al; metaph, of divine help and guidance, Jhn.3:2, Act.7:9, Php.4:9, al; opp. to εἶναι κατά, Mat.12:30, Luk.11:23; in Hellenistic usage (but see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 106, 246f.), πολεμεῖν μετά = cl. π, with dative, <b>to wage war against</b> (so LXX for נִלְחַם עִם, 1Ki.17:33), Rev.2:16, al; with genitive of thing(s), χαρᾶς, Mat.13:20, Mrk.4:16, al; ὀργῆς, Mrk.3:5, al. II. C. accusative, 1) of place, <b>behind, after</b>: Heb.9:3. 2) Of time, <b>after</b>: Mat.17:1, Mrk.14:1, Luk.1:24, Act.1:5, Gal.1:18, al; μετὰ τοῦτο, Jhn.2:12, al; ταῦτα, Mrk.16:[12], Luk.5:27, Jhn.3:22, al; with inf. artic. (BL, §71, 5; 72, 3), Mat.26:32, Mrk.1:14, al. III. In composition, 1) <b>of association or community</b>: μεταδίδωμι, μετέχω, etc. 2) <b>Exchange or transference</b>: μεταλλάσσω, μετοικίζω, etc. 3) <b>after</b>: μεταμέλομαι. (AS)

G3349	μετεωρίζω	meteōrizō	to worry	G:V	<b>μετ-εωρίζω</b> (&lt; μετέωρος, (a) in mid air; (b) buoyed up; (with) in suspense; Thuc; in π. opp. to ἀμέριμνος, see Zorell, see word) [in LXX: Ob 4 (גָּבַהּ hi.), Mic.4:1 (נָשָׂא ni.), Psa.131:1, Eze.10:16-17, 19 (רוּם), 2Ma.5:17 2Mac 7:34, 3Ma.6:5 *;] to raise on high (Thue, Xen, al; Ob, Mi, Ez, ll with). Metaph, (a) <b>to buoy up</b>; pass, to be elated, puffed up (Polyb, al, Psa.2:1-12, 3 Mac, ll. with) (b) to be anxious, in suspense (Polyb, see 70, 10; FlJ, BJ, iv, 2, 5): Luk.12:29. (AS)

G3360	μέχρι	mechri	until	G:Prep	<b>μέχρι</b> (bef. consonants, exc. G3361	μή	mē	not	G:Neg	<b>μή</b>, <i>subjective negative particle</i>, used where the negation depends on a condition or hypothesis, expressed or understood, as distinct from οὐ, which denies absolutely. μή is used where one <i>thinks</i> a thing is not, as distinct from an absolute negation. As a general rule, οὐ negatives the indic, μή the other moods, incl, ptcp. [In LXX for אֵין,אַיִן,אַל] I. As a neg. adv, <b>not</b>; 1) with ref. to thought or opinion: Jhn.3:18, Tit.1:11, 2Pe.1:9. 2) In delib. questions, with subjc. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 185): Mrk.12:14, Rom.3:8. 3) <b>In conditional and final sentences, after εἰ, ἐάν, ἄν, ἵνα, ὅπως</b>: Mat.10:14, Mrk.6:11 12:19, Luk.9:5, Jhn.6:50, Rom.11:25, al. 4) C. inf. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 234f, 239, 255), (a) after verbs of saying, etc: Mat.2:12 5:34, Mrk.12:18, Act.15:38, Rom.2:21, al; (b) with artic. inf: after a prep, Mat.13:5, Mrk.4:5, Act.7:19, 1Co.10:6, al; without a prep, Rom.14:13, 2Co.2:1, 13 1Th 4:6; (with) <b>in sentences expressing consequence, after ὥστε</b>: Mat.8:28, Mrk.3:20, 1Co.1:7, 2Co.3:7, al. 5) C. ptcp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 231f, 239), in hypothetical references to persons of a certain character or description: Mat.10:28 12:30, Luk.6:49, Jhn.3:18, Rom.4:5, 1Co.7:38, 1Jn.3:10, al; where the person or thing being definite, the denial is a matter of opinion: Jhn.6:64, 1Co.1:28 4:7, 18, 2Co.5:21, al; where the ptcp. has a concessive, causal or conditional force, <b>if, though, because not</b>: Mat.18:25, Luk.2:45, Jhn.7:49, Act.9:26, Rom.2:14 5:13, 2Co.3:14, Gal.6:9, Ju 5; where the ptcp. has a descriptive force (<i>being such as</i>), <b>not</b>: Act.9:9, Rom.1:28, 1Co.10:33, Gal.4:8, Heb.12:27, al. 6) μή prohibitive, in indep. sentences, (a) with subjc. praes, 1 of person(s) pl: Gal.5:26 6:9, 1Th.5:6, 1Jn.3:18; (b) with imperat. praes, <b>usually where one is bidden to desist from what has already begun </b>(cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 122ff.): Mat.7:1, Mrk.5:36, Luk.6:30, Jhn.2:16 5:45, Act.10:15, Rom.11:18, Jas.2:1, Rev.5:5, al; (with) <b>forbidding that which is still future</b>: with imperat. aor, 3 of person(s), Mat.24:18, Mrk.13:15, Luk.17:31, al; with subjc. aor, 2 of person(s), Mat.3:9 10:26, Mrk.5:7, Luk.6:29, Jhn.3:7, Rom.10:6, al; (d) with optative, <b>in wishes</b>: 2Ti.4:16 (LXX); μὴ γένοιτο (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194; Bl, §66, 1), Luk.20:16, Rom.3:3, al; μή τις, Mrk.13:5, al. II. As a conj, 1) after verbs of fearing, caution, etc, <b>that, lest, perhaps</b> (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 192f.): with subjc. praes, Heb.12:15; with subjc. aor, Mat.24:4, Mrk.13:5, Luk.21:8, Act.13:40, Gal.5:15, al; ὅρα μή (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 124, 178), elliptically, Rev.19:10 22:9; with indic, fut. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, l.with), Col.2:8. 2) <b>in order that not</b>: with subjc. aor, Mrk.13:36, 2Co.8:20 12:6. III. Interrogative, in hesitant questions (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 170), or <b>where a negative answer is expected</b>: Mat.7:9, 10, Mrk.2:19, Jhn.3:4, Rom.3:3 10:18, 19, 1Co.1:13, al; μή τις, Luk.22:35, al; before οὐ (Rom.10:17, al. in Pl.), expecting an affirm, ans; οὐ μή, Luk.18:7, Jhn.18:11. IV. οὐ μή as emphatic negation (cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 188, 190ff; Bl. §64, 5), <b>not at all, by no means</b>: with indic, fut, Mat.16:22, Jhn.6:35, Heb.10:17, al; with subjc. aor, Mat.24:2, Mrk.13:2, Luk.6:37, Jhn.13:8, 1Co.8:13, al. (AS)

G3378	μὴ οὐκ	mē ouk	isn't it? G3379	μήποτε	mēpote	lest	G:Neg	<b>μήποτε</b> (= μή ποτε, and so written in WH, exc. Mat.25:9), negative particle, related to οὔποτε as μή to οὐ. 1) As neg. particle, <b>never</b>: Heb.9:17 (R, mg, but see infr; WH, txt, μή τότε). 2) As conjc, lest ever, lest haply (the idea of chance rather than of time seems to prevail in NT): Mat.4:6 (LXX) Mat.5:25 7:6 13:15 " (LXX), Mat.13:29 15:32 27:64, Mrk.4:12 " (LXX) Mrk.14:2, Luk.4:11 12:58 14:12, 29, Act.28:27; after verbs of fearing or taking heed, Luk.21:34, Heb.2:1 3:12 4:1; with ellipse of the verb or ptcp, Luk.14:8, Act.5:39; in later writers (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 192 f.), perhaps, Mat.25:9. 3) <b>As interrogative</b>; (a) <b>in direct questions, like μή, expecting a negative answer</b>: Jhn.7:26, Heb.9:17, (R, txt, cf. Westc, in l; but see supr.); (b) <b>in indirect questions, whether haply, if haply</b>: Luk.3:15, 2Ti.2:25. (AS)

M, <i>Th.</i>, in l, but see supr.). μήπου (WH, μή που), <b>lest anywhere, lest haply</b>: Act.27:29. (AS)

G3383	μήτε	mēte	neither	G:Neg+G:Conj	<b>μή-τε </b> <b>negative particle, differing from οὔτε as μή from οὐ, neither, nor</b>: μήτε. μήτε, neither. nor, Mat.11:18, Luk.7:33 9:3, Act.23:12, 21 27:20, Heb.7:3; μὴ (μηδὲ). μήτε. μήτε, Mat.5:34, 36, Mrk.3:20 T, Act.23:8, 2Th.2:2, 1Ti.1:7, Jas.5:12, Rev.7:1, 3. (AS)
G3384	μήτηρ	mētēr	mother	G:N-F	<b>μήτηρ </b> genitive, μητρός, ἡ, [in LXX chiefly for אֵם;] <b>mother</b>: Mat.1:18 2:11, al; figuratively, of one who takes the place of a mother, ἰδοὺ, ἡ μ. μου, Mat.12:49 (cf. Mat.12:50, Mrk.3:35, Jhn.19:27, Rom.16:13, 1Ti.5:2); of a city, ἥτις ἐσὶν μ. ἡμῶν, Gal.4:26; symbolically of Babylon, ἡ μ. τ. πορνῶν, Rev.17:5 (AS)
G3385	μήτι	mēti	surely not	G:Neg+G:Conj	<b>μή-τι </b> interrog. particle, <b>expecting a negative answer</b>: Mat.7:16 26:22, 25, Mrk.4:21 14:19, Luk.6:39, Jhn.8:22 18:35, Act.10:47, 2Co.12:18, Jas.3:11; in hesitant questions (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 170.), μ οὗτός ἐστιν, can this be, Mat.12:23, Jhn.4:29; μ. ἄρα, 2Co.1:17; On εἰ μήτι (Luk.9:13, cf. Bl, § 65, 6), see: εἰ. <b>εἰ</b>, <i>conjunctive particle</i>, used in conditions and in indirect questions. I. Conditional, <b>if</b>; 1) with indic, expressing a general assumption; (a) pres: before indic, pres, Mat.11:14, Rom.8:25, al; before imperat, Mrk.4:23 9:22, Jhn.15:18, 1Co.7:9, al; before fut. indic, Luk.16:31, Rom.8:11, al; before pf. or aor, with negation in apodosis, Mat.12:26, Rom.4:14, al; similarly, before impf, Luk.17:6, Jhn.8:39; before quæst, Mat.6:23, Jhn.5:47 7:23 8:46, 1Pe.2:20; (b) fut: Mat.26:33, 1Pe.2:20; (with) pf: Jhn.11:12, Rom.6:5, al; (d) aor: Luk.16:11 19:8, Jhn.13:32, 18:23, Rev.20:15, al. 2) <b>Where the assumption is certain = ἐπεί</b>: Mat.12:28, Jhn.7:4, Rom.5:17, al. 3) Of an unfulfilled condition, with indic, impf, aor. or plpf, before ἄν, with imp. or aor. (see: ἄν, I, i). 4) C. indic, after verbs denoting wonder, etc, sometimes, but not always, coupled with an element of doubt: Mrk.15:44, 1Jn.3:13, al. 5) C. indic, as in LXX (Num.14:3 o, 1Ki.14:45, al. = Heb. אִם), in oaths, with the formula of imprecation understood in a suppressed apodosis (WM, 627; Burton, §272): Mrk.8:12, Heb.3:11 " (LXX) 4:3 (LXX). 6) Rarely (cl.) with optative, <b>to express a merely possible condition</b>: Act.24:19 27:39, 1Co.14:10 15:37, I Pe3:14, 17. II. Interrogative, <b>if, whether</b>. 1) As in cl, in indir. questions after verbs of seeing, asking, knowing, saying, etc: with indic. pres, Mat.26:63, Mrk.15:36, Act.19:2, 2Co.13:5, al; fut, Mrk.3:2, Act.8:22, al; aor, Mrk.15:44, 1Co.1:16, al; with subjc. aor. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 194), Php.3:12. 2) As in LXX (= Heb. אִם and interrog. הֲ, Gen.17:17, al; see WM, 639f; Viteau, i, 22), <b>in direct questions</b>: Mrk.8:23 (Tr, WH, txt.), Luk.13:23, 22:49, Act.19:2, al. III. With other particles. 1) εἰ ἄρα, εἴγε, εἰ δὲ μήγε, see: ἄρα, γε. 2) εἰ δὲ καί, <b>but if also</b>: Luk.11:18; <b>but even if</b>, 1Co.4:7, 2Co.4:3 11:16. 3) εἰ δὲ μή, <b>but if not, but if otherwise</b>: Mrk.2:21, 22 Jhn.14:2, Rev.2:5, al. 4) εἰ καί, <b>if even, if also, although</b>: Mrk.14:29, Luk.11:8, 1Co.7:21, 2Co.4:16, Php.2:17, al. 5) καὶ εἰ, <b>even if</b>, see: καί 6) εἰ μή, <b>if not, unless, except, but only</b>: Mat.24:22, Mrk.2:26 6:5, Jhn.9:33, 1Co.7:17 (<b>only</b>), Gal.1:19 (cf. ἐὰν μή, 2:16; see Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, xvi); ἐκτὸς εἰ μή, pleonastic (Bl, §65, 6), 1Co.14:5 15:2, 1Ti.5:19. 7) εἰ μήν = cl. ἦ μήν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 46), in oaths, <b>surely</b> (Eze.33:27, al.): Heb.6:14. 8) εἴ πως, <b>if haply</b>: Act.27:12, Rom.1:10. 9) εἴτε. εἴτε, <b>whether. or</b>; Rom.12:6-8, 1Co.3:22 13:8, al. (AS)

G3417	μνεία	mneia	remembrance	G:N-F	<b>μνεία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; μιμνήσκω), [in LXX for זָכַר, its parts and deriva­tives;] remembrance, mention (= μνήμη): Php.1:3; μ. ποιεῖσθαι, with genitive of person(s), Rom.1:9, Eph.1:16, 1Th.1:2, Phm 4 (cf. G3418	μνῆμα	mnēma	tomb	G:N-N	<b>μνῆμα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; μνάομαι), [in LXX for קֶבֶר, קְבוּרָה;] 1) a memorial. 2) <b>a sepulchral monument, a sepulchre, tomb</b>: Mrk.5:3, 5 15:46 16:2 (WH, μνημεῖον), Luk.8:27 23:53 24:1, Act.2:29 7:16, Rev.11:9. (AS)
G3419	μνημεῖον	mnēmeion	grave	G:N-N	<b>μνημεῖον</b>, -ου, τό [in LXX for קֶבֶר, קְבוּרָה;] 1) a memorial, record (cl, cf. Wis.10:7). 2) (a) (cl.) a monument: Luk.11:47; (b) a sepulchre, tomb (Gen.23:6, 9, Isa.22:16, al.): Mat.23:29, Mrk.5:2, Luk.11:44, Jhn.5:28, and freq. in Gospels, Act.13:29 (AS)
G3420	μνήμη	mnēmē	remembrance	G:N-F	<b>μνήμη</b>, -ης, ἡ (&lt; μνάομαι), [in LXX for זֵכֶר, זִכְרוֹן;] <b>memory, remembrance, mention</b>: μ. ποιεῖσθαι, with genitive, to remember, 2Pe.1:15 (but in cl, π, μ. π. more freq. = to make mention, and so perh. here, cf. Mayor, in l; and for ex. from π, see Zorell, see word). (AS)
G3421	μνημονεύω	mnēmoneuō	to remember	G:V	<b>μνημονεύω</b> (&lt; μνήμων, mindful) [in LXX for זָכַר;] 1) <b>to call to mind, remember </b>: absol, Mrk.8:18; with genitive of person(s), Luk.17:32, Col.4:18, 1Th.1:3, Heb.11:15 (but see infr.) Heb.13:7; τ. πτωχῶν, Gal.2:20; with genitive of thing(s), Jhn.15:20 16:4, 21, Act.20:35; with accusative obj. (as more freq. in cl.), of persons, 2Ti.2:8; of things, Mat.16:9, 1Th.2:9, Rev.18:5; before ὅτι, Act.20:31, Eph.2:11, 2Th.2:5; πόθεν, Rev.2:5; πῶς, Rev.3:3. 2) <b>to make mention of</b>: with genitive, Heb.11:15 (but see supr, and cf. M, <i>Th.</i>, I, 18); before περί, Heb.11:22. (AS)
G3422	μνημόσυνον	mnēmosunon	memorial	G:N-N	<b>μνημόσυνον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; μνήμων, mindful), [in LXX freq. for זֵכֶר, זִכְרוֹן and cogn. forms;] <b>a memorial</b>: Mat.26:13, Mrk.14:9, Act.10:4 (where cf. Lev.2:9, 16 5:12, Num_5:28, Sir.45:16, al.). (AS)
G3423	μνηστεύω	mnēsteuō	to betroth	G:V	<b>μνηστεύω </b> [in LXX for אָרַשׂ pi, pu;] 1) to woo and win, espouse. 2) <b>to promise in marriage, betroth</b>; pass, of the woman, <b>to be be­trothed</b>: with dative of person(s), Mat.1:18, Luk.1:27 2:5. (AS)
G3424	μογιλάλος	mogilalos	hardly talking	G:A	<b>μογι-λάλος</b>, -ον (&lt; μόγις, λάλος), [in LXX: Isa.35:6 (אִלֵּם) *;] <b>speaking with difficulty</b>: Mrk.7:32 (Tr, txt, μογγιλάλος, thick-voiced, see Swete, in l). (AS)
G3425	μόγις	mogis	hardly	G:Adv	<b>μόγις</b> <i> adv.</i> (&lt; μόγος, toil), [in LXX: Wis.9:16 א A (μόγις, B), 3Ma.7:6 *;] <b>with toil or difficulty, hardly</b>: Luk.9:39 (μόγις, WH). (AS)
G3426	μόδιος	modios	bucket	G:N-M	<b>μοιχαλίς</b>, -ίδος, ἡ (= Att. μοιχάς, fem. of μοιχός), [in LXX: Pro.18:22 30:20), Eze.16:38 23:45, Hos.3:1, Mal.3:5 (נַאֲפוּף, נָאַף) *;] <b>an adulteress</b>: Rom.7:3; meton, for μοιχεία, 2Pe.2:14. Metaph, of infidelity to God (cf. Eze.16:15 ff. Eze.23:43 ff, al.), Jas.4:4; as an adj, Mat.12:39 16:4, Mrk.8:8. (AS)
G3427	μοί	moi	to me	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)

(נָאַף);] <b>to commit adultery</b>: absol, Mat.5:27 19:18, Mrk.10:19, Luk.16:18 18:20, Rom.2:22 13:9, Jas.2:11; with accusative fem, Mat.5:28. Pass, of the woman, Mat.5:32 19:9 WH, mg.), Jhn.8:4. Metaph, of idolatry (see: μιοιχαλίς, and cf. Jer.3:9, a1.), before μετ᾽ αὐτῆς, Rev.2:22. (AS)

G3440	μόνον	monon	only	G:Adv	<b>μόνον</b>, see: μόνος. <b>μόνος</b>, -η, -ον, [in LXX chiefly for לְבַד;] 1) <i>adj.</i>, <b>alone, solitary, forsaken</b>: with verb, Mat.14:23, Mrk.6:47, Luk.9:36, al; with pron, Mat.18:15, Mrk.9:2, al; with subst, Mrk.9:8, Luk.4:8, al; pleonast, οὐκ. εἰ μὴ μ, Mat.12:4, Luk.6:4, al; attrib, only, (ὁ) μ. θεός, Jhn.5:44 17:3, Rom.16:27, 1Ti.1:17, Ju 25. 2) As <i>adv</i>, (a) neut, (μόνον, <b>alone, only</b>: referring to verb or predic, Mat.9:21, Mrk.5:36, Jas.1:22, al. G3450	μοῦ	mou	of me	G:PerP	<b>ἐγώ</b>, genitive, etc, ἐμοῦ, ἐμοί, ἐμέ (enclitic μου, μοι, με), pl. ἡμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς, <i>of person(s) pron.</i> <b>I</b>. (a) The nom. is usually emphatic, when expressed as subjc, as in Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:8, Luk.3:16, al. But often there is no apparent emphasis, as Mat.10:16, Jhn.10:17; ἰδοὺ ἐ. (= Heb. הִנֵּנִי, cf. 1Ki.3:8), Act.9:10; ἐ. (like Heb. אֲנִי), <b>I am</b>, Jhn.1:23 (LXX), Act.7:32 (LXX). (b) The enclitic forms (see supr.) are used with nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, where there is no emphasis: ἐν τ. πατρί μου, Jhn.14:20; μου τ. λόγους, Mat.7:24; ὀπίσω μου, Mat.3:11; ἰσχυρότερός μου, ib; λέγει μοι, Rev.5:5; also with the prep. πρός, as Mrk.9:19, al. The full forms (ἐμοῦ, etc.) are used with the other prepositions, as δι᾽ ἐμοῦ, ἐν ἐμοί, εἰς ἐμέ, etc, also for emphasis, as Luk.10:16, Jhn.7:23, Mrk.14:7, al. (with) The genitive μου and ἡμῶν are often used for the poss. pronouns ἐμός, ἡμέτερος: τ. λαόν μου, Mat.2:6; μου τῂ ἀπιστιᾳ, Mrk.9:24. (d) τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί (= Heb. מַה־לִי וָלָךְ, Jdg.11:12, al.), i.e. <b>what have we in common</b>: Mat.8:29, Mrk.1:24, 5:7, Luk.8:28, Jhn.2:4; τί γάρ μοι, 1Co.5:2. (e) The interchange of ἐγώ and ἡμεῖς, common in π, appears in Pauline Epp. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86f, M, <i>Th.</i>, 131f.). (f) κἀγώ (= καὶ ἐγώ, <b>and I, even I, I also</b>: Mat.2:8, Luk.2:48, Jhn.6:56, Rom.3:7, 1Co.7:40, al; κἀγώ. καί, <b>both. and</b>, Jhn.7:28. (AS)

G3466	μυστήριον	mustērion	mystery	G:N-N	<b>μυστήρισν</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; μυέω), [in LXX: Dan LXX TH Dan.2:18 ff. (רָז), Tob.12:7, 11, Jdth.2:2, Wis.2:22 6:22 14:15, 23, Sir.3:18 22:22 27:16-17, 21, 2Ma.13:21 *;] 1) that which is known to the μύστης (initiated), a mystery or secret doctrine, mostly in pl, τὰ μ. (Æsch, Hdt, al.). 2) In later writers (Menand, Incert, 168), that which may not be revealed (not, however, as in the modern sense, intrinsically difficult to understand), a secret or mystery of any kind (To, Jth, 2Mac, ll, with). 3) In NT, of the counsels of God (cf. <i>Th.</i>: Job.15:8, Psa.25:14 for סוֹד), once hidden but now revealed in the Gospel or some fact thereof; (a) <b>of the Christian revelation generally </b>: Rom.16:25, 1Co.2:7, Col.1:26-27, Eph.3:3, 9; τ. βασιλείας τ. θεοῦ, Mrk.4:11; τ. θεοῦ, 1Co.2:1, Rev.10:7; τ. θ, Χριστοῦ, Col.2:2; τ. Χριστοῦ, Col.4:3, Eph.3:4; τ. θελήματος αὐτοῦ, Eph.1:9; τ. εὐαγγελίον, Eph.6:19; τ. πίστεως, 1Ti.3:9; τ. εὐσεβείας, 1Ti.3:16; (b) <b>of particular truths, or details, of the Christian revelation </b>: Rom.11:25, 1Co.15:51, Eph.5:32, 2Th.2:7, Rev.1:20 17:5, 7; pl, τὰ μ, 1Co.13:2 14:2; θεοῦ, 1Co.4:1; τ. βασιλείας τ. οὐρανῶν (θεοῦ), Mat.13:11, Luk.8:10 (cf. Westc, <i>Eph.</i>, 180 ff; AR, <i>Eph.</i>, 234 ff; Lft, Col, 165 f; Hatch, <i>Essays</i>, 57 f; <i>DB</i>, iii, 465 ff; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 213 ff.). (AS)

Χριστοῦ, Gal.6:2. 6) By meton, of the books which contain the law; (a) <b>of the Pentateuch</b>: Mat.12:5, Jhn.1:45, al; ὁ ν. καὶ οἱ προφῆται, Mat.5:17, Luk.16:16, al; ὁ ν. καὶ προφῆται κ. ψαλμοί, Luk.24:44. (cf. cl. νυμφαγωγός, νυμφευτής), the bridegroom's friends who have charge of the nuptial arrangements: Mat.9:15, Mrk.2:19, Luk.5:34. (AS)
G3568	νῦν	nun	now	G:Adv	<b>νῦν</b>, <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX chiefly for עַתָּה;] 1) prop, of time, <b>now</b>, i.e. at the present time: as opp. to past, Jhn.4:18, Act.7:52, Rom.13:11, 2Co.7:9, Col.1:24, al; opp. to fut, Jhn.12:27, Rom.11:31, al; with art, ὁ (ἡ, τὸ) and subst, <b>the present</b>: Rom.3:26, Gal.4:25, 1Ti.6:17, Tit.2:12, al; απὸ τοῦ ν. (LXX for מֵעַתָּה), Luk.1:48, Act.18:6, al; ἄχρι τοῦ ν, Rom.8:22, Php.1:5; ἕως τοῦ ν. (LXX for עַד עַתָּה), Mat.24:21, Mrk.13:19; τὰ ν, <b>as regards the present</b>, Act.5:38; with pret, <b>just now, but now</b>, Mat.26:65, Jhn.11:8 21:10; with fut, <b>now, presently</b>, Jhn.12:31, Act.20:22; so with praes, <b>presently, forthwith</b>, Jhn.12:31 17:13; καὶ ν, Jhn.11:22 17:5, al; ἀλλὰ ν, Luk.22:36; ἔτι ν, 1Co.3:2; τότε (πότε). ν. (δέ), Rom.6:21 11:30; ν. ἤδη, 1Jn.4:3; ν. οὖν, Act.10:33, al. 2) Of logical sequence (often difficult to disting. from the temporal sense; cf. Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 113f.), <b>now, therefore, now, however, as it is</b>: Luk.11:39; καὶ ν, Act.3:17, 2Th.2:6, 1Jn.2:28; id. before δεῦρο, Act.7:34; ν. δέ, Jhn.8:40 9:41 15:22, 24, 18:36, 1Co.5:11 7:14 12:20, al. (cf. WM, 579.11). (AS)

G3586	ξύλον	xulon	wood	G:N-N	<b>ξύλον</b>, -ου, τό [in LXX chiefly for עֵץ;] 1) <b>wood</b>: 1Co.3:12, Rev.18:12. 2) a piece of wood, hence, anything made of wood, as, (a) <b>a cudgel, staff</b>: pl, Mat.26:47, 55, Mrk.14:43, 48, Luk.22:52; (b) stocks, for confining the feet (Job.33:11, סַד): Act.16:24; (with) a beam to which malefactors were bound (late Gk.), in LXX, of a gibbet (Deu.21:22-23), in NT, of the Cross: Act.5:30 10:39 13:29, Gal.3:13, 1Pe.2:24. 3) In late writers (see MM, xvii), a tree (Gen.1:29, Isa.14:8, al.): Luk.23:31; ξ. τῆς ζωῆς, Rev.2:7 22:2, 14 22:19. (AS)
G3587	ξυράω	xuraō	to shave	G:V	<b>ξυράω</b>, -ῶ late form of ξυρέω (which see): 1Co.11:6 (ξυρᾶσθαι, Rec. and Edd, but see: ξύρω). <b>ξύρω</b>, rare form of ξυρέω (Veitch, see word), aor. mid, ξύρασθαιι (Bl, § 24, see word; Zorell, see word, etc.) for -ᾶσθαι (Rec, Edd.): 1Co.11:6. (AS)
G3588	ὁ	ho	the/this/who	G:Art	<b>ὁ</b>, ἡ, τό, <i>the prepositive article</i> (ἄρθρον προτακτικόν), originally a demonstr. pron. (so usually in Hom.), in general corresponding to the Eng. definite article. I. As demonstr. pron. 1) As freq. in Hom, absol, <b>he (she, it), his</b> (etc.): Act.17:28 (quoted from the poet Aratus). 2) Distributive, ὁ μὲν. ὁ δέ, <b>the one. the other</b>: 1Co.7:7, Gal.4:22; pl, Act.14:4, 17:32, Php.1:16, al; οἱ μὲν. ἄλλοι δέ, Mat.16:14, Jhn.7:12; οἱ μεν̀. ὁδέ, Heb.7:21, 23. 3) In narration (without ὁ μὲν preceding), ὁ δέ, <b>but he</b>: Mat.2:14, Mrk.1:45, Luk.8:21, Jhn.9:38, al. mult. II. As prepositive article, <b>the</b>, prefixed, 1) <b>to nouns unmodified</b>: ὁ θεός, τὸ φῶς, etc; to abstract nouns, ἡ σοφία, etc, to pl. nouns which indicate a class, οἱ ἀλώπεκες, foxes, Mat.8:20, al; to an individual as representing a class, ὁ ἐργάτης, Luk.10:7; with nom. = voc. in addresses, Mat.11:26, Jhn.19:3, Jas.5:1, al; to things which pertain to one, ἡ χεῖρ, <b>his hand</b>, Mrk.3:1; to names of persons well known or already mentioned; usually to names of countries (originally adjectives), ἡ Ἰουδαία, etc. 2) <b>To modified nouns</b>: with of person(s) pron. genitive, μοῦ, σοῦ, etc; with poss. pron, ἐμός, σός, etc; with adj. between the art. and the noun, ὁ ἀγαθὸς ἄνθρωπος, Mat.12:35; the noun foll, by adj, both with art, ὁ ποιμὴν ὁ καλός, Jhn.10:11 (on ὁ ὄχλος πολύς, Jhn.12:9, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 84); before adjectival phrases, ἡ κατ᾽ ἐκλογὴν πρόθεσις, Rom.9:11. 3) To Other parts of speech used as substantives; (a) <b>neuter adjectives</b>: τ. ἀγαθόν, etc; (b) <b>cardinal numerals</b>: ὁ εἶς, οἷ δύο, etc; (with) <b>participles</b>: ὁ βαπτίζων (= ὁ Βαπτιστής, Mat.14:2), Mrk.6:14; πᾶς ὁ, with ptcp, <b>every one who</b>, etc; (d) <b>adverbs</b>: τὸ πέραν, τὰ νῦν, ὁ ἔσω ἄνθρωπος; (e) <b>infinitives</b>: nom, τὸ θέλειν, Rom.7:18, al; genitive, τοῦ, after adjectives, ἄξιον τοῦ πορεύεσθαι, 1Co.16:4; verbs, ἐλαχεν τοῦ θυμιᾶσαι, Luk.1:9; and freq. in a final sense, ἐξῆλθεν ὁ σπείρειν, Mat.13:3 (on the artic. inf, see Bl, §71). 4) In the neut. to sentences, <b>phrases or single words treated as a quotation</b>: τὸ Ἐι δύνῃ, Mrk.9:23; τὸ ἔτι ἅπαξ, Heb.12:27; τὸ ἀνέβη, Eph.4:9, al. 5) <b>To prepositional phrases</b>: οἱ ἀπὸ Ἰταλίας, Heb.13:24; οἱ ἐκ νόμου, Rom.4:14; neut. accusative absol, in adverbial phrases, τὸ καθ᾽ ἡμέραν, <b>daily</b>, Luk.11:3; τὸ κατὰ σάρκα, <b>as regards the flesh</b>, Rom.9:5. 6) To nouns in the genitive, denoting kinship, association, etc: ὁ τοῦ, <b>the son of</b> (unless context indicates a different relationship), Mat.10:2, al; τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ, <b>the things that pertain to God</b>, Mat.16:23; τὰ τῆς εἰρήνης, Rom.14:19 (cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 81ff; Bl, §§46, 47). (AS)

G3598	ὁδός	hodos	road	G:N-F	<b>ὁδός</b>, -οῦ, ἡ, [in LXX chiefly (very freq.) for דֶּרֶךְ;] 1) <b>a way, path, road</b>: Mat.2:12, Mrk.10:46, Luk.3:5 al; κατὰ τὴν ὁ, Luk.10:4, al; παρὰ τὴν ὁ, Mat.13:4, al; with genitive of person(s), (subj.), τὴν ὁ. ἑτοιμάζειν (fig.), Mat.3:3, Mrk.1:3, al; with genitive term. (obj.), ἐθνῶν, Mat.10:5; τ. ἁγίων (figuratively), Heb.9:8; accusative, ὁδόν, with force of prep. (like Heb. דֶּרֶךְ; Bl, §34, 8; 35, 5), ὁ. θαλάσσης, Mat.4:15 (LXX). 2) A traveller's <b>way, journey</b>: ἐν τ. ὁ, Mat.5:25, Mrk.8:27, al; ἐξ ὁ, Luk.11:6; εἰς ὁ, Mat.10:10; τ. ὁδὸν πορεύεσθαι, Act.8:39; ὁ. ἡμέρας, Luk.2:44; ὁδὸν ποιεῖν (= cl, ὁ. ποιεῖσθαι; V. Field, <i>Notes</i>, 25), <b>to make</b> one's <b>way</b>, i.e. proceed on one's journey, Mrk.2:23. 3) Metaph. (cl; but esp. freq. in Heb; see Cremer, 442ff.), of a course of conduct, a way of thinking or acting: Act.14:16, 1Co.4:17 12:31, Jas.1:8 5:20; τοῦ Κάϊν, Ju 11; τ. Βαλαάμ, 2Pe.2:15; εἰρήνης, Rom.3:17; ζωῆς, Act.2:28; ἡ ὁ. ἡ ἀπάγουσα εἰς τ. ζωήν (Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 160), Mat.7:14; τ. δικαιοσύνης, Mat.21:32; σωτηρίας, Act.16:17; αἱ ὁ. τ. θεοῦ (κυρίου), Act.13:10, Rom.11:33, Rev.15:3 (cf. Hos.14:9 Psa.94 (95):10, Sir.39:24, al.); ἡ ὁ. τ. θεοῦ (the way approved by God), Mat.22:16, Mrk.12:14, Luk.20:21; id, of the Christian religion, Act.18:26; so, absol, ἡ ὁ, Act.9:2 19:9, 23 24:22; of Christ as the means of approach to God, Jhn.14:6. 4) Ellipsis of ὁ: ποίας (sc. ὁδοῦ), Luk.5:19; ἐκείνης, ib. 19:4 (see Bl, §36, 13; 44, 1). G3600	ὀδυνάω	odunaō	be anguished	G:V	<b>ὀδυνάω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ὀδύνη), [in LXX: Zec.9:5 (חוּל), Zec.12:10 (מָרַר hi.), La 1:13 (דָּוֶה), Wis.14:24, al;] <b>to cause pain or suffering</b>; pass. and mid, <b>to suffer pain, be tormented or greatly distressed</b>: Luk.2:48 16:24-25 (ὀδυνᾶσαι, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 53 f.); before ἐπί, Act.20:38. (AS)
G3601	ὀδύνη	odunē	anguish	G:N-F	<b>ὀδύνη</b>, -ης, ἡ [in LXX for יָגוֹן, מַר, etc. (26 words in all);] <b>pain, distress, of body or mind </b>: Rom.9:2, 1Ti.6:10. (AS)
G3602	ὀδυρμός	odurmos	mourning	G:N-M	<b>ὀδυρμός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; ὀδύρομαι, to lament), [in LXX: Jer.31:15 (תַּמְרוּר), 2Ma.11:6 *;] <b>lamentation, mourning</b>: Mat.2:18 (LXX), 2Co.7:7. (AS)
G3603	ὅ ἐστι	ho esti	which is	G:V	1. as Substantive Verb, <b>to be, to exist </b>, οὐκ ἔσθ᾽ οὗτος ἀνήρ, οὐδ᾽ ἔσσεται (Odyssey by Homer); τεθνηῶτος, μηδ᾽ ἔτ᾽ ἐόντος (Odyssey by Homer); οὐκέτ᾽ ἔστι he <b>is no more </b>, (Euripides); θεοὶ αἰὲν ἐόντες (Iliad by Homer); ἐσσόμενοι posterity, (Iliad by Homer); ζώντων καὶ ὄντων Ἀθηναίων (Demosthenes Orator);so of cities, etc, ὄλωλεν, οὐδ᾽ ἔτ᾽ ἔστι Τροία (compare <b>Troja fuit) </b>, (Euripides) 2. of things, <b>to be, exist </b>, εἰ ἔστιν ἀληθέως [ἡ τράπεζα] (Herdotus Historicus); ἕως ἂν ὁ πόλεμος ἦι so long as it <b>last </b>, (Thucydides) 3. <b>to be </b>, opp. to <b>appearing to be </b>, as <b>esse </b> to <b>videri </b>, τὸν ἐόντα λόγον the <b>true </b> story, (Herdotus Historicus); τὰ ὄντα ἀπαγγέλλειν (Thucydides); τῶι ὄντι, Lat. <i>revera</i>, in reality, in fact, (Plato Philosophus) 4. followed by the Relative, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅς, <b>no one </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc; εἰσὶν οἵ, Lat. <i>sunt qui</i>, (Thucydides), etc; ἐστὶν ἅ <b>some things </b>, (Thucydides); also ἔστιν οἵ, for εἰσὶν οἵ, (Herdotus Historicus), etc;so withrelat. Particles, ἔστιν ἔνθα, Lat. <i>est ubi</i>, (Xenophon Historicus), etc; ἔστιν ὅπη, ἔσθ᾽ ὅπου, <b>somewhere </b>, or <b>somehow </b>, (Plato Philosophus), etc; ἔστιν ὅπως <b>in some manner </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; ἔστιν ὅτε, ἔσθ᾽ ὅτε, <b>sometimes </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 5. ἔστι <i>impersonal</i>, with <i>infinitive</i>, like πάρεστι, <b>it is possible </b>, (Homer), attic 6. <b>to be </b>, Copula connecting predicate with subject, both being in the same case, (Homer), etc. 7. sometimes εἶναι with Part. represents finite Verb, ἦν τεθνηκώς, for ἐτεθνήκει, (Aeschulus Tragicus); πεφυκός ἐστι = πέφυκε, (Aristophanes Comicus) 8. the Inf. is redundant in some phrases, ἑκὼν εἶναι (see. ἑκών II); τὸ ἐπ᾽ ἐκείνοις εἶναι <b>quantum in illis esset </b>, (Thucydides); τὸ σύμπαν εἶναι (Herdotus Historicus); τὸ νῦν εἶναι (Plato Philosophus), etc. (ML)

G3606	ὅθεν	hothen	whence	G:Conj	<b>ὅθεν </b> <i>adv.</i>, <b>whence</b>; (a) <b>of direction or source</b>: Mat.12:44, Luk.11:24, Act.14:26 28:13; = ἐκεῖθεν ὅπου, Mat.25:24, 26 (cf. Thuc, i, 89, 3); ὅ. γινώσκομεν, 1Jn.2:18; (b) <b>of cause, whence, wherefore</b>: Mat.14:7, Act.26:19, Heb.2:17 3:1 7:25 8:3 9:18 11:19. (AS)

G3609	οἰκεῖος	oikeios	of one’s household	G:A	<b>οἰκεῖος</b>, -α, -ον (&lt; οἶκος), [in LXX for דּוֹד, שְׁאֵר, etc; in Isa.58:7, οἰ. τοῦ σπέρματος for בָּשָׂר;] <b>in or of the house </b>(opp. to ξένος, ἀλλότριος); (a) <b>of things</b>; τὰ οἰ, household affairs or goods; (b) <b>of persons, of the same family or kin</b>; as subst, οἱ οἰ, <b>kinsmen</b>: 1Ti.5:8; with genitive of person(s), of the family of: metaph, τ. θεον, Eph.2:19; τ. πίστεως (Lft, in l), Gal.6:10. <b>SYN,</b>: συγγενής, ἴδιος (see Cremer, 446; Deiss, BS, 123) (AS)

G3611	οἰκέω	oikeō	to dwell	G:V	<b>οἰκέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; οἶκος), [in LXX chiefly for יָשַׁב;] (a) trans, <b>to inhabit</b>: with accusative, 1Ti.6:16; (b) intrans, <b>to dwell</b>: before μετά (of married life), 1Co.7:12-13; metaph, before ἐν: ἀγαθόν, Rom.7:18; ἁμαρτία, Rom.7:20; πνεῦμα θεοῦ, Rom.8:9, 11, 1Co.3:16 (cf. ἐν, κατ, ἐν-κατ, παρ, περι, συν-οικέω). G3612	οἴκημα	oikēma	cell	G:N-N	<b>οἴκημα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; οἰκέω), [in LXX: Eze.16:24 (גַב), Tob.2:4, Wis.13:15 *;] a dwelling. As a euphemism for other definite terms (e.g. brothel. Hdt, ii, 121; cf. Ez, l.with), a prison (Thus, iv, 47 f.); Act.12:7. (AS)

G3614	οἰκία	oikia	home	G:N-F	<b>οἰκία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; οἶκος), [in LXX chiefly (very freq.) for בַּיִת;] <b>a house, dwelling</b>: Mat.2:11 7:24-27, Mrk.1:29, al; ἐν οἰκίᾳ (= cl. κατ ̓ οἰκίαν), at home, Luk.8:27; εἰς οἰ, II Jn 10; οἰ, with genitive of person(s), usually has the art. G3625	οἰκουμένη	oikoumenē	world	G:N-F	<b>οἰκουμένη</b>, -ης, ἡ (fern. G3635	ὀκνέω	okneō	to delay	G:V	<b>ὀκνέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ὄκνος, shrinking, hesitation), [in LXX: Num.22:16 (מָנַע ni.), Jdg.18:9 (אָצַל ni.), Tob.12:6, 13, Jdth.12:13, Sir.7:35, 4Ma.14:4 *;] <b>to shrink from doing, hesitate to do </b>(Hom, Thuc, al.); hence, to delay with inf, Act.9:38 (cf. (Bl, §33, 1), Mat.1:21, Mrk.3:16; τ. ὄ. ἐν (τ.) βίβλῳ ζωῆς (cf. Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 121), Php.4:3, Rev.13:8, cf. Luk.10:20 (ἐν τ. οὐρανοῖς); ὄ. βλασφημίας, Rev.13:1; the name as opp. to the reality, Rev.3:1 (cf. Hdt, vii, 138); as a title: Eph.1:21, Php.2:9, 10 (Lft, in l.). 2) By a usage similar to that with ref. to Heb. שֵׁם (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 106f.), but also common in Hellenistic (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 100; Bl, §39, 4; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 146f, 196f; <i>LAE</i>, 123:4, of all that the name implies, of rank, authority, character, etc: of acting on one's authority or in his behalf, ἐν (εἰς) ὄ, with genitive of person(s) (see reff. supr.), Mat.10:41 21:9 28:19, Mrk.11:9, Luk.13:35, Jhn.5:43, Act.8:16, 1Co.1:13; of the name Christian, 1Pe.4:16; esp. of the name of God as expressing the divine attributes: ἁγιάζειν (ἅγιον) τὸ ὄ. (τ. Πατρός, Κυρίου), Mat.6:9, Luk.1:49 11:2; ψάλλειν (ὁμολογεῖν) τῷ ὀ, Rom.15:9, Heb.13:15; δοξάζειν (φανεροῦν, φοβεῖσθαι) τὸ ὄ, Jhn.12:28 17:6, 26 Rev.11:18 15:4; βλασφημεῖν, Rom.2:24, 1Ti.6:1, Rev.13:6; similarly, of the name of Christ: τ. καλὂν ὄ. (Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 276); πιστεύειν τῷ ὀ, 1Jn.3:23; π. εἰς τ. ὄ. (Bl, §39, 4), Jhn.1:12 2:23 3:18; ὀνομάζειν τὸ ὄ, 2Ti.2:19; κρατεῖν, Rev.2:13; οὐκ ἀρνεῖσθαι, Rev.3:8; ἐν τ. ὀ. (see reff. supr.), Mrk.9:38 16:[17], Luk.10:17, Jhn.14:13 16:23, 24 20:31, Act.3:6 4:12, Eph.5:20, 1Pe.4:14, al; εἰς τ. ὄ. συνάγεσθαι, Mat.18:20; ἕνεκεν τοῦ ὀ, Mat.19:29; διὰ τὸ ὄ, Mat.10:22, Mrk.13:13, al; διὰ τοῦ ὀ, 1Co.1:10; ὑπὲρ τοῦ ὀ, Act.9:16, Rom.1:5, al; id. absol, Act.5:41, 3Jo.7; πρὸς τὸ ὄ, Act.26:9. 3) <b>cause, ground, reason</b> (in cl, usually in bad sense, <b>pretext</b>): Mrk.9:41 (Swete, in l; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 305f.). 4) In late Greek (Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 196f.), <b>an individual, a person</b>: Act.1:15, Rev.3:4 11:13. (AS)
G3687	ὀνομάζω	onomazō	to name	G:V	<b>ὀνομάζω</b> (&lt; ὄνομα), [in LXX for זָכַר, נָקַב, קָרָא;] 1) <b>to name, mention, or address by name</b>: Act.19:13; pass, Rom.15:20, Eph.1:21 5:3; of the use of the Divine name in praise and worship, 2Ti.2:19 (LXX, Num.16:26; cf. Isa.52:11, Amo.6:10). 2) <b>to name, call, give a name to</b>: Mrk.3:14 (T, R, txt. om.), Luk.6:13-14; pass, 1Co.5:11; before ἐξ (cl.), Eph.3:15 (cf. ἐπ-ονομάζω). (AS)

G3694	ὀπίσω	opisō	after	G:Prep	<b>ὀπίσω </b> <i>adv.</i> of place and time, [in LXX chiefly for אַחַר and cogn. forms;] 1) prop, as in cl, adv, (a) <b>of time </b>(not in NT); (b) <b>of place, back, behind, after</b>: Mat.24:18, Luk.7:38; τὰ ὀ, Php.3:13; εἰς τὰ ὀ, Mrk.13:16, Luk.9:62 17:31, Jhn.6:66 18:6 20:14. 2) By a usage not found in cl, and in LXX representing the <i>Heb.</i> prep. אַחַר (Bl, § 40, 8; Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 46 f.), but also prob. general in vernacular (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 99), as prep. with genitive; (a) <b>of time, after</b>: Mat.3:11, Mrk.1:7 Jhn.1:15, 27 1:30; (b) <b>of place, behind, after</b>: Mat.4:19 10:38 16:23-24, Mrk.1:17, 20 8:33-34, Luk.9:33 14:27 19:14 21:8, 2Pe 2;10, Ju 7, Rev.1:10 12:15; in constr. praegn. G3697	ὁποῖος	hopoios	what sort	G:Cor+G:Intg	<b>ὁποῖος</b>, -οία, -οῖον [in LXX: Sng.5:10, 2Ma.11:37 *;] <b>of what sort</b>: 1Co.3:13, Gal.2:6, 1Th.1:9, Jas.1:24; τοιοῦτος ὁ, such as, Act.26:29. (AS)
G3698	ὁπότε	hopote	when(-ever)	G:Conj	1. of Time, correlated to πότε, much like ὅτε: 2. with the <i>indicative</i>, <b>when </b>, Lat. <i>quando</i>, (Homer); εἰς ὁπότε, with <i>future</i>, <b>when, by what time </b>, λέγειν εἰς ὁπότ᾽ ἔσται (Aeschines Orator) 3. with the <i>optative</i> in reference to the past, <b>whenever </b>, to express an event that has often occurred, ὁπότε Κρήτηθεν ἵκοιτο (Iliad by Homer), etc;also in oratio obliqua, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 4. in indirect phrases, ἴδμεν, ὁππότε Τηλέμαχος νεῖται when he <b>is to return </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); with <i>optative</i>, δέγμενος ὁππότε ναυσὶν ἐφορμηθεῖεν (Iliad by Homer) 5. in causal sense, <b>for that, because, since </b>, like Lat. quando for <b>quoniam </b>, (Theognis Elegiacus), etc: so ὁπότε γε, Lat. <i>quandoquidem</i>, (Sophocles Tragicus) (ML)
G3699	ὅπου	hopou	where(-ever)	G:Conj	<b>ὅπου </b> <i>adv.</i> of place, correlat. of ποῦ (which see), where. I. Prop, of place, 1) <b>where</b>; (a) in relative sentences, with indic: Mat.25:24, 26, Mrk.2:4 4:5, 15 5:40 13:14, Jhn.3:8 6:62 7:34, 36 11:32 14:3 17:24 20:19, Rom.15:20, Rev.2:13; after nouns of place, for relat. prepositional phrase (ἐν ᾧ, etc.), Mat.6:19-20 13:5 26:57 28:6, Mrk.6:55 9:48 Luk.12:33, Jhn.1:28 4:20, 46 6:23 7:42 10:40 11:30 12:1 18:1, 20 19:18, 20 19:41 20:12, Act.17:1, Rev.2:13 11:8 20:10; before ἐκεῖ, Mat.6:21, Luk.12:34 17:37 Jhn.12:26; id. pleonast. (= <i>Heb.</i> שָׁם. אֲשֶׁר; Aram. תַּמָּן. דּ; of. Gen.13:3), ὅ. ἐκεῖ, Rev.12:6, 14; ὅ. ἐπ᾽ αὐτῶν, Rev.17:9; ὅ. ἄν, wherever (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 168), with impf. indic, Mrk.6:56; with Pres. subjc, Mat.24:28; ὅ. ἐάν, Mat.26:13, Mrk.6:10 9:18 14:9, 14 a; (b) in quaest. indir, with aor. subjc: Mrk.14:14 b, Luk.22:11. 2) In late writers (sometimes also in cl; Bl, § 25, 2), with verbs of motion, = ὅποι, <b>whither</b>: with indic, Jhn.8:21-22 13:33, 36 14:4 21:18, Heb.6:20, Jas.3:4; ὅ. ἄν, whithersoever, with pres. ind, Rev.14:4; subjc, Luk.9:57; ὅ. ἐάν, Mat.8:19. II. Without strict local sense, 1) <b>of time or condition</b>: Col.3:11, Heb.9:16 10:18, Jas.3:16, 2Pe.2:11. 2) <b>Of cause or reason </b>(AV, whereas): 1Co.3:3. (AS)

G3708	ὁράω	horaō	to see	G:V	<b>ὁράω</b>, -ῶ, [in LXX chiefly for ראה, also for חזה, etc;] in "durative" sense (hence aor. act, εἶδον, pass, ὤφθην, fut, ὄψομαι, from different roots; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 110f.), <b>to see</b> (in colloq. even the pres. is rare, its place being generally taken by θεωρέω, see BL, §24). 1) Of bodily vision, <b>to see, perceive, behold</b>: absol, Mrk.6:38, al; ἔρχου καὶ ἴδε, Jhn.1:46, al; before ὅτι, Mrk.2:16, al; with accusative, Mat.2:2, Mrk.1:10 16:7, Gal.1:19, al; θεόν, Jhn.1:18, 1Jn.4:20, al. 2) <b>to see</b> with the mind, <b>perceive, discern</b>: absol, Rom.15:21; with accusative of thing(s), Mat.9:2 27:54, Act.8:23, Col.2:18, al. 3) <b>to see, take heed, beware</b>: ὅρα μή, with aor. subjc, Mat.8:4 18:10, Mrk.1:44, 1Th.5:15; id, sc. μὴ ποήσῃς, Rev.19:10 22:9 (Bl, §81, 1); before imperat. G3739	ὅς	hos, hē	which	G:RelP	<b>ὅς</b>, ἥ, ὅ, <i>the postpositive <i>article</i> (ἄρθρον ὑποτακτικόν).</i> I. As demonstr. pron. = οὗτος, ὅδε, <b>this, that</b>, also for αὐτός, chiefly in nom: ὅς δέ, <b>but he</b> (cf. ἦ δὲ ὅς, freq. in Plat.), Mrk.15:23, Jhn.5:11; ὃς μὲν. ὃς δέ, <b>the one. the other</b>, Mat.21:35, 22:5, 25:15, Luk.23:33, Act.27:14, Rom.14:5, 1Co.11:21, 2Co.2:18, Ju 22; neut, ὃ μὲν. ὃ δέ, <b>the one. the other, some. some</b>, Mat.13:8, 23, Rom.9:21; ὃς (ὃ) μὲν. (ἄλλος (ἄλλο)). ἕτερος, Mrk.4:4, Luk.8:5, 1Co.12:8-10; οὓς μέν, absol, 1Co.12:28; ὃς μὲν. ὁ δέ, Rom.14:2. II. As relat. pron, <b>who, which, what, that</b>; 1) <b>agreeing in gender with its antecedent, but differently governed as to case</b>: Mat.2:9, Luk.9:9, Act.20:18, Rom.2:29, al. mult. 2) <b>In variation from the common construction</b>; (a) <b>in gender, agreeing with a noun in apposition to the antecedent</b>: Mrk.15:16, Gal.3:16, Eph.6:17, al; constr. ad sensum: Jhn.6:9, Col.2:19, 1Ti.3:16, Rev.13:14, al; (b) in number, constr. ad sensum: Act.15:36, 2Pe.3:1; (with) <b>in case, by attraction to the case of the antecedent </b>(Bl, §50, 2): Jhn.4:18, Act.3:21, Rom.15:18, 1Co.6:19, Eph.1:8, al. 3) The neut. ὅ with nouns of other gender and with phrases, <b>which thing, which term</b>: Mrk.3:17 12:42, Jhn.1:39, Col.3:14, al; with a sentence, Act.2:32, Gal.2:10, 1Jn.2:8, al. 4) With ellipse of a demonstrative (οὗτος or ἐκεῖνος), <b>before or after</b>: before, Mat.20:23, Luk.7:43, Rom.10:14, al; after, Mat.10:38, Mrk.9:40, Jhn.19:22, Rom.2:1 al. 5) <b>Expressing purpose, end or cause</b>: Mat.11:10 (<b>who = that he may</b>), Mrk.1:2, Heb.12:6 al. 6) C. prep, as periphrasis for conjc: ἀνθ᾽ ὧν (= ἀντὶ τούτων ὧν), <b>because</b>, Luk.1:20, al; <b>wherefore</b>, Luk.12:3; ἐξ οὗ, <b>since, for that</b>, Rom.5:12; ἀφ᾽ οὗ, <b>since</b> (temporal), Luk.13:25; ἐξ οὗ, <b>whence</b>, Php.3:20; etc. 7) <b>With particles</b>: ὃς ἄν (ἐάν), see: ἄν, ἐάν; ὃς καί, Mrk.3:19, Jhn.21:20, Rom.5:2, al; ὃς καὶ αὐτός, Mat.27:57. 8) Gen, οὗ, absol, as adv. (see: οὗ). (AS)

G3748	ὅστις	hostis, hētis	who/which	G:RelP	<b>ὅστις</b>, ἥτις, ὅ τι (also written ὅ, τι and ὅτι; see LS, see word; WH, §411; Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, 111), in NT scarcely ever except in nom. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 91), the only instance of the oblique cases being found in ἕως ὅτου (see: ἕως), relative of indef. reference (related to simple ὅς as Lat. quisquis to qui), <b>whoever, anyone who</b>; (a) of an indef. person or thing: in general statements, Mat.5:39, 41 13:12, and freq, Luk.14:27, Gal.5:4, al; in relative sentences, Mat.7:26, Luk.15:7, Php.3:7, al; πᾶς, with indic, Mat.7:24 10:32; ὅ ἄν (ἐάν), with subjc, Mat.12:50 13:12, Jhn.14:13, 1Co.16:2, Gal.5:10, al; (b) of a definite person or thing, indicating quality, "either generic,<i> which, as other like things,</i> or essential, <i>which by its very nature</i>" (Hort on 1Pe.2:11), <b>who is such as</b>: Mat.2:6 7:26, Luk.2:10 7:37, Jhn.8:53, Act.7:53, Rom.6:2, 1Co.3:17, Gal.4:24, Eph.1:23, al; (with) where the relative sentence expresses a reason, consequence, etc. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 92), <b>seeing that he (it, they), and he (it, they)</b>: Luk.8:3 10:42, Act.10:47 11:28, Php.4:3, al; (d) as in Ionic and late Greek (Bl, §50, 1; M, <i>Pr.</i>, l.with), differing but little from ὅς: Luk.2:4 9:30, Act.17:10, Rev.12:13. G3754	ὅτι	hoti	that/since	G:Conj	<b>ὅτι</b>, <i>conjc.</i> (prop. neut. of ὅστις). I. As conjc, introducing an objective clause, <b>that</b>; 1) <b>after verbs of seeing, knowing, thinking, saying, feeling</b>: Mat.3:9 6:32 11:25, Mrk.3:28, Luk.2:49, Jhn.2:22, Act.4:13, Rom.1:13 8:38 10:9, Php.4:15, Jas.2:24, al; elliptically, Jhn.6:46, Php.3:12, al. 2) <b>After εἶναι </b>(γίνεσθαι): defining a demonstr. or of person(s) pron, Jhn.3:19 16:19, Rom.9:6, 1Jn.3:16 al; with pron. interrog, Mat.8:27, Mrk.4:41, Luk.4:36, Jhn.4:22 al; id. elliptically, Luk.2:49, Act.5:4, 9, al; 3) <b>Untranslatable, before direct discourse </b>(ὅτι recitantis): Mat.7:23, Mrk.2:16, Luk.1:61, Jhn.1:20, Act.15:1, Heb.11:18, al. (on the pleonastic ὡς ὅτι, see: ὡς). II. As causal particle, <b>for that, because</b>: Mat.5:4-12, Luk.6:20, 21, J0 1:30 5:27, Act.1:5, 1Jn.4:18, Rev.3:10, al. mult; διὰ τοῦτο ὅτι, Jhn.8:47 10:17, al; answering a question (διὰ τί), Rom.9:32, al; οὐκ ὅτι. ἀλλ᾽ ὅτι, Jhn.6:26 12:6. (AS)
G3755	ὅτου	hotou	until	G:Prep	<b>ὅστις</b>, ἥτις, ὅ τι (also written ὅ, τι and ὅτι; see LS, see word; WH, §411; Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, 111), in NT scarcely ever except in nom. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 91), the only instance of the oblique cases being found in ἕως ὅτου (see: ἕως), relative of indef. reference (related to simple ὅς as Lat. quisquis to qui), <b>whoever, anyone who</b>; (a) of an indef. person or thing: in general statements, Mat.5:39, 41 13:12, and freq, Luk.14:27, Gal.5:4, al; in relative sentences, Mat.7:26, Luk.15:7, Php.3:7, al; πᾶς, with indic, Mat.7:24 10:32; ὅ ἄν (ἐάν), with subjc, Mat.12:50 13:12, Jhn.14:13, 1Co.16:2, Gal.5:10, al; (b) of a definite person or thing, indicating quality, "either generic,<i> which, as other like things,</i> or essential, <i>which by its very nature</i>" (Hort on 1Pe.2:11), <b>who is such as</b>: Mat.2:6 7:26, Luk.2:10 7:37, Jhn.8:53, Act.7:53, Rom.6:2, 1Co.3:17, Gal.4:24, Eph.1:23, al; (with) where the relative sentence expresses a reason, consequence, etc. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 92), <b>seeing that he (it, they), and he (it, they)</b>: Luk.8:3 10:42, Act.10:47 11:28, Php.4:3, al; (d) as in Ionic and late Greek (Bl, §50, 1; M, <i>Pr.</i>, l.with), differing but little from ὅς: Luk.2:4 9:30, Act.17:10, Rev.12:13. (AS)
G3756	οὐ	ou	no	G:Neg	<b>οὐ</b>, before a vowel with smooth breathing οὐκ, before one with rough breathing οὐχ (but improperly οὐχ ἰδού, Act.2:7, WH, mg; cf. WH, <i>Intr.</i>, §409; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 44, 244), [in LXX for אֵין,אַיִן,לֹא;] <i>neg. particle</i>, <b>not, no</b>, used generally with indic, and for a denial of fact (cf. μή); 1) absol. (accented), οὔ, <b>no</b>: Mat.13:29 Jhn.1:21 21:5; οὒ οὕ, Mat.5:37 Jas.5:12. 2) Most freq. negativing a verb or other word, Mat.1:25 10:26, 38, Mrk.3:25 9:37, Jhn.8:29, Act.7:5, Rom.1:16, Php.3:3, al; in litotes, οὐκ ὀλίγοι (i.e. <b>very many</b>), Act.17:4, al; οὐκ ἄσημος, Act.21:39; πᾶς. οὐ, with verb, (like Heb. כֹּל. לֹא), <b>no, none</b>, Mat.24:22, Mrk.13:20, Luk.1:37, Eph.5:5, al; in disjunctive statements, οὐκ. ἀλλά, Luk.8:52 Jhn.1:33 Rom.8:2 o, al; with 2 of person(s) fut. (like Heb. לֹא, with impf.), as emphatic prohibition, Mat.4:7, Luk.4:12, Rom.7:7, al. 3) With another negative, (a) <b>strengthening the negation</b>: Mrk.5:37, Jhn.8:15 12:19, Act.8:39, al; (b) <b>making an affirmative</b>: Act.4:20, 1Co.12:15. 4) <b>With other particles</b>: οὐ μή (see: μή); οὐ μηκέτι, Mat.21:19; with μή interrog, Rom.10:18, 1Co.9:4, 5 11:22. 5) <b>Interrogative, expecting an affirmative answer </b>(Lat. nonne): Mat.6:26, Mrk.4:21, Luk.11:40, Jhn.4:35, Rom.9:21, al. G3772	οὐρανός	ouranos	heaven	G:N-M	<b>οὐρανός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ, [in LXX chiefly for שָׁמַיִם (hence, often pl, οἱ οὐ, see infr.);] <b>heaven</b>; 1) <b>of the vault or firmament of heaven, the sky and the aerial regions above the earth</b>: opp. to ἡ γῆ, Heb.1:10, 2Pe.3:5, 10; ὁ οὐ. καὶ ἡ γῆ, i.e. the world, the universe, Mat.5:18, Mrk.13:31, Luk.10:21, Act.4:24, Rev.10:6, al; ἀπ᾽ ἄκρων οὐ. ἕως ἄ. αὐτῶν (on the absence of art. aft. prep, see Bl, §46, 5), Mat.24:31; ὑπὸ τὸν οὐ, Act.2:5, Col.1:23; ὑψωθῆναι ἕως τοῦ οὐ, figuratively, Mat.11:23, Luk.10:15; σημεῖον ἐκ τοῦ οὐ, Mat.16:1, Mrk.8:11, al; αἱ νεφέλαι, Mat.24:30, al; τὰ πετεινὰ τοῦ οὐ, Mat.6:26, Mrk.4:32, al; οἱ ἀστέρες τοῦ οὐ, Rev.6:13, al; pl. (οἱ) οὐ. (Bl, §32, 5), Mat.3:16, Mrk.1:10, Jhn.1:32, 2Pe.3:7, 13 al. 2) <b>Of the abode of God and other blessed beings</b>: of angels, Mat.24:36, Mrk.12:25, Gal.1:8, Rev.10:1, al; of Christ glorified, Mrk.16:[19], Luk.24:51, Act.3:21, Rom.10:6, al; of God, Mat.5:34, Rom.1:18, al; ὁ Πατὴρ ὁ ἐν τοῖς οὐ. (Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 184ff.), Mat.5:16 6:1, al; θησαυρὸς ἐν οὐ, Mat.6:20, Mrk.10:21, al. 3) By meton, (a) <b>of the inhabitants of heaven</b>: Rev.18:20 (cf. ib. 12:12, Job.15:15, Isa.44:23); (b) as an evasive reference to God, characteristic of later Judaism (Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 204ff.): Mat.21:25, Mrk.11:30, Luk.15:18, Jhn.3:27, al; ἡ βασιλεία τῶν οὐ. (= τοῦ Θεοῦ); see: βασιλεία). <b>βασιλεία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; βασιλεύω), [in LXX chiefly for מַמְלָכָה,מַלְכוּת;] 1) prop. abstract, <b>sovereignty, royal power, dominion</b>: Luk.1:33 22:29, Jhn.18:36, Act.1:6, Heb.1:8, 1Co.15:24; λαβεῖν β, Luk.19:12, 15 Rev.17:12; δοῦναι τὴν, ib. 17; ἔχειν β, ib. 18; ἔρχεσθαι ἐν τ. (εἰς τὴν) β, Mat.16:28, Luk.23:42; β. τ. θεοῦ, Rev.12:10. 2) By meton, concrete (MM, <i>Exp.</i>, x), (a) <b>a kingdom</b>, the territory or people over whom the king rules (Est.5:3, al.): Mat.4:8 12:25, 26 24:7, Mrk.3:24 6:23, Luk.4:5, Heb.11:33, al; (b) <b>the royal majesty</b> (cf. our phrase <i>His Majesty</i>), <b>the king</b> himself (τ. σπέρμα τῆς β, 4Ki.11:1). 3) In LXX (Wis.6:5, Tob.13:1, al.), Targ. and NT, of the Messianic rule and kingdom, ἡ β. τ. θεοῦ, τ. οὐρανῶν (Heb. מַלְכוּת שָׁמַיִם, Aram. מַלְכוּתָא דִשׁמַיָּא; see Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 91-147; Cremer, 132, 658), <b>the kingdom of God</b> (on the equivalence of the two phrases, see Dalman, <i>op. cit.</i>, 93, 218f.); τ. θεοῦ, Mat.6:33 12:28, al; τ. οὐρανῶν, Mat.3:2 4:17, al; τ. Χριστοῦ (מַלִכוּת דִמְשִׁיחא, Targ. Jon. on Isa.53:10), Eph.5:5; τ. κυρίου, 2Pe.1:11, Rev.11:15; τ. Δαυείδ, Mrk.11:10; absol, ἡ β, Mat.4:23, Jas.2:5, al. The kingdom is regarded as present: Mat.11:12, Luk.17:21, Rom.14:17, al; as that which is to be consummated in the future, Mat.6:10, Mrk.9:1, Jhn.3:5, 2Pe.1:11, al. Noteworthy phrases are: ζητεῖν τὴν β, Mat.6:33; δέχεσθαι, Mrk.10:15; κλρονομεῖν, Mat.25:34; διδόναι, Lk 12:32; παραλαμβάνειν, Heb.12:28; αὐτῶν (τοιούτων) εστὶν ἡ β, Mat.5:3, 10 19:14, Mrk.10:14, Luk.18:16; διὰ τὴν β, Mat.19:12; ἕνεκεν τῆς β, Luk.18:29; εὐαγγελίζεσθαι, κηρύσσειν, διαγγέλλειν τὴν β, Luk.4:43 9:2, 60; ἤγγικεν ἡ β, Mat.3:2, Mrk.1:15; κλεῖς τῆς β, Mat.16:10; κλείειν τὴν β, Mat.23:14; υἱοὶ τῆς β, Mat.8:12 13:38 (cf. Cremer, 132, 658). \ (AS)

G3779	οὕτως	ohutō, ohutōs	thus(-ly)	G:Adv	<b>οὕτως</b>, rarely (Bl, §5, 4; WH, <i>App.</i>, 146f.) οὕτω, <i>adv.</i> (&lt; οὗτος), [in LXX chiefly for כֵּן;] <b>in this way, so, thus</b>; 1) <b>referring to what precedes</b>: Mat.5:16 6:30, Mrk.10:43 14:59, Luk.1:25 2:48 15:7, Jhn.3:8, Rom.1:15, 1Co.8:12, al; οὕτως καί, Mat.17:12, Mrk.13:29, al; pleonastically, resuming a ptcp. (cl; see Bl, §74, 6), Act.20:11 27:17. 2) <b>Referring to what follows</b>: Mat.1:18 6:9, Luk.19:31, Jhn.21:1, 1Pe.2:15; bef. quotations from OT, Mat.2:5, Act.7:6, 1Co.15:45, Heb.4:4. 3) C. adj. (marking intensity): Heb.12:21, Rev.16:18; similarly with adv, Gal.1:6 (cl.). 4) <b>As a predicate </b>(Bl, §76, 1): Mat.1:18 9:33, Mrk.2:1, 2 4:26, Rom.4:18 9:20, I Pe 2:15; οὕ ἔχειν (Lat. sic or ita se habere), Act.7:1, al; ἐκαθέζετο (as he was, without delay or preparation), Jhn.4:6. 5) In comparison, with correlative adv: καθάπερ. οὕ, Rom.12:4, 5 al; καθὼς. οὕ, Luk.11:30, al; οὕ. καθώς, Luk.24:24, al; ὡς. οὕ, Rom.5:15, al; οὕ. ὡς, Mrk.4:26, al; ὥσπερ. οὕ, Mat.12:40, al; οὕ. οὕ, 1Co.7:7. (AS)
G3780	οὐχί	ouchi	not	G:Neg	<b>οὐχί </b> strengthened form of οὐ, <b>not</b>; (a) in neg. sentences, <b>not, not at all</b>: Luk.1:60 12:51, Jhn.13:10, al; (b) more freq. in questions where an affirm. ans. is expected (Lat. nonne): Mat.5:46-47, Luk.6:39, Jhn.11:9, al. (AS)

G3801	ο ων και ο ην και ο ερχομενος	o ōn kai o ēn kai o erchomenos	was, is, will be	G:Art+G:V+G:Conj+G:Art+G:V+G:Conj+G:Art+G:V	1. as Substantive Verb, <b>to be, to exist </b>, οὐκ ἔσθ᾽ οὗτος ἀνήρ, οὐδ᾽ ἔσσεται (Odyssey by Homer); τεθνηῶτος, μηδ᾽ ἔτ᾽ ἐόντος (Odyssey by Homer); οὐκέτ᾽ ἔστι he <b>is no more </b>, (Euripides); θεοὶ αἰὲν ἐόντες (Iliad by Homer); ἐσσόμενοι posterity, (Iliad by Homer); ζώντων καὶ ὄντων Ἀθηναίων (Demosthenes Orator);so of cities, etc, ὄλωλεν, οὐδ᾽ ἔτ᾽ ἔστι Τροία (compare <b>Troja fuit) </b>, (Euripides) 2. of things, <b>to be, exist </b>, εἰ ἔστιν ἀληθέως [ἡ τράπεζα] (Herdotus Historicus); ἕως ἂν ὁ πόλεμος ἦι so long as it <b>last </b>, (Thucydides) 3. <b>to be </b>, opp. to <b>appearing to be </b>, as <b>esse </b> to <b>videri </b>, τὸν ἐόντα λόγον the <b>true </b> story, (Herdotus Historicus); τὰ ὄντα ἀπαγγέλλειν (Thucydides); τῶι ὄντι, Lat. <i>revera</i>, in reality, in fact, (Plato Philosophus) 4. followed by the Relative, οὐκ ἔστιν ὅς, <b>no one </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc; εἰσὶν οἵ, Lat. <i>sunt qui</i>, (Thucydides), etc; ἐστὶν ἅ <b>some things </b>, (Thucydides); also ἔστιν οἵ, for εἰσὶν οἵ, (Herdotus Historicus), etc;so withrelat. Particles, ἔστιν ἔνθα, Lat. <i>est ubi</i>, (Xenophon Historicus), etc; ἔστιν ὅπη, ἔσθ᾽ ὅπου, <b>somewhere </b>, or <b>somehow </b>, (Plato Philosophus), etc; ἔστιν ὅπως <b>in some manner </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; ἔστιν ὅτε, ἔσθ᾽ ὅτε, <b>sometimes </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 5. ἔστι <i>impersonal</i>, with <i>infinitive</i>, like πάρεστι, <b>it is possible </b>, (Homer), attic 6. <b>to be </b>, Copula connecting predicate with subject, both being in the same case, (Homer), etc. 7. sometimes εἶναι with Part. represents finite Verb, ἦν τεθνηκώς, for ἐτεθνήκει, (Aeschulus Tragicus); πεφυκός ἐστι = πέφυκε, (Aristophanes Comicus) 8. the Inf. is redundant in some phrases, ἑκὼν εἶναι (see. ἑκών II); τὸ ἐπ᾽ ἐκείνοις εἶναι <b>quantum in illis esset </b>, (Thucydides); τὸ σύμπαν εἶναι (Herdotus Historicus); τὸ νῦν εἶναι (Plato Philosophus), etc. (ML)

G3813	παιδίον	paidion	child	G:N-N	<b>παιδίον</b>, -ου, τό dimin, of παῖς, [in LXX chiefly for יֶלֶד, also for נַעַר, בֵּן, etc, freq. in To in ref. to full-grown youth;] <b>a young child, a little one</b>: Mat.2:8-9, 11, ff, Luk.1:59, 66 1:76, 80 2:17, 27 2:40, Jhn.16:21, Heb.11:23; of older children, Mat.18:2, 4-5, Mrk.5:39-41 7:30 9:24, 36, Luk.9:47-48 18:17, Jhn.4:49; in pl, Mat.11:16 14:21 15:38 18:3 19:13-14, Mrk.7:28 10:13 ff, Luk.7:32 11:7 18:16, Heb.2:13-14 Metaph, 1Co.14:20. G3814	παιδίσκη	paidiskē	maidservant	G:N-F	<b>παιδίσκη</b>, -ης, ἡ dimin, of παῖς, [in LXX for שִׁפְחָה, אָמָה, etc;] 1) a young girl, a maiden (נַעֲרָה, Rut.4:12). 2) Colloq, <b>a young female slave, a maid-servant </b>(see Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 40 f; Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 186, 332.2): Mat.26:69, Mrk.14:66, 69, Luk.12:45 22:56, Jhn.18:17, Act.12:13 16:16; of Hagar, Gal.4:22-23, 30 " (LXX); id, metaph, Gal.4:31. (AS)
G3815	παίζω	paizō	to play	G:V	<b>παίζω</b> (&lt; παῖς), [in LXX: Gen.21:9 26:8, Exo.32:6 (צָחַק pi.); and more freq. (Jdg.16:25, al.) for (שָׂחַק pi;] prop, to play as a child, hence, generally, to play (as with singing and dancing): 1Co.10:7 (LXX) (cf. ἐμ-παίζω). (AS)
G3816	παῖς	pais	child	G:N-B	<b>παῖς</b>, genitive, παιδός, ὁ, ἡ [in LXX chiefly for עֶבֶד, also for נַעַר, נַעֲרָה, etc;] 1) <b>a child, boy, youth, maiden</b>: ὁ π, Mat.17:18, Luk.2:43 9:42, Act.20:12; ἡ π. Luk.8:51, 54 (on the artic. fern, of address, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 70 f, 235; B1, § 33, 4); pl, Mat.2:16 21:15; of parentage, with genitive, Jhn.4:51 2) Like <i>Heb.</i> עֶבֶד, Lat. Auer, Fr. garcon, Eng. boy (Æsch, Aristoph, Xen, al.), <b>servant, slave, attendant</b>: Mat.8:6, 8 8:13 Luk.7:7 12:45 15:26; in late writers (Diod, LXX: Gen.41:37, al.), of a king's attendant or minister: Mat.14:2; so (= <i>Heb.</i> יְהוָֹה עֶבֶד) π. τ. θεοῦ (Psa.69:18, Isa.41:8, Wis.2:13, al.), of Israel, Luk.1:54; of David, Luk.1:69, Act.4:25; of Jesus (but see Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 277 f.), Mat.12:18 (LXX), Act.3:13, 26 4:27, 30. 1) τέκνον, <b>child</b>, with emphasis on parentage and the consequent community of nature; υἱός, son, with emphasis on the privileged position of heirship; π. refers both to age and parentage, but with emphasis on the former. Cf. also (παιδάριον), (παιδίον), (παιδίσκη), and see Westc. on 1Jn.3:1. 2) see: θεράπων, and cf. Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 7 f (AS)

G3844	παρά	para	from/with/beside	G:Prep	<b>παρά</b>, <i>prep.</i> with genitive, dative, accusative, with radical sense, <b>beside</b>. I. C. genitive of person(s), <b>from the side of, from beside, from</b>, indicating source or origin, [in LXX for מֵאֵצֶל,מִיַד,מִלִּפְנֵי;] after verbs of motion, Mrk.14:43, Luk.8:49, Jhn.15:26, al; after verbs of seeking, receiving, hearing, etc, Mrk.8:11 12:2, Jhn.4:9, 52 10:18, Php.4:18, 2Ti.1:18, Jas.1:7, al; after passive verbs, of the agent (like ὑπό), Mat.21:42, Mrk.12:11, Luk.1:37; absol, οἱ παρ᾽ αὐτοῦ, <i>his family, his kinsfolk</i>, Mrk.3:21 (cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 106f; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 25f; Swete, in l.); τὰ παρ᾽ αὐτῆς (αὐτῶν, ὑμῶν, <i>one's means, wealth</i>, Mrk.5:26, Luk.10:7, Php.4:18. II. C. dative of person(s) (exc. Jhn.19:25, π. τ. σταυρῷ), <b>by the side of, beside, by, with</b>, [in LXX for בְּעֵינֵי,בְּיַד,אֵצֶל;] Luk.11:37 19:7, Jhn.1:40 4:40, Act.28:14, al; παρ᾽ ἑαυτῷ, <i>at home</i>, 1Co.16:2; with dative pl, <b>among</b>, Mat.22:25, Col.4:16, al; metaph, Mat.19:26, Mrk.10:27, Luk.1:30, Rom.2:13, Jas.1:27, al. III. C. accusative, of motion by or towards, [in LXX for בְּעֵבֶר,עַל יַד,אֵצֶל;] 1) of place, <b>by the side of, beside, by, along</b>: Act.10:32, Heb.11:12; after verbs of motion, Mat.4:18, Mrk.4:4, Luk.8:5, Act.4:35, al; after verbs of rest, Mat.13:1, Mrk.5:21, Luk.8:35, al. 2) <b>beside, beyond</b>, metaph; (a) <b>beyond, against, contrary to</b>: Act.18:13, Rom.1:26 4:18 11:24, al; except, 2Co.11:24; (b) <b>beyond, above, in comparison with</b>: Luk.3:13, Rom.12:3 14:5, Heb.1:4, 9 3:3, al; (with) <b>on account of</b>: 1Co.12:15, 16. IV. <b>In composition</b>: <b>beside, to</b> (παραλαμβάνω, παράγω), <b>at hand</b> (πάρειμι), <b>from</b> (παραρρέω), <b>amiss</b> (παρακούω), <b>past</b> (παρέρχομαι), <b>compared with</b> (παρομοιάζω), <b>above measure</b> (παροργίζω). (AS)

(twice), to go by the side of, stand beside. 2) In Æsch, Herod, Thuc, al, to go past or pass over, chiefly metaph, to overstep, violate, transgress (Jos.7:11, Eze.16:59, Sir.40:14, al.): τ. παράδοσιν, Mat.15:2; τ. ἐντολήν, Mat.15:3; before ἀπό (as מִן סוּר, Deu.17:20, al.), <b>to turn aside, fall away </b>(cf. π. τῆς ἀληθείας, Arist, Cael, i, 5, 2): Act.1:25. G3850	παραβολή	parabolē	parable	G:N-F	<b>παραβολή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; παραβάλλω), [in LXX (cf. McNeile, Mt, 185): Num.23:7, Deu.28:37, Psa.44:14, Pro.1:6, Eze.12:22, al. Cited by Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 84, 120. <b>παρα-βουλεύομαι</b>, to consult amiss, or perh. (see LS, see word), a vulg. form of παρα-βολ- (which see): Php.2:30, Rec. (AS)
G3852	παραγγελία	paraggelia	order	G:N-F	<b>παρ-αγγελία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; παραγγέλλω), <b>an instruction, charge, com­mand</b>: Act.5:28 16:24, 1Th.4:2, 1Ti.1:5 1:18. (In Xen, Polyb, of a military order.) (AS)
G3853	παραγγέλλω	paraggellō	to order	G:V	<b>παρ-αγγέλλω</b> (&lt; παρά, ἀγγὲλλω), [in LXX for שָׁמַע pi, hi, etc;] 1) to transmit a message (Æsch, Eur.). 2) to order, command (Hdt, Xen, al.): with inf, Act.15:5; with accusative of thing(s), 1Co.11:17, 2Th.3:4, 1Ti.4:11 5:7; before ἵνα (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 207; Bl, § 69, 4), Mrk.6:8, 2Th.3:12; with dative of person(s), Act.17:30 R, txt, 1Th.4:11; before λέγων, Mat.10:5; with inf. aor, Mat.15:35, Mrk.8:6, Luk.8:29, Act.10:42 16:18 (aoristic pres; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 119); id. with neg, μή, Luk.5:14 8:56, Act.23:22, 1Co.7:10; with inf. pres, Act.16:23, 2Th.3:6; id. with neg, ιή, Luk.9:21, Act.1:4 4:18 5:28, 40, 1Ti.1:3 6:17; with accusative, τοῦτο, before ὅτι (E1, § 70, 3), 2Th.3:10; with accusative and inf, Act.23:30, 2Th.3:6, 1Ti.6:13 (Bl, § 72, 5). G3854	παραγίνομαι	paraginomai	to come	G:V	<b>παρα-γίνομαι</b> (Ion. and late for -γίγν-), [in LXX chiefly for בּוֹא;] 1) to be beside or at hand (Hom, Hdt, al.), hence, to stand by, sup­port (Æsch, Thuc, al.): with dative of person(s), 2Ti.4:16. 2) <b>to come, come up, arrive </b>(Hdt, Xen, al, and freq. in later writers; see MM, xviii; Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 267.2): absol, Luk.14:21 19:16, Jhn.3:23, Act.5:21-22, 25 9:39 10:32-33 11:23 14:27 17:10 18:27 21:18 23:16, 35 24:17, 24 25:7 28:21, 1Co.16:3; before εἰς, Jhn.8:2, Act.9:26 15:4; ἐπί, with accusative, Luk.22:52; πρός, with accusative, Luk.7:4, 20 8:19, Act.20:18; id. before ἐκ, Luk.11:6; παρά, with genitive, Mrk.14:43; ἀπὸ. εἰς, Mat.2:1, Act.13:14; ἀπὸ. ἐπὶ. πρός, Mat.3:13; of a teacher coming forward in public: Mat.3:1, Luk.12:51, Heb.9:11. G3893	παραπικραίνω	parapikrainō	to rebel	G:V	<b>παρα-πικραίνω </b> [in LXX chiefly for מָרַד qal, hi, מְרִי, most freq. in Psa and Eze;] <b>to embitter, provoke</b>: absol. (yet sc. τ. θεόν, cf. Psa.106:7, Eze.2:5-8, al, and with τὸν θ. added, Psa.5:4, Eze.20:21, al.), Heb.3:16 (cf. παραπικρασμός). (AS)
G3894	παραπικρασμός	parapikrasmos	rebellion	G:N-M	<b>παρα-πικρασμός</b>, -οῦ, ἁ (&lt; παραπικραίνω) [in LXX: Psa.95:8 (מְרִיבָה elsewhere rendered Λοιδόρησις, Exo.17:7; ἀντιλογία, Deu.33:8, al; λοιδορία, Num.20:24)*;] <b>provocation</b>: ἐν τῷ π. (Heb. at Meribah), Heb.3:8, 15 " (LXX). (AS)
G3895	παραπίπτω	parapiptō	to defect	G:V	<b>παρα-πίπτω </b> [in LXX: Eze.14:13 15:8 18:24 20:27 (מָעַל), Eze.22:4 (אָשַׁם), Est.6:10 (נָפַל hi.), Wis.6:9 12:2, 2Ma.10:4 A*;] 1) most freq. (Hdt, Thuc, al.), to fall in one's way, befall. 2) to fall into or in (before εἰς, Polyb; with dative, 2Mac, l.with). 3) to fall away (En, Wis, ll. with; in Polyb, with genitive): absol, Heb.6:6. 4) to fail (λόγος, Es, l.with; cf. 1Ki.3:19). (AS)

G3904	παρασκευή	paraskeuē	Preparation Day	G:N-F	<b>παρα-σκευή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ [in LXX: Exo.35:24 39:42 (עֲבֹדָה, with seel, ἀποσκ, κατασκ-), Jdth.2:17 4:5, 1Ma.9:35 א, 2Ma.15:21 *;] 1) preparation. 2) equipment (Jth, ll with). 3) In Jewish usage, the day of preparation for a Sabbath or a feast (= προσάββατον, which see): Mat.27:62, Mrk.15:42, Luk.23:54, Jhn.19:31; with genitive, τοῦ πάσχα, Jhn.19:14; τ. Exo.14:19-20, Jdg.4:16, al; freq. in Polyb.); (b) a camp (Exo.29:14, al.): Heb.13:11, 13 Rev.20:9; (with) <b>barracks, soldiers' quarters</b>: Act.21:34, 37 22:24 23:10, 16 23:32 28:16 (WH, txt, R, om.). παρ-εμ-βάλλω, [in LXX freq. and chiefly for מַחֲנֶה;] 1) to put in beside or between, interpose. 2) In late writers (Polyb, al, LXX) as technical military term; (a) of soldiers, to draw up in line (freq. in 1Ma.2:32, al.); (b) <b>of siege works, to cast up</b>: with accusative and dative, χάρακά σοι, Luk.19:43. G3936	παρίστημι	paristēmi	to stand by	G:V	<b>παρ-ίστημι </b> [in LXX for עָמַד, etc;] I. G3941	πάροικος	paroikos	foreigner	G:A	<b>άρ-οικος</b>, -ον [in LXX chiefly for גֵּר, תּוֹשָׁב;] 1) in cl. Attic, dwelling near, neighbouring; as subst, a neighbour. 2) In late writers (LXX, Philo) and in Iuser. (Deiss, BS, 227 f; Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 102), foreign, alien; as subst, <b>an alien, a sojourner</b>: Act.7:6 (LXX), Act.7:29; metapb, ξένοι καὶ π. (opp. to συμπολίτης), Eph.2:19; π. καὶ παρεπιδήμους (which see), 1Pe.2:11 (see Lft. on Clem. Rom, 1 Co, § 1). (AS)
G3942	παροιμία	paroimia	proverb	G:N-F	<b>παροιμία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; πάροιμος, by the way), [in LXX. Pr title Pro.1:1 25:1, (מָשַׁל) subscr, Sir.6:35 8:8 18:29 39:3 47:17 *;] 1) a wayside saying (Hesych; see LS, see word), <b>a byword, maxim, proverb</b>: 2Pe.2:22. 2) In NT, of figurative discourse (as מָשַׁל, Isa.14:4, al.), <b>a parable, allegory</b>: Jhn.10:6 16:25, 29 (see Abbott, <i>Essays</i>, 82 ff.). G3952	παρουσία	parousia	coming	G:N-F	<b>παρ-ουσία</b>, -ας, ἡ [in LXX: Neh.2:6 A, Jdth.10:18, 2Ma.8:12 2Mac 15:21, 3Ma.3:17 *;] 1) usually in cl, a being present, <b>presence</b>: 1Co.16:17, 2Co.10:10; opp. to ἀπουσία, Php.2:12 (cf. 2Ma.15:21). 2) a coming, arrival, advent (Soph, Eur, Thuc, al, see LS, see word; so Jth, l.with, 2Ma.8:12): 2Co.7:6-7, Php.1:26, 2Th.2:9; in late writers (see M, <i>Th.</i>, 145 ff; MM, xix; <i>LAE</i>, 372 ff.) as technical term for the visit of a king; hence, in NT, specif. of the Advent or Parousia of Christ: Mat.24:3, 27 24:37, 39, 1Co.15:23, 1Th.2:19 3:13 4:15 5:23, 2Th.2:1 2:8, Jas.5:7-8, 2Pe.1:16 3:4 3:12, 1Jn.2:28. G3954	παρρησία	parrēsia	boldness	G:N-F	<b>παρρησία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; πᾶς + ῥῆσις, speech) [in LXX; Lev.26:13 (μετὰ π, קוֺמְמִיּוּת קוֹמְמִיּוּת), Pro.1:20 10:10, Wis.5:1, al;] 1) freedom of speech, plainness, openness, freedom in speaking (Eur, Plat, al.): Act.4:13, 2Co.3:12; παρρησίᾳ, adverbially, freely, openly, plainly, Mrk.8:32, Jhn.7:13, 26 10:24 11:14 16:29 18:20; opp. to ἐν παροιμίαις, Jhn.16:25; ἐν π, Eph.6:19; μετὰ π, Act.2:29 4:29, 31 28:31 2) In LXX (1Ma.4:18, Wis.5:1, al.), FlJ, and NT, also (from the absence of fear which accompanies freedom of speech), <b>confidence, boldness</b>: 2Co.7:4, Php.1:20, 1Ti.3:13; ἔχειν π, Eph.3:12, Phm 8, Heb.3:6 10:19, 35, 1Jn.2:28 Jn 3:21 Jn 4:17 Jn 5:14; μετὰ π, He 416; ἐν π, Col.2:15; id. G3956	πᾶς	pas	all	G:A	<b>πᾶς</b>, πᾶσα, πᾶν, genitive, παντός, πάσης, παντός, [in LXX chiefly for כֹּל;] <b>all, every</b>. I. As adj, 1) with subst. anarth, <b>all, every, of every kind</b>: Mat.3:10 4:23, Mrk.9:49, Luk.4:37, Jhn.2:1 o, Act.27:20, Rom.7:8, Rev.18:17, al. mult; pl, <b>all</b>, Act.22:15, Rom.5:12, Heb.1:6, al; of the highest degree, π. ἐξουσία (προθυμία, χαρά), Mat.28:18, Act.17:11, Phi 2:29, al; also <b>the whole</b> (though in this sense more freq. with art.), Mat.2:3, Act.2:36, Rom.11:26. 2) C. art. (before the art, after the noun, or, denoting totality, between the art. and noun), <b>all, whole</b>: Mat.8:32 13:2, Mrk.5:33, Luk.1:10, Act.7:14, Rom.3:19, Gal.5:14, Eph.4:16, al; pl, Mat.2:4, Mrk.4:13, Rom.1:5, al. II. As pron, 1) masc. and fem, <b>every one</b>: Mrk.9:49, Luk.16:16, Heb.2:9; before rel. pron, Mat.7:24, Act.2:21, Gal.3:10, al; with ptcp. (anarth.), Mat.13:19, Luk.11:4; with ptcp. (with art.), Mat.5:22, Mrk.7:8, Luk.6:47, Jhn.3:8, Rom.1:16, al; pl, πάντες, absol, <b>all, all men</b>, Mat.10:22, Mrk.13:13, Luk.20:38, Jhn.1:7 3:26, 1Co.8:1, al; οἱ π. (collectively, as a definite whole), Rom.11:32, 1Co.1:17, Eph.4:13, al; π. οἱ (ὅσοι), Mat.4:24, Mrk.1:32, Luk.4:40, al. 2) Neut, (a) sing, πᾶν, <b>everything, all</b>: πᾶν τό, with ptcp, 1Co.10:25, 27, Eph.5:13, 1Jn.2:16 5:4 (sc. ὄν); πᾶν ὅ, Jhn.17:2, Rom.14:23; collectively, of persons (Westc, in l.), Jhn.6:37, 39; with prep, in adverbial phrases, διὰ παντός, <b>always</b>, Mat.18:10, al; ἐν παντί, <b>in everything, in every way</b>, 2Co.4:8, Phi 4:6, al; (b) pl, πάτνα, <b>all things</b>: absol, Jhn.1:3, 1Co.2:10, Heb.2:8, al; of certain specified things, Mrk.4:34, Luk.1:3, Rom.8:28, 1Th.5:21, al; accusative, πάντα, adverbially, <b>wholly, in all things, in all respects</b>, Act.20:35, 1Co.9:25, al; with art, τὰ π, <b>all things</b> (a totality, as distinct from anarth. πάντα, all things severally; cf. Westc, <i>Eph.</i>, 186f.), absol: Rom.11:36, 1Co.8:6, Eph.3:9, Heb.1:3, al; relatively, Mrk.4:11, Act.17:25, Rom.8:32, al; πάντα, with ptcp, Mat.18:31, al; πάντα ταῦτα (ταῦτα π.), Mat.6:32, 33, al; πάντα, with prep, in adverbial phrases, πρὸ πάντων, <b>above all things</b>, Jas.5:12, 1Pe.4:8; ἐν π́, <b>in all things, in all ways</b>, 1Ti.3:11, 1Pe.4:11, al; κατὰ πάντα, <b>in all respects</b>, Act.17:22, al. 3) C. neg, πᾶς οὐ (μή) = οὐδείς, see: οὐ and μή, and cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 245f. (AS)
