G3980	πειθαρχέω	peitharcheō	to obey	G:V	<b>πειθαρχέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; πείθομαι, ἀρχή) [in LXX: Dan LXX 7:27 (שְׁמַע), Sir.33:28, I Est.8:94 *;] <b>to obey one in authority, be obedient</b>: Tit.3:1; with dative, Act.27:21; θεῷ, Act.5:29, 32. (AS)
G3981	πειθός	peithos	persuasive	G:A	<b>πειθός</b> (πιθός, WH), -ή, -όν (&lt; πείθω), = cl. πιθανός, <b>persuasive</b>: 1Co.2:4 (not found elsewhere). (AS)
G3982	πείθω	peithō	to persuade	G:V	<b>πείθω</b>, [in LXX chiefly for בָּטַח בֶּטַח, its parts and derivatives;] (i) <b>Active; </b> 1) trans, to apply persuasion ("conative" in pres; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 147), <b>to prevail upon or win over, persuade</b>: absol, Mat.28:14, Act.19:26; before περί, with genitive of thing(s), Act.19:8; with accusative of person(s), Act.12:20 14:19 18:4, 2Co.5:11, Gal.1:10; τ. καρδίας ἡμῶν, 1Jn.3:19; with accusative before περί, Act.28:23; with accusative and inf, Act.13:43 26:28 (see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 141 ff.); with accusative before ἵνα (Plut.), Mat.27:20. 2) Intrans, 2 pf. πέποιθα with Pres. sense (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 147, 154; Bl, § 59, 2): to trust, <b>be confident, have confidence</b>: with accusative and inf, Rom.2:19; with accusative ref. (see Ellic, in l): Php.1:6, 25; with dative, Php.1:14, Phm 21; ἑαυτῷ, with inf, 2Co.10:7; before ἐν, Php.3:3-4; ἐν κυρίῳ ὅτι, Php.2:24; ἐπί, with dative, Mat.27:43 (WH, mg.), Mrk.10:24 (T, WH, R, mg, om.), Luk.11:22 18:9, 2Co.1:9, Heb.2:13; ἐπί, with accusative, Mat.27:43 (with dative, WH, mg.); id. before ὅτι, 2Co.2:3, 2Th.3:4 (see Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 127); εἰς, with accusative of person(s) before ὅτι, Gal.5:10. (ii) Pass. and mid; 1) to be persuaded, believe (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 158): absol, Luk.16:31, Act.17:4 21:14, Heb.13:18; with dative, Act.28:24; with accusative and inf, Act.26:26; so also pf, πέπεισμαι, πεπεισμένος εἰμί: with accusative ref. before περί, Heb.6:9; with accusative and inf, Luk.20:6; ὅτι, Rom.8:38, 2Ti.1:5 1:12; id. with ἐν κυρίῳ, Rom.14:14; περί, with genitive before ὅτι, Rom.15:14. 2) <b>to listen to, obey</b>: with dative of person(s), Act.5:36-37, 40 23:21 27:11, Rom.2:8, Gal.5:7, Heb.13:17, Jas.3:3 (cf. ἀνα-πείθω). <b>Πειθώ</b>, -οῦς, ἡ 1) Peitho, Persuasion (as a goddess). 2) <b>per­suasion</b>: ἐν πειθοῖ (so Orig, Eus. and some cursives in 1Co.2:4 for πειθός, which see). (AS)
G3983	πεινάω	peinaō	to hunger	G:V	<b>πεινάω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX chiefly for = רָעֵב;] <b>to hunger, be hungry</b>: Mat.4:2 12:1, 3 21:18 25:35, 37 25:42, 44, Mrk.2:25 11:12, Luk.1:53 4:2 6:3, Rom.12:20 " (LXX), 1Co.4:11 11:21 11:34 Php.4:12, Rev.7:16; metaph, Mat.5:6, Luk.6:21, 25, Jhn.6:35. (AS)
G3984	πεῖρα	peira	test	G:N-F	<b>πεῖρα</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; πειράω), [in LXX: Deu.28:56 (π. λαμβάνειν, נָסָה pi.) Deu.33:8 (מַסָּה), Wis.18:20, 25, 2Ma.8:9, 4Ma.8:1 *;] <b>trial, experiment</b>; π. λαμβάνειν, <b>to make trial, have experience of</b>: Heb.11:29, 36 (for exx, see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 232 f.). (AS)
G3985	πειράζω	peirazō	to test/tempt	G:V	<b>πειράζω </b> poët. and late prose form of πειράω, which see, [in LXX for נָסָה pi;] 1) to make proof of (Hom.). 2) to try, attempt (Luc, Polyb, with inf. (see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 205; B1, § 69, 4), Act.9:26 16:7 24:6. 3) In LXX and NT, like <i>Heb.</i> נָסָה, with accusative of person(s), to test, try, prove; (a) <b>in a good sense </b>: Jhn.6:6, 2Co.13:5, Heb.11:17, Rev.2:2; esp. of trials and af6ictions sent or permitted by God (Gen.22:1, Exo.20:20, Wis.3:5, al.), 1Co.10:13, Heb.2:18 4:15 11:17, 37, Rev.3:10; (b) <b>in a bad sense </b>(Apoll. Rhod, 3, 10): of the attempts made to ensnare Jesus in his speech, Mat.16:1 19:3 22:18, 35 Mrk.8:11 10:2 12:15, Luk.11:16, Jhn.8:6; of temptation to sin, to tempt, Jas.1:13-14 (see Hort, in l), Gal.6:1, Rev.2:10; esp. of temptations of the devil, Mat.4:1, 3 Mrk.1:13, Luk.4:2, 1Co.7:5, 1Th.3:5; ὁ πειράζων, the tempter, Mat.4:3, 1Th.3:5; (with) in bad sense also (Exo.17:2, 7, Num.14:22, al.), of distrustful testing, trying or challenging of God: Act.15:10, 1Co.10:9 (WH, mg, ἐξεπείρασαν), Heb.3:9; τ. πνεῦμα Κυρίου, Act.5:9 (of. ἐκ-πειράζω). (AS)
G3986	πειρασμός	peirasmos	temptation/testing	G:N-M	<b>πειρασμός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; πειράζω), [in LXX for מַסָּה, עִנְיָן;] 1) = πεῖρα, an experiment Diosc.). 2) a trial, of ethical purpose and effect, whether good or evil (see Hort on Jas.1:13) (a) <b>in good or neutral sense</b>: Gal.4:14, Jas.1:12, 1Pe.4:12; esp. of afflictions sent by God (Deu.7:19, Sir.21:1-28, al.): 2Pe.2:9, Rev.3:10; pl, Luk.22:28, Act.20:19, Jas.1:2, 1Pe.1:6; (b) <b>of trial regarded as leading to sin, temptation</b>: Luk.8:13, 1Co.10:13, 1Ti.6:9; of the temptation of Jesus by the devil, Luk.4:13; εἰσφέρειν (ἔρχεσθαι, εἰσέρχ-) εἰς π, Mat.6:13 26:41, Mrk.14:38, Luk.11:4 22:40, 46; (with) of the testing or challenge of God by man (see: πειράζω, 3, with): Heb.3:8 (LXX: Psa.95:9, where κατα τ. ἡμέραν πειρασμοῦ = מַסָּה the day of Massah). G4005	πεντηκοστή	pentēkostē	Pentecost	G:N-F	<b>πεντηκοστός</b>, -ή, -όν [in LXX for חֲמִישִׁי, חֲמִישִׁי, Lev.25:10-11, 4Ki.15:23 15:27; 1Ma.4:1-61, 2Ma.14:4; ἡ π, Tob.2:1, 2Ma.12:32 *;] fiftieth. G4007	περ	per	fully	G:Part	<b>πέρ</b> (akin to περί), <b>enclitic particle, adding force or positiveness to the word which precedes it</b>: indeed, by far, etc. In the NT, it is always affixed to the word to which it relates, see: διόπερ, άἐνπερ, εἴπερ, ἐπείπερ, ἐπειδήπερ, ἤπερ, καθάπερ, καίπερ, ἅσπερ, ὥσπερ <b>ὥσ-περ </b> <i>adv.</i>, <b>just as, even as</b>: Mat.6:2 20:28, Act.3:17, 1Co.8:5, 1Th.5:3 al; in protasis, with οὕτως (καί) in apodosis: Mat.12:40, Luk.17:24, Jhn.5:21, Rom.5:19, Gal.4:29, Jas.2:26, al (AS)

Ἰορδάνου, Mat.4:15 (LXX), Mat.4:25 19:1, Mrk.3:8 10:1, Jhn.1:28 3:26 10:40; τ. χειμάρρου τ. G4010	Πέργαμος	Pergamos	Pergamum	N:N-F-L	<b>Πέργαμος</b>, -ου, ἡ (so Xen, Paus, al, but -ον, τό in Strabo, Polyb, and most writers, also in Inscr; in NT the termination is uncertain) <b>Pergamum, a city of Mysia</b>: Rev.1:11 2:12. (AS)
G4011	Πέργη	Pergē	Perga	N:N-F-L	<b>Πέργη</b>, -ης, ἡ <b>Perga, a city of Pamphylia</b>: Act.13:13-14 14:25. (AS)
G4012	περί	peri	about	G:Prep	<b>περί</b>, <i>prep.</i> with genitive, accusative (in cl. also with dative; cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 105f.), with radical sense <b>round about</b> (as distinct from ἀμφί, <i>on both sides</i>). I. C. genitive, 1) of place, <b>about</b> (poët.). 2) Causal, <b>about, on account of, concerning, in reference to</b>: Mat.2:8, Mrk.1:44, Luk.4:38, Jhn.16:26, Act.28:21, al. mult; τὰ περί, with genitive, <b>the things concerning</b> one, <b>one's <i>state</i> or <i>case</i></b>: Mrk.5:27, Act.1:3 28:15, Eph.6:22, al; at the beginning of a sentence, περί, <b>regarding, as to</b>, 1Co.7:1, al; in the sense <b>on account of</b> (Mat.26:28, 1Co.1:13, al.), often with ὑπέρ as variant (cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 105). II. C. accusative, 1) of place, <b>about, around</b>: Mat.3:4, Mrk.1:6, Luk.13:8, Act.22:6, al; οἱ περί, with accusative of person(s), of one's associates, friends, etc, Mrk.4:10, Luk.22:49, Jhn.11:19, Act.13:13; οἱ περὶ τ. τοιαῦτα ἐργάται, Act.19:25; metaph, <b>about, as to, concerning</b>: 1Ti.1:19 6:4 2Ti.2:18 3:8, Tit.2:7; τὰ περὶ ἐμέ, Php.2:23; αἱ περὶ τ. λοιπὰ ἐπιθυμίαι, Mrk.4:19. 2) Of time, in a loose reckoning, <b>about, near</b>: Mat.20:3, 5 6, 9 27:46, Mrk.6:48, Act.10:3, 9 22:6. III. <b>In composition</b>: <b>round about</b> (περιβάλλω, περίκειμαι), <b>beyond, over and above</b> (περιποιέω, περιλείπω), <b>to excess</b> (περιεργάζομαι, περισσεύω). (AS)
G4013	περιάγω	periagō	to take/go around	G:V	<b>περι-άγω </b> [in LXX: Amo.2:10 (הָלַךְ hi.); Isa.28:27, Eze.47:2 (סָבַב hi, ho.); Eze.37:2 46:21 (עָבַר hi), 2Ma.4:38 2Mac 6:10 *;] 1) <b>to lead about or around</b>: with accusative of person(s), 1Co.9:5. 2) Intrans, <b>to go about</b>: Act.13:11; before ἐν, Mat.4:23; with accusative loc. (governed by the περι, not so in cl, see Bl, § 34, 1; 53, 1), Mat.9:35 23:15, Mrk.6:6. (AS)
G4014	περιαιρέω	periaireō	to take away	G:V	<b>περι-αιρέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX chiefly for סוּר hi;] to take away that which surrounds, take away, take off (τείχη, Hdt, Thuc; χιτῶνα, Plat; δακτύλιον, Gen.41:42, cf. σφρηγῖδα, Hdt, ii, 151): τ. κάλυΜΜα, pass, 2Co.3:16; as nautical term (RV, cast off), ἀγκύρας, Act.27:40; absol, <b>to cast loose</b>: Act.28:13. Metaph, <b>to take away entirely</b>: ἐλπίς, pass, Act.27:20; ἁμαρτίας, Heb.10:11. (AS)
G4015	περιαστράπτω	periastraptō	to shine	G:V	<b>περι-αστράπτω </b> [in LXX: 4Ma.4:10 *;] <b>to flash around</b>: with accusative, Act.9:3; before περί Act.22:6 (Eccl, and Byzant.). (AS)

G4061	περιτομή	peritomē	circumcision	G:N-F	<b>περι-τομή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; περιτέμνω), [in LXX: Gen.17:13, Exo.4:25-26 (מוּל ni, מוּלָה), Jer.11:16 *;] <b>circumcision</b>; (a) <b>of the rite itself </b>: Jhn.7:22-23 Act.7:8, Rom.4:11, Gal.5:11, Php.3:5; (b) <b>of the state of circumcision</b>: Rom.2:25-28 3:1, 1Co.7:19, Gal.5:6 6:15, Col.3:11; ἐν π. ὤν, Rom.4:10; (with) by meton, π. = οἱ περιτμηθέντες, <b>the circumcised</b>: Rom.3:30 4:9, 12 15:8, Gal.2:7-9, Eph.2:11; οἱ ἐκ τῆς π, of Jews, Rom.4:12; of Jewish Christians, Act.11:2, Gal.2:12, Tit.1:10; οἱ ἐκ π. πιστοί, Act.10:45; οἱ ὄντες ἐκ π, Col.4:11 Metaph, Rom.2:29, Col.2:11, Php.3:3. (AS)

G4100	πιστεύω	pisteuō	to trust (in)	G:V	<b>πιστεύω</b>, [in LXX chiefly for אמן hi;] 1) intrans, <b>to have faith</b> (in), <b>to believe</b>; in cl, with accusative, dative, in NT also with prep, (on the significance of the various constructions, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 67f; Vau. on Rom.4:5; Ellic. on 1Ti.1:16; Abbott, <i>JV</i>, 19-80): absol, Mat.24:23, 26 Mrk.13:21, 1Co.11:18; with accusative of thing(s), Act.13:41, 1Co.13:7; with dative of person(s) (to believe what one says), Mrk.16:[13, 14], 1Jn.4:1; τ. ψεύδει, 2Th.2:11; περί. ὅτι, Jhn.9:18; esp. and most freq. with reference to religious belief: absol, Mat.8:13, Mrk.5:36, Luk.8:50, Jhn.11:40, al; before ὅτι, Mat.9:28, al; with dative (see supr, and cf. <i>DB</i>, i, 829a), Jhn.3:12 5:24 6:30 8:31, Act.16:34, Gal.3:6 " (LXX), 2Ti.1:12, 1Jn.5:10, al; with prep, (expressing personal trust and reliance as distinct from mere credence or belief; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, l.with; <i>DB</i>, i, 829b), <b>to believe in or on</b>: ἐν (Psa.77 (78):22, al.), Mrk.1:15 (see Swete, in l.); εἰς, Mat.18:6, Jhn.2:11 (see Westc, in l.), and freq, Act.10:43 19:4, Rom.10:14, Gal.2:16, Php.1:29, I Jhn.5:10, 1Pe.1:8; εἰς τ. ὄνομα, Jhn.1:12 2:23 3:18, 1Jn.5:13; ἐπί, with accusative, Mat.27:42, Act.9:42 11:17 16:31 22:19, Rom.4:5; ἐπί, with dative, Rom.9:33 (LXX) 10:11 (ib.), 1Ti.1:16, 1Pe.2:6 " (LXX); ptcp. pres, οἱ π, as subst, Act.2:44, Rom.3:22, 1Co.1:21, al; aor, Mrk.16:[16], Act.4:32; pf, Act.19:18 21:20 (on Johannine use of the tenses of π, see Westc, <i>Epp. Jo.</i>, 120). 2) Trans, <b>to entrust</b>: with accusative and dative, Luk.16:11, Jhn.2:24; pass, <b>to be entrusted with</b>: with accusative, Rom.3:2, 1Co.9:17, Gal.2:7, 1Th.2:4 (see Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 21f.), 1Ti.1:11, Tit.1:3. G4101	πιστικός	pistikos	pure	G:A	<b>πιστικός</b>, -ή, -όν (πίστις), 1) having the gift of persuasion (Plat, <i>Gorg.</i>, 455A). 2) (a) of persons, <b>faithful, trusty</b> (Plut.); (b) of things, <b>trustworthy, genuine</b>: νάρδος π, Mrk.14:3, Jhn.12:3. (AS)
G4102	πίστις	pistis	faith/trust	G:N-F	<b>πίστις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; πείθω), [in LXX chiefly for אֱמוּנָה;] 1) in active sense, <b>faith, belief, trust, confidence</b>, in NT always of religious faith in God or Christ or spiritual things: Mat.8:10, Luk.5:20, Act.14:9, Rom.1:8, 1Co.2:5, 2Co.1:24, 1Ti.1:5, al; with genitive obj, Mrk.11:22, Act.3:16, Rom.3:22, Gal.2:16, Eph.3:12, Jas.2:1, al; with prep, ἐν, Rom.3:25, Gal.3:26, Eph.1:15, Col.1:24, 1Ti.1:14 3:13, 2Ti.1:13 3:15, 2Pe.1:1; εἰς, Act.20:21 24:24 26:18, Col.2:5, 1Pe.1:21; πρός, 1Th.1:8, Phm 5; ἐπί, with accusative Heb.6:1; ἐν τῇ π. στήκειν (εἶναι, μένειν), 1Co.16:13, 1Co.13:5, 1Ti.2:15; ὑπακοὴ τῆς π, Rom.1:5 16:26; ὁ ἐκ π, Rom.3:26 4:16, Gal.3:12; διὰ (τῆς) π, Rom.3:30, Gal.2:16, Php.3:9. By meton, objectively, that which is the object or content of belief, <b>the faith</b>: Act.6:7 14:22, Gal.1:23 3:23 6:10, Php.1:26, 27 Ju 3, 20, and perh. also Act.13:8 16:5, Rom.1:5 and 16:26 (see supr.), 1Co.16:13, Col.1:23, 2Th.3:2 (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 125), 1Ti.1:19 3:9 4:1, 6 5:8 6:10, 12, 2Ti.3:8 4:7 Tit.1:4, 13 3:15, 1Pe.5:9. 2) In passive sense, (a) <b>fidelity, faithfulness</b>: Mat.23:23, Gal.5:22; ἡ π. τοῦ θεοῦ, Rom.3:3; (b) objectively, <b>plighted faith, a pledge</b> of fidelity: 1Ti.5:12. (On the various shades of meaning in which the word is used in NT, see esp. <i>ICC</i> on Rom.1:17, pp. 31ff; Lft, <i>Ga.</i>, 154ff; Stevens, <i>Th. NT</i>, 422, 515ff; <i>DB</i>, i, 830ff; Cremer, see word) (AS)
G4103	πιστός	pistos	faithful	G:A	<b>πιστός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; πείθω), [in LXX chiefly for אָמַן;] I. Pass, to be trusted or believed; 1) <b>of persons, trusty, faithful </b>: Mat.24:45 25:21, 23 Luk.12:42, Act.16:15, 1Co.4:2 4:17 7:25, Eph.1:1 6:21, Col.1:2, 7 4:7, 9, 1Ti.1:12, 2Ti.2:2, Heb.2:17 3:2, 5, 1Pe.5:12, Rev.2:13 19:11; of God, 1Co.1:9 10:13, 2Co.1:18, 1Th.5:24, 2Th.3:3, Heb.10:23 11:11, 2Ti.2:13, 1Jn.1:9, 1Pe.4:19; before ἐν, Luk.16:10-12 19:17, 1Ti.3:11; ἐπί, with accusative, Mat.25:23; ἄχρι θανάτου, Rev.2:10; ὁ μάρτυς ὁ π, Rev.1:5; id. καὶ ἀληθινός, Rev.3:14. 2) <b>Of things, trustworthy, reliable, sure</b>: Act.13:34, 1Ti.1:15 3:1 4:9, 2Ti.2:11, Tit.1:9 3:8, Rev.21:5 22:6. II. Act, <b>believing, trusting, relying</b>: Act.16:1, 2Co.6:15, Gal.3:9, 1Ti.4:10 5:16 6:2, Tit.1:6, Rev.17:14; pl, Act.10:45, 1Ti.4:3 4:12; opp. to ἄπιστος, Jhn.20:27; π. εἰς θεόν, 1Pe.1:21; π. ποιεῖν, III Jn 5. (On the difficulty of choosing in some cases between the active and the passive meaning, see Lft, <i>Gal.</i>, 157.) (AS)
G4104	πιστόω	pistoō	be convinced	G:V	<b>πιστόω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; πιστός), [in LXX chiefly for אָמֵן ni;] to make trustworthy (Thuc, 3Ki.1:36), hence, to establish (1Ch.17:14). Pass. and mid, <b>to be assured of</b>: with accusative of thing(s), 2Ti.3:14. (AS)
G4105	πλανάω	planaō	to lead astray	G:V	<b>πλανάω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; πλάνη), [in LXX chiefly for תָּעָה;] to cause to wander, lead astray. Pass, <b>to go astray, wander</b>: Mat.18:12-13 Heb.11:38, 1Pe.2:25 (cf. Isa.53:6). Metaph, <b>to lead astray, deceive</b>: with accusative of person(s), Mat.24:4-5, 11 24:24, Mrk.13:5-6, Jhn.7:12, 2Ti.3:13; 1Jn.1:8 Jn 2:26 Jn 3:7, Rev.2:20 12:9 13:14 19:20 20:3, 8 20:10; pass, <b>to be led astray, to err</b>: Mat.22:29, Mrk.12:24, 27, Luk.21:8, Jhn.7:47, 2Ti.3:13, Tit.3:3, Heb.5:2, 2Pe.2:15, Rev.18:23; τ. καρδίᾳ, Heb.3:10; ἀπὸ τ. ἀληθείας, Jas.5:19; μὴ πλανᾶσθε, 1Co.6:9 15:33, Gal.6:7. Jas.1:16 (cf. ἀπο-πλανάω). (AS)
G4106	πλάνη	planē	error	G:N-F	<b>πλάνη</b>, -ης, ἡ [in LXX: Pro.14:8 (מִרְמָה), Wis.1:12, al;] a wandering. Metaph, <b>a going astray, an error </b>(in NT always with respect to morals or religion): Mat.27:64, Rom.1:27, Eph.4:14, 1Th.2:3, 2Th.2:11, Jas.5:20, 2Pe.2:18 3:17 3:1-18; 1Jn.4:6, Ju 11. (AS)
G4107	πλανήτης	planētēs	wandering	G:A	<b>πλανήτης</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; πλανάω), [in LXX: Hos.9:17 (נָדַד) *;] <b>= πλάνης, a wanderer</b>: ἀστέρες π. (cl. planets), wandering stars, Ju 13 (WH, mg, -τες). (AS)

G4109	πλάξ	plax	tablet	G:N-F	<b>πλάξ</b>, -ακός, ἡ [in LXX for לוּחַ;] anything flat and broad. 1) a plain (poët.). 2) In late writers (Luc, al.), <b>a flat stone, a tablet</b>: 2Co.3:3, Heb.9:4. (AS)

G4111	πλάσσω	plassō	to mold	G:V	<b>πλάσσω </b> [in LXX chiefly for יָצַר;] <b>to form, mould</b>: Rom.9:26 (LXX), 1Ti.2:13. (AS)
G4112	πλαστός	plastos	made-up	G:A	<b>πλαστός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; πλάσσω), 1) formed, moulded (Hes, Plat, al.). 2) Metaph, <b>made up, fabricated, feigned </b>(Hdt, Xen, al.): 2Pe.2:3. (AS)

G4118	πλεῖστος	pleistos	most	G:A	<b>πλεῖστος</b>, πλείων, see: πολύς. <b>πολύς</b>, πολλή, πολύ, [in LXX chiefly for רַב and cognate forms;] 1) as <i>adj.</i>, <b>much, many, great</b>, of number, space, degree, value, time, etc: ἀριθμός, Act.11:21; ὄχλος, Mrk.5:24; θερισμός, Mat.9:37; χόρτος, Jhn.6:10; χρόνος, Mat.25:19; γογγυσμός, Jhn.7:12; πόνος, Col.4:13; δόξα, Mat.24:30; σιγή, Act.21:40; pl, προφῆται, Mat.13:17; ὄχλοι, Mat.4:25; δαιμόνια, Mrk.1:34; δυνάμεις, Mat.7:22, 2) As subst, pl. masc, πολλοί, <b>many</b> (persons): Mat.7:22, Mrk.2:2, al; with genitive partit, Mat.3:7, Luk.1:16, al; before ἐκ, Jhn.7:31, Act.17:12; with art, οἱ π, <b>the many</b>, Mat.24:12, Rom.12:5, 1Co.10:17, 33 2Co.2:17; opp. to ὁ εἶς (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 291), Rom.5:15, 19; neut. pl, πολλά: Mat.13:3, Mrk.5:26, al; accusative with adverbial force, Mrk.1:45, Rom.16:6 (Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 317), 1Co.16:12, Jas.3:2, al; neut. sing, πολύ: Luk.12:48; adverbially, Mrk.12:27, al; πολλοῦ (genitive pret.), Mat.26:9; with compar. (Bl, §44, 5), π. σπουδαιότερον, 2Co.8:22; πολλῷ πλείους, Jhn.4:41. Compar, <b>πλείων</b>, neut, πλεῖον and πλέον (see WH, <i>App.</i>, 151), pl, πλείονες, -ας, -α, contr, πλείους, -ω (cf. Mayser, 69), <b>more, greater</b>; 1) as <i>adj.</i>: Jhn.15:2, Act.18:2 o, Heb.3:3; before παρά, Heb.11:4 (cf. Westc, in l. Was ΠΛΙΟΝΑ here a primitive error for ΗΔΙΟΝΑ?); pi, Act.13:31, al; with genitive compar, Mat.21:36; with num. (ἤ of comp. omitted), Act.4:22 24:11, al. 2) As subst, οἱ π, <b>the greater number</b>: Act.10:32 27:12, 1Co.10:5 15:6; also (Bl, §44, 3) <b>others, more, the more</b>: 2Co.2:6 4:15, Php.1:14; πλείονα, Luk.11:53; πλειον, πλέον, Mat.20:10, 2Ti.3:9; with genitive comp, Mk 12:43, Luk.21:3; π. Ἰωνᾶ ὧδε, Mat.12:41; adverbially, Act.4:17 20:9 24:4. 3) As <i>adv.</i>, πλεῖον: before ἤ, Luk.9:13; with genitive comp, Mat.5:20; πλείω: with num, Mat.26:53. Superl, <b>πλεῖστος</b>, -η, -ον, (a) prop, <b>most</b>: Mat.11:20 21:8; adverbially, τὸ π, 1Co.14:27; (b) elative (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 79), <b>very great</b>: ὄχλος π, Mrk.4:1. (AS)

G4130	πλήθω, πίμπλημι	plēthō, pimplēmi	to fill	G:V	<b>πίμπλημι </b> [in LXX chiefly for מָלֵא, also for שָׂבַע;] trans. form in pres. and impf. of πλήθω (intrans. in these tenses), which supplies the other tense forms; <b>to fill</b>: with accusative, Luk.5:7; with accusative and genitive, Mat.27:48; pass, Mat.22:10, Act.19:29; of that which fills or takes possession of the mind: pass, with genitive, Luk.1:15, 41 1:67 4:28 5:26 6:11, Act.2:4 3:10 4:8, 31 5:17 9:17 13:9, 45. Metaph. (as in LXX for מָלֵא: Gen.29:27, Job.15:32), <b>to complete, fulfil</b>: pass, of prophecy, Luk.21:22; of time, Luk.1:23, 57 2:6, 21-22 (cf. ἐμ-πίμπλημι). πλήθω, see: πίμπλημι (AS)
G4131	πλήκτης	plēktēs	bully	G:N-M	<b>πλήκτης</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; πλήσσω), [in Sm: Psa.35:15 *;] <b>a striker, brawler</b>: 1Ti.3:3, Tit.1:7 (Arist, Plut, al.). (AS)
G4132	πλήμμυρα	plēmmura	flood	G:N-F	<b>πλήμμυρα</b>, -ης (for Att. -ας, see Bl, § 7, 1) (&lt; πλήθω), [in LXX: π. γένεσθαι, Job.40:18 (23) (נָהָר עָשַׁק) *;] a flood (of sea or river): Luk.6:48. (AS)
G4133	πλήν	plēn	but/however	G:Conj	<b>πλήν </b> <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX for רַק, בַּד, אַךְ, etc;] 1) introducing a clause (= ἀλλά, δέ; "it is obvious that πλήν was the regular word in the vulgar language": Bl, § 77, 13), <b>yet, howbeit, only</b>: Mat.11:22, 24 18:7 26:39, 64 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86), Luk.6:24, 35 10:11, 14 10:20 11:41 12:31 13:33 17:1 18:8 19:27 22:21-22, 42 (WH, mg. om.) (the article as a rule being used when the Spirit is regarded as a Person or a Divine Power, and omitted when the reference is to an operation, influence or gift of the Spirit; see WM, 151:5; Bl, §46, 7): anarth, Mat.1:18 3:11, 16 4:1, Mrk.1:8 (Swete, in l.), ib.10, Luk.1:15, Jhn.7:39, Act.19:2, Rom.5:5, 1Co.2:4, al; with art, Mat.4:1 12:31, 32 Mrk.1:10 3:29, Luk.2:26, Jhn.7:36 14:26, Act.4:31 5:3, Rom.8:16, al; (τὸ) π. Ἰησοῦ, Act.16:7; Χριστοῦ, Rom.8:9; Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ, Php.1:19; τὸ π. τ. ἀληθείας, Jhn.15:26 16:13, 1Jn.4:6; λείγει (μαρτυρεῖ) τὸ π. G4160	ποιέω	poieō	to do/make	G:V	<b>ποιέω</b>, -ῶ, [in LXX for a great variety of words, but chiefly for עשׂה;] 1) <b>to make, produce, create, cause</b>: with accusative of thing(s), Mat.17:4, Mrk.9:5, Jhn.9:11, Act.9:39, Rom.9:20, al; of God as Creator (with accusative of person(s) also), Mat.19:4, Mrk.10:6, Luk.11:40, Act.4:24, Heb.1:2, al; like Heb. עשׂה, absol. = ἐργάζομαι, <b>to work</b>, Mat.20:12 (cf. Rut.2:19; so AV, but see infr.), Rev.13:5, R, mg. (but see infr.); σκάνδαλα, Rom.16:17; εἰρεήνην, Eph.2:15, Jas.3:18; ἐπίστασιν, Act.24:12; συστροφήν, Act.23:12; with accusative of thing(s) and dative of person(s), Luk.1:68, Act.15:3; with nouns expressing action or its accomplishment, forming a periphr. for the cogn. verb: ὁδόν π. (cl. ὁ ποιεῖσθαι), <b>to go on, advance</b>, Mrk.2:23; πόλεμον, Rev.11:7, al; ἐκδίκησιν, Luk.18:7, 8; ἐνέδραν, Act.25:3; κρίσιν, Jhn.5:27, Ju 15; ἔργα, Jhn.5:36, al; (σημεῖα), Jhn.2:23 and freq, Act.2:22, al; so also mid. ποιεῖσθαι: μονήν, Jhn.14:23; πορείαν, Luk.13:22; κοινωνίαν, Rom.15:26; of food, <b>to make ready, prepare</b>: δεῖπνον, Mrk.6:21, al; δοχήν, Luk.5:29 14:13; γάμους, Mat.22:2; of time, <b>to spend</b> (cl.): ὥραν, Mat.20:12, RV (but see supr. and cf. (Dem, Exo.23:16, al.), Act.18:21, Rec; πάσχα, Mat.26:18; <b>to make</b> or <b>offer a sacrifice</b> (Plat, Xen, al; Job.42:8, 3Ki.11:33; so some understand τοῦτο ποιεῖτε, Luk.22:19, but see Abbott, <i>Essays</i>, 110ff.); before ἵνα (WM, 422f; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228), Jhn.11:37, Col.4:16, Rev.3:9. 2) <b>to do, perform, carry out, execute</b>: absol, with adv, καλῶς π, Mat.12:12, 1Co.7:37, 38 Jas.2:19; id. before ptcp. (the act. becomes obsolete in late Gk; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 162), <b>to cause to go over, carry, convey</b>. Mid. (always in LXX and NT), ־ομαι, <b>to go, proceed, go on one's way</b>: with accusative, ὁδόν, Act.8:39; before ἐκεῖθεν, Mat.19:15; ἐντεῦθεν, Luk.13:31; ἀπό, Mat.25:41, Luk.4:42; εἰς, Mat.2:20, Mrk.16:12, Luk.1:39, Jhn.7:35, al; εἰς εἰρήνην (cf. 1Ki.1:17). Luk.7:50; ἐν εἰρήνῃ, Act.16:36; ἐπί, with accusative, Mat.22:9, Act.25:12, al; ἕως, Act.23:23; οὗ, Luk.24:28, 1Co.16:6; πρός, with accusative of person(s), Mat.25:9, Luk.11:5, al; κατὰ τ. ὁδόν, Act.8:36; διά, with genitive, Mat.12:1, Mrk.9:30; with inf, Luk.2:3, Jhn.14:2; σύν, Luk.7:6, al; ἵνα, Jhn.11:11; absol, Mat.2:9, Luk.7:8, Jhn.4:50, Act.5:20, al; ptcp, πορευθείς (on the pass. form of the aor, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 161f.), redundant (as in Heb. and Aram; V. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 231; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 21), Mat.2:8, Luk.7:22, al. Metaph. (cf. Soph, <i>O.T.</i>, 884; Xen, Cyr, 2, 2, 24, al), (a) like οἴχομαι in cl, as euphemism for θνήσκω (so הלךְ in Gen.15:2); Luk.22:22 and perh. also 13:33 (see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 66); (b) in ethical sense (Deu.19:9, Psa.14:2, al; cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 11.2; Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 107): before ἐν, Luk.1:6, 1Pe.4:3, 2Pe.2:19; κατά, with accusative, 2Pe.3:3, Ju 16, 18; with dative (Bl, §38, 3), Act.9:31 14:16, Ju 11; (with) of disciples or partisans (Jdg.2:12, 3Ki.11:10, Sir.46:10): before ὀπίσω, with genitive of person(s), Luk.21:8 (cf. δια, εἰς, (-μαι), ἐκ- (-μαι), ἐν- (-μαι), ἐπι- (-μαι), παρα- (-μαι), προ, προσ- (-μαι), συν- (-μαι)). (AS)

G4242	πρεσβεία	presbeia	delegation	G:N-F	<b>πρεσβεία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; πρεσβεύω), [in LXX: 2Ma.4:11 *;] 1) age, seniority. 2) rank, dignity. 3) <b>an embassy</b>; by meton, of the am­bassadors, <b>embassy</b>: Luk.14:32 19:14. (AS)

G4245	πρεσβύτερος	presbuteros	elder	G:A	<b>πρέσβυς</b>, -εως, ὁ poët. form of πρεσβύτης (which see), [in LXX (= πρεσβευτής, an ambassador): Num.21:20 (21), al. (מֲלְאָךְ), Isa.13:8 57:9 (צִיר), 1Ma.9:70, al;] an old man. Compar, πρεσβύτερος, -α, -ον, [in LXX chiefly for זָקֵן;] 1) <b>of age, elder</b>: ὁ νἱὸς ὁ π, Luk.15:25; as subst, opp. to νεανίσκοι, Act.2:17; to νεώτερος, 1Ti.5:1-2; of the religious leaders of the past, Mat.15:2, Mrk.7:3, 5, Heb.11:2 (= οἱ πατέρες, Heb.1:1). 2) <b>Of dignity, rank or office </b>(as found in π. and Inscr. of civil and religious offices, including priesthood, in Asia Minor and in Egypt; see Deiss, BS, 154 ff, 233 If; <i>LAE</i>, 373); (a) <b>among Jews</b>: Mat.16:21 26:47, 57 27:3, 12 27:20, 41 28:12, Mrk.8:31 11:27 14:43, 53 15:1, Luk.7:3 9:22 20:1 22:52, Jhn.8:9, Act.4:5, 8 4:23 6:12 23:14 24:1; τ. Ἰουνδαίων, Act.25:15; τ. λαοῦ, Mat.21:23 26:3 27:1; (b) <b>among Christians</b>: Act.11:30 14:23 15:2, 4 15:6, 22-23 16:4 21:18, 1Ti.5:17 5:19, Tit.1:5, II Jn 1, 3Jn.1, 1Pe.5:1 5:5; τ. ἐκκλησίας, Act.20:17, Jas.5:14; (with) <b>in the visions of the Apocalypse</b>: Rev.4:4, 10 5:5-6, 8 5:11, 14 7:11, 13 11:16 14:3 19:4. G4263	πρόβατον	probaton	sheep	G:N-N	<b>πρόβατον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; προβαίνω), [in LXX chiefly for צֹאן, also for שֶׂה, more rarely for כֶּבֶשׂ (כֶּשֶׂב), רָחֵל;] 1) in Hom, Hdt, cattle, esp. of small cattle, sheep and goats. 2) In NT, as in Attic writers generally (cf. G4287	προθεσμία	prothesmia	set time	G:N-F	<b>προ-θέσμιος</b>, -α, -ον [in Sm: Job.28:3, Dan.9:26 *;] appointed before­hand. In Attic law, as subst. (so always in cl.), ἡ π. (sc. ἡμέρα), <b>a day appointed beforehand, a previously appointed time</b>: Gal.4:2. (AS)

G4314	πρός	pros	to/with	G:Prep	<b>πρός</b>, <i>prep. with genitive, dative, accusative</i> I. I. C. genitive, of motion from a place, <b>from the side of</b>, hence metaph, <b>in the interests of</b>, Act.27:34 (cf. Page, in l.). II. II. C. dative, of local proximity, <b>hard by, near, at</b>: Mrk.5:11, Luk.19:37, Jhn.18:16 20:11, 12 Rev.1:13. III. C. accusative, of motion or direction towards a place or object, <b>to, towards</b>. 1) Of place, (a) <b>after verbs of motion or of speaking and other words with the idea of direction</b>: ἔρχομαι, ἀναβαίνω, πορεύομαι, λέγω, ἐπιστολή, etc, Mat.3:14, Mrk.6:51, Luk.11:5, Jhn.2:3, Act.9:2, al. mult; metaph, of mental direction, hostile or otherwise, Luk.23:12, Jhn.6:52, 2Co.7:4, Eph.6:12, Col.3:13, al; of the issue or end, Luk.14:32, Jhn.11:4, al; of purpose, Mat.26:12, Rom.3:26, 1Co.6:5, al; πρὸς τό, with inf, denoting purpose (cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 218, 220; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 131), Mat.5:28, Mrk.13:22, Eph.6:11, 1Th.2:9, al; (b) of close proximity, <b>at, by, with</b>: Mat.3:10, Mrk.11:4, Luk.4:11, Act.3:2, al; after εἶναι, Mat.13:56, Mrk.6:3, Jhn.1:1, al. 2) 2. Of time, (a) <b>towards</b> (Plat, Xen, LXX: Gen.8:11, al.): Luk.24:29; (b) <b>for</b>: πρὸς καιρόν, Luk.8:13, 1Co.7:5; πρὸς ὥραν, Jhn.5:35, al; πρὸς ὀλίγον, Jas.4:14. 3) Of relation (a) <b>toward, with</b>: Rom.5:1, 2Co.1:12, Col.4:5, 1Th.4:12, al; (b) <b>with regard to</b>: Mat.19:8, Mrk.12:12, Rom.8:31, al; (with) <b>pertaining to, to</b>: Mat.27:4, Jhn.21:22, Rom.15:17, Heb.2:17 5:1; (d) <b>according to</b>: Luk.12:47, 2Co.5:10, Gal.2:14, Eph.3:4 4:14; (e) <b>in comparison with</b>: Rom.8:18. IV. <b>In composition</b>: <b>towards</b> (προσέρχομαι), <b>to</b> (προσάγω), <b>against</b> (προσκόπτω), <b>besides</b> (προσδαπανάω). (AS)

G4383	πρόσωπον	prosōpon	face	G:N-N	<b>πρόσωπον</b>, -ου, τό (&lt; πρός, ὤψ), [in LXX chiefly and very freq. for פָּנִים;] 1) prop, of persons (so always in cl.); (a) <b>the face, countenance</b>: Mat.6:16-17, Mrk.14:65, Luk.9:29, 2Co.3:7, Rev.4:7, al; τὸ π. τῆς γενέτεως (EV, natural face), Jas.1:23; πίπτειν ἐπὶ (τὰ) π, Mat.17:6, Luk.5:12, Rev.7:11, al; ἀγνοούμενος τῷ π, Gal.1:22; π, οὐ καρδίᾳ, 1Th.2:17; κατὰ πρόσωπον (in front, <b>facing</b>: Thuc, Xen, al.), when present, face to face, Act.25:16, 2Co.10:1 10:7, Gal.2:11; id. with genitive, as compound prep, in the presence of (not cl; see Bl, § 40, 9; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 99 f; Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 43 f.), Luk.2:31, Act.3:13; similarly ἀπὸ π. (Heb. (פָּנִים מִלִּפְּנֵי); see Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 29), from the presence of, Act.3:19 5:41 7:45, 2Th.1:9, Rev.12:14 20:11; πρὸ π. (Heb. (פָּנִים לִפְנֵי), before, Mat.11:10, Mrk.1:2, Luk.7:27 " (LXX), al; in other phrases resembling <i>Heb.</i> idiom (Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 42), βλέπειν (ὁρᾶν, θεωρεῖν, ἰδεῖν) τὸ π, to see one's face, i.e. see him in person, Mat.18:10, Act.20:25, 38, 1Th.3:10, Rev.22:4; ἐμφανισθῆναι τῷ π. τοῦ θεοῦ, Heb.9:24; ἐν π. Χριστοῦ, 2Co.2:10 4:6; μετὰ τοῦ π. σου with thy presence, Act.2:28 (LXX); εἰς π. τῶν ἐκκλησιῶν, 2Co.8:24; στηρίζειν τὸ π. (Heb. פָּנִים שׂוּם: Jer.21:10, al; see Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 30), with inf, to set one's face towards, Luk.9:51; similarly, τὸ π. αὐτοῦ ἦν πορευόμενον (<i>op. cit.</i>, 31), Luk.9:53; τὸ π. τοῦ κυρίου ἐπί, 1Pe.3:12 (LXX) (b) <b>form, person</b>: καυχᾶσθαι. ἐν π. καὶ μὴ ἐν καρδίᾳ, 2Co.5:12 (cf. 1Ki.16:7); metaph, as in <i>Heb.</i> idiom, of judgment according to appearance, <b>external condition or circumstances </b>(פָּנִים H5387; see Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 30; Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 43 f.): λαμβάνειν π, Luk.20:21, Gal.2:6; βλέπειν εἰς π, Mat.22:16, Mrk.12:14; θαυμάζειν πρόσωπα, Ju 16. 2) Of things (cf. Dalman, l.with) (a) face, appearance (Psa.104:30): Mat.16:3 (WH, R, mg, om.), Luk.12:56, Jas.1:11 (b) surface (Gen.2:6): Luk.21:35, Act.17:26 (AS)

G4396	προφήτης	prophētēs	prophet	G:N-M	<b>προφήτης</b>, -ου, ὁ [&lt; πρόφημι, <b>to speak forth</b>), [in LXX chiefly for נָבִיא;] one who acts as an interpreter or forth-teller of the Divine will (see Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 83f; Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, §vi), <b>a prophet</b>; 1) in cl. G4423	πτόησις	ptoēsis	fear	G:N-F	<b>πτόησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; πτοέω) [in LXX: Pro.3:25 (פַּחַד), Sir 50:4 א1, 1Ma.3:25 R *;] a fluttering, excitement, caused by any emotion, but esp. by fear, <b>hence, terror</b>: φοβεῖσθαι πτόησιν, to be afraid with (cogn. accusative) or of any terror (see <i>ICC</i>, in l): 1Pe.3:6. G4430	πτῶμα	ptōma	corpse	G:N-N	<b>πτῶμα -τος</b>, τό (&lt; πίπτω), [in LXX: Jdg.14:8 (מַפֶּלֶת), Job.16:15 (14) (פֶּרֶץ), Isa.51:19 (שֹׁד), Jdth.8:19, Wis.4:18, al;] 1) a fall, metaph, a misfortune, calamity (Trag, Plat, Polyb, al; LXX). 2) <b>That which has fallen</b>; (a) <b>of buildings, a ruin </b>(Polyb.); (b) of living creatures, in cl. (poët. only) usually with genitive, νεκρῶν, etc, but also absol, as in late writers and NT, <b>a fallen body, a carcase, corpse</b>: Mat.14:12 24:28, Mrk.15:45; π. αὐτοῦ, Mrk.6:29; αὐτῶν, Rev.11:8-9 (cf. G4432	πτωχεία	ptōcheia	poverty	G:N-F	<b>πτωχεία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; πτωχεύω), [in LXX chiefly for עֳנִי;] <b>beggary, destitution</b>: 2Co.8:2 8:9, Rev.2:9. (AS)
G4433	πτωχεύω	ptōcheuō	be poor	G:V	<b>πτωχεύω</b> (&lt; πτωχός), [in LXX: Jdg.6:6, Psa.79:8 (דָּלַל); Jdg.14:15 A, Pro.23:21 (יָרַשׁ); Psa.34:10 (רוּשׁ), Tob.4:21 *;] 1) to be a beggar, to beg (so chiefly in cl.). 2) <b>to be poor as a beggar, to be destitute, poor</b>: opp. to πλούσιος ὤν, 2Co.8:9. G4434	πτωχός	ptōchos	poor	G:A	<b>πτωχός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; πτώσσω, to crouch, cower), [in LXX for עָנִי, דַּל, רָשׁ, etc;] of one who crouches and cowers, hence, 1) as subst, <b>a beggar</b>: Luk.14:13, 21 16:20, 22. 2) As adj, (a) prop, <b>beggarly</b>: metaph, στοιχεῖα, Gal.4:9 (see Lft, in l); (b) in broader sense (opp. to πλούσιος), <b>poor</b>: Mat.11:5 19:21 26:9, 11, Mrk.10:21 12:42-43 14:5, 7, Luk.4:18 7:22 18:22 19:8 21:3, Jhn.12:5-6, 8 13:29, Rom.15:26, 2Co.6:10, Gal.2:10, Jas.2:2-3, 6, Rev.13:16; π. τ. κόσμῳ, Jas.2:5; metaph, Luk.6:20, Rev.3:17; π. τ. πνεύματι, Mat.5:3. G4435	πυγμή	pugmē	fist	G:N-F	<b>πυγμή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ [in LXX: Exo.21:18, Isa.58:4 (אֶגְרֹף) *;] <b>the fist</b>: πυγμῇ νίψασθαι τ. χῖρας (Τ, πυκνά; Vg, Goth, Copt, crebro), <b>to wash the hands with the fist </b>(diligently, R, txt; up to the elbow, R, mg; the exact meaning is doubtful; see Swete, in l): Mrk.7:3. G4436	Πύθων	Puthōn	divining spirit	G:N-M	<b>πύθων</b>, -ωνος, ὁ 1) in cl, Python, a serpent slain by Apollo, who is hence surnamed the Pythian. 2) In Plut. (ii, 414 E), a name given to ventriloquist soothsayers (ἐγγαστρίμυθοι; cf. Lev.19:31 20:6, 27, 1Ki.28:7), and perhaps in this sense πνεῦμα πύθωνα, <b>a python-spirit</b>: Act.16:16. (AS)

G4518	σαβαχθάνι	sabachthani	sabachthani	A:V	<b>σαβαχθανεί</b> (Rec. -νί; ζαφθανεί, Mt, l.with, WH, mg.) G4521	σάββατον	sabbaton	Sabbath	G:N-N	<b>σάββατον</b>, -ου, τό (Aram. שַׁבָּתָא, transliterated σάββατα, and this being mistaken for a pl, the sing. σάββατον was formed from it), and σάββατα, -ων, τά [in LXX for שַׁבָּת, שַׁבָּתוֹן;] 1) the seventh day of the week, the sabbath (a) the sing. form -ον, τὸ σ: Mat.12:8, Mrk.2:27, Luk.6:5, al; ἡ ἡμέρα τοῦ σ. (in LXX, Exo.20:8, al, usually τῶν σ, see infr.), Luk.13:16 14:5; ὁδὸς σαββάτου, Act.1:12 (cf. Mat.24:29); dative, of time (τῷ) σ, Luk.6:9 14:1; ἐν (τῷ) σ, Mat.12:2, Luk.6:7, Jhn.5:16, al; accusative, of duration, τὸ σ, Luk.23:56; κατὰ πᾶν σ, Act.13:27 15:21 18:4; pl, σ. τρία, Act.17:2 R, txt. (but see infr.); (b) as most freq. in LXX (see Swete, <i>Mk.</i>, 17; Thackeray, <i>Gr.</i>, 35) the pl. form, τὰ σ. (see supr. on the Aram. form. There is also an analogy in the names of other festivals, τ. ἐγκαίνια, ἄζυμα, etc.): Mat.28:1, Col.2:16; ἡ ἡμέρα τῶν σ. (Exo.20:8, al.), Luk.4:16, Act.13:14 16:13; dative pl. (in LXX -τοις, but 1Ma.2:38 as in NT) by metaplasmus (El, § 9, 3), σάββασι, Mat.12:1, 5 12:10-12 Mrk.1:21 2:23 3:2, 4, Luk.4:31 6:2. 2) <b>seven days, a week</b>; (a) the sing. form: πρώτη σαββάτσυ, Mrk.16:9; δὶς τοῦ σ. (Bl, § 35, 4; 36, 13), Luk.18:12; κατὰ μίαν σαββάτου, 1Co.16:2; pl, σ. τρία, Act.17:2 R, mg. (but see supr.); (b) the pl. form: ἡ μία τῶν σ. (where the genitive = μετὰ τά; Soph, <i>Lex.</i>, 43a), Mat.28:1, Mrk.16:2, Luk.24:1, Jhn.20:1, 19, Act.20:7 (AS)
G4522	σαγήνη	sagēnē	dragnet	G:N-F	<b>σαγήνη</b>, -ης, ἡ [in LXX chiefly for חֵרֶם;] <b>a drag-net, seine</b>: Mat.13:47. (AS)
G4523	Σαδδουκαῖος	Saddoukaios	Sadducee	N:N--T	<b>Σαδδουκαῖος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; Heb. צָדוֹק, 2Ki.15:24, al.), <b>a Sadducee </b>(cf. Swete, <i>Mk.</i>, 277): Mat.3:7 16:1, 6 16:11-12 22:23-34 Mrk.12:18, Luk.20:27, Act.4:1 5:17 23:6-8. (AS)
G4524	Σαδώκ	Sadōk	Zadok	N:N-M-P	<b>Σαδώκ</b>, ὁ indecl. (Heb. צָדוֹק, see supr, see word Σαδδουκαῖος) <b>Sadoc, Zadok</b>: Mat.1:14. (AS)
G4525	σαίνω	sainō	to shake	G:V	<b>σαίνω </b> 1) prop. (Hom, al.), of dogs, to wag the tail, fawn. 2) Metaph, of persons, with accusative, <b>to fawn upon, flatter, beguile</b>: pass, 1Th.3:3 (for conjectural emendations of the text, see <i>ICC</i>, and M, <i>Th.</i>, in l). (AS)
G4526	σάκκος	sakkos	sackcloth	G:N-M	<b>σάκκος </b> also written σάκος, -ου, ὁ (cf. <i>Heb.</i> שַׂק, which it renders in LXX), 1) <b>a coarse cloth, sackcloth, usually made of hair</b>: Rev.6:12. 2) <b>Anything made of sackcloth</b>; (a) a sack (Gen.42:25, al.); (b) <b>a garment of sackcloth, expressive of mourning or penitence</b>: Mat.11:21, Luk.10:13, Rev.11:3. (AS)

G4530	Σαλείμ	Saleim	Salim	N:N--L	<b>Σαλείμ</b>, τό indecl, <b>Salim</b>: Jhn.3:23 (see Westc, in l; <i>DB</i>, iii, 354). (AS)
G4531	σαλεύω	saleuō	to shake	G:V	<b>σαλεύω</b> (&lt; σάλος), [in LXX for מוֹט, זוּעַ, etc;] prop, of the action of wind, storm, etc, <b>to agitate, shake</b>: of a reed, Mat.11:7, Luk.7:24; a house, Luk.6:48, Act.4:31 16:26; the earth, Heb.12:26; the heavenly bodies, Mat.24:29, Mrk.13:25, Luk.21:26; of a vessel shaken in filling, Luk.6:38. Metaph, (a) to shake, i.e. to render insecure: τὰ σαλευόμενα, τὰ μὴ, Heb.12:27; (b) with accusative of person(s), to cast down from a sense of security and happiness: Act.2:25 (LXX); (with) <b>to unsettle or drive away</b>: pass, before ἀπὸ τ. νοός, 2Th.2:2; (d) <b>to stir up</b>: τ. ὄχλους, Act.17:13. (AS)

G4559	σαρκικός	sarkikos	fleshly	G:A	<b>σαρκικός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; σάρξ) (seel. for σάρκινος, Arist, H.A, x, 2, 7) = Lat. carnalis, i.e. (a) <b>associated with or pertaining to the flesh, fleshly, carnal</b>: Rom.15:27, 1Co.9:11; (b) <b>in a more ethical sense, of the nature of the flesh, under the control of its appetites, fleshly, carnal, sensual </b>(but including more than mere sensuality; cf. Hort, 1Pe, 133): 1Co.3:3, 2Co.1:12 10:4, 1Pe.2:11. (AS)
G4560	σάρκινος	sarkinos	fleshly	G:A	<b>σάρκινος</b>, -η, -ον (&lt; σάρξ), [in LXX: 2Ch.32:8, Eze.11:19 36:26 (בָּשָׂר), Est.4:17, Pro.24:23 (Pro.29:27) *;] = Lat. carneus (the termination -ινος denoting the substance or material of a thing; see Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, § LXXii; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 184; and for illustrations from π, see MM, xxii), of the flesh, of flesh, <b>fleshy </b>(Plat, Arist, Plut, al.): Rom.7:14, 1Co.3:1, 2Co.3:3, Heb.7:16. (Rec. has -ικός in all these passages except 2Co.3:3, but the evidence is decisive against it.) (AS)
G4561	σάρξ	sarx	flesh	G:N-F	<b>σάρξ</b>, σαρκός, ἡ [in LXX chiefly for בָּשָׂר;] <b>flesh</b>; 1) as in cl. generally, (a) prop, of the soft substance of the animal body: 1Co.15:39, 2Co.12:7, Gal.6:13, al; σ. καὶ αἷμα, 1Co.5:50; σ. καὶ ὀστέα, Luk.24:39; pl, of the flesh of many or parts of the flesh of one (cl.), Rev.17:16 19:18; φαγεῖν, Re, ll. with (cf. κατεσθίειν, 4Ki.9:36, al, and βιβρώσκειν, freq. in l.); metaph, Jas.5:3; mystically, φ. (τρώγειν) τὴν σ. τοῦ υἱοῦ τ. ἀνθρώπου, Jhn.6:52-56; (b) <b>Of the whole substance of the body, = σῶμα</b>: Act.2:26 (LXX), 31, 2Co.12:7, Gal.4:14, Eph.5:29; μία σ, Mrk.10:8; εἰς σ. μίαν (Gen.2:24), Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, 1Co.6:16, Eph.5:31; hence, of the material as opp. to the immaterial part of man (cf. Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 88): opp. to πνεῦμα, 1Co.5:5, 2Co.7:1, Col.2:5, 1Pe.3:18, 4:6; to ψύχη, Act.2:31, Rec; of the present life, ἐν (τῇ) σ, Rom.7:5, Gal.2:20, Php.1:22, 24 1Pe.4:2; of Christ's life on earth, αἱ ἡμέραι τ. σαρκὸς αὐτοῦ, Heb.5:7; of things pertaining to the body, ἐν (τῇ) σ, Gal.6:12, 13 Php.3:3, 4. 2) As in Heb. idiom, (a) <b>of a living creature</b>: πᾶσα σ. (Heb. כָּל־בָּשָׂר; cf. Bl, §47, 9), Mat.24:22, Mrk.13:20, 1Pe.1:24; esp. of man and his mortality (Psa.55 (56):5, Sir.28:5, al.), Jhn.1:14; πᾶσα σ. (see supr.), Luk.3:6, Jhn.17:2, Act.2:17, ἐν σ, 1Jo.4:2, 1Ti.3:16; (b) of natural origin and relationship (Gen.2:24, Isa.58:7, al.): τέκνα τῆς σ, Rom.9:8; κατὰ σάρκα, ib. 3, 5, 1Co.10:18, Gal.4:23, 29; ἡ σ. μου, Rom.11:14 (cf. Jdg.9:2, 2Ki.5:1, al.). 3) Of the physical nature as subject to sensation and desire (Plut.), (a) <b>without any ethical disparagement</b>: Rom.7:18 13:14; opp. to πνεῦμα, Mat.26:41, Mrk.14:38; τ. θέλημα τῆς σ, Jhn.1:13; ἡ ἐπιθυμία τῆς σ, 1Jn.2:16; pl, 2Pe.2:18; παθεῖν σαρκί, 1Pe.4:1; (b) in ethical sense, esp. in Pauline Epp, of the flesh as the seat and vehicle of sinful desires: opp. to νοῦς, Rom.7:25; to πνεῦμα, Rom.8:4-9, 12, 13, Gal.5:16, 17 19 6:8 (cf. <i>DB</i>, ii, 14f; iv, 165f; Cremer, 844ff.). (AS)

G4570	σβέννυμι	sbennumi	to extinguish	G:V	<b>σβέννυμι </b> [in LXX chiefly for כָּבָה;] <b>of fire or things on fire, to quench</b>: with accusative, Mat.12:20, Eph.6:16, Heb.11:34; pass, Mat.25:8, Mrk.9:48, [44, 46]. G4571	σέ	se	you	G:PerP	<b>αὐτός</b>, -ή, -ό, <i>determinative pron.</i>, in late Gk. much more freq. than in cl. (WM, 178f; Jannaris, <i>HGG</i>, §1399). 1) Emphatic (so always in nom. exc. when preceded by the art, see infr, iii); (1) <b>self</b> (ipse), expressing opposition, distinction, exclusion, etc, αὐ. ἐκχυθήσεται, Luk.5:37; αὐ. ἐγινώσκεν, Jhn.2:25; αὐ.ὑμεῖς, Jhn.3:28; καὶ αὐ. ἐγώ, Rom.15:14; αὐ. Ἰησοῦς, Jhn.2:24; αὐ. καὶ οἱ μετ᾽ αὐτοῦ, Mrk.2:25; ὑμεῖς αὐ, Mrk.6:31; esp. (as freq in cl.) αὐ. ὁ, Mat.3:4, Mrk.6:17, Jhn.16:27, 1Th.3:11, al; in late Gk, sometimes weakened, ἐν αὐτῇ τ. ὥρᾳ, <b>in that hour</b>, Luk.10:21 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 91; MM, see word); (2) emphatic, <b>he, she, it</b> (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86; Bl, §48, 1, 2, 7), Mat.1:21, 12:50, Luk.6:35, al; pointing to some one as master (cl.), Mat.8:24, Mrk.4:38, al; αὐ, καὶ αὐ. = οὗτος, ὁ δε (BL, §48, 1), Mat.14:2, Mrk.14:15, 44, Luk.1:22, 2:28, al. 2) In oblique cases (cl.), for the simple pron. of 3rd of person(s), <b>he, she, it</b>, Mat.7:9, 10:12, 26:44, al; with ptcp. in genitive absol, Mat.9:18, Mrk.13:1, al. (for irreg. constructions, V. Bl, §74, 5); pleonastically after the relative (cf. Heb. אֲשֶׁר לוֹ; WM, 184ff; Bl, §50, 4; MM, see word), Mrk.7:25, Rev.3:8, 7:2, al; in constr. ad sensum, without proper subject expressly indicated, Mat.4:23, Act.8:5, 2Co.2:13, al; genitive αὐτοῦ = ἐκείνου, Rom.11:11, 1Th.2:19, Tit.3:5, Heb.2:4. 3) ὁ, ἡ, τὸ αὐ, <b>the same</b>: Heb.1:12, 13:8; τὸ αὐ, ποιεῖν, Mat.5:46, 47, al; φρονεῖν, Rom.12:16, 15:5, Php.2:2, al; τὰ αὐ, Act.15:27, Rom.2:1, al; κατὰ τὸ (τὰ) αὐ. (MM, see word), Act.14:1, Luk.6:23, al; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐ, <b>together</b> (MM, see word), Mat.22:34, Act.1:15, al; ἓν κ. τὸ αὐ, 1Co.11:5, 12:11; with dative (cl.), 1Co.11:5; with a noun, λόγος, Mrk.14:39; μέτρος, Php.1:30; πνεῦμα, 1Co.12:4. (AS)
G4572	σεαυτοῦ	seautou	yourself	G:RefP	<b>σεαυτοῦ</b>, -ῆς, -οῦ (in NT not contracted, σαυτοῦ, as in Att.), <i>reflex. prop. of 2nd of person(s) sing.</i>, used only in <i>genitive, dative and accusative </i> (of, to) thyself: Mat.4:6, Jhn.8:13, 1Ti.4:16, al. (In Hellenistic, the pl. is ἑαυτῶν (which see), not ὑμῶν αὐτῶν as in Attic, see Bl, § 13, 1.) (AS)
G4573	σεβάζομαι	sebazomai	to worship	G:V	<b>σεβάζομαι</b> (&lt; σέβας, reverential awe), [in Aq: Hos.10:5 *;] 1) to fear (Hom). 2) <b>In later writers, = σέβομαι, to worship</b>: Rom.1:25 (AS)

G4575	σεβαστός	sebastos	emperor	G:A	<b>σεβαστός</b>, -ή, -όν (σεβάζομαι) 1) reverend, august. 2) In late writers, with reference to <b>the Roman Imperial name</b>; (a) ὁ Σ, Augustus, i.e. the Roman Emperor: Act.25:21, 25; (b) <b>Augustan</b>: σπείρα σ, Act.27:1 (See further, Deiss, BS, 218.) (AS)

Ἕλληνες), devout, Act.13:43, 50 17:4, 17 (cf. προσήλυτος). (AS)

G4583	σεληνιάζομαι	selēniazomai	be epileptic	G:V	<b>σεληνιάζω</b> (&lt; σελήνη), act, in Manetho (Caren, 4, 81), in NT depon. -ομαι, to be moonstruck, i.e. epileptic (epilepsy being supposed to be influenced by the moon): Mat.4:24 17:15. (AS)

G4623	σιωπάω	siōpaō	be quiet	G:V	<b>σιωπάω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; σιωπή, silence) [in LXX for חָשָׁה, חָרַשׁ hi, etc;] <b>to be silent or still, keep silence</b>: Mat.20:31 26:63, Mrk.3:4 9:34 10:48 14:61, Luk.19:4, Act.18:9; of one dumb, Luk.1:20 (cf. 4Ma.10:18); addressed rhetorically to the sea, σιώπα, Mrk.4:39. G4624	σκανδαλίζω	skandalizō	to cause to stumble	G:V	<b>σκανδαλίζω</b> (&lt; σκάνδαλον), [in LXX: Dan LXX 11:41 (כָּשַׁל ni.), Sir.9:5 (Sir.35:15 32:15) (יָקֹשׁ ho.) Sir.23:8 (also in Aq, Sm, <i>Th.</i>, and in Psa Sol Psa.16:7; not elsewhere, except NT and eccl.)*;] prop, to put a snare or stumbling-block in the way; in NT always metaph. of that which hinders right conduct or thought, <b>to cause to stumble</b>: with accusative of person(s), Mat.5:29-30 17:27 18:6, 8-9 Mrk.9:42-43, 45 9:47 Luk.17:2, Jhn.6:61, 1Co.8:13. Pass, <b>to be made to stumble, to stumble</b>: Mat.11:6 13:21, 57 15:12 24:10 26:31, 33, Mrk.4:17 6:3 14:27, 29, Luk.7:23, Jhn.16:1, Rom.14:21 (WH, R, txt, om.), 2Co.11:29, (AS)
G4625	σκάνδαλον	skandalon	stumbling block	G:N-N	<b>σκάνδαλον</b>, -ου, τό (late form of the rare word σκανδάληθρον, see LS, see word) [in LXX chiefly for מוֹקֵשׁ, מִכְשׁוֹל;] prop, the bait-stick of a trap, a snare, stumbling-block (Lev.19:14, Jdth.5:1): figuratively, Rom.9:33, 1Pe.2:8 (Isa.8:14; aliter in LXX; στερεὸν σκανδάλου in Aq.). Metaph, of that which causes error or sin; (a) <b>of persons</b>: Mat.13:41 16:23; Χριστὸς ἐσταυρωμένος, 1Co.1:23; (b) <b>of things</b>: Mat.18:7, Rom.11:9 " (LXX) Rom.14:13, 1Jn.2:10 Rev.2:14; τὸ σ. τοῦ σταυροῦ, Gal.5:11; pl, Mat.18:7, Luk.17:1, Rom.16:17. (AS)

G4632	σκεῦος	skeuos	vessel	G:N-N	<b>σκεῦος</b>, -ους, τό [in LXX chiefly for כְּלִי;] <b>a vessel, implement </b>(for exx. in various senses, see MM, xxii): Mrk.11:16, Luk.8:16, Jhn.19:29, Act.10:11, 16 11:5, Rom.9:21, Rev.18:12; pl, 2Ti.2:20, Rev.2:27; τὰ σ. τῆς λειτουργίας, Heb.9:21; pl, τὰ σ, utensils, goods, Mat.12:29, Mrk.3:27, Luk.17:31; id. of the tackle or gear of a ship (Xen, Polyb, al.); so in sing, τὸ σ, Act.27:17. Rom.9:21), 2Ti.2:21; of woman, ἀσθενέστερον σ, 1Pe.3:7; so perh. τ. ἑαυτοῦ σ, 1Th.4:4 (but see infr.); of the body, 2Co.4:7; so perh. 1Th.4:4 (but see supr, and see: κτάομαι). <b>κτάομαι</b>, -ῶμαι [in LXX chiefly for קָנָה;] in pres, impf, fut. and aor, <b>to procure for oneself, get, gain, acquire </b>(the pf. and plpf, to have acquired, hence to possess, do not occur in NT): with accusative of thing(s), Mat.10:9, Luk.18:12, Act.8:20; with genitive pret, Act.22:28; ἐκ with genitive pret, Act.1:18; τ,ψυχὰς ὑμῶν (MM, xvi), Luk.21:19; τ. ἑαυτοῦ σκεῦος κτᾶσθαι, 1Th.4:4 (where if σ. = body, κ. must = pf, κέκτημαι; see MM, xvi; M, <i>Th.</i>, in l; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 72 f. But σ. is most freq. taken as = wife; see Thayer, see word; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 53 ff; <i>ICC</i>, in l). (AS)

G4670	Σόδομα	Sodoma	Sodom	N:N--L	<b>Σόδομα</b>, -ων, τά (Heb. סְדֹם), Sodom (Gen.13:10, 12, al.): Mat.10:15 11:23-24 Luk.10:12 17:29, Rom.9:29 " (LXX), 2Pe.2:6, Ju 7, Rev.11:8. (AS)
G4671	σοί	soi	you	G:PerP	<b>αὐτός</b>, -ή, -ό, <i>determinative pron.</i>, in late Gk. much more freq. than in cl. (WM, 178f; Jannaris, <i>HGG</i>, §1399). 1) Emphatic (so always in nom. exc. when preceded by the art, see infr, iii); (1) <b>self</b> (ipse), expressing opposition, distinction, exclusion, etc, αὐ. ἐκχυθήσεται, Luk.5:37; αὐ. ἐγινώσκεν, Jhn.2:25; αὐ.ὑμεῖς, Jhn.3:28; καὶ αὐ. ἐγώ, Rom.15:14; αὐ. Ἰησοῦς, Jhn.2:24; αὐ. καὶ οἱ μετ᾽ αὐτοῦ, Mrk.2:25; ὑμεῖς αὐ, Mrk.6:31; esp. (as freq in cl.) αὐ. ὁ, Mat.3:4, Mrk.6:17, Jhn.16:27, 1Th.3:11, al; in late Gk, sometimes weakened, ἐν αὐτῇ τ. ὥρᾳ, <b>in that hour</b>, Luk.10:21 (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 91; MM, see word); (2) emphatic, <b>he, she, it</b> (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86; Bl, §48, 1, 2, 7), Mat.1:21, 12:50, Luk.6:35, al; pointing to some one as master (cl.), Mat.8:24, Mrk.4:38, al; αὐ, καὶ αὐ. = οὗτος, ὁ δε (BL, §48, 1), Mat.14:2, Mrk.14:15, 44, Luk.1:22, 2:28, al. 2) In oblique cases (cl.), for the simple pron. of 3rd of person(s), <b>he, she, it</b>, Mat.7:9, 10:12, 26:44, al; with ptcp. in genitive absol, Mat.9:18, Mrk.13:1, al. (for irreg. constructions, V. Bl, §74, 5); pleonastically after the relative (cf. Heb. אֲשֶׁר לוֹ; WM, 184ff; Bl, §50, 4; MM, see word), Mrk.7:25, Rev.3:8, 7:2, al; in constr. ad sensum, without proper subject expressly indicated, Mat.4:23, Act.8:5, 2Co.2:13, al; genitive αὐτοῦ = ἐκείνου, Rom.11:11, 1Th.2:19, Tit.3:5, Heb.2:4. 3) ὁ, ἡ, τὸ αὐ, <b>the same</b>: Heb.1:12, 13:8; τὸ αὐ, ποιεῖν, Mat.5:46, 47, al; φρονεῖν, Rom.12:16, 15:5, Php.2:2, al; τὰ αὐ, Act.15:27, Rom.2:1, al; κατὰ τὸ (τὰ) αὐ. (MM, see word), Act.14:1, Luk.6:23, al; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐ, <b>together</b> (MM, see word), Mat.22:34, Act.1:15, al; ἓν κ. τὸ αὐ, 1Co.11:5, 12:11; with dative (cl.), 1Co.11:5; with a noun, λόγος, Mrk.14:39; μέτρος, Php.1:30; πνεῦμα, 1Co.12:4. G4672	Σολομών, Σαλωμών	Solomōn, Salōmōn	Solomon	N:N-M-P	<b>Σολομών</b>, -ῶνος (so prop, but Rec. has freq. -ῶν, -ῶντος, as also WH in Act.3:11 5:12; in Act.7:47 T has Σαλωμών, as LXX freq, indecl; see B1, § 10, 1; Tdf, Prol, 104, 119; WH, <i>App.</i>, 158), ὁ (Heb. שְׁלֹמֹה), <b>Solomon</b>: Mat.1:6-7 6:29 12:42, Luk.11:31 12:27, Jhn.10:23, Act.3:11 5:12 7:47. G4707	σπουδαιότερος	spoudaioteros	more diligent	G:A	- more diligent, prompt, earnest (MT)
G4708	σπουδαιοτέρως	spoudaioterōs	more eagerly	G:Adv	earnestly, zealously, with vigor; (compar.) all the more eager, with special urgency eagerly <b>earnestly, eagerly, diligently,</b> Lk. 7:4; 2Tim. 1:17; Tit. 3:13; <i>comparative</i> σπουδαιοτέρως, <b>more earnestly, with special urgency,</b> Phil. 2:28 (MT)
G4709	σπουδαίως	spoudaiōs	diligently	G:Adv	<b>σπουδαίως</b> <i> adv.</i> (&lt; σπουδαῖος), [in LXX: Wis.2:6 *;] 1) with haste or zeal, i.e. earnestly, <b>zealously, diligently</b>: Luk.7:4, 2Ti.1:17, Tit.3:13; compar, -οτέρως, Php.2:28 (RV, Lft, Weymouth, al, but see infr.) 2) <b>hastily, speedily</b>: compar, -οτέρως, Php.2:28 (Thayer, Zorell, see word; <i>ICC</i>, in l, al, but see supr.). (AS)
G4710	σπουδή	spoudē	diligence	G:N-F	<b>σπουδή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; σπεύδω), [in LXX chiefly for בָּהַל, its parts and derivatives;] 1) <b>haste, speed</b>: μετὰ σ. (Wis.19:2), Mrk.6:25, Luk.1:39. 2) <b>zeal, diligence, earnestness</b>: Rom.12:11, 2Co.7:11-12 8:7-8; ἐν σ, Rom.12:8 (see M, Pr, 104); before ὑπέρ, 2Co.8:16; σπουδὴν ἐνδείκνυσθαι, Heb.6:11; σ. παρεισφέρειν, 2Pe.1:5; πᾶσαν σ. ποιεῖσθαι, Ju 3 (see MM, xxiii; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 214; Deiss, BS, 361, 364). (AS)
G4711	σπυρίς	spuris	basket	G:N-F	<b>σφυρίς</b> (T, Rec. σπυρίς, see WH, <i>App.</i>, 148; 131, § 6, 7), -ίδος, ἡ, <b>a flexible mat-basket for carrying provisions</b>: Mat.15:37 16:10, Mrk.8:8, 20 Act.9:25 (see: κόφινος). (AS)
G4712	στάδιος	stadios	stadium	G:N-L	<b>στάδιον</b>, -ου, τό pl, στάδια (Jhn.6:19, T), and metapl, στάδιοι (see B1, 9, 1), [in LXX: Dan LXX 4:9, Sus 1:37, 2Ma.11:5 2Mac 12:9 ff. *;] a stadium, i.e. 1) a measure of length = 600 Greek feet or 1⁄8 of a Roman mile Mat.14:24 (Rec, WH, txt, R, mg.), Luk.24:13, Jhn.6:19 11:18, Rev.14:20 21:16, and, this being the length of the Olympic course, 2) <b>a race-course</b>: 1Co.9:24. (AS)
G4713	στάμνος	stamnos	jar	G:N-F	<b>στάρνος</b>, -ου (ὁ and), ἡ [in LXX: Exo.16:33 (צִנְצֶנֶת), 3Ki.12:24 14:3 (בַּקְבֻּק), Dan LXX Bel, 1:32 *;] prop, an earthen jar for racking off wine, hence, generally, <b>a jar</b>: Heb.9:4. (AS)
G4714	στάσις	stasis	uprising	G:N-F	<b>στάσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ἵστημι), [in LXX chiefly for עָמַד, its parts and derivatives, also for רִיב (Pr 1714), etc. (see Deiss, BS, 158 f.);] 1) <b>a standing, place, status</b>: σ. ἔχειν (Polyb, v, 5, 3; and cf. Lat. locum habere), Heb.9:8. 2) <b>insurrection, sedition</b>: Mrk.15:7, Luk.23:19, 25, Act.19:40 24:5. 3) In poets and late prose, strife, dissension (cf. MM, xxiii) Act.15:2 23:7, 10. (AS)
G4715	στατήρ	statēr	coin	G:N-M	<b>στατήρ</b>, -ῆρος, ὁ [in Aq, Sm, for מִשְׁקָל;] <b>a stater</b>; (a) <b>a weight</b>; (b) <b>a coin </b>(used by late writers of the Greek τετράδραχμον): Mat.17:27 26:16, WH, mg. (AS)
G4716	σταυρός	stauros	cross	G:N-M	<b>σταυρός</b>, -oῦ, ὁ 1) an upright pale or stake (Hom, Hdt, Thuc, al.) 2) In late writers (Diod, Plut, al.) of the Roman instrument of crucifixion, <b>the Cross</b>: of the Cross on which Christ suffered, Mat.27:32, 40 27:42, Mrk.15:21, 30 15:32, Luk.23:26, Jhn.19:17, 19 19:25, 31, Col.2:14, Heb.12:2; θάνατος σταυροῦ, Php.2:8; τ. αἷμα τοῦ σ, Col.1:20. Metaph, <b>in proverbial sayings</b>: αἴρειν (λαμβάνειν, βαστάζειν) τὸν σ, Mat.10:38 16:24, Mrk.8:34 10:21, 15:21, Luk.9:23 14:27 (for an interesting ex. of metaph. use in π, see MM, xxiii) By meton, <b>for Christ's death on the Cross</b>: 1Co.1:17, Gal.5:11 6:12, 14, Eph.2:16, Php.3:18; ὁ λόγος ὁ τοῦ σ, 1Co.1:18. (AS)
G4717	σταυρόω	stauroō	to crucify	G:V	<b>σταυρόω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; σταυρός), [in LXX: Est.7:9 (תָּלָה), Est.8:13 *;] 1) to fence with pales, impalisade (Thuc.). 2) In late writers (Polyb, FlJ; but ἀνασταυρόω is more common) to crucify: with accusative of person(s), Mat.20:19 23:34 26:2 27:22 ff. Mat.28:5, Mrk.15:16 ff. Mrk.16:6, Luk.23:21, 23 23:33 24:7, 20, Jhn.19:6 ff, Act.2:36 4:10, 1Co.1:13 1:23 2:2 2:8, 2Co.13:4, Gal.3:1, Rev.11:8; metaph, Gal.5:24 6:14. (AS)
G4718	σταφυλή	staphulē	grapes	G:N-F	<b>σταφυλή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ [in LXX for עֵנָב;] <b>a bunch of grapes</b>: Mat.7:16, Luk.6:44, Rev.14:18. "σ. is properly the ripe grape-cluster as opp. to ὄμφαξ, cf. Gen.40:10, Job.15:33; as contrasted with βότρυς, it describes the grapes rather than the cluster on which they grow" (Swete, Apoc, 187 f.). (AS)

G4722	στέγω	stegō	to endure	G:V	<b>στέγω</b> (cf. Lat. tego), [in LXX: Sir.8:17 *;] 1) prop, to cover closely, to protect by covering, esp. to keep water in or out (Soph, Plat, al.). 2) <b>to cover, keep secret, conceal </b>(Sir, l.with, Polyb, al.): 1Co.13:7, R, mg. 3) <b>By covering to ward of, bear up under, endure </b>(for exx, see, Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 40; M, <i>Th.</i>, 36): 1Co.9:12 13:7, 1Th.3:1 3:5. G4723	στεῖρα	steira	infertility	G:N-F	<b>στεῖρος</b>, -ον also -α, -ον, [in LXX for עָקָר;] <b>barren</b>: of a woman, Luk.1:7, 36 23:29, Gal.4:27 " (LXX). (AS)
G4724	στέλλω	stellō	to avoid	G:V	<b>στέλλω </b> [in LXX (mid.): Mal.2:5 (חָתַת ni.), Pro.31:24 (26), Wis.7:14 14:1, 2Ma.5:1, 3Ma.1:19 3Mac 4:11 *;] 1) prop, to set, place, arrange, fit out; hence, mid, to set oneself for, prepare (Wis, xi Mac, ll. with). 2) to bring together, gather up (in Hom. of furling sails), hence to restrain, check; mid, <b>to restrain or withdraw oneself, hold aloof, avoid</b>: 2Co.8:20; before ἀπό, 2Th.3:6 (cf. ἀπο, ἐξ-απο, συν-απο, δια, ἐπι, κατα, συ(ν), ὑπο-στέλλω). G4729	στενοχωρέω	stenochōreō	to press upon	G:V	<b>στενο-χωρέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; στενός + χῶρος, space) [in LXX: Jos.17:15 (אוּץ), Jdg.16:16 (אָלַץ pi.), Isa.28:19 (20) (קָצַר) Isa.49:19 (צָרַר), 4Ma.11:11 *;] 1) to be straitened (cf. G4735	στέφανος	stephanos	crown	G:N-M	<b>στέφανος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; στέφω, to encircle), [in LXX chiefly for עֲטָרָה;] 1) that which surrounds or encompasses (as a wall, <b>a crowd</b>: Hom, al.). 2) a crown, i.e. the wreath, garland or chaplet given as a prize for victory, as a festal ornament, or as a public honour for disting­uished service or personal worth (so to sovereigns, especially on the occasion of a παρουσία, which see; cf. Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 312), 2Ti.4:8; τ. δόξης, 1Pe.5:4; καυχήσεως, 1Th.2:19 (see M, <i>Th.</i>, in l); τ. ζωῆς (genitive appos.), Jas.1:12, Rev.2:10. (AS)

G4739	στήκω	stēkō	to stand	G:V	<b>στήκω </b> late Pres, formed from perf, ἕστηκα (see B1, § 17; WH, <i>App.</i>, 169; Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 158; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 238; MM, xxiii), [in LXX: Exo.14:13 A, Jdg.16:26 B, 3Ki.8:11 B *;] <b>= ἵστημι, to stand</b>: Mrk.3:31 11:25, Jhn.1:26, Rev.12:4 (ἕστηκεν T). G4747	στοιχεῖον	stoicheion	principle	G:N-N	<b>στοιχεῖον</b>, -ου, τό [in LXX: Wis.7:17 19:18, 4Ma.12:13 *;] prop, one of a row (στοῖχος) or series, hence, 1) the shadow-line of a dial (Aristoph.). 2) an elementary sound or letter of the alphabet (Anth, Plut, π.). 3) the elements or rudiments of knowledge (Arist, al.) Heb.5:12; πτωχὰ σ, Gal.4:9; σ. τοῦ κόσμου, Gal.4:3, Col.2:8, 20 (but see infr.). 4) <b>The material elements of the universe </b>(Plat; LXX, ll. with): 2Pe.3:10 3:12. 5) The heavenly bodies (Ding. Laert.). 6) The demons or tutelary spirits of nature (Enoch, Test, Sol, al; for this sense in Ga, Col, ll. with, see <i>ICC</i> on Col.2:8; Enc. Bibl, see word " Elements "). (AS)
G4748	στοιχέω	stoicheō	to follow	G:V	<b>στοιχέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; στοῖχος, a row), [in LXX: Ecc.11:6 (כָּשֵׁר) *;] to be in rows (of waves, plants, etc, as well as of men), to walk in line (esp. of marching in file to battle; Xen, Cyr, vi, 3, 34, al.). Metaph, <b>in late writers, to walk by rule</b>: Act.21:24; with dative, to walk by or in (as a rule of life), Rom.4:12 (cf. MM, xxiii), Gal.5:25 6:16, Php.3:16 (cf. συν-στοιχέω). (AS)
G4749	στολή	stolē	robe	G:N-F	<b>στολή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; στέλλω), [in LXX chiefly for בֶּגֶד, also for לְבוּשׁ, etc;] 1 1, an equipment, an armament (Æsch.). 2) Equipment in clothes, apparel, esp. flowing raiment, <b>a festal robe</b>: (cf. Jon.3:6, Est.8:15, 1Ma.6:15): Mrk.12:38 16:5, Luk.15:22 20:46, Rev.6:11 7:9, 13-14 22:14. (AS)
G4750	στόμα	stoma	mouth	G:N-N	<b>στόμα</b>, -τος, τό [in LXX chiefly for פֻּם;] <b>the mouth</b>: of man, Mat.15:11, Jhn.19:29, Act.11:8, al; of animals, Mat.17:27, 2Ti.4:17 (fig.), Heb.11:33, Jas.3:3, al; figuratively, of inanimate things (ποταμοῦ, Hom.), ἤνοιξεν ἡ γῆ τὸ σ, Rev.12:16; σ. μαχαίρας (Heb. חֶרֶב ־פֶּה, Gen.34:26 al.), the edge of the sword, Luk.21:24, Heb.11:34; esp. of the mouth as the organ of speech: opp. to καρδία, Mat.12:34, Rom.10:8, 10; in various phrases (some cl, some resembling Hebrew; cf. Bl, § 40, 9): ἀνοίγειν τ. σ. (see: ἀνοίγω); σ. πρὸς σ. (פֶּה ־אֵל פֶּה Num.12:8; = cl, κατὰ σ, Hdt, al.), face to face, II Jn 12, 3Jn.14; διὰ τοῦ σ. (of the Holy Spirit), Luk.1:70, Act.1:16, al; ἀπὸ (ἐκ) τοῦ σ. (cf. ἀπὸ σ. εἰπεῖν, Plat, al.), of speaking by word of mouth, Luk.22:71, Act.22:14; δόλος (ψεῦδος) ἐν τ. σ, 1Pe.2:22, Rev.14:5 " (LXX); metaph, ἡ ῥομφαία τοῦ σ, Rev.2:16. By meton, <b>for speech </b>(Soph.): Mat.18:16 (LXX), Luk.19:22 21:15, 2Co.13:1 (AS)
G4751	στόμαχος	stomachos	stomach	G:N-M	<b>στόμαχος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; στόμα), prop, a mouth, an opening; (a) in early Gk. writers, the throat; (b) <b>of the opening of the stomach </b>(Arist.); (with) in later writers (Plut, al.), <b>the stomach</b>: 1Ti.5:23. (AS)
G4752	στρατεία	strateia	warfare	G:N-F	<b>στρατεία</b> (on the orthogr, see Deiss, BS, 181 f.), -ας, ἡ (&lt; οτρατεύω), [in LXX chiefly for צָבָא;] <b>an expedition, a campaign, warfare</b>: metaph, 2Co.10:4 (-τιά, T), 1Ti.1:18. (AS)
G4753	στράτευμα	strateuma	troops	G:N-N	<b>στράτευμα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; στρατεύω), [in LXX: 1Ma.9:34, 2Ma.5:24 2Mac 8:21 2Mac 12:38 2Mac 13:13; pl, Jdth.11:8, 4Ma.5:1 *;] 1) = στρατεία (Hdt, al.). 2) <b>an army, a host</b>: pl, Mat.22:7, Rev.9:16 19:14, 19; = soldiers, company of soldiers, Act.23:10, 27; pl, Luk.23:11. (AS)
G4754	στρατεύω	strateuō	to battle	G:V	<b>στρατεύω </b> and depon, -ομαι, so always in NT (&lt; στρατός, an encamped army), [in LXX for מההּ hith, יָצָא, צָבָא; metaph, 4Ma.9:23;] used of the general, to make war, do battle, and (chiefly) of the soldiers serving under him, <b>to serve as a soldier</b>: Luk.3:14, 1Co.9:7, 2Ti.2:4. Metaph. (cf. MM, ii, xxiii), of spiritual conflict, <b>to war, make war</b>: 2Co.10:3, 1Ti.1:18, Jas.4:1, 1Pe.2:11. (AS)
G4755	στρατηγός	stratēgos	officer/magistrate	G:N-M	<b>στρατηγός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; στραός, ἄγω), [in LXX chiefly for סָגָן (always in pl.), שַׂר;] 1) a military commander, a general (Hdt, al.). 2) <b>A civic commander, a governor, magistrate </b>(Hdt, Xen, al.): Act.16:20, 22 16:35-36, 38. 3) The commander of the Levitical guard of the Temple, ὁ σ. τ. ἱεροῦ (EV, captain of the Temple): Act.4:1 5:24, 26; pl, Luk.22:4, 52. (AS)
G4756	στρατιά	stratia	army	G:N-F	<b>στρατιά</b>, -ᾶς, ἡ [in LXX chiefly for צָבָא;] 1) <b>= στρατός, an army, a host</b>: of angels (3Ki.22:19, al.), Luk.2:13; of the stars of heaven (Jer.8:2, 2Ch.33:3), Act.7:42. 2) As sometimes in cl. (poët.), = στρατεία: 2Co.10:4, T (WH, RV, στρατεία). (AS)
G4757	στρατιώτης	stratiōtēs	soldier	G:N-M	<b>στρατιώτης</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX; 2Ki.23:8 B1, 2Ma.5:12 2Mac 14:39, III Mac 3:12; 3Ma.3:4 Mac3 *;] <b>a soldier</b>: Mat.8:9, Mrk.15:16, Jhn.19:2, Act.10:7, al; metaph, σ. Χριστοῦ Ἰησ, 2Ti.2:3. (AS)
G4758	στρατολογέω	stratologeō	to enlist	G:V	<b>στρατολογέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; στρατός, λέγω), <b>to levy a troop, enlist soldiers</b>: 2Ti.2:4 (Diod, Plut, al.). (AS)
G4759	στρατοπεδάρχης	stratopedarchēs	commander	G:N-M	<b>στρατοπέδ-αρχος</b> (Rec. -ης), -ου, ὁ (&lt; στρατόπεδον, ἄρχω), a military commander, esp. the Pretorian prefect: Act.28:16 (WH, om.). στρατοπεδάρχης, see: στρατοπέδαρχος (AS)
G4760	στρατόπεδον	stratopedon	army camp	G:N-N	<b>στρατό-πεδον</b>, -ου, τό (στρατός + πέδον, a plain), [in LXX: Jer.34:1 (חַיִל), 2Ma.8:12, al;] (a) <b>a military camp</b>; (b) <b>an army</b>: Luk.21:20. (AS)
G4761	στρεβλόω	strebloō	to distort	G:V	<b>στρεβλόω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; στρέφω), [in LXX: 2Ki.22:27 (פָּתַל hithp.), 3Ma.4:14, 4Ma.9:17 4Mac 12:4 4Mac 12:11 4Mac 15:14 *;] to twist, torture. Metaph. (cf. 2Ki, l.with), <b>to twist or pervert language</b>: 2Pe.3:16. (AS)
G4762	στρέφω	strephō	to turn	G:V	<b>στρέφω </b> [in LXX chiefly for הָפַךְ, also for סָבַב, etc;] <b>to turn</b>: with accusative of thing(s) dative of person(s), Mat.5:39; = ἀποσ, to bring back, Mat.27:3 (cf. Isa.38:8); reflexively (WM, § 38, 1), to turn oneself, Act.7:42; with accusative before εἰς, = μετασ, to change, Rev.11:6. Pass, <b>reflexive, to turn oneself</b>: before εἰς, Jhn.20:14, Act.7:39 13:46; ptcp, στραφείς, with indic, Mat.7:6 9:22 16:23, Luk.7:9 9:55 14:25 22:61, Jhn.1:38 20:16; id. before πρός, Luk.7:44 10:22 (WH, R, om.), Luk.7:23 23:28; metaph, <b>to change</b>: absol, Mat.18:3, Jhn.12:40 (cf. ἀνα, ἀπο, δια, ἐκ, ἐπι, κατα, μετα, συ(ν), ὑπο-στρέφω). (AS)
G4763	στρηνιάω	strēniaō	to revel	G:V	<b>στρηνιάω</b>, ῶ (&lt; στρῆνος, which see), [in Sm: Isa.61:6 (אָכַל) *;] a word which first appears in the middle comedy (Rutherford, <i>NPhr.</i>, 475 f.), <b>to run riot, wax wanton</b>: Rev.18:7-9 (cf. κατα-στρηνιάω). (AS)
G4764	στρῆνος	strēnos	luxury	G:N-N	<b>στρῆνος</b>, -ους, τό (cf. Lat. strenuus), [in LXX: 4Ki.19:28 (שַׁאֲנָן)*;] <b>insolent luxury, wantonness</b>: Rev.18:3 (a late word, first found in a Comic poet, B.C. 300, see Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 41, cf. στρηνιάω). (AS)
G4765	στρουθίον	strouthion	sparrow	G:N-N	<b>στρουθίον</b>, -ου, τό [in LXX chiefly for צִפּוֹר;] dimin. of στρουθός <b>a sparrow</b>: Mat.10:29, 31, Luk.12:6-7. (AS)
G4766	στρώννυμι	strōnnumi	to spread	G:V	<b>στρωννύω</b> or στρώννυμι (seeBl, § 23, 1; Veitch, see word), [in LXX for יַצַע hoph, etc;] <b>to spread</b>: ἱμάτια ἐν τ. ὁδῷ (εἰς τ. ὁδόν), Mat.21:8, Mrk.11:8; of making a bed, στρῶσον (sc. τ. κλίνην) σεαυτῷ, Act.9:34; of furnishing a room, ἐστρωμένον, spread with carpets or carpeted couches (cf. Eze.23:41), Mrk.14:15, Luk.22:12. (AS)
G4767	στυγητός	stugētos	hated	G:A	<b>στυγητός</b>, -όν (&lt; στυγέω, to hate), <b>hated, hateful</b>: Tit.3:3. (AS)
G4768	στυγνάζω	stugnazō	be gloomy	G:V	<b>στυγνάζω</b> (&lt; στυγνός, sombre, gloomy, sullen, Isa.5:17, Wis.17:5, Dan LXX 2:12*), [in LXX: Eze.27:35 28:19 32:10 (שָׁמֵם)*;] <b>to have a sombre, gloomy appearance</b>: of the human countenance (RV, his countenance fell), Mrk.10:22; of the sky (so στυγνότης, Polyb, iv, 21, 1), Mat.16:3 ([WH], R, mg, om.). (AS)
G4769	στῦλος	stulos	pillar	G:N-M	<b>στύλος (T</b>, στῦλος, as in cl.), -ου, ὁ [in LXX chiefly for עַמּוּד, also for קֶרֶשׁ, etc;] <b>a pillar, regarded especially as a support</b>: σ. πυρός, Rev.10:1; σ. ἐν τ. ναῷ, figuratively, Rev.3:12, Metaph, Gal.2:9; τ. ἀληθείας, 1Ti.3:15. (AS)
G4770	Στωϊκός	Stōikos	Stoic	G:A	<b>Στωικός</b> (Rec. -ϊκός, T, Στοϊκός), -ή, -όν, <b>Stoic</b>: Act.17:18. (AS)
G4771	σύ	su	you	G:PerP	<b>σύ</b>, <i>pron.</i> of 2nd of person(s), <b>thou, you</b>, genitive, σοῦ, dative, σοί, accusative, σέ, pl, ὑμεῖς, -ῶν, -ῖν, -ᾶς (enclitic in oblique cases sing, except after prep. (BL, §48, 3), though πρὸς σέ occurs in Mat.25:39). Nom. for emphasis or contrast: Jhn.1:30, 4:10, 5:33, 39, 44, Act.4:7, Eph.5:32; so also perhaps σὺ εἶπας, Mat.26:64, al. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 86); before voc, Mat.2:6, Luk.1:76, Jhn.17:5, al; sometimes without emphasis (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 85f.), as also in cl, but esp. as rendering of Heb. phrase, e.g. υἱός μου εἶ σύ (בְּנִי־אַתָּה, Psa.2:7), Act.13:33. The genitive (σοῦ, ὑμῶν) is sometimes placed bef. the noun: Luk.7:48, 12:30, al; so also the enclitic σοῦ, Mat.9:6; on τί ἐμοὶ κ. σοί, see: ἐγώ. (AS)
G4772	συγγένεια	suggeneia	kindred	G:N-F	<b>συγγένεια</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; συγγενής), [in LXX chiefly for מִשְׁפָּחָה;] 1) kinship. 2) By meton, <b>kinsfolk, kindred</b>: Luk.1:61, Act.7:3, 14 (AS)
G4773	συγγενής	suggenēs	kindred	G:A	<b>σνγγενής</b>, -ές (dative pl, -εῦσιν, Mrk.6:4, Luk.2:44, as though from -εύς, see Swete, <i>Mk.</i>, l.with; Bl, § 8, 6; cf. 1Ma.10:89 A א2 *;) (&lt; σύν, γένος), [in LXX for דּוֹד, דּוֹדָה, מִשְׁפָּחָה;] 1) congenital, natural, innate. 2) <b>akin to</b>; as subst, <b>a kinsman</b>: Mrk.6:4, Luk.1:58 2:44 14:12 21:16, Jhn.18:26, Act.10:24; of tribal kinship, Rom.9:3 16:7, 11 16:21. (AS)
G4774	συγγνώμη	suggnōmē	concession	G:N-F	<b>συν-γνώμη (Rec. συγγ-), -ης, ἡ</b> (&lt; συγγιγνώσκω, (a) to agree with; (b) to pardon), [in LXX: Sir prol.14 (B1N1 cm.) 313, 2Mac 14:20 *;] 1) confession. 2) <b>fellow feeling; hence, concession, allowance</b>: 1Co.7:6 (see <i>ICC</i>, in l). 3) pardon. (AS)
G4775	συγκάθημαι	sugkathēmai	to sit with	G:V	<b>συν-κάθημαι</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Psa.101:6 (יָשַׁב) *;] <b>to sit together or with</b>: with dative, Act.26:30; before μετά, with genitive, Mrk.14:54. (AS)
G4776	συγκαθίζω	sugkathizō	to sit down with	G:V	<b>περι-καθ-ίζω </b> [in LXX for חָנָה, לָחַם ni, etc;] 1) <b>to invest, besiege</b> (Diod, 4Ki.6:24, 1Ma.11:61, al.). 2) <b>to sit around</b>: Luk.22:55, L, txt. (AS)
G4777	συγκακοπαθέω	sugkakopatheō	to suffer with	G:V	<b>συν-κακοπαθέω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), -ῶ, <b>to bear evil treatment along with, take one's share of ill-treatment</b>: 2Ti.2:3; with dative commod, τ. εὐαγγελίῳ, 2Ti.2:18. (AS)
G4778	συγκακουχέομαι	sugkakoucheomai	to suffer with	G:V	<b>συν-κακουχέομαι</b> (Rec. συγκ-), -οῦμαι, pass. <b>to endure adversity with</b>: with dative of person(s), Heb.11:25. Not elsewhere. (AS)
G4779	συγκαλέω	sugkaleō	to call together	G:V	<b>συν-καλέω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), -ῶ, [in LXX for קָרָא;] <b>to call together</b>: with accusative, Mrk.15:16, Luk.15:6, 9 (seel. -εῖται, see B1, § 55, 1), Act.5:21. Mid, <b>to call together to oneself</b>: Luk.9:1 (and seel. in Luk.15:6, 9 see supr.) Luk.23:13, Act.10:24 28:17. (AS)
G4780	συγκαλύπτω	sugkaluptō	to conceal	G:V	<b>συν-καλύπτω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX chiefly for כָּסָה pi;] <b>to veil or cover completely</b>: with accusative, pass, Luk.12:2. (AS)
G4781	συγκάμπτω	sugkamptō	to bend	G:V	<b>συν-κάμπτω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Psa.68:10, 23 (מעד hi.), etc;] <b>to bend completely, bend together</b>: τ. νῶτον, figuratively, Rom.11:10 (LXX). (AS)
G4782	συγκαταβαίνω	sugkatabainō	to descend with	G:V	<b>συν-κατα-βαίνω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Psa.49:17 (יָרַד), Wis.10:13, Dan LXX TH 3:49 *;] <b>to go down with</b>: Act.25:5. In late writers also metaph. (Wis, l.with), to condescend, on WH. see Rutherford, <i>NPhr.</i>, 485 f. (AS)
G4783	συγκατάθεσις	sugkatathesis	agreement	G:N-F	<b>συν-κατά-θεσις</b> (Rec συγκ-), -εως, ἡ (&lt; συνκατατίθημι) <b>concord, agreement</b>: 2Co.6:16 (Polyb, Plut, al.). (AS)
G4784	συγκατατίθημι	sugkatatithēmi	to consent	G:V	<b>συν-κατα-τίθημι</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Exo.23:1 (שִׁית יָד), Exo.23:32 (בְּרִית), Da TH Su 1:20 *;] to deposit together. Mid, <b>to deposit one's vote with, hence, to agree with, assent to</b>: with dative, Luk.23:51. (AS)
G4785	συγκαταψηφίζομαι	sugkatapsēphizomai	to numbered with	G:V	<b>συν-κατα-ψηφίζω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), 1) to condemn with or together (Plut, Themist, 21). 2) <b>to vote one a place among</b>: pass, Act.1:26. Not elsewhere. (AS)
G4786	συγκεράννυμι	sugkerannumi	to unite	G:V	<b>συν-κεράννυμι</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Dan LXX 2:43 (עֲרַב ithpa.), 2Ma.15:39 *;] <b>to mix or blend together, compound</b>: with accusative, 1Co.12:24; ptcp. pf. pass, Heb.4:2, T, WH, mg, R, mg; id, of persons, with dative instr, to be united with, agree with, ib, WH, txt, R, txt. (see Westc, in l). (AS)
G4787	συγκινέω	sugkineō	to stir up	G:V	<b>συν-κινέω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), -ῶ, to move together. Metaph, <b>to excite, stir up</b>: τ. λαόν, Act.6:12 (Arist, Polyb, al.). (AS)
G4788	συγκλείω	sugkleiō	to confine	G:V	<b>συν-κλείω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX chiefly for סגר;] <b>to shut together, enclose, shut in on all sides</b>: of a catch of fish, Luk.5:6; metaph. (Psa.31:9, al.), Rom.11:32, Gal.3:22-23. (AS)
G4789	συγκληρονόμος	sugklēronomos	co-heir	G:A	<b>συν-κληρο-νόμος</b> (Rec. συγκ-), -ου, ὁ <b>a co-inheritor, fellow-heir</b>: Rom.8:17, Eph.3:6; with genitive of thing(s), Heb.11:9, 1Pe.3:7 (for exx, see Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 88 f.). (AS)
G4790	συγκοινωνέω	sugkoinōneō	to share with	G:V	<b>συν-κοινωνέω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), -ῶ, <b>to have fellowship with or in </b>(in cl, with genitive of thing(s), dative of person(s)): with dative of thing(s), Eph.5:11, Rev.18:4; id. with genitive of person(s), Php.4:14. (AS)
G4791	συγκοινωνός	sugkoinōnos	sharer	G:N-M	<b>συν-κοινωνός</b> (Rec. συγκ-), όν, <b>partaking jointly of</b>: with genitive of thing(s), Rom.11:17, 1Co.9:23; id. with genitive of person(s), Php.1:7; before ἐν, Rev.1:9. (AS)
G4792	συγκομίζω	sugkomizō	to entomb	G:V	<b>συν-κομίζω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Job.5:26 (עָלָה) *;] 1) to bring together, collect (Hdt, Xen, al.). 2) <b>to take up a body for burial </b>(Soph, Aj, 1048): Act.8:2 (see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 116). (AS)
G4793	συγκρίνω	sugkrinō	to compare	G:V	<b>συν-κρίνω (Rec. συγκ-) </b> [in LXX chiefly for פָּתַר;] 1) <b>to compound, combine</b>: 1Co.2:13, R, mg.1 (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 180 f.). 2) In Arist. and later writers (Wis.7:29, a1.) = παραβάλλω, <b>to compare</b>: 1Co, l.with, R, txt. (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 168), 2Co.10:12 3) In LXX, of dreams, to interpret (Gen.40:8, 1Co, l.with, R, mg. 2 (but see reff. supr.). (AS)
G4794	συγκύπτω	sugkuptō	to bend	G:V	<b>συν-κύπτω</b> (Rec. συγκ-), [in LXX: Job.9:27 (עָזַב), Sir.12:11 19:26 *;] 1) to bend forwards (Arist, al.). 2) <b>to be bowed down</b>: Luk.13:11. (AS)
G4795	συγκυρία	sugkuria	coincidence	G:N-F	<b>συγκυρία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; συγκυρέω, to happen), [in Sm: 1Ki.6:9 (מִקְרֶה) *;] (more freq. in late writers, συγκύρησις, -ημα), <b>chance, coincidence</b>: κατὰ σ. (see MM, xxiii), Luk.10:31 (Hippocr, Eccl.). (AS)
G4796	συγχαίρω	sugchairō	to rejoice with	G:V	<b>συν-χαίρω</b> (Rec. συγ-), [in LXX: Gen.21:6 (צָחַק), 3Ma.1:8 R *;] 1) <b>to rejoice with</b>: with dative of person(s), Luk.1:58 15:6, 9, Php.2:17-18, EV; with dative of thing(s), 1Co.12:26 13:6. 2) <b>to congratulate </b>(Æschin, Polyb, al.): Phi, l.with (Lft, in I; cf. MM, xxiv). (AS)
G4797	συγχέω	sugcheō	to confound	G:V	<b>συν-χέω</b> (Rec. συγ-), [in LXX for בָּלַל, רָגַז, etc;] <b>to pour together, commingle, confuse</b>; metaph, <b>confound, throw into confusion, stir up trouble</b>: Act.21:27 (cf. συν-χύννω). (AS)
G4798	συγχράομαι	sugchraomai	to associate with	G:V	<b>συν-χράομαι</b> (Rec. συγ-), -ῶμαι, [in Al: 1Ki.30:19 *;] to use together with. Metaph, with dative of person(s), <b>to associate with</b>: Jhn.4:9 (Polyb, a1.). (AS)
G4799	σύγχυσις	sugchusis	confusion	G:N-F	<b>σύγχυσις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; συγχέω), [in LXX: Gen.11:9 (בָּבֶל), 1Ki.5:6 5:12 (11) 1Ki.14:20 (מְהוּמָה) *;] <b>confusion</b>: of a popular uproar, Act.19:29. (AS)
G4800	συζάω	suzaō	to live together	G:V	<b>συν-ζάω</b> (Rec. συζ-), <b>to live with</b>: opp. to συναποθανεῖν, 2Co.7:3; of life in union with Christ, here and hereafter, Rom.6:8, 2Ti.2:11. (AS)
G4801	συζεύγνυμι	suzeugnumi	to join	G:V	<b>συν-ζεύγνυμι</b> (Rec. συζ-), [in LXX: Eze.1:11, 23 (חָבַר) *;] <b>to yoke to­gether</b>: metaph, of union in wedlock, Mat.19:6, Mrk.10:9. (AS)
G4802	συζητέω	suzēteō	to debate	G:V	<b>συν-ζητέω</b> (Rec. συζ-), -ῶ, [in LXX: Neh.2:4 AB1 (בָּקַשׁ pi.) *;] 1) to search or examine together (Plat.). 2) In NT (and π, see MM, xxiii; also in M<i>Gr.</i>, see Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 155), <b>to discuss, dispute</b>: Mrk.1:27 12:28, Luk.24:15; before quæst. indir, Mrk.9:10; with dative of person(s), Mrk.8:11 Act.6:9; before πρός, with accusative of person(s), Mrk.9:14, 16, Act.9:29; id. before quæst. indir, Luk.22:23. (AS)
G4803	συζήτησις	suzētēsis	discussion	G:N-F	<b>συν-ζήτηαις</b> (Rec. συζ-), -εως, ἡ <b>disputation</b>: Act.28:29 (WH, R, txt, om.). (AS)
G4804	συζητητής	suzētētēs	debater	G:N-M	<b>συν-ζητητής</b> (Rec. συζ-), -οῦ, ἁ (&lt; συνζητέω), <b>a disputer, disputant</b>: 1Co.1:20. (AS)
G4805	σύζυγος	suzugos	yokefellow	G:A	<b>σύν-ζυγος</b> (Rec. ουζ-), or as WH, mg, Σύνζυγος, -ον (&lt; συνζεύγνυμι), [in Aq, Eze.23:21 *;] a yoke fellow. Prob, as proper name, Σ. γνήσιε, genuinely Synzygus, S. properly so-called, Php.4:3 (see <i>ICC</i>, Lft, in l; MM, xxiii). (AS)
G4806	συζωοποιέω	suzōopoieō	to make alive with	G:V	<b>συν-ζωο-ποιέω</b> (Rec. συζ-), ῶ, <b>to make alive or quicken together with</b>; metaph, of the spiritual life: τ. Χριστῷ, Eph.2:5; σὺν τ. Χ, Col.2:13. (AS)
G4807	συκάμινος	sukaminos	mulberry tree	G:N-F	<b>συκάμινος</b>, -ου, ἡ [in LXX for שִׁקְמָה (pl.);] <b>the mulberry tree </b> (Lat. morus; cf. μόρον, 1Ma.6:34 *), <b>the sycamine</b>: Luk.17:6. (In LXX, σ. appears to represent the συκόμορος (see: συκομορέα), but St. Luke distinguishes between the two; see <i>ICC</i>, in l; <i>DB</i>, iv, 634.) (AS)
G4808	συκῆ	sukē	fig tree	G:N-F	<b>συκῆ</b> (contr. fr. συκέα), -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; σῦκον), [in LXX for תְּאֵן;] <b>a fig-tree</b>: Mat.21:19-21 24:32, Mrk.11:13, 20-21 13:28, Luk.13:6-7 21:29, Jhn.1:49, 51, Jas.3:12, Rev.6:13. (AS)
G4809	συκομωραία	sukomōraia	sycamore tree	G:N-F	<b>συκο-μορέα</b> (Rec. -μωραία, L, -μωρέα), -ας, ἡ, more commonly (so Aq, Sm, Psa.78:47, Isa.9:10) συκόμορος (&lt; σῦκον + μόρον, the black mulberry), <b>a fig-mulberry, a sycamore</b>: Luk.19:4 (cf. συκάμινος). (AS)

G4822	συμβιβάζω	sumbibazō	to join with	G:V	<b>συν-βιβάζω</b> (Rec. συμ-), [in LXX: Exo.4:12, 15, Lev.10:11, Jdg.13:8, Psa.32:8 (יָרָה hi.); Exo.18:16, Deu.4:9, Isa.40:13 (יָדַע hi.), Isa.40:14 (בִּין hi.), Da TH Dan.9:22 (שָׂכַל hi.) *;] 1) <b>to join or knit together, unite</b>: Eph.4:16, Col.2:2 (but see infr.), Col.2:19. 2) <b>to compare, consider, conclude </b>(Plat.): Act.16:10. 3) <b>to deduce, prove, demonstrate </b>(Arist.): Act.9:22. 4) As in LXX ("translation Greek," = ἐμβιβάζω, metaph.), <b>to teach, instruct</b>: 1Co.2:16 Act.19:33, R, mg. G4823	συμβουλεύω	sumbouleuō	to consult	G:V	1. <b>to advise, counsel </b>, Lat. <i>consulere alicui</i>, with <i>dative</i> pers. et <i>infinitive</i>, <b>to advise </b> one to do a thing, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. without the <i>infinitive</i>, ς. τινί τι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; ς. τι <b>to recommend </b> a measure, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], attic;Pass, τὰ συμβουλευόμενα <b>the advice given </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>absolute</i> <b>to advise, give advice </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ὁ συμβουλεύων or -εύσας, <b>an adviser </b>, Lat. <i>auctor sententiae</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 4. Mid. <b>to consult with </b> a person, i. e. <b>ask </b> his <b>advice </b>, Lat. <i>consulere aliquem</i>, with <i>dative</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc: <i>absolute</i> <b>to consult, deliberate </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G4855	συμφύω	sumphuō	to grow with	G:V	<b>συν-φύω</b> (Rec. συμ-), [in LXX: Wis.13:13 *;] to cause to grow together. Pass, <b>to grow together or with </b>(Plat. al.): Luk.8:7. (AS)
G4856	συμφωνέω	sumphōneō	to agree with	G:V	<b>συμ-φωνέω</b>, -ῶ, [in LXX: Gen.14:3 (H2266) 2Ki.12:8 (9) (H225 ni.), Isa.7:2 (H5117), 4Ma.14:6 *;] prop, to agree in sound, be in harmony (Plat, Arist.). Metaph, (a) <b>to agree with, agree together</b>: Luk.5:36; with dative of thing(s), Act.15:15; before περί, Mat.18:19; pass, with dative of person(s), συνεφωνήθη ὑμῖν, Act.5:9; (b) <b>to agree as to a price </b>(Polyb, Diod.): with dative of person(s), genitive pret, Mat.20:13; before μετά. ἐκ, Mat.20:2. (AS)
G4857	συμφώνησις	sumphōnēsis	harmony	G:N-F	<b>συμ-φώνησις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; συμφωνέω), <b>concord, agreement</b>: before πρός, with accusative of person(s), 2Co.6:15. (AS)
G4858	συμφωνία	sumphōnia	music	G:N-F	<b>συμφωνία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; σύμφωνος), [in LXX: Dan LXX TH Dan.3:5, 15, TH Dan.3:7, 10 (סוּמְפּוֹנְיָה) 4Ma.14:3 A *;] 1) <b>symphony, music</b>: Luk.15:25 2) a musical instrument (Polyb, al; Da, ll. with; v MM, xxiv). (AS)
G4859	σύμφωνος	sumphōnos	mutual consent	G:A	<b>σύμφωνος</b>, -ον (&lt; ούν, φωνή), [in LXX: Ecc.7:14 (עֻמָּה), 4Ma.7:7 4Mac 14:7 *;] agreeing in sound. Metaph, <b>harmonious, agreeing</b>: ἐκ συμφώνου (for exx. from π, see Deiss, BS, 255), by agreement, 1Co.7:5. (AS)
G4860	συμψηφίζω	sumpsēphizō	to calculate	G:V	<b>συμ-ψηφίζω </b> [in LXX: Jer.29:20 (Jer.49:20) A *;] <b>to reckon together, count up</b>: Act.19:19. (AS)
G4861	σύμψυχος	sumpsuchos	harmonious	G:A	<b>σύν-ψυχος</b> (Rec. συμ-), -ον (&lt; ψυχή), <b>of one mind</b>: Php.2:2. (AS)
G4862	σύν	sun	with	G:Prep	<b>σύν</b> (old Att. ξύν), <i>prep. with dative, </i> expressing association, fellowship and inclusion. It gradually gave way to μετά, with genitive (cf. LS, see word; Bl, §41, 3), and is therefore comparatively infrequent in NT, being rare in Mat.4, Mrk.6, Jhn.3, and elsewhere (exx. Jas.1:11, 2Pe.1:18) only in Lk (Gosp. and Ac) and Paul. <b>With, together with</b>: of companionship and association, Luk.2:13, Jhn.21:3, Act.10:23, al; εἶναι σύν τινι, Luk.7:12, Act.4:13, Php.1:23, al; of partisanship, Act.4:13; οἱ σύν τινι, of attendants, companions or colleagues, Mrk.2:26, Luk.5:9, Act.5:17, al; of assistance, ἡ χάρις τ. θεοῦ σὺν ἐμοί, 1Co.15:10; of two or more things together, almost = καί, Luk.23:11, Act.3:4 10:2 14:5 23:25, Eph.3:18; σὺν Χριστῷ ζῆν, 2Co.13:4; besides (FlJ, LXX), σὺν πᾶσι τούτοις, Luk.24:21. In composition: <b>with</b> (συνχαίρω), <b>together</b> (συνωδίνω), <b>altogether</b> (συντελέω) (AS)
G4863	συνάγω	sunagō	to assemble	G:V	<b>συν-άγω </b> [in LXX chiefly for אָסַף, also for קָבַץ, etc. (cf. Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 128);] <b>to gather or bring together</b>: of things, Jhn.6:12-13; before εἰς, Mat.3:12, al; ἐκεῖ, Luk.12:18; ποῦ, Luk.12:17; συναγαγὼν πάντα (sc. εἰς ἀργύριον; see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 68, MM, xxiv), <b>having sold off all</b>: Luk.15:13; of persons, Jhn.11:52; esp. of assemblies, Mat.2:4, Jhn.11:47, Act.14:27, al. Pass, <b>to be gathered or come together</b>: Mat.22:41, Mrk.2:2, Luk.22:66, al; before ἐπί Mrk.5:21, Act.4:27; πρός, Mat.13:2, Mrk.4:1, al; εἰς, Rev.19:17; ἐν, Act.11:26; μετά, Mat.28:12; οὗ, Mat.18:20; ὅπου, Mat.26:57; ἐκεῖ, Jhn.18:2, al. In late writers (see Kennedy, <i>Sources</i>, 128; cf. Deu.22:2, al.), <b>to receive hospitably, entertain</b>: Mat.25:35, 38 25:43 (cf. ἐπι-συνάγω) (AS)
G4864	συναγωγή	sunagōgē	synagogue	G:N-F	<b>συν-αγωγή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ [in LXX chiefly for עֵדָה, also for קָהָל, etc;] prop, a bringing together; 1) of things, (a) <b>a gathering in of harvest</b>; (b) a collection of money. 2) <b>Of persons, </b> (a) <b>a collecting, assembling </b>(Polyb.); (b) <b>an assembly </b>(MM, xxiv; Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 101 ff.): Rev.2:9 3:9; esp. of a Jewish religious assembly, <b>a synagogue</b>: Luk.12:11, Act.9:2, al; of a Christian assembly, Jas.2:2. WH, <i>Intr.</i>, 95 ff.); ὅπου, Jhn.18:20; with inf, Luk.5:15; εἰς τ. φαγεῖν, 1Co.11:33; εἰς τ. ἧσσον, 1Co.11:17 11:34; of sexual intercourse (Xen, al; γυναικί or absol.), Mat.1:18. 2) In later sense (see exx. in Milligan, Selections, 64, 105), <b>to accompany</b>: with dative of person(s), Luk.23:55, Act.1:21 9:39 10:23, 45 11:12; before σύν, Act.21:16; εἰς, Act.15:38. G4972	σφραγίζω	sphragizō	to seal	G:V	<b>σφραγίζω </b> [in LXX chiefly for חָתַם (Deu.32:34, al.), also for סָתַם (Da TH Dan.8:26);] <b>to seal, </b> (a) <b>for security</b>: Mat.27:66, Rev.20:3; τ. καρπὸν τοῦτον, figuratively (cf. G4981	σχολή	scholē	lecture hall	G:N-F	<b>σχολή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ [in LXX: Gen.33:14 (κατὰ σ, אַט), Pro.28:19, Sir.38:24 *;] 1) leisure. 2) Later (from Plato on), (a) <b>that for which leisure is employed, a disputation, lecture</b>; (b) <b>the place where lectures are delivered, a school</b>: Act.19:9 (for the later sense of employment, see MM, xxiv).
