G4982	σῴζω	sōzō	to save	G:V	<b>σώζω</b> (on the more accurate σῴζω, see WH, <i>Intr.</i>, §410; Bl, §3, 1-3), [in LXX chiefly for ישׁע hi, also for מלט ni, נצל ni, etc;] <b>to save</b> from peril, <b>injury or suffering</b>: Mat.8:25, Mrk.13:20, Luk.23:35, al; τ. ψυχήν, Mat.16:25, al; before ἐκ, Jhn.12:27, Heb.5:7, Ju 5; of healing, <b>restoring to health</b>: Mat.9:22, Mrk.5:34, al. In NT, esp. of salvation from spiritual disease and death, in which sense it is "spoken of in Scripture as either (1) past, (2) present, or (3) future, according as redemption, grace, or glory is the point in view. Thus (1) Rom.8:24, Eph.2:5, 8 2Ti.1:9, Tit.3:5; (2) Act.2:47, 1Co.1:18, 15:2, 2Co.2:15; (3) Mat.10:22, Rom.13:11, Php.2:12, Heb.9:28 " (Vau. on Rom.5:9). Seq. ἀπό, Mat.1:21, Act.2:40, Rom.5:9; ἐκ, Jas.5:20, Ju 23 (cf. Cremer, 532ff.). (AS)
G4983	σῶμα	sōma	body	G:N-N	<b>σῶμα</b>, -τος, τό, [in LXX for גְּוִיָּה,בָּשָׂר, etc, and for Aram. נְבֵלָה;] <b>a body</b>. 1) Prop, of the human body, (a) as always in Hom. (opp. to δέμας), of the dead body: Mat.27:58, 59 Mrk.15:43, al; (b) <b>of the living body</b>: Luk.11:34, 1Co.6:13, al; ἐν σ. εἶναι, Heb.13:3; as the instrument of the soul, τὰ διὰ τοῦ σ, 2Co.5:10; opp. to πνεῦμα, Rom.8:10, 1Co.5:3 7:4, Jas.2:26; to ψυχή, Mat.6:25 10:28, Luk.12:22 (cf. Wis.1:1, al.); to τὸ π. καὶ ἡ ψ, 1Th.5:23; σ. ψυχικόν, opp. to σ. πνευματικόν, 1Co.15:44; ὁ ναὸς τοῦ σ. αὐτοῦ (genitive epexeg.), Jhn.2:21; τὸ σ. τ. ταπεινώσεως (Hebraistic "genitive of definition"; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 73f; Bl, §35, 5), opp. to τὸ σ. τ. δοξῆς αὐτοῦ, Php.3:21; similarly, τὸ σ. τ. σαρκός, Col.1:22; σ. τοῦ θανάτου (subject to death), Rom.7:24; σ. τ. ἁμαρτίας, Rom.6:6; (with) periphr, ἀνθρώπου, then absol, σῶμα (Soph, Xen, al.), <b>a person</b>, and in later writers (Polyb, al.), <b>a slave</b>: Rev.18:13 (cf. MM, i, ii, xxiv; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 160). 2) <b>Of the bodies of animals</b>: living, Jas.3:3; dead, Heb.13:11 (Exo.29:14, al.). 3) <b>Of inanimate objects </b>(cf. Eng. "heavenly bodies"): 1Co.15:37, 38 40 (Diod, al.). 4) <b>Of any corporeal substance </b>(Plat, al.): opp. to σκιά, Col.2:17. Metaph, of a number of persons united by a common bond; in NT, of the Church as the spiritual body of Christ: Rom.12:5, 1Co.10:16, 17 12:13, 27, Eph.1:23 2:16 4:4, 12, 16 5:23, 30, Col.1:18, 24 2:19 3:15; ἓν σ. κ. ἓν πνεῦμα, Eph.4:4. (AS)

G4990	σωτήρ	sōtēr	savior	G:N-M	<b>σωτήρ</b>, -ῆρος, ὁ (&lt; σώζω), [in LXX for יָשַׁע and cognate forms;] saviour, deliverer, preserver, a freq. epithet of kings in the Ptolemaic and Rom. periods (Deiss, BS, 83; <i>LAE</i>, 368 f; MM, xxiv), in NT, (a) of God (as LXX: Psa.24:5, Isa.12:2, al.): Luk.1:47, 1Ti.1:1 2:3 4:10, Tit.1:3 2:10 3:4, Ju 25; (b) <b>of Christ</b>: Luk.2:11, Act.5:31 13:23, Php.3:20; τ. κόσμου, Jhn.4:42, 1Jn.4:14 (for the general use of the word, see Westc, in l); ἡμῶν, 2Ti.1:10, Tit.1:4 3:6; θεὸς (κύριος) καὶ σ. G4991	σωτηρία	sōtēria	salvation	G:N-F	<b>σωτηρία</b>, -ας, ἡ (&lt; σωτήρ), [in LXX for יֶשַׁע, יְשׁוּעָה, תְּשׁוּעָה, פְּלֵיטָה, etc;] <b>deliverance, preservation, salvation, safety </b>(Lat. salus): Act.7:25 27:34, Heb.11:7; ἐξ ἐχθρῶν, Luk.1:71. G5010	τάξις	taxis	order	G:N-F	<b>τάξις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; τάσσω), [in LXX: Job.38:12 (מָקוֹם), Psa.110:4 (דִּבְרָה), 2Ma.9:18, al;] 1) an arranging, hence, in military sense, disposition of an army, battle array (Thuc, al.). 2) <b>arrangement, order </b>(Plat, al): Luk.1:8. 3) <b>due order</b>: Col.2:5 (<i>ICC</i>, in l); κατὰ τάξιν, 1Co.14:40. 4) <b>office, order </b>(for exx, see MM, xxiv): Heb.5:6 (LXX), Heb.5:6 6:20 7:11, 17 " (LXX). G5011	ταπεινός	tapeinos	lowly	G:A	<b>ταπεινός</b>, -ή, -όν [in LXX for שָׁפָל, עָנִי, etc;] <b>low-lying</b>; metaph, (a) <b>lowly, of low degree, brought low</b>: Jas.1:9, 2Co.7:6 (cf. Sir.25:23); οἱ τ, opp. to δυνάσται, Luk.1:52; τ. ταπεινοῖς (neut, R, txt; masc, R, mg; see <i>ICC</i>, in l), Rom.12:16; (b) lowly in spirit, humble, in cl. usually in a slighting sense (see Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, § xlii; but see also Abbott, <i>Essays</i>, 81), in NT in an honourable sense: 2Co.10:1; before τ. καρδίᾳ, Mat.11:29 (cf. Psa.34:19); opp. to ὑπερήφανος, Jas.4:6, 1Pe.5:5 " (LXX). (AS)

G5023	ταῦτα	tauta	this	G:DemP	<b>οὗτος</b>, αὕτη, τοῦτο, genitive, τούτου, ταύτης, τούτου, [in LXX chiefly for זֹאת,זֶה;] <i>demonstr. pron.</i> (related to ἐκεῖνος as hic to ille), <b>this</b>; 1) as subst, <b>this one, he</b>; (a) absol: Mat.3:17, Mrk.9:7, Luk.7:44, 45, Jhn.1:15, Act.2:15, al; expressing contempt (cl.), Mat.13:55, 56, Mrk.6:2, 3, Jhn.6:42, al; εἰς τοῦτο, Mrk.1:38, Rom.14:9; μετὰ τοῦτο (ταῦτα; V. Westc. on Jhn.5:1), Jhn.2:12 11:7, al; (b) <b>epanaleptic </b>(referring to what precedes): Mat.5:19, Mrk.3:35, Luk.9:48, Jhn.6:46, Rom.7:10, al; (with) <b>proleptic </b>(referring to what follows): before ἵνα (Bl, §69, 6), Luk.1:43, Jhn.3:19 (and freq.) 15:8, Rom.14:9, al; before ὅτι, Luk.10:11, Jhn.9:3 o, Act.24:14, Rom.2:3, al; ὅπως, Rom.9:17; ἐάν, Jhn.13:35; (d) <b>special idioms</b>: τοῦτο μὲν. τ. δέ (cl), <b>partly. partly</b>. Heb.10:33; καὶ τοῦτο (τοῦτον, ταῦτα), <b>and that (him) too</b>, Rom.13:11, 1Co.2:2, Heb.11:12; τοῦτ᾽ ἐστιν, Mat.27:46. 2) As adj, with subst; (a) with art. (α) before the art: Mat.12:32, Mrk.9:29, Luk.7:44, Jhn.4:15, Rom.11:24, Rev.19:9, al; (β) <b>after the noun</b>: Mat.3:9, Mrk.12:16, Luk.11:31, Jhn.4:13, Act.6:13, Rom.15:28, 1Co.1:20, Rev.2:24, al; (b) with subst. anarth. (with predicative force; Bl, §49, 4): Luk.1:36 2:2 24:21, Jhn.2:11 4:54 21:14, 2Co.13:1. (AS)

G5037	τε	te	and/both	G:Conj	<b>τέ</b>, <i>enclitic copulative particle</i> (= Lat. -que as καί = and, ac, atque, not very freq. in NT, more than two-thirds of the occurrences being in <i>Ac. </i> 1) τέ solitarium, <b>and</b>, denoting a closer affinity than καί between words and sentences which it connects (BL, §77, 8): Mat.28:12, Jhn.4:42, Act.2:33, 37 40 10:22 11:21, al. 2) Denoting a closer connection than simple καί, τὲ. καί, τὲ καί, τὲ. τέ (Act.26:16 Rom.14:8), <b>as well. as also, both. and</b>: Luk.12:45, Act.1:1 15:9, 21:30, al; τὲ. δέ, <b>and. and</b>, Act.19:2; τὲ γάρ. ὁμοίως δὲ καί, Rom.1:26, 27. G5046	τέλειος	teleios	perfect	G:A	<b>τέλειος</b>, -α, -ον (&lt; τέλος), [in LXX chiefly for שָׁלֵם, תָּמִים and cogn. forms;] <b>having reached its end, finished, mature, complete, perfect</b>; 1) of persons, primarily of physical development, (a) <b>full-grown, mature</b>: Heb.5:14; ethically: Php.3:15; opp. to νήπιος (-άζειν), 1Co.2:6 14:20, Eph.4:13; τ. καὶ πεπληροφορημένοι, Col.4:12; τ. ἐν Χριστῷ, Col.1:28; (b) complete, perfect (expressing the simple idea of complete goodness, without reference either to maturity or to the philosophical idea of a τέλος; see Hort on Jas.1:4): Mat.5:48 19:21, Jas.1:4 3:2; of God, Mat.5:48. 2) <b>Of things, complete, perfect</b>: Rom.12:2; ἔργον, Jas.1:4; νόμος, Jas.1:25; δώρημα, Jas.1:17; ἀγάπη, 1Jn.4:18; τὸ τ, 1Co.13:10; compar, τελειοτέρα (σκηνή), Heb.9:11. G5101	τίς	tis	which? I. I. As subst, 1) 1. masc, fem: τίς; <b>who, what?</b>, Mat.3:7 26:68; Mrk.11:28, Luk.9:9, al. mult; with genitive partit, Act.7:52, Heb.1:5, al; before ἐκ (= genitive partit.), Mat.6:27, Luk.14:28, Jhn.8:46; = ποῖος, Mrk.4:41 6:2, Luk.19:3, Act.17:19, al; = πότερος (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 77), Mat.21:31 27:17, Luk.22:27, al; = ὅς or ὅστις (rare in cl; cf. Bl, §50, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 93), Act.13:25. 2) Neut: τί; <b>what?</b>, Mat.5:47 11:7, Mrk.10:3, al; χάριν τίνος, 1Jn.3:12; διὰ τί, Mat.9:11, al; εἰς τί, Mat.14:31, al; elliptically, ἵνα τί (sc. γένηται), <b>why</b>, Mat.9:5, al; τί οὖν, Rom.3:9 6:1, 15 1Co.14:15, al; τί γάρ, Rom.3:3, Phi 1:18; τί ἐμοὶ (ὑμῖν) καὶ σοί, see: ἔγω. II. As adj: <b>who? what? which?</b>, Mat.5:46, Luk.14:31, Jhn.2:18, al. III. As adv: = διὰ τι (τί ὅτι), <b>why</b>, Mat.6:28, Mrk.4:40, Luk.6:46, Jhn.18:23, al; in rhet. questions, = a negation, Mat.27:4, Jhn.21:22, 23 1Co.5:12 7:16, al. in exclamations (like Heb. מָה), <b>how</b> (2Ki.6:20, Psa.3:2, al.), Luk.12:49. (AS)
G5102	τίτλος	titlos	title	G:N-M	<b>τίτλος</b>, -ου, ὁ (Lat. titulus), [in Aq, Sm, <i>Th.</i>: Jer.21:4 *;] <b>a title, inscription</b>: Jhn.19:19-20 (in Christian Inscr, epitaph, see MM. xxiv). (AS)
G5103	Τίτος	Titos	Titus	N:N-M-P	<b>Τίτος</b>, -ου, ὁ <b>Titus</b>; 1) St. Paul's disciple and companion: 2Co.2:13 7:6 7:13-14 8:6 8:16 8:23 12:18, Gal.2:1, 3, 2Ti.4:10, Tit.1:4, subscr, Rec. (Τῖτος). 2) <b>One surnamed Justus</b>: Act.18:7, RV (T, WH, Τίτιος). (AS)
G5104	τοί	toi	certainly	G:Part	1. enclit. Particle, serving to express belief in an assertion, <b>let me tell you, surely, verily </b>, used to express an inference, <b>then, consequently </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; and in [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota, to introduce a general sentiment. 2. to strengthen other Particles, γάρ τοι, ἤτοι, καίτοι, μέντοι, τοιγάρτοι, etc: compare τἆρα, τἄν, μεντἄν. (ML)
G5105	τοιγαροῦν	toigaroun	therefore	G:Conj	<b>τοι-γαρ-οῦν </b> <i>an inferential particle</i>, [in LXX: Job.22:10 24:22, Sir.41:16, al;] <b>wherefore then, so therefore</b>: 1Th.4:8, Heb.12:1 (Hat, Plat, al.). (AS)
G5106	τοίνυν	toinun	then	G:Conj	<b>τοί-νυν </b> <i>an inferential particle</i>, [in LXX: Isa.3:10 5:13 27:4, Wis.1:11 8:9, a1. *;] <b>accordingly, therefore</b>: as in cl, after the first word in a sentence, 1Co.9:26; accusative to later usage, at the beginning, Luk.20:25, Heb.13:13. (AS)
G5107	τοιόσδε	toiosde	such as this	G:DemP	<i>antecedent</i> to οἷος, as ἀοιδοῦ τοιοῦδ᾽ οἷος ὅδ᾽ ἐστί of <b>such a </b> minstrel as is this one, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; <i>absolute</i>, ἀλλ᾽ ὅδ᾽ ἐγὼ τοιόσδε here am I <b>such as you see </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];also, <b>so great, so noble, so bad </b>, τοιάδε λαίφη <b>such </b> clothes, i. e. <b>so bad </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; τοσόσδε καὶ τοιόσδε [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];also with a qualifying word, τοιόσδ᾽ ἠμὲν δέμας ἠδὲ καὶ ἔργα <b>such </b> both in form and works, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];with the Art, ὁ τ. ἀνήρ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc; οἱ τοιοίδε [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἐν τῷ τοιῷδε in <b>such </b> circumstances, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];the sense is made more indefinite in τοιόσδε τις <b>such a </b> one, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>neuter</i> <i>plural</i> τοιάδε <b>as follows </b>, τοιαῦτα <b>as aforesaid </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G5108	τοιοῦτος	toioutos	such as this	G:DemP	<b>τοιοῦτος</b>, -αύτη, -οῦτο (as usually in Att. prose. Ep. and Ion. neut. -οῦτον in Al, Act.21:25, Rec. only), correlat. of οἷος, ὁποῖος, ὥς, etc, <b>such as this, of such a kind, such</b>: Mat.9:8 18:5, Mrk.4:33 6:2 7:13 9:37 (T, τούτων), Jhn.9:16, Act.16:24, 1Co.5:1 11:16, 2Co.3:4 3:12 12:3, Heb.7:26 8:1 12:3 13:16, Jas.4:16; οἷος. τ, 1Co.15:48, 2Co.10:11; id. pleonast. (see Bl, § 50, 4), Mrk.13:19; before ὁποῖος, Act.26:29; ὥς, Phm 9. As subst, <b>anarth</b>: pl, Luk.9:9; with art, ὁ τ, such a one (Bl, § 47, 9; Ellic. on Gal.5:21): Act.22:22, 1Co.5:5, al; pl, Mat.19:14, Mrk.10:14, al; neut. pl, Act.19:25, Rom.1:32, al (AS)
G5109	τοῖχος	toichos	wall	G:N-M	<b>τοῖχος</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX chiefly for קִיר;] a wall, esp. of a house: figuratively, Act.23:3 (cf. τεῖχος). (AS)
G5110	τόκος	tokos	interest	G:N-M	<b>τόκος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; τίκτω), [in LXX for נֶשֶׁךְ, etc;] (a) <b>a bringing forth, birth</b>; (b) offspring. Metaph, of the produce of money lent out, <b>interest, usury </b>(cf. Merch. of Venice, I, iii, "a breed of barren metal "): Mat.25:27, Luk.19:23 (Soph, Plat, al.). (AS)
G5111	τολμάω	tolmaō	be bold	G:V	<b>τολμάω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: Job.15:12 (לָקַח), Est.1:18 7:5 (לֵב מָלֵא) Jdth.14:13, 2Ma.4:2, 3Ma.3:21 R, 4Ma.8:18 *;] <b>to have courage, to venture, dare, be bold</b>: absol, 2Co.11:21; before ἐπί, 2Co.10:2; with inf. (Bl, § 69, 4), Mat.22:46, Mrk.12:34, Luk.20:40, Jhn.21:12, Act.5:13 7:32, Rom.15:18, 1Co.6:1, 2Co.10:12, Php.1:14, Ju 9; to submit to (in cl. usually absol. in this sense), Rom.5:7 (see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 155); τολμήσας εἰσῆλθεν, took courage and went in (see Field, <i>op. cit.</i>, 44), Mrk.15:43 (cf. ἀπο-τολμάω). (AS)
G5112	τολμηρότερον	tolmēroteron	more boldly	G:Adv	<b>τολμηρῶς </b> <i>adv.</i>, (&lt; τολμηρός, bold, daring), <b>boldly</b>: compar, -ότερως (T, Rec. -ότερον), Rom.15:15. (AS)
G5113	τολμητής	tolmētēs	bold man	G:N-M	<b>τολμητής</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; τολμάω), <b>a bold, daring man</b>: 2Pe.2:10 (Thuc.). (AS)
G5114	τομώτερος	tomōteros	sharper	G:A	<b>τομός</b>, -ή, -όν (&lt; τέμνω), <b>sharp</b>: compar, -ώτερος, metaph, Heb.4:12. (AS)

G5117	τόπος	topos	place	G:N-M	<b>τόπος</b>, -ου, ὁ, [in LXX chiefly for מָקוֹם;] <b>place</b>: Luk.4:37 10:1, 32 Jhn.5:13 6:10, Act.12:17, 1Co.1:2, al; τ. ἅγιος (cf. Isa.60:13), Mat.24:15; ἔρημος, Mat.14:13, al; πεδινός, Luk.6:17; ἄνυδρος (pl.), Mat.12:43, Luk.11:24; κατὰ τόπος (BV, <i>in divers places</i>), Mat.24:7, Mrk.13:8; τραχεῖς τ, Act.27:29; τ. διθάλασσος (which see), ib. 41; ἑτοιμάζειν τ, Jhn.14:2, 3; ἔχειν, Rev.12:6; διδόναι, Luk.14:9; with genitive defin, τ. βασάνου, Luk.16:28; τ. καταπαύσεως, Act.7:49; κρανίου, Mat.27:33, Mrk.15:22, Jhn.19:17; before οὗ, Rom.9:26; ὅπου, Mat.28:6, Mrk.16:6, Jhn.4:20 6:23 10:40 11:30 19:41; ἐν ᾧ, Jhn.11:6; ἐφ ̓ ᾧ, Act.7:33; of a place which a person or thing occupies, Rev.2:5 6:14 12:8; τ. μαχαίρας, Mat.26:52; ὁ ἴδιος τ, Act.1:25; of a place in a book, Luk.4:17 (cf. Clem. Rom, <i>I Co.</i>, 8, 4). Metaph, of condition, <b>station, occasion, opportunity or power</b>: Act.25:16, Rom.12:19 15:23, Eph.4:27 (cf. Sir.38:12). (AS)
G5118	τοσοῦτος	tosoutos	so great	G:Cor	<b>τοσοῦτος</b>, -αύτη, -οῦτο (Heb.7:22) and (elsewhere, as usually in Attic) -οῦτον, correlat. of ὅσος, of quantity, size, number, so great, so much, pl, <b>so many</b>: Mat.8:10 Luk.7:9, Heb.12:1, Rev.18:7, 16; of time, so long, χρόνος, Jhn.14:9, Heb.4:7; pl, Luk.15:29 (ἔτη), Jhn.12:37 21:11, 1Co.14:10; before ὥστε, Mat.15:33; absol: pl, Jhn.6:9, Gal.3:4; of price, τοσούτου, Act.5:8; dative, τοσούτῳ κρείττων, Heb.1:4; τ. μᾶλλον ὅσῳ, Heb.10:25; καθ᾽ ὅσον. κατὰ τ, Heb.7:22. (AS)
G5119	τότε	tote	then	G:Adv	<b>τότε</b>, <i>demonstr. adv.</i> of time, correlat. of ὅτε, <b>then, at that time</b>; (a) <b>of concurrent events</b>: Mat.2:17 3:5 and freq, Rom.6:21; before ptcp, Mat.2:16, Gal.4:8; opp. to νῦν, Gal.4:29, Heb.12:26; ὁ τ. κόσμος, 2Pe.3:6; (b) of consequent events, <b>then, thereupon</b>: Mat.2:7 3:5 4:1 and freq, Luk.11:26; τ. οὖν, Jhn.11:14 19:1, 16 20:8; εὐθέως τ, Act.17:14; ὅτε. τ, Mat.13:26 21:1, Jhn.12:16; ἀπὸ τ, Mat.4:17 16:21 26:16, Luk.16:16; (with) <b>of things future</b>: Mat.24:28, 40 25:1, 31 ff; opp. to ἄρτι, 1Co.13:12; καὶ τ, Mat.7:23, Mrk.13:21, Luk.21:27, 1Co.4:5, al; ὅταν. τ, Mat.9:15, Mrk.2:20, Luk.5:35, 1Th.5:3, al. G5124	τοῦτο	touto	that	G:DemP	<b>οὗτος</b>, αὕτη, τοῦτο, genitive, τούτου, ταύτης, τούτου, [in LXX chiefly for זֹאת,זֶה;] <i>demonstr. pron.</i> (related to ἐκεῖνος as <i>hic to ille), </i> <b>this</b>; 1) as subst, <b>this one, he</b>; (a) absol: Mat.3:17, Mrk.9:7, Luk.7:44, 45, Jhn.1:15, Act.2:15, al; expressing contempt (cl.), Mat.13:55, 56, Mrk.6:2, 3, Jhn.6:42, al; εἰς τοῦτο, Mrk.1:38, Rom.14:9; μετὰ τοῦτο (ταῦτα; V. Westc. on Jhn.5:1), Jhn.2:12 11:7, al; (b) <b>epanaleptic </b>(referring to what precedes): Mat.5:19, Mrk.3:35, Luk.9:48, Jhn.6:46, Rom.7:10, al; (with) <b>proleptic </b>(referring to what follows): before ἵνα (Bl, §69, 6), Luk.1:43, Jhn.3:19 (and freq.) 15:8, Rom.14:9, al; before ὅτι, Luk.10:11, Jhn.9:3 o, Act.24:14, Rom.2:3, al; ὅπως, Rom.9:17; ἐάν, Jhn.13:35; (d) <b>special idioms</b>: τοῦτο μὲν. τ. δέ (cl), <b>partly. partly</b>. Heb.10:33; καὶ τοῦτο (τοῦτον, ταῦτα), <b>and that (him) too</b>, Rom.13:11, 1Co.2:2, Heb.11:12; τοῦτ᾽ ἐστιν, Mat.27:46. 2) As adj, with subst; (a) with art. (α) before the art: Mat.12:32, Mrk.9:29, Luk.7:44, Jhn.4:15, Rom.11:24, Rev.19:9, al; (β) <b>after the noun</b>: Mat.3:9, Mrk.12:16, Luk.11:31, Jhn.4:13, Act.6:13, Rom.15:28, 1Co.1:20, Rev.2:24, al; (b) with subst. anarth. (with predicative force; Bl, §49, 4): Luk.1:36 2:2 24:21, Jhn.2:11 4:54 21:14, 2Co.13:1. (AS)

G5129	τούτῳ	toutō	to this	G:DemP	<b>οὗτος</b>, αὕτη, τοῦτο, genitive, τούτου, ταύτης, τούτου, [in LXX chiefly for זֹאת,זֶה;] <i>demonstr. pron.</i> (related to ἐκεῖνος as <i>hic to ille), </i> <b>this</b>; 1) as subst, <b>this one, he</b>; (a) absol: Mat.3:17, Mrk.9:7, Luk.7:44, 45, Jhn.1:15, Act.2:15, al; expressing contempt (cl.), Mat.13:55, 56, Mrk.6:2, 3, Jhn.6:42, al; εἰς τοῦτο, Mrk.1:38, Rom.14:9; μετὰ τοῦτο (ταῦτα; V. Heb.10:33; καὶ τοῦτο (τοῦτον, ταῦτα), <b>and that (him) too</b>, Rom.13:11, 1Co.2:2, Heb.11:12; τοῦτ᾽ ἐστιν, Mat.27:46. 2) As adj, with subst; (a) with art. (α) before the art: Mat.12:32, Mrk.9:29, Luk.7:44, Jhn.4:15, Rom.11:24, Rev.19:9, al; (β) <b>after the noun</b>: Mat.3:9, Mrk.12:16, Luk.11:31, Jhn.4:13, Act.6:13, Rom.15:28, 1Co.1:20, Rev.2:24, al; (b) with subst. anarth. (with predicative force; Bl, §49, 4): Luk.1:36 2:2 24:21, Jhn.2:11 4:54 21:14, 2Co.13:1. (AS)

G5177	τυγχάνω	tugchanō	to obtain/happen	G:V	<b>τυγχάνω </b> [in LXX: Deu.19:5 (מָצָא), Job.3:21 7:2 17:1, Pro.30:23 (without definite <i>Heb.</i> equiv.), Wis.15:19, 1Ma.11:42, 3Ma.3:7, al;] I. Trans. 1) to hit (opp. to ἁμαρτάνω, <b>to miss the mark</b>: Hom, Xen, al.). 2) <b>to hit upon, light upon</b>; (a) <b>of persons, to meet with, fall in with</b>: absol, ptcp, ὁ τυχών, a chance person, anyone (Lat. quivis), οὐ τυχών, not common or ordinary, Act.19:11 28:2; (b) <b>of things, to reach, get, obtain</b>: with genitive of thing(s) Luk.20:35, Act.24:3 26:22 27:3, 2Ti.2:10 Heb.8:6 11:35. II. Intrans, to happen; of things, <b>to happen, chance, befall</b>: impers, εἰ τύχοι, it may be, perhaps, 1Co.14:10 15:37; so ptcp, τυχόν (old accusative absol; see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 74), 1Co.16:6 (cf. ἐν, ὑπερ-εν, ἐπι, παρα, συν-τυγχάνω). τυχόν, adv, see: τυγχάνω (AS)

G5179	τύπος	tupos	mark/example	G:N-M	<b>τύπος</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; τύπτω), [in LXX: Exo.25:39 (40) (תַּבְנִית), Amo.5:26, 3Ma.3:30, 4Ma.6:19 *;] 1) <b>the mark of a blow</b>: τῶν ἥλων, Jhn.20:25. 2) <b>An impression, impress, the stamp made by a die; hence, a figure, image</b>: Act.7:43 (LXX). 3) <b>form </b>(Plat.): Rom.6:17; the sense or substance of a letter (3Mac, l.with), Act.23:25. 4) <b>an example, pattern</b>: Act.7:44, Heb.8:6 " (LXX); in ethical sense, Php.3:17, 1Th.1:7, 2Th.3:9, 1Ti.4:12, Tit.2:7, 1Pe.5:3; in doctrinal sense, type (see <i>ICC</i>, in l), Rom.5:14. τυπικῶς, adv. (&lt; τύπος), (a) typically (Greg. Naz.) (b) <b>by way of example</b>: 1Co.10:11. (AS)
G5180	τύπτω	tuptō	to strike	G:V	<b>τύπτω </b> [in LXX chiefly for hi;] <b>to strike, smite, beat</b>: with accusative, Mat.24:49, Mrk.15:19, Luk.12:45, Act.18:17 21:32 23:2-3; of mourners, τὰ στήθη, Luk.18:13 23:48; ἐπὶ τ. σιαγόνα, Luk.6:29; εἰς τ. κεφαλήν, Mat.27:30. G5181	Τύραννος	Turannos	Tyrannus	N:N-M-P	1. <b>an absolute sovereign </b>, unlimited by law or constitution, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc: not applied to old hereditary sovereignties βασιλεῖαι); such as those of [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] or of Sparta; for the term rather regards the irregular way in which the power was <b>gained </b>, than the way in which it was <b>exercised </b>, being applied to the mild Pisistratus, but not to the despotic kings of Persia. However, the word soon came to imply reproach, like our <b>tyrant </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. in a wider sense, <b>the tyrant's son </b>, or <b>any member of his family </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];so, ἡ τύραννος was both <b>the queen </b> herself or <b>a princess </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. τύραννος, ον, as <i>adjective</i> <b>kingly, royal </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota 4. <b>imperious, despotic </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τύραννα δρᾶν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] τύραννος is probably from same Root as κύριος, κοίρανος. (ML)

G5207	υἱός	uhios	son	G:N-M	<b>υἱός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ, [in LXX very freq. and nearly always for בֵּן, Gen.4:17, al; for בַּר, Dan LXX TH 7:13, al; etc;], <b>a son</b>; 1) <b>in the ordinary sense</b>: Mat.10:37, Mrk.9:17, Luk.1:13, al. mult; omitted with the art. of origin (WM, §30, 3; Bl, §35, 2), τὸν τοῦ Ἰεσσαί, Act.13:22 (LXX); also with genitive anarth. (cl.), Σώπατρος Πύρρου Βεροιαῖος, Act.20:4; with adj, προτότοκος, Luk.2:7; μονογένης, Luk.7:12; opp. to νόθος, Heb.12:8; in a wider sense, of posterity: ὁ υἱ. Δαυΐδ, of the Messiah (cf. Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 316ff; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 653f.), Mat.22:42, 45 Mrk.12:35, 37 Luk.20:41, 44 al; υἱοὶ Ἰσραήλ, (cf. υἷες Ἀχαιῶν, Hom, <i>Il.</i>, i, 162, al.), Mat.27:9, Act.9:15, al. 2) Metaph; (a) <b>as belonging to, being connected with or having the quality of that which follows </b>(a usage mainly due to translation from a Semitic original; cf. Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 161ff; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 115f; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 652f.): τ. πονεροῦ (διαβόλου), Mat.13:38, Act.13:10; τ. νυμφῶνος (see: νυμφών), Mat.9:15, Mrk.2:19, al; τ. φωτός (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 74), Luk.16:8, Jhn.12:36, 1Th.5:5; τ. εἰρεήμης, Luk.10:6; γεέννης, Mat.23:15; τ. ἀπωλείας, Jhn.17:12, 2Th.2:3; τ. αἰῶνος τούτου, Luk.16:8 20:34; τ. ἀπειθειάς, Eph.2:2 5:6; βροντῆς, Mrk.3:17; τ. ἀναστάσεως, Luk.20:36; παρακλήσεως, Act.4:36; τ. προφητῶν κ. τ. διαθήκης, Act.3:25; (b) υἱὸς τ. θεοῦ (cf. Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 268ff; Deiss, <i>BS</i>, 166f; <i>DB</i>, iv, 570 ff; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 654ff.), of men, as partakers of the Divine nature and of the life to come: Mat.5:9, Luk.20:36, Rom.8:14 9:26, al; υἱοὶ (κ. θυγατέρες) τ. ὑψίστου, Luk.6:35, 2Co.6:18; in an unique sense of Jesus, Mat.4:3 8:29 28:19, Mrk.3:4, Luk.4:41, Jhn.9:35 11:27, al; ὁ Χριστὸς ὁ υἱ. τ. θεοῦ ζῶντος (τ. εὐλογητοῦ), Mat.16:16, Mrk.14:61; (with) (ὁ) υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου (in LXX for Heb. בּן אדם, Aram, בּר אנשׁ; cf. Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 234ff; <i>DB</i>, iv, 579ff; <i>DCG</i>, ii, 659ff; Westc, <i>St. John</i>, i, 74ff; other reff. in Swete, <i>Mk</i>, 2:10), based on the Aram. of Dan.7:13, where the phrase, like the corresponding Heb. (as in Psa.8:5), means <b>a man</b>, one of the species, and indicates the human appearance of the person in question. It is used of the Messiah in Enoch, with 46, §1-4, also in II Est.13:3, 12, al. Our Lord first makes the phrase a title, using the def. art. It seems to combine the ideas of his true humanity and representative character. Exc. in Act.7:56 and (anarth.) Rev.1:13 14:14, it is used of Jesus only by himself: Mat.8:20, Mrk.2:10, Luk.5:24, Jhn.1:52, al. (AS)

(MM, see word), Act.14:1, Luk.6:23, al; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐ, <b>together</b> (MM, see word), Mat.22:34, Act.1:15, al; ἓν κ. τὸ αὐ, 1Co.11:5, 12:11; with dative (cl.), 1Co.11:5; with a noun, λόγος, Mrk.14:39; μέτρος, Php.1:30; πνεῦμα, 1Co.12:4. (for irreg. constructions, V. Bl, §74, 5); pleonastically after the relative (cf. Heb. אֲשֶׁר לוֹ; WM, 184ff; Bl, §50, 4; MM, see word), Mrk.7:25, Rev.3:8, 7:2, al; in constr. ad sensum, without proper subject expressly indicated, Mat.4:23, Act.8:5, 2Co.2:13, al; genitive αὐτοῦ = ἐκείνου, Rom.11:11, 1Th.2:19, Tit.3:5, Heb.2:4. 3) ὁ, ἡ, τὸ αὐ, <b>the same</b>: Heb.1:12, 13:8; τὸ αὐ, ποιεῖν, Mat.5:46, 47, al; φρονεῖν, Rom.12:16, 15:5, Php.2:2, al; τὰ αὐ, Act.15:27, Rom.2:1, al; κατὰ τὸ (τὰ) αὐ. (MM, see word), Act.14:1, Luk.6:23, al; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐ, <b>together</b> (MM, see word), Mat.22:34, Act.1:15, al; ἓν κ. τὸ αὐ, 1Co.11:5, 12:11; with dative (cl.), 1Co.11:5; with a noun, λόγος, Mrk.14:39; μέτρος, Php.1:30; πνεῦμα, 1Co.12:4. (AS)

Field, <i>Notes</i>, 225). 4) In more colourless sense, = περί (M, <i>Pr.</i>, l.with), <b>for, concerning, with regard to</b>: Rom.9:27, 2Co.1:6 8:23 12:8, Php.1:7, 2Th.2:1, al. II. C. accusative, primarily of place, <b>over, beyond, across</b>, hence, metaph, of measure or degree in excess, <b>above, beyond, over, more than</b>: Mat.10:24, 37 Luk.6:40, Act.26:13, 1Co.10:13, 2Co.1:8, Eph.1:22 3:20, Phm 16, al; after comparatives = <b>than</b> (Jdg.11:25, al.), Luk.16:8, Heb.4:12. III. As <i>adv.</i> (see supr. ad init.), <b>more</b>: ὕπερ ἐγώ, <b>I more</b>, 2Co.11:23; in compounds, see: ὑπεράνω, ὑπερλίαν, ὑπερπερισσῶς. IV. <b>In composition</b>: <b>over</b> (ὑπεραίρω), <b>beyond</b> (ὑπερβάλλω), <b>more</b> (ὐπερνικάω), <b>on behalf of</b> (ὐπερεντυγχάνω). (AS)

G5246	ὑπέρογκος	huperogkos	boastful	G:A	<b>ὑπέρ-ογκος</b>, -ον [in LXX: Deu.30:11 (פָּלָא), etc;] <b>of excessive weight or size</b>; metaph, excessive, immoderate, in late writers, of arrogant speech (see Mayor on Ju, l.with): n. pl, 2Pe.2:18, Ju 16. (AS)
G5247	ὑπεροχή	huperochē	authority	G:N-F	<b>ὑπεροχή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ (&lt; ὑπερέχω) [in LXX: Jer.52:22 (קוֹמָה), 2Ma.3:11, al;] a projection, eminence, as the peak of a mountain. Metaph. (Arist.), <b>excellence, pre-eminence</b>: λόγου ἢ σοφίας, 1Co.2:1; οἱ ἐν ὑ (for a parallel to this phrase, see Deiss, BS, 255, and cf. 2Mac, l.with), 1Ti.2:2. (AS)
G5248	ὑπερπερισσεύω	huperperisseuō	to abound	G:V	<b>ὑπερ-περισσεύω </b> <b>to abound more exceedingly</b>: Rom.5:21. Mid, in same sense (RV, overflow): with dative of thing(s), 2Co.7:4. (AS)
G5249	ὑπερπερισσῶς	huperperissōs	exceedingly	G:Adv	<b>ὑπερ-περισσῶς </b> <i>adv.</i>, <b>beyond measure, exceedingly</b>: Mrk.7:37. (AS)
G5250	ὑπερπλεονάζω	huperpleonazō	to abound	G:V	<b>ὑπερ-πλεονάζω </b> <b>to abound exceedingly</b>: 1Ti.1:14 (Ps Sol 5:19; Herm, Mand, v, 2, 5). (AS)
G5251	ὑπερυψόω	huperupsoō	to exalt	G:V	<b>ὑπερ-υψόω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: Psa.37:35 (עָרִיץ) Psa.97:9 (עָלָה ni.), Da TH Dan.4:34 11:12 (רוּם), ib. LXX TH Dan.3:52 ff.*;] 1) <b>to exalt beyond measure, exalt to the highest place</b>: Php.2:9. 2) to extol (Da, ll. with). (AS)
G5252	ὑπερφρονέω	huperphroneō	be haughty	G:V	<b>ὑπερ-φρονέω</b>, -ῶ [in LXX: 4Ma.13:1 4Mac 14:11 4Mac 16:2 *;] 1) <b>to be overproud, high-minded </b>(Æsch.): μὴ ὑ. παρ᾽ ὃ δεῖ φρονεῖν (on the paranom, see Vau, in l), Rom.12:3. 2) to overlook, think slightly of (Thuc, Plat.). (AS)
G5253	ὑπερῷον	huperōon	upper room	G:N-N	<b>ὑπερῷον</b>, -ου, τό (neut. of ὑπερῷος, above, &lt; ὑπέρ) [in LXX for עֲלִיָּה and cogn. forms;] 1) in cl, the upper story or upper rooms where the women resided (Hom, a1.). 2) <b>In LXX and NT, an upper chamber, roof-chamber, built on the flat roof of the house </b>(see <i>DB</i>, iii, 674a): Act.1:13 9:37, 39 20:8 (cf. 4Ki.23:22). (AS)
G5254	ὑπέχω	hupechō	to undergo	G:V	<b>ὑπ-έχω </b> [in LXX: Psa.89:50 (נָשָׂא), La 5:7 (סָבַל), Wis.12:21, 2Ma.4:48 *;] to hold or put under. Metaph, <b>to undergo, suffer</b>: δίκην, Ju 7 (Soph, Eur, al.). (AS)
G5255	ὑπήκοος	hupēkoos	obedient	G:A	<b>ὑπήκοος</b>, -ον (&lt; ὑπακσύω), [in LXX: Jhn.17:13 (לָמַם) Pro.21:28 (שָׁמַע), etc;] <b>giving ear, obedient, subject</b>: Php.2:8; with dative of person(s), Act.7:39; εἰς πάντα, 2Co.2:9. (AS)
G5256	ὑπηρετέω	hupēreteō	to serve	G:V	<b>ὑπηρετέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ὑπηρέτης) [in LXX: Wis.16:21, 24-25 19:6, Sir.39:4 *;] prop, to serve as rower on a ship (Diod, al.). In cl. always metaph, <b>to minister to, serve</b>: with dative of person(s), Act.13:36 20:34 24:23. (AS)
G5257	ὑπηρέτης	hupēretēs	servant	G:N-M	<b>ὑπηρέτης</b>, -ου, ὁ (&lt; ὑπό + ἐρέτης, a rower) [in LXX: Pro.14:35 (עֶבֶד), Wis.6:4, al;] prop, an under rower; hence, generally, <b>a servant, attendant, minister</b>: of a magistrate's attendant, Mat.5:25; of officers of the Synagogue or Sanhedrin, Mat.26:58, Mrk.14:54, 65, Luk.4:20, Jhn.7:32, 45-46 18:3, 12 18:22 19:6, Act.5:22, 26; of the attendants of kings, οἱ ὑ. οἱ ἑμοί Jhn.18:36; of Christian ministers, Act.13:5 26:16; ὑπηρέται λόγου, Luk.1:2; Χριστοῦ, 1Co.4:1; δοῦλοι κ. ὑ, Jhn.18:18. (AS)
G5258	ὕπνος	hupnos	sleep	G:N-M	<b>ὕπνος</b>, -ου, ὁ [in LXX for שֵׁנָה, חֲלוֹם, etc;] <b>sleep</b>: Mat.1:24, Luk.9:32, Jhn.11:13, Act.20:9; metaph, Rom.13:11. (AS)
G5259	ὑπό	hupo	by/under	G:Prep	<b>ὑπό</b> (before smooth breathing ὑπ᾽, Mat.8:9 b, Luk.7:8 b; before rough breathing ὑφ᾽, Rom.3:9; on the neglect of elision in Mt, Lk, ll. witha, Gal.3:22, see WH, <i>App.</i>, 146; Tdf, <i>Pr.</i>, iv), <i>prep. with genitive, dative (not in NT), accusative </i> I. C. genitive, primarily of place, <b>under</b>, hence, metaph, of the efficient cause, <b>by</b>: after passive verbs, with genitive of person(s), Mat.1:22, Mrk.1:5, Luk.2:18, Jhn.14:21, Act.4:11, 1Co.1:11, Heb.3:4, al; with genitive of thing(s), Mat.8:24, Luk.7:24, Rom.3:21, al; with neut. verbs and verbs with pass, meaning, Mat.17:12, Mrk.5:26, 1Co.10:9, 10 1Th.2:14, al. II. C. accusative, <b>under</b>; 1) <b>of motion</b>: Mat.5:15 8:8, Mrk.4:21, Luk.13:34; hence, metaph, of subjection, Rom.7:14, 1Co.15:27, Gal.3:22, 1Pe.5:6, al. 2) <b>Of position</b>: Jhn.1:49, Act.4:12, Rom.3:13, 1Co.10:1, al; hence, metaph, <b>under, subject to</b>, Mat.8:9, Rom.3:9, 1Co.9:20, Gal.4:5, al. 3) <b>Of time, about</b>: Act.5:21. III. <b>In composition</b>: <b>under</b> (ὑποδέω), hence, of <b>subjection</b> (ὑποτάσσω), compliance (ὑπακούω), <b>secrecy</b> (ὑποβάλλω), <b>diminution</b> (ὑποπνέω). (AS)
G5260	ὑποβάλλω	hupoballō	to instigate	G:V	<b>ὑπο-βάλλω </b> [in LXX? Dan.3:9 A, I Est.2:18 *;] to throw or put under. Metaph, (a) <b>to subject, submit</b>; (b) <b>to suggest, whisper, prompt</b>; (with) to suborn (see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 113), <b>instigate</b>: with accusative of person(s), Act.6:11. (AS)
G5261	ὑπογραμμός	hupogrammos	example	G:N-M	<b>ὑπογραμμός</b>, -οῦ, ὁ (&lt; ὑπογράφω, (a) to write under; (b) to trace letters for copying), [in LXX: 2Ma.2:28 *;] 1) <b>a writing-copy, hence, </b> 2) <b>an example</b>: 1Pe.2:11 (Philo). (AS)
G5262	ὑπόδειγμα	hupodeigma	example	G:N-N	<b>ὑπό-δειγμα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; ὑποδείκνυμι), [in LXX: Eze.42:15, Sir.44:16, 2Ma.6:28 2Mac 6:31, 4Ma.17:23 *;] used by later writers (Xen. onwards) for παράδειγμα (see Rutherford, <i>NPhr.</i>, 62), (a) <b>a figure, copy</b>: Heb.8:5 9:23; (b) <b>an example</b>: for imitation, Jhn.13:15, Jas.5:10; for warning, Heb.4:11, 2Pe.2:6. (AS)

G5265	ὑποδέω	hupodeō	to put on	G:V	<b>ὑπο-δέω </b> [in LXX: 2Ch.28:15, Eze.16:10 (נָעַל) *;] to blind under, esp. of foot gear. G5271	ὑποκρίνω	hupokrinō	to pretend	G:V	<b>ὑπο-κρίνομαι </b> [in LXX: (Job.40:2) אּ1 (AB אּ2 ἀπο, עָנָה), Sir.1:29 35:15 (32:15) Sir.36:2 (33:2), 2Ma.5:25 2Mac 6:21 2Mac 6:24, 4Ma.6:15 4Mac 6:17 *;] 1) = Att. ἀποκρίνομαι (which see), to answer, reply (Hom, Hdt, al.). 2) to answer on the stage, play apart (Arist, al.). G5287	ὑπόστασις	hupostasis	confidence/essence	G:N-F	<b>ὑπό-στασις</b>, -εως, ἡ (&lt; ὑφίστημι, to set under, stand under, support) [in LXX for מַצָּב (1Ki.13:23 14:4 B), תִּקְוָה (Rut.1:12, Eze.19:5), etc, also in Wis.16:21;] 1) a support, base or foundation (in various senses). 2) <b>substance </b>(Arist, al; opp. to φαντασία, ἔμφασις): Heb.1:3 3) steadiness, firmness (Polyb, al.), <b>hence, assurance, confidence</b>: 2Co.9:4 11:17, Heb.3:14 11:1 (here perhaps title-deed, as that which gives reality or guarantee; see MM, xxv). G5293	ὑποτάσσω	hupotassō	to subject	G:V	<b>ὑπο-τάσσω </b> [in LXX for דָבַר hi, דָּמַם, שׂוּם, שִׁית, etc;] 1) as a military term, to place or rank under (Polyb.). 2) <b>to subject, put in subjection</b>: 1Co.15:27, Php.3:21, Heb.2:5, 8; pass, Rom.8:20, 1Co.15:27-28, 1Pe.3:22, Eph.1:22. Mid, <b>to subject oneself, obey</b>: absol, Rom.13:5, 1Co.14:34; with dative of person(s), Luk.2:51 10:17, 20, Rom.8:7 10:3 13:1, 1Co.14:32 15:28 (ὑποταγήσεται; cf. M, <i>Pr.</i>, 163), 1Co.16:16, Eph.5:21-22 (T, WH, txt, R, om.), Eph.5:24, Col.3:18, Tit.2:5, 9 3:1, Heb.12:9, 1Pe.2:18 3:1 3:5 5:5; imperat, Jas.4:7, 1Pe.2:13 5:5. (AS)
G5294	ὑποτίθημι	hupotithēmi	to lay	G:V	<b>ὑπο-τίθημι </b> [in LXX for שׂוּם, etc;] to place under, lay down. Metaph, τ. τράχηλον ὑποθεῖναι, <b>to risk one's life </b>(see Deiss, <i>LAE</i>, 119 f.): Rom.16:4; mid, <b>to suggest</b>: 1Ti.4:6. (AS)

G5302	ὑστερέω	hustereō	to lack	G:V	<b>ὑστερέω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; ὕστερος), [in LXX for חָסֵר, חָדַל etc;] to come late, be behind (opp. to προτερέω, φθάνω; with genitive of thing(s), for; with genitive of person(s), later than). Metaph, 1) of persons, (a) absol, <b>to come short, fail</b>: Heb.4:1; before ἀπό, Heb.12:15; (b) with genitive of person(s), <b>to come short of, be inferior to</b>: 2Co.11:5; οὐδέν (in nothing, in no respect), 2Co.12:11; (with) with reference to things, to come short (of), <b>be in want </b>(of): with accusative of thing(s), Mat.19:20 (Sir.51:24); with genitive of thing(s), Luk.22:35; so mid. (Diod, FlJ), Rom.3:23; absol, to be in want, suffer want, Luk.15:14, 1Co.8:8, 2Co.11:8, Heb.11:37 (Sir.11:11); opp. to περισσεύειν, Php.4:12; before ἐν, 1Co.1:7. 2) <b>Of things, </b> (a) <b>to fail, be lacking</b>: Jhn.2:3; with accusative of person(s) (see Swete, in l; Mozley, Psa.42:1-11), Mrk.10:21; (b) <b>to be inferior</b>: mid, 1Co.12:24 (cf. ἀφ-υστερέω). G5337	φαῦλος	phaulos	evil	G:A	<b>φαῦλος</b>, -η, -ον [in LXX: Pro.22:8 (עֶוֶל) Pro.29:9 (אֱוִיל), etc;] <b>slight, worthless, of no account</b>, both of persons and things in various shades of meaning (see LS, see word), in NT, as freq. in cl, always with distinct moral reference (see Ellic, <i>Past. Epp</i>, 203; Hort, <i>Ja.</i>, 85; Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, LXXxiv), <b>worthless, bad</b>: Jhn.3:20, Tit.2:8, Jas.3:16; opp. to ἀγαθός (which see), Jhn.5:29, Rom.9:11, 2Co.5:10. (AS)
G5338	φέγγος	pheggos	brightness	G:N-N	<b>φέγγος</b>, -ους, τό [in LXX chiefly for נֹגַהּ;] light, brightness, usually with genitive of something that shines or reflects: of the moon, Mat.24:29, Mrk.13:24; of a lamp, Luk.11:33 (WH, RV, φῶς). (AS)
G5339	φείδομαι	pheidomai	to spare	G:V	<b>φείδομαι </b> [in LXX for חָמַל, חוּס, חָשַׂךְ, etc;] <b>to spare</b>: 2Co.13:2; with genitive of person(s), Act.20:29, Rom.8:32 11:21, 1Co.7:28, 2Co.1:23, 2Pe.2:4-5; with inf, to forbear, 2Co.12:6. (AS)
G5340	φειδομένως	pheidomenōs	sparingly	G:Adv	<b>φειδομένως </b> adv. from ptcp. (see 131, § 25, 1), <b>sparingly</b>: 2Co.9:6 (Plut.). (AS)
G5341	φελόνης, φαιλόνης	phelonēs, phailonēs	cloak	G:N-M	<b>φελόνης</b> (Rec. φαιλ-), -ου, ὁ by metath. for παινόλης (also φενόλης, φαινόλιον; Lat. pænula) <b>a cloak </b>(see <i>DCG</i>, i, 338; on the idea that the meaning here is book-cover, see CGT, in l; Milligan, <i>NTD</i>, 20; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 217 f, where the view that the φ. here is an eccl. vestment is discussed): 2Ti.4:13. (AS)
G5342	φέρω	pherō	to bear/lead	G:V	<b>φέρω </b> [in LXX chiefly for בּוֹא. hi, also for נָשָׂא, etc;] <b>to bear</b>; 1) <b>to bear, carry</b>: with accusative, Luk.23:26 24:1, Jhn.19:39, Heb.1:3 (see Westc, in l); pass, Act.2:2 27:15, 17 Heb.6:1, 2Pe.1:17-18; of the mind, 2Pe.1:21. 2) <b>to bear, endure</b>: with accusative of thing(s), Heb.12:20 13:13; with accusative of person(s), Rom.9:22. 3) <b>to bring, bring forward</b>: with accusative of person(s), Act.5:16; id. before πρός, Mrk.1:32 2:3 9:17, 19-20; ἐπί, Luk.5:18; with dative, Mrk.7:32 8:22; with accusative of thing(s), Mrk.6:27 11:2 12:15, Luk.15:23, Act.4:34, 37 5:2, 2Ti.4:13; id. before πρός, Mrk.11:7; εἰς, Rev.21:24, 26; ἐπί, Mat.14:11, Mrk.6:28; ἀπό, Jhn.21:10; with dative, Mrk.12:15, Jhn.2:8; id. before ὧδε, Mat.14:18 17:17; before φαγεῖν (sc. τι), Jhn.4:33; τ. δάκτυλον (χεῖρα), Jhn.20:27; pass, ἡ χάρις, 1Pe.1:13; διδαχήν, II Jn 10; θάνατον (cf. Field, <i>Notes</i>, 230), Heb.9:16; κρίσιν, 2Pe.2:11; κατηγορίαν, Jhn.18:29; αἰτίαν, Act.25:18; αἰτιώματα, Act.25:7, Rec. 4) <b>to bear, produce, bring forth</b>: καρπόν, Mat.7:18, Mrk.4:8, Jhn.12:24 15:2, 4-5 15:8, 16. 5) <b>to bring, lead</b>: Mrk.15:22, Jhn.21:18, Act.14:13; metaph, of a gate (ὁδός, cl.), Seq. εἰς, Act.12:10 (cf. ἀνα, ἀπο, δια, εἰσ, παρ-εισ, ἐκ, ἐπι, κατα, -παρα, περι, προ, προσ, συν, ὑπο-φέρω). <b>SYN</b>: φορέω, which expresses habitual and continuous bearing as distinct from (φέρω) that which is accidental and temporary (cf. Mat.11:8, al, see word φορέω, and see Tr, <i>Syn.</i>, § lviii) (AS)

G5440	φυλακτήριον	phulaktērion	phylactery	G:N-N	<b>φυλακτήριον</b>, -ου, τό 1) an outpost, fortification (Thuc, al.). 2) a safeguard (Plat.). 3) <b>an amulet </b>(Plut, al.); in NT for the Talmudic תְּפִלִּין, a prayer fillet, a phylactery, a small strip of parchment on which portions of the law were written and worn on the forehead and next the heart (cf. Exo.13:16): Mat.23:5. (AS)

G5481	χαρακτήρ	charaktēr	reproduction	G:N-M	<b>χαρακτήρ</b>, -ῆρος, ὁ (&lt; χαράσσω, to engrave), [in LXX: Lev.13:28 (צָרֶבֶת), 2Ma.4:10, 4Ma.15:4 א R *;] 1) a tool for graving. 2) <b>a stamp or impress</b>: as on a coin or seal; metaph, χ. τ. ὑποστάσεως, Heb.1:3. (AS)

G5483	χαρίζω	charizō	to give grace	G:V	<b>χαρίζομαι</b> (&lt; χάρις), [in LXX: Est.8:7 (נָתַן), Sng.1:4 א, Sir.12:3, 2 - 4Ma.9:1-32 *;] 1) <b>to show favour or kindness</b>: with dative of person(s), Gal.3:18. 2) <b>to give freely, bestow</b>: with accusative and dative, Luk.7:21, Act.3:14 25:11, 16 27:24, Rom.8:32, 1Co.2:12, Php.1:29 2:9, Phm 22. 3) In late Gk. (= Lat. condonare), <b>to grant forgiveness, forgive freely</b>: of debt, Luk.7:42-43 (EGT, in l); of sin, 2Co.2:7 2:10 12:13, Eph.4:32, Col.2:13 3:13 (cf. <i>DB</i>, ii, 57a). (AS)
G5484	χάριν	charin	because of	G:Prep	therefore, because of this, for this reason the acc. sg form of the noun χάριν which can be used as an <i>improper preposition</i>, <b>on account of, because of, for this reason</b> Lk. 7:47; Eph. 3:1, 14; 1Jn. 3:12; <b>for the sake of, in order to,</b> Gal. 3:19; Tit. 1:5, 11; Jude 16; <b>on the score of,</b> 1Tim. 5:14 * (MT)
G5485	χάρις	charis	grace	G:N-F	<b>χάρις, -ιτος, ἡ Abbott-Smith does not include the article here. </b>, accusative, χάριν (χάριτα in Act.24:27, Ju 4; see WH, <i>App.</i>, 157), [in LXX chiefly for חֵן;] 1) objectively, that which causes favourable regard, <b>gracefulness, grace, loveliness</b> of form, <b>graciousness</b> of speech (cl; Ecc.10:12, Sir.21:16, al.): Col.4:6; λόγοι τ. χάριτος (genitive qual.), Luk.4:22. 2) Subjectively, (a) on the part of the giver, <b>grace, graciousness, kindness, goodwill, favour</b>: Luk.2:52, Act.7:10, al; esp. in NT of the divine <b>favour, grace</b>, with emphasis on its freeness and universality: Luk.1:30, Act.14:26, Rom.1:7, 1Co.1:3, al; opp. to ὀφείλημα, Rom.4:4, 16; to ἔργα, Rom.11:6; (b) on the part of the receiver, a sense of favour received, <b>thanks, gratitude</b>: Rom.6:17 7:25, al; χ. ἔχειν, <b>to be thankful</b>, Luk.17:9, 1Ti.1:12, al. 3) Objectively, of the effect of grace, (a) a state of <b>grace</b>: Rom.5:2, 2Ti.2:1, 1Pe.5:12, 2Pe.3:18; (b) a proof or gift of <b>grace</b> (cl, <b>a favour</b>): Jhn.1:16, Act.6:8, Rom.1:5, 1Co.3:10, 2Co.9:8, Gal.2:9, Eph.3:2, 1Pe.5:5, 10 al. (For fuller treatment of the NT usage, see AR, <i>Eph.</i>, 221ff; <i>DB</i>, ii, 254ff; <i>DCG</i>, i, 686ff; Cremer, see word). (AS)
G5486	χάρισμα	charisma	gift	G:N-N	<b>χάρισμα</b>, -τος, τό (&lt; χαρίζομαι) [in LXX: Sir.7:33 א (AB, χάρις) Sir.38:30 Bl (א AB2R, χρῖσμα) *;] a gift of grace, a free gift, esp. of extra­ordinary operations of the Spirit in the Apostolic Church, but including all spiritual graces and endowments (Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 148 f.): Rom.1:11 5:15-16 6:23 11:29 12:6, 1Co.1:7 7:7 12:4 12:9 12:28 12:30-31, 2Co.1:11, 1Ti.4:14, 2Ti.1:6, 1Pe.4:10. (AS)
G5487	χαριτόω	charitoō	to favor	G:V	<b>χαριτόω</b>, -ῶ (&lt; χάρις), [in LXX: Sir.18:17 (ἀνδρί κεχαριτωμένῳ; Vg, justificato; Syr, saintly) *;] to endow with χάρις (which see), i.e. 1) (a) to make graceful; (b) to make gracious (Sir, l.with). 2) In Hellenistic writings (for exx, see AR, <i>Eph.</i>, 227; Lft, <i>Notes</i>, 315), (a) <b>to cause to find favour</b>; (b) <b>to endue with grace </b>(i.e. divine favour): Luk.1:28, Eph.1:6. G5504	χθές	chthes	yesterday	G:Adv	<b>ἐχθές</b> (Rec. χθές), adv, [in LXX for תְּמוֹל, etc;] <b>yesterday</b>: Jhn.4:52, Act.7:28, Heb.13:8 (on the form, see Rutherford, <i>NPhr.</i>, 370 f.). <b> ἐχθές</b>, <i>adverb</i> ={χθές}, <b>yesterday</b>, (5th-6th c.BC: Aristophanes Comicus “Nubes” 175, “Th.” 616, etc; ἀπ᾽ ἐ. “Anthologia Graeca” 11.35 (1st c.BC: Philodemus Gadarensis Epigrammaticus); μέσφα τό γ᾽ ἐ. 3rd c.BC: Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus 2.144); οὐ γάρ τι νῦν γε κἀ. today or <b>yesterday</b>, (5th c.BC: Sophocles Tragicus “Antigone” 456; οὐκ ἐ. οὐδὲ πρῴην 5th c.BC: Antipho Orator “fragment” 58); ἐ. καὶ τρίτης [ἡμέρας] (LXX.Ruth.2.11, compare 2nd c.AD: Marcus Antoninus Imperator 10.7. (ἐχθές is commoner than χθές) in Comedy texts and LXX, is the only form used in “NT”, and frequently in papyri of all periods, (“PSI” 4.442.21 (3rd c.BC), etc.)) (AS)

G5537	χρηματίζω	chrēmatizō	to announce	G:V	<b>χρηματίζω</b> (&lt; χρῆμα), [in LXX: Jer.26:2 29:23 30:2 36:2, 4 A (דָבַר pi.), Jer.25:30) (שָׁאַג), 3Ki.18:27, Job.40:8 *;] 1) <b>to transact business, hence, to consult, deliberate </b>(Thuc, Dem, al.); hence in later writers, 2) <b>to make answer </b>(esp. of offcial pronounce­ments by magistrates, etc; in π. of the royal reply to an ἔντευξις, which see; cf. G5574	ψεύδομαι	pseudomai	to lie	G:V	<b>ψεύδω </b> to deceive by lies; more freq. in the depon. mid, form ψεύδομαι (so always in NT), [in LXX chiefly for כָּחַשׁ pi;] 1) absol, <b>to lie</b>: Heb.6:18, 1Jn.1:6, Rev.3:9; οὐ ψεύδομαι, Rom.9:1, 2Co.11:31, Gal.1:20, 1Ti.2:7 with dative of person(s) (Psa.18:45, Jhn.5:12, al.), Act.5:4; before εἰς, Col.3:9; κατά, Jas.3:14 (Hort, in l). 2) Like act, with accusative, <b>to deceive by lies </b>(Æsch, al.): Act.5:3. G5590	ψυχή	psuchē	soul	G:N-F	<b>ψυχή</b>, -ῆς, ἡ, [in LXX very freq. for נֶפֶשׁ, sometimes for לֵבַב,לֵב, etc;] 1) <b>breath</b> (Lat. anima), <b>breath of life, life</b> (Hom, al; in Arist, of <b>the vital principle</b>): Mat.6:25, Mrk.3:4 10:45, Luk.12:22, Jhn.10:11, Act.20:10, 24 2Co.1:23, Php.2:30, 1Th.2:8, al. 2) <b>the soul</b>, (a) <b>as the seat of the will, desires and affections</b>: Mat.26:38, Mrk.12:30 " (LXX) 14:34, Luk.1:46, Jhn.10:24, Act.14:2, Php.1:27, al; ἐκ ψυχῆς, <b>from the heart</b>, <b>heartily</b>: Eph.6:6, Col.3:23; (b) <b>as a periphrasis for person or self </b>(freq. in translation from Semitic originals, see M, <i>Pr.</i>, 87; Robinson, <i>Gospels</i>, 113ff; but also freq. in cl, see LS, see word II, 2; Edwards, <i>Lex.</i>, App. A.): Mat.11:29, Mrk.8:36, Act.2:41, Rom.2:9, 1Pe.3:20, al; πᾶσα ψ, Act.2:43 3:23 " (LXX), Rom.13:1; ψ. ζῶσα (ζωῆς), 1Co.15:45, Rev.16:3; (with) <b>as the object of divine grace and eternal salvation</b>: Heb.13:17, Jas.1:21 5:20, 1Pe.1:9, 22 2:11 4:19, 3 Jo.2. G5598	Ὦ	Ō	Omega	G:N	<b>Ω, ω, ὦ μέγα</b> (cf. ὂ μικρόν), omega, ô, the twenty-fourth and last letter. As a numeral, ω᾽ = 800, ω, = 800,000. As a symbol of the last (= τὸ τέλος), τὸ Ὦ (Rec. Ω, L, ὦ, T, ω), <b>the Omega</b>: Rev.1:8 21:6 22:13 (cf. Ἄλφα). (AS)
G5599	ὦ	ō	oh!	G:Intj	<b>ὦ </b> interj, with vocat, <b>O</b>; (a) in simple address (less freq. than in cl; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71); Act.1:1 18:14 27:21, Rom.2:1, 3 9:20, 1Ti.6:20; expressing reproof, Jas.2:20; (b) in exclamations of surprise, etc: Mat.15:28, Luk.24:25, Act.13:10, Rom.11:33, Gal.3:1; with nom. (Bl, § 33, 4), Mat.17:17, Mrk.9:19, Luk.9:41. (AS)
G5600	ὦ	ō	may be	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G5601	Ὠβήδ	Ōbēd	Obed	N:N-M-P	<b>Ἰωβήδ</b> (WH, -βήλ, Lk, l.with; Rec, RV, Ὠβήδ), ὁ, indecl, <b>Jo bed </b>(Obed): Mat.1:5, Luk.3:32. (AS)
G5602	ὧδε	hōde	here	G:Adv	<b>ὧδε</b>, <i>adv.</i>, [in LXX for חֲלֹם,פֹּה,הִנֶּה, etc;] 1) prop, of manner, <b>so</b> (Hom, al.). 2) In poets (rarely) and late writers, of place, (a) <b>hither</b> (BL, §25, 2): Mat.8:29, Mrk.11:3, Luk.9:41, Jhn.6:25, al; ἕως ὧδε, Luk.23:5; (b) <b>here</b>: Mat.12:6, Mrk.9:1, Luk.9:33, Jhn.6:9, al; τὰ ὧδε, Col.4:9; opp. to ἐκεῖ, Heb.7:8; ὧδε. ἢ ὧδε (ἐκεῖ), Mat.24:23, Mrk.13:21; metaph, <b>here</b> (i.e. in this circumstance or connection), 1Co.4:2, Rev.13:10, 18 14:12 17:9. G5604	ὠδίν	ōdin	labor	G:N-F	<b>ὠδίν</b> (late form of ὠδίς), -ῖνος, ἡ [in LXX for חֵבֶל חֶבֶל (and wrongly for חֶבֶל חֶבֶל, cf. G5607	ὤν	ōn	being	G:V	<b>εἰμί</b>, with various uses and significations, like the English verb <b>to be</b>. I. As substantive verb. 1) Of persons and things, <b>to be, exist</b>: Act.17:28, Jhn.1:1, 8:58, 17:5, al; ὁ ὢν καὶ ὁ ἦν (for past ptcp.), Rev.1:4, 8, 4:8, 11:17, 16:5 (see Swete, <i>Ap.</i>, 5; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 228); τὰ (μὴ) ὄντα, Rom.4:17, 1Co.1:28. 2) Of times, events, etc, <b>to be, happen, take place</b>: Mat.24:3, Mrk.14:2, 15:42, Luk.21:23, Jhn.4:6, 23, 5:10, al. 3) <b>to be present, be</b> in a place, <b>have come</b>: Mat.2:13, 15, Mrk.1:45, 5:21, 15:40, Luk.1:80, 5:29, Jhn.7:30, al; before εἰς, Mrk.2:1; before ἐκ, (ἐξ), Mat.1:20, 21:25, Mrk.11:30, Jhn.3:31, al. 4) Impers, ἔστι, ἦν, etc; (a) <b>there is</b> (Fr. <i>il y a</i>), <b>was</b>, etc: Mat.16:28, Luk.16:19, Jhn.3:1, 5:2, Rom.3:10, al; with dative (of the possessor; Bl, §37, 3), Mat.16:22, Luk.1:7, Jhn.18.10, Rom.9:2, al; ἔστιν ὅς, ὅστις (chiefly in pl), Mat.16:28, 19:2, Mrk.9:1, al; (b) with inf, = ἔξεστιν (which see), <b>it is possible</b>: Heb.9:5, 1Co.11:20, RV (but see <i>ICC</i>, in l.). II. As copula uniting subject and predicate. 1) <b>Expressing simply identity or equivalence</b>: Mat.5:13, 14:15, Luk.1:18, 19, Jhn.1:1, 4:19, Rev.3:9, al. mult. 2) Explicative, as in parable, figure, type, etc: Mat.13:19, 1Co.9:2, 10:4, 11:25, Gal.4:24, Rev.17:15, al; ταῦτ᾽ ἔστιν, Mat.27:46, Mrk.7:2, Rom.7:18 al; ὅ ἐστιν, Mrk.3:17, Col.1:24, Heb.7:2, al; akin to this is the sacramental usage: Mat.26:26-28, Mrk.14:22, 24, Luk.22:19, 1Co.11:24 (see <i>ICC</i> on Mk, I Co, ll. with; <i>DB</i>, iii, 148 f.). 3) C. genitive: qual, etc, Mrk.5:42, Luk.3:23, 1Co.14:33, Heb.12:11, al; part, 1Ti.1:20, 2Ti.1:15; poss, Mat.5:3, 10, Mrk.12:7, Luk.4:7; of service or partisanship, Rom.8:9, 1Co.1:12, 2Co.10:7, 2Ti.2:19. 4) C. dative (BL, §37, 3): Act.1:8, 9:15, Rom.4:12, 1Co.1:18, 2:14, Rev.21:7, al. 5) C. ptcp, as a periphrasis for the simple verb (Bl, §62, 1, 2; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 225 ff.); (a) with ptcp. pf. (cl.): Mat.10:30, Luk.9:32, Jhn.3:24, Act.21:35, 1Co.15:19, al; (b) with ptcp. pr. (esp. in impf, as in Heb. and Aram; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 35 f.), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Luk.4:31, 14:1, Act.1:10, al. mult, id. for imper. (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 180f, 182f.), with ellipsis of εἰμί, Rom.12:9, 10, Heb.13:5, al; (with) with ptcp. aor. (cl), Luk.23:9. 6) Seq. εἰς (cf. Heb. הָיָה לְ), a vernac. usage (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71): Mat.19:5, Mrk.10:8, Heb.8:10, al. 7) C. adv: Mat.19:20, Mrk.4:26, Luk.18:11, al. 8) <b>Ellipses</b>; (a) <b>of the copula </b>(Bl, §30, 3): Mat.8:29, 24:32, Jhn.21:22, 23, Heb.6:4, al; (b) <b>of the predicate</b>: ἐγώ εἰμί, Mat.14:27, Mrk.6:50, al; absol. (cf. Deu.32:39; אֲנִי הוּא), Mrk.13:6, Jhn.4:26, al. (cf. ἄπ, ἔν, πάρ, συμ-πάρ, σύν-ειμι). (AS)
G5608	ὠνέομαι	ōneomai	to buy	G:V	<b>ὠνέομαι</b>, -οῦραι <b>to buy</b>: ὠνήσατο (= cl. ἐπρίατο; see Rutherford, <i>NPhr.</i>, 210 ff; Veitch, see word), with genitive pret, Act.7:16. (AS)
G5609	ᾠόν	ōon	an egg	G:N-N	<b>ᾠόν</b> (Rec. ὠόν), -οῦ, τό [in LXX for בֵּיצָה;] <b>an egg</b>: Luk.11:12. (AS)
G5610	ὥρα	hōra	hour	G:N-F	<b>ὥρα</b>, -ας, ἡ, [in LXX chiefly for עֵת and in Da for שָׁעָה;] 1) any <b>time</b> or <b>period</b> fixed by nature, esp. a <b>season</b> (Hom, Hdt, Plat, al.). 2) A part of the day, and esp. a twelfth part of day or night, <b>an hour</b>: Mat.24:36, Mrk.13:32, Act.10:3, al; accus. in ans. to "when"? (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 63, 215; Bl, §34, 8), Jhn.4:52, Act.10:3, 30 1Co.15:30, Rev.3:3; accusative of duration, Mat.20:12 26, Mrk.14:37; inexactly, πρὸς ὥραν, <b>for a season, for a time</b>, Jhn.5:35, 2Co.7:8, Gal.2:5; πρὸς καιρὸν ὥρας, <b>for a short season</b> (<b>ICC</b>, in l.), 1Th.2:17. 3) A definite point of time, <b>time, hour</b>: Mat.26:45; with genitive of thing(s), Luk.1:10 14:17, Rev.3:10, al; with genitive of person(s), Luk.22:53, Jhn.2:4 7:30, al; ἡ ἄρτι ὥρα, 1Co.4:11; ἐσχάτη ὥ, 1Jn.2:18; before ὅτε, Jhn.4:21, 23 5:25 16:25; ἵνα, Jhn.12:23, al; with accusative and inf, Rom.13:11 (cf. <i>DB</i>, ext, 475b 476b). (AS)
G5611	ὡραῖος	hōraios	beautiful/timely	G:A	<b>ὡραῖος</b>, -α, -ον (&lt; ὥρα), [in LXX for נָאָה, טוֹב, יָפָה, etc;] seasonable, timely, esp. of ripe fruits; hence, <b>blooming, beautiful </b>(both of things and persons): Mat.23:27, Act.3:2, 10, Rom.10:15 (LXX, ὥρα). (AS)
G5612	ὠρύομαι	ōruomai	to roar	G:V	<b>ὠρύομαι </b> depon, [in LXX for שָׁאַג;] of animals (also of men, Hdt, al.), <b>to roar, howl</b>: λέων, 1Pe.5:8. (AS)
G5613	ὡς	hōs	which/how	G:Conj	<b>ὡς</b>, adverbial form of the relative pron. ὅς, ἥ, ὅ. I. As <i>relat. adv.</i> of manner, <b>as, like as, just as, even as</b>; 1) <b>with a demonstrative, like οὕτως, expressed or understood</b>: οὕτως. ὡς, Mrk.4:26, 1Co.3:15, Eph.5:28, Jas.2:12, al; ὡς. οὕτως, Act.8:32, 1Co.7:17, al; elliptically (sc. οὕτως, οὕτω), with nom, Mat.6:29, al; with accusative, Mat.19:19, Mrk.12:31, al; with prep, Mat.26:55, Mrk.14:48, Luk.22:52, Jhn.7:10, al; with verb, Jhn.15:6, 2Co.3:1, Eph.2:3, 1Th.5:6, al; with ptcp. (the ptcp. however not having the special force wh. it has in cl; see Bl, §73, 5; 74, 6), Mat.7:29, Mrk.1:22, Heb.13:17, al; freq implying opinion or belief, Rom.9:32; so esp, with genitive absol, 1Co.4:18, 2Co.5:20, 1Pe.4:12, 2Pe.1:3. 2) Before numerals, <b>about, nearly</b>: Mrk.5:13, Jhn.1:40, Act.5:7, al. 3) Before adjectives and adverbs, <b>how</b>: Rom.10:15 11:33, 1Th.2:10; with superl, ὡς τάχιστα, <b>as quickly as possible</b>, Act.17:15. II. As conjunction; 1) temporal, (a) <b>as, when, since</b>: Mrk.9:21 14:72, Luk.1:23, Jhn.2:9, al; (b) <b>while, when, as long as</b>: Luk.12:58, Jhn.12:36, Gal.6:10 (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 191); ὡς ἄν (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 167, and see: ἄν), Rom.15:24, 1Co.11:34, Php.2:23. 2) Final, <b>in order that</b>; with inf, <b>in order to</b> (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 204n), Luk.9:52, Act.20:24, Heb.7:9. (AS)
G5614	ὡσαννά	hōsanna	Hosanna!	H:Intj	<b>ὡσαννά (T</b>, ὠσ-) (Heb נָא and הוֹשֵׁעַ; see Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 220 IL; <i>Gr.</i>, 249), <b>hosanna</b>: Mat.21:9, Mrk.11:9-10, Jhn.12:13; τ. υἱῷ Δανείδ, Mat.21:9, 15. (AS)

(AS)

G6033	ἔνθεν	enthen	hence	G:Adv	1. <i>adverb</i>: 2. Demonstr, 3. of Place, Lat. <i>inde</i>, thence, (Homer); ἔνθεν μὲν, ἑτέρωθι δέ, <b>on the one side </b> and the other, (Odyssey by Homer); ἔνθεν καὶ ἔνθεν <b>on this side </b> and <b>on that </b>, Lat. <i>hinc illinc</i>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; with <i>genitive</i>, ἔνθεν καὶ ἔνθεν τῶν τροχῶν <b>on both sides of </b> the wheels, (Xenophon Historicus) 4. of Time, <b>thereupon, thereafter </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 5. of occasion, <b>thence, from that point </b>, (Odyssey by Homer) 6. Relat, for ὅθεν, 7. of Place, Lat. <i>unde</i>, whence, from which, (Odyssey by Homer) 8. of occasion, <b>whence </b>, like Lat. <i>unde</i>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) Hence (ML)

G6063	οἶδα	oida	to know	G:V	1. <b>to know </b>, εὖ οἶδα <b>I know </b> well; εὖ ἴσθι <b>be assured </b>: often with <i>accusative</i> rei, νοήματα οἶδε, μήδεα οἶδε <b>he is versed in </b> counsels, (Homer); with neut. Adjs, πεπνυμένα, φίλα, ἀθεμίστια εἰδώς (Homer); also with <i>genitive</i>, τόξων εὖ εἰδώς <b>cunning in the use of </b> the bow; οἰωνῶν σάφα εἰδώς (Odyssey by Homer); χάριν εἰδέναι τινί <b>to acknowledge a debt to another, thank him </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc;the Imperat. in protestations, ἴστω Ζεὺς αὐτός <b>be </b> Zeus <b>my witness </b>, (Iliad by Homer); doric ἴττω Ζεύς, ἴττω (Aristophanes Comicus); εἰδώς <i>absolute</i> <b>one who knows </b>, εἰδυίηι πάντ᾽ ἀγορεύω (Iliad by Homer); ἰδυίηισι πραπίδεσσι with <b>knowing </b> mind, (Iliad by Homer) 2. with <i>infinitive</i> <b>to know how </b> to do, (Iliad by Homer), attic 3. with the <i>participle</i> <b>to know that </b> so and so is the case, ἴσθι μοι δώσων <b>know that </b> thou wilt give, (Aeschulus Tragicus); τὸν Μῆδον ἴσμεν ἐλθόντα (Thucydides) 4. οὐκ οἶδα εἰ, <b>I know </b> not whether, expresses disbelief, like Lat. <i>nescio an non</i>, οὐκ οἶδ᾽ ἂν εἰ πείσαιμι (Euripides) 5. οἶδα or ἴσθι are often parenthetic, οἶδ᾽ ἐγώ (Euripides); οἶδ᾽ ὅτι, οἶσθ᾽ ὅτι, ἴσθ᾽ ὅτι, πάρειμι (Sophocles Tragicus); so, εὖ οἶδ᾽ ὅτι (Demosthenes Orator);in [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota also, οἶσθ᾽ ὃ δρᾶσο; equivalent to δρᾶσον; οἶσθ᾽ ; <b>do </b>; know'st thou what? i. e. make haste and do; οἶσθ᾽ ὡς ποίησον, etc. (ML)

G6081	συμπίπτω	sumpiptō	be downcast	G:V	1. <b>to fall together, meet in battle, come to blows </b>, Lat. <i>concurrere</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: ς. ἐς νείκεα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <b>to encounter </b>, κλύδωνι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; G6111	ἄγαλμα	agalma	a statue		1. <b>a glory, delight, honour </b>, (Iliad by Homer), attic; ἀγάλματ᾽ ἀγορᾶς <b>mere ornaments </b> of the agora, (Euripides) 2. <b>a pleasing gift </b>, especially for the gods, (Odyssey by Homer) 3. <b>a statue in honour of a god </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), attic; <b>an image </b>, as an object of worship, etc, (Aeschulus Tragicus); then generally,= ἀνδριάς, <b>any statue </b>, (Plato Philosophus): also <b>a portrait, picture </b>, ἐξαλειφθεῖς᾽ ὡς ἄγαλμα (Euripides) (ML)

G6118	ἀγκών	agkōn	an angle		1. <b>the bend of the arm, the elbow </b>, (Homer) 2. generally <b>the arm </b>, like ἀγκάλη, (Pindar) 3. <b>any bend </b>, as the <b>jutting angle </b> of a wall, (Iliad by Homer): <b>the bend </b> or <b>reach </b> of a river, (Herdotus Historicus); ἕσπεροι ἄγκωνες, in (Sophocles Tragicus), seem to be the <b>angle </b> of the bay of Rhoeteium. (ML)

G6121	ἄγνος	agnos	a chaste tree		a chaste tree (MT)
G6122	ἄγονος	agonos	barren		1. <i>passive</i> <b>unborn </b>, (Iliad by Homer): <b>not yet born </b>, (Euripides) 2. <i>active</i> <b>not producing, unfruitful, barren </b>; τόκοισιν ἀγόνοις travail <b>without issue, bringing no children to the birth </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 3. with <i>genitive</i> <b>not productive of, barren in </b> a thing, (Plato Philosophus) 4. <b>childless </b>, (Euripides) (ML)

G6127	ἄγροικος	agroikos	rugged		1. <b>of </b> or <b>in the country </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus), etc. 2. of men, <b>dwelling in the country, a countryman, rustic </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus); then, opp. to ἀστεῖος, <b>clownish, boorish, rude </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus); the character of the ἄγροικος is described by (Theophrastus Philosophus) 3. <i>adverb</i> -κως, (Aristophanes Comicus); <i>comparative</i> -οτέρως, (Plato Philosophus); but -ότερον, (Plato Philosophus) 4. of land, <b>rough, uncultivated </b>, (Thucydides) (ML)

G6134	ἀδάμας	adamas	adamant		1. properly <b>the untamed, unconquerable </b>: 2. as <i>Substantive</i> <b>adamant </b>, i. e. the hardest metal, probably <b>steel </b>: <i>metaphorically</i> of any thing <b>unalterable </b>, ἔπος ἐρέω ἀδάμαντι πελάσσας having fixed it <b>firm as adamant </b>, (Oracle quoted in Herdotus Historicus) 3. <b>the diamond </b>, (Theophrastus Philosophus) 4. as <i>adjective</i>, <i>metaphorically</i>, <b>the inflexible </b>, of Hades, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus) (ML)

G6190	ἀκμή	akmē	at this moment		1. <b>a point, edge </b>: <i>proverbial</i>, ἐπὶ ξυροῦ ἀκμῆς on the rasor's <b>edge </b> (see. ξυρόν); ἀμφιδέξιοι ἀκμαί <b>the fingers </b> of both hands, (Sophocles Tragicus); ποδοῖν ἀκμαί the toes, (Sophocles Tragicus) 2. <b>the highest point </b> of anything, <b>the bloom, flower, prime </b>, of man's age, Lat. <i>flos aetatis</i>, ἀκμὴ ἥβης (Sophocles Tragicus); ἀκμὴ βίου (Xenophon Historicus); ἐν ἀκμῆι εἶναι = ἀκμάζειν, (Plato Philosophus); ἀκμὴν ἔχειν, of corn, to be ripe, (Thucydides); also of time, ἀ. ἦρος the spring- <b>prime </b>, (Pindar); ἀ. θέρους <b>mid </b>-summer, (Xenophon Historicus); ἀ. τῆς δόξης (Thucydides); <i>periphrastic</i> like βία, ἀκμὴ Θησειδᾶν (Sophocles Tragicus) 3. like καιρός, <b>the best, most fitting time </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; ἔργων, λόγων ἀκμή <b>the time </b> for doing, speaking, (Sophocles Tragicus); ἀκμή ἐστι, with <i>infinitive</i>, 'tis <b>high time </b> to do, (Aeschulus Tragicus); ἐπ᾽ ἀκμῆς εἶναι, with <i>infinitive</i>, to be on <b>the point </b> of doing, (Euripides); ἐπ᾽ αὐτὴν ἥκει τὴν ἀκμήν 'tis come to <b>the critical time </b>, (Demosthenes Orator) 4. ἀκμήν, <i>accusative</i> of ἀκμή, used as <i>adverb</i>, <b>just </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 5. <b>yet, still </b>, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus) (ML)
G6191	ἄκμων	akmōn	anvil		1. originally probably <b>a thunderbolt </b>, ἄκμων οὐρανόθεν κατιών (Hesiod) 2. <b>an anvil </b>, (Homer), etc: <i>metaphorically</i>, λόγχης ἄκμονες <b>very anvils </b> to bear blows, (Aeschulus Tragicus) (ML)
G6192	ἀκόλαστος	akolastos	unrestrained		1. Lat. <i>non castigatus</i>, unchastised, undisciplined, unbridled, (Herdotus Historicus), attic, etc. 2. <b>licentious, intemperate </b>, opp. to σώφρων, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc; so in <i>adverb</i>, ἀκολάστως ἔχειν (Plato Philosophus); <i>comparative</i>, ἀκολαστοτέρως ἔχειν πρός τι to be <b>too intemperate </b> in a thing, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
G6193	ἀκονάω	akonaō	to sharpen		<b>to sharpen, whet </b>, μαχαίρας (Aristophanes Comicus); λόγχην (Xenophon Historicus);Mid, ἀκονᾶσθαι μαχαίρας <b>to sharpen their </b> swords, (Aristophanes Comicus) (ML)
G6194	ἀκοντίζω	akontizō	to shoot		1. <b>to hurl a javelin </b>, τινός at one, (Iliad by Homer); ἐπί τινι (Iliad by Homer);the weapon is put in <i>dative</i>, ἀκόντισε δουρί <b>darted with </b> his spear, (Iliad by Homer); also in <i>accusative</i>, ἀκόντισαν ὀξέα δοῦρα <b>darted </b> their spears, (Odyssey by Homer) 2. with <i>accusative</i> pers. <b>to hit with a javelin </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; Pass. <b>to be so hit </b> or <b>wounded </b>, (Euripides) 3. <b>to shoot forth rays </b>, of the moon, (Euripides) 4. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to pierce </b>, εἴσω γῆς (Euripides) (ML)

G6200	ἀκουστός	akoustos	audible		1. <b>heard, audible </b>, (Homeric Hymns), etc. 2. <b>that should be heard </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) (ML)
G6201	ἀκουτίζω	akoutizō	to cause to hear		to cause to hear (MT)
G6202	ἄκρα	akra	Akra		1. <b>a headland, foreland, cape </b>, (Homer), etc. 2. <b>a mountain-top, summit </b>: used by (Homer) only in the phrase κατ᾽ ἄκρης <b>from top to bottom </b>, i. e. <b>utterly </b>, πόλιν αἱρέειν κατ᾽ ἄκρης (Herdotus Historicus); so in attic, κατ᾽ ἄκρας <b>utterly </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota, (Plato Philosophus) 3. <b>the citadel </b> of a city, Lat. <i>arx</i>, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
G6203	ἀκριβασμός	akribasmos	restriction		restriction (MT)
G6204	ἀκροάομαι	akroaomai	to hear		1. <b>to hearken to, listen to </b>, with <i>genitive</i> pers, <i>accusative</i> rei, (Thucydides), etc; with <i>genitive</i> rei, (Thucydides) 2. <i>absolute</i> <b>to listen </b>, ὁ ἀκροώμενος <b>a hearer, disciple </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 3. <b>to attend to, obey </b>, τινός (Thucydides), etc. (ML)
G6205	ἀκρόασις	akroasis	a hearing		1. <b>a hearing </b> or <b>listening </b>, (Thucydides), etc. 2. <b>obedience to </b> another, with <i>genitive</i>, (Thucydides) (ML)
G6206	ἀκρόβυστος	akrobustos	uncircumcised		uncircumcised (MT)
G6207	ἀκρόδρυα	akrodrua	a fruit tree		1. <b>fruit-trees </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. <b>fruits </b>, (Aristotle Philosopher) (ML)
G6208	ἄκρος	akros	a toe/thumb/tip		1. <b>at the furthest point </b>, and so either <b>topmost </b> = Lat. <i>summus</i>, or <b>outermost </b> = Lat. <i>extremus</i>: 2. <b>highest, topmost </b>, ἐν ἄκρηι πόλει = ἐν ἀκροπόλει, (Iliad by Homer); μέλαν ὕδωρ ἄκρον <b>at its surface </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc. 3. <b>outermost </b>, ἄκρη χείρ, ἄκροι πόδες, ἄκρος ὦμος <b>the end </b> of the hand, <b>ends </b> of the feet, <b>tip </b> of the shoulder, (Iliad by Homer); ἐπ᾽ ἄκρων [δακτύλων] <b>on tiptoe </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); ἄκροισι λαίφους κρασπέδοις <b>with the outermost </b> edges of the sail, i. e. under <b>close-reefed </b> sails, (Euripides) 4. of Time, it denotes <b>completeness </b>, ἄκραι σὺν ἑσπέραι when eve <b>was fully come </b>, (Pindar); ἄκρας νυκτός at <b>dead </b> of night, (Sophocles Tragicus) 5. of Degree, <b>the highest </b> in its kind, <b>exceeding good, consummate, excellent </b>: of persons, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; ἄκρος μάντις (Sophocles Tragicus);often with an <i>accusative</i> modi added, ψυχὴν οὐκ ἄκρος not <b>strong </b> in mind, (Herdotus Historicus); ἄκροι τὰ πολέμια, <b>skilful </b> in war, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; also with <i>genitive</i> modi, οἱ ἄκροι τῆς ποιήσεως (Plato Philosophus); also, ἄκρος εἰς or περί τι (Plato Philosophus) 6. as <i>Substantive</i>, see. ἄκρα, ἄκρον. 7. <i>neuter</i> as <i>adverb</i> <b>on the top </b> or <b>surface </b>, <b>just </b>, ἄκρον ἐπὶ ῥηγμῖνος <b>on the very </b> edge of the surf, il. 8. <b>exceedingly </b>, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus) 9. <b>utterly, completely </b>, (Plato Philosophus) (ML)
G6209	ἀκρότομος	akrotomos	chiseled		<b>cut off sharp, abrupt </b>, (Polybius Historicus) (ML)
G6210	ἀκρωτήριον	akrōtērion	an extremity		1. <b>any prominent part </b>, ἀκρ. τοῦ οὔρεος a mountain- <b>peak </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. <b>a cape, promontory </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. <b>the extremity </b> of anything, ἀκρ. νηός a ship's <b>beak </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 4. in <i>plural</i> <b>the extremities of the body, hands and feet, fingers and toes </b>, (Thucydides), etc; τὰ ἀκρ. τῆς Νίκης her <b>wings </b>, (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)
G6211	ἄκυρος	akuros	void		1. <b>without authority </b>: 2. of laws and contracts, <b>invalid </b>, ἄκυρον ποιεῖν, Lat. <i>irritum facere</i>, to set aside, and ἄκυρον γίγνεσθαι, to become <b>of no force </b>, to be set aside, (Plato Philosophus); νόμοις ἀκύροις χρωμένη, i. e. having laws, but not enforcing them, (Thucydides) 3. of persons, <b>having no right </b> or <b>power </b>, ἄκ. ποιεῖν τινά (Xenophon Historicus); with <i>genitive</i>, ἄκυροι πάντων γενήσεσθε (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)
G6212	ἀλαζονεύομαι	alazoneuomai	to act ostentatiously		<b>to make false pretensions </b>, of the Sophists, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
G6213	ἀλάλαγμα	alalagma	a price		1. = ἀλαλαγή, <b>a shouting </b>. 2. <b>a loud noise </b>, τυμπάνων, αὐλοῦ (Euripides) (ML)
G6214	ἀλαλαγμός	alalagmos	a shout		a shout (MT)
G6215	ἀλάομαι	alaomai	be a runaway		1. <b>to wander, stray </b> or <b>roam about </b>, (Homer), etc: <b>to wander from home, be banished </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); with <i>accusative</i> loci, ἀλ. γῆν <b>to wander over </b> the land, (Sophocles Tragicus) 2. with <i>genitive</i> <b>to wander away from, cease to enjoy </b>, εὐφροσύνας (Pindar); τῆς πάροιθ᾽ εὐπραξίας (Euripides) 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to wander in mind, be distraught </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) (ML)
G6216	ἀλγέω	algeō	to ache		1. <b>to feel bodily pain, suffer </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc; the suffering part in <i>accusative</i>, ἀλγ. ἧπαρ (Aeschulus Tragicus); τὸν δάκτυλον, τὰ ὄμματα (Plato Philosophus) 2. <b>to suffer hardship </b>, (Odyssey by Homer) 3. <b>to feel pain of mind, to grieve, be troubled </b> or <b>distressed </b>, ἀλγεῖν ψυχήν, φρένα (Herdotus Historicus), etc; ἀλγ. τινί <b>to be pained at </b> a thing, (Herdotus Historicus); ἐπί τινι (Sophocles Tragicus); διά τι (Herdotus Historicus); περί τι or τινος (Thucydides); with <i>genitive</i>, (Aeschulus Tragicus); with <i>accusative</i>, ἀλγῶ μὲν ἔργα (Aeschulus Tragicus); with <i>participle</i>, ἤλγης᾽ ἀκούσας (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G6226	ἁλίσκομαι	haliskomai	to capture		1. <b>to be taken, conquered </b>, of persons and places, (Homer), etc; ἁλίσκεσθαι εἰς πολεμίους <b>to fall into the hands of </b> the enemy, (Plato Philosophus) 2. <b>to be caught, seized </b>, θανάτῳ ἁλῶναι or without θανάτῳ, <b>to die </b>, (Homer); ἑάλωσαν εἰς Ἀθήνας γράμματα letters <b>were seized and taken </b> to Athens, (Xenophon Historicus) 3. in good sense, <b>to be won, achieved, attained </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 4. with <i>participle</i> <b>to be caught </b> or <b>detected </b> doing a thing, (Herdotus Historicus); ἐὰν ἁλῷς τοῦτο πράττων (Plato Philosophus); also with a <i>Substantive</i> or <i>adjective</i>, the <i>participle</i> ὤν being omitted, οὐ γὰρ δὴ φονεὺς ἁλώσομαι (Sophocles Tragicus) 5. as attic law-term, <b>to be convicted and condemned </b>, (Plato Philosophus);with <i>genitive</i> criminis, <b>to be convicted of </b>, ἁλῶναι ψευδομαρτυριῶν, etc. (ML)

G6285	ἀνακαλέω	anakaleō	to call by name		1. <b>to call up the dead </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus); so in Mid, (Euripides) 2. <b>to call again and again </b>: 3. <b>to invoke, appeal to </b>, θεούς (Herdotus Historicus), etc;so in Mid, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. <b>to summon, cite </b>, (Herdotus Historicus);Mid. <b>to call to oneself, send for, summon </b>, (Euripides) 5. <b>to call </b> by a name, ἀν. κακούς (Euripides); Δαναούς (Thucydides);Pass, Ἀργεῖος ἀνακαλούμενος (Sophocles Tragicus) 6. <b>to call on </b>, so as to encourage, (Thucydides); Mid, ἀνακαλεῖσθαι τὰς κύνας <b>to cheer on </b> the hounds, (Xenophon Historicus) 7. <b>to call back, recall </b>, mostly in Mid, (Aeschulus Tragicus); especially <b>from </b> exile, (Plato Philosophus); ἀνακαλεῖσθαι τῆι σάλπιγγι to sound a retreat, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)

G6288	ἀνακρούω	anakrouō	to play music		1. <b>to push back, stop short, check </b>, ἵππον χαλινῶι (Xenophon Historicus) 2. Mid, ἀνακρούεσθαι πρύμνην <b>to put one's </b> ship astern, by backing water, (Aristophanes Comicus); so ἀνακρούεσθαι alone, (Thucydides); also, ἐπὶ πρύμνην ἀν, (Herdotus Historicus);<i>metaphorically</i> <b>to put back </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 3. in Music, <b>to strike up </b>, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus) (ML)
G6289	ἀναλάμπω	analampō	to blaze up		1. <b>to flame up, take fire </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to break out anew </b>, as war, (Plutarch) 3. <b>to come to oneself again, revive </b>, (Plutarch) (ML)
G6290	ἀνάλγητος	analgētos	unfeeling		1. <b>without pain </b>, and so: 2. of persons, <b>insensible to pain </b>, (Aristotle Philosopher) 3. <b>unfeeling, hard-hearted, ruthless </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); ἀναλγητότερος εἶναι <b>to feel less grieved </b>, (Thucydides): with <i>genitive</i>, ἀν. εἶναί τινος to be <b>insensible to </b>, (Plutarch);<i>adverb</i> -τως, <b>unfeelingly </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. of things, <b>not painful </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 5. <b>cruel </b>, πάθος (Euripides) (ML)

G6500	ἀποτέμνω	apotemnō	to shred		1. <b>to cut off, sever </b>, (Iliad by Homer), attic;Pass, τὴν γλῶτταν ἀποτμηθείς <b>having </b> his tongue <b>cut out </b>, (Aeschines Orator) 2. <b>to sever, divide </b>, in a geographical sense, (Herdotus Historicus);Pass, of troops, <b>to be cut off from </b> the main body, (Xenophon Historicus) 3. Mid. <b>to cut off for oneself </b>, (Iliad by Homer); with <i>genitive</i> <b>to cut off a bit </b> of a thing, (Herdotus Historicus) 4. <b>to cut off </b>, so as <b>to appropriate </b>, βοῦς (Homeric Hymns); Φοινίκης ἀπ. <b>to have a slice </b> or <b>portion of </b> Phoenicia, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus); ἀπ. τῶν Ἀθηναίων <b>to cut off </b> power from the Athenians, (Thucydides) (ML)

G6508	ἀποφαίνω	apophainō	to sentence		1. <b>to shew fort, display, produce </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. <b>to make known, declare </b>, (Herdotus Historicus): <b>to give evidence of </b> a thing, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. <b>to shew by reasoning, shew, represent as </b> doing or being, with <i>participle</i>, (Herdotus Historicus); and with <i>participle</i> omitted, ἀπ. ἑωϋτὸν αἴτιον (i.e. ὄντα) (Herdotus Historicus); so, ἀπ. τινα ἐχθρόν (Demosthenes Orator) 4. with <i>accusative</i> et <i>infinitive</i> <b>to represent that </b>, (Plato Philosophus); so, ἀπ. ὡς, ὅτι, (Herdotus Historicus) 5. <b>to give an account of </b>, τὴν οὐσίαν (Demosthenes Orator): <b>to pay in money </b> to the treasury, (Demosthenes Orator) 6. <b>to render </b> or <b>make </b> so and so, (Aristophanes Comicus) 7. <b>to appoint </b> to an office, (Plato Philosophus) 8. Mid. <b>to display something of one's own </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) (Plato Philosophus): <i>absolute</i> <b>to make a display of oneself, shew off </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 9. <b>to produce </b> evidence, (Herdotus Historicus) 10. ἀποφαίνεσθαι γνώμην <b>to declare one's </b> opinion, (Herdotus Historicus), attic; <i>absolute</i> <b>to give an opinion </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), attic. Hence 11. used like Act, (Plato Philosophus) (ML)

G6575	ἀστράγαλος	astragalos	a vertebrae		1. <b>one of the neck-vertebrae </b>, (Homer) 2. <b>the ball of the ankle joint </b>, Lat. <i>talus</i>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. <i>plural</i> ἀστράγαλοι, <b>dice </b> or <b>agame played with dice </b>, (Iliad by Homer);they were at first made of knuckle-bones, and never had more than four flat sides, whereas the κύβοι had six. They played with four: the best <b>throw </b> (βόλος), when each die came differently, was called Ἀφροδίτη, Lat. jactus Veneris; the worst, when all came alike, κύων, Lat. <i>canis</i>. (ML)

G6585	ἄσωτος	asōtos	carnal		1. <b>having no hope of safety, abandoned, profligate </b>, Lat. <i>perditus</i>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 2. <i>active</i>, ἄσωτος γένει <b>bringing ruin on </b> the race, <b>fatal </b> to it, (Aeschulus Tragicus) (ML)
G6586	ἀτάρ	atar	nevertheless		1. <b>but, yet </b>, Lat. <i>at</i>, to introduce an objection or correction, (Iliad by Homer), attic; it always begins a sentence or clause, but is placed after the <i>vocative</i>, Ἕκτορ, ἀτάρ που ἔφης <b>still </b> thou didst say, (Iliad by Homer); ἀτάρ sometimes answers to μέν, more emphatic than δέ, (Homer), attic 2. in attic to mark a rapid transition to another thought, (Aeschulus Tragicus), etc; so ἀτὰρ δή (Euripides) (ML)
G6587	ἀτείχιστος	ateichistos	unwalled		1. <b>unwalled, unfortified </b>, (Thucydides) 2. <b>not walled in, not blockaded </b>, (Thucydides) (ML)

G6590	ἀτιμώρητος	atimōrētos	unpunished		1. <b>unavenged </b>, i. e, 2. <b>unpunished </b>, ἀτ. γίγνεσθαι to escape punishment, (Herdotus Historicus); <i>adverb</i> -τως, <b>with impunity </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 3. <b>for which no revenge has been taken </b>, ἀτιμώρητον ἐᾶν θάνατον (Aeschines Orator) 4. <b>undefended, unprotected </b>, (Thucydides) (ML)
G6591	ἄτρακτος	atraktos	a spindle		1. <b>a spindle </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 2. <b>an arrow </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); compare ἠλακάτη. (ML)
G6592	ἀτραπός	atrapos	a short cut		properly <b>a path with no turnings </b>, generally <b>a path-way, road </b>, (Homer), etc. (ML)

G6603	αὖλαξ	aulax	a furrow		1. <b>a furrow </b> made in ploughing, Lat. <i>sulcus</i>, (Homer), etc; αὔλακ᾽ ἐλαύνειν to draw <b>a furrow </b>, (Hesiod) 2. <i>metaphorically</i> of <b>a wife </b> as <b>the bearer of children </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 3. <i>metaphorically</i> also, <b>a furrow in the skin, a gash, wound </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 4. = ὄγμος, <b>a swathe </b>, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus) (Prob. from same Root as ὁλκός, Lat. <i>sulcus</i>, from ἕλκω.) G6647	βαίνω	bainō	to go		1. in most forms, 2. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to walk, step </b>, properly of motion <b>on foot </b>, ποσσὶ or ποσὶ βαίνειν (Homer), etc; with <i>infinitive</i> in (Homer), βῆ ἰέναι, βῆ ἰέμεν <b>set out </b> to go, <b>went </b> his way, (Iliad by Homer); βῆ θέειν <b>started </b> to run, (Iliad by Homer); βῆ δ᾽ ἐλάαν, (Iliad by Homer), etc;with <i>accusative</i> loci, (Sophocles Tragicus); and with all Preps. implying motion, as, ἐπὶ νηὸς ἔβαινεν <b>was going on </b> board ship, (Odyssey by Homer); ἐφ᾽ ἵππων βάντες <b>having mounted </b> the chariot, (Odyssey by Homer); βαίνειν δι᾽ αἵματος <b>to wade </b> through blood, (Euripides), etc. 3. in <i>perfect</i> <b>to stand </b> or <b>be </b> in a place, χῶρος ἐν ὧι βεβήκαμεν (Sophocles Tragicus); often almost= εἰμί <b>(sum) </b>, εὖ βεβηκώς <b>on a </b> good <b>footing </b>, well <b>established, prosperous </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; so, οἱ ἐν τέλει βεβῶτες they who <b>are </b> in office, (Herdotus Historicus); compare ξυρόν. 4. <b>to go, go away, depart </b>, (Iliad by Homer); βέβηκα euphamistic for τέθνηκα, (Aeschulus Tragicus);of things, ἐννέα ἐνιαυτοὶ βεβάασι nine years <b>have come and gone </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 5. <b>to come </b>, τίπτε βέβηκα; (Iliad by Homer): <b>to arrive </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 6. <b>to go on, advance </b>, ἐς τόδε τόλμης, ἐς τοσοῦτον ἐλπίδων (Sophocles Tragicus) 7. with <i>accusative</i> <b>to mount </b>, (Homer) only in aor1 <i>middle</i>, βήσασθαι δίφρον; Pass, ἵπποι βαινόμεναι <b>brood </b> mares, (Herdotus Historicus) 8. χρέος ἔβα με debts <b>came on </b> me, (Aristophanes Comicus) 9. in Poets, with <i>accusative</i> of the instrument of motion, which is simply pleonastic, βαίνειν πόδα <b>to advance </b> the foot, <b>step on </b>, (Euripides), etc. 10. Causal, in <i>future</i> βήσω, aor1 ἔβησα; <b>to make to go </b>, βῆσεν ἀφ᾽ ἵππον, ἐξ ἵππων βῆσε <b>brought </b> them <b>down </b> from the chariot, (Iliad by Homer) The <i>present</i> in this sense is βιβάζω. (ML)

G6704	βύω	buō	to plug		1. <b>to stuff </b>, 2. with <i>genitive</i> rei, <b>to stuff full of </b>, only in Pass, νήματος βεβυσμένος <b>stuffed full of </b> spun-work or yarn, (Odyssey by Homer); τὸ στόμα ἐβέβυστο [i.e. χρυσοῦ] (Herdotus Historicus) 3. with <i>dative</i> rei, <b>to stop </b> or <b>bung up with, plug </b>: Pass, σπογγίωι βεβυσμένος (Aristophanes Comicus) 4. <i>absolute</i>, βεβ. τὰ ὦτα <b>deaf </b>, (Lucian) (ML)

G6736	γίγας	gigas	a giant		1. mostly in <i>plural</i> Γίγαντες, <b>the Giants </b>, a savage race destroyed by the gods, (Odyssey by Homer); <b>the sons of Gaia </b>, (Hesiod) 2. as <i>adjective</i> <b>mighty </b>, Ζέφυρος γίγας (Aeschulus Tragicus) (ML)

G6772	γυμνόω	gumnoō	be naked	G:V	<b>to strip naked </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); τὰ ὀστέα τῶν κρεῶν γ. <b>to strip </b> the bones of their flesh, (Herdotus Historicus);in Pass, of warriors, <b>to be left naked </b> or <b>exposed </b>, (Homer); so, τεῖχος ἐγυμνώθη the wall <b>was left bare </b>, i. e. <b>defenceless </b>, (Iliad by Homer): but also <b>to strip oneself naked </b> or <b>to be stript naked </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); with <i>genitive</i>, ἐγυμνώθη ῥακέων <b>he stript himself </b> of his rags, (Odyssey by Homer); so later, γυμνωθὲν ξίφος (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G6784	δασύς	dasus	bushy		1. opp. to ψιλός in all senses: 2. <b>thick with hair, hairy, shaggy, rough </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); of young hares, <b>downy </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. <b>thick with leaves </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); θρίδαξ δασέα a lettuce <b>with all the leaves </b> on, (Herdotus Historicus);of places, <b>thick with bushes </b> or <b>wood </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); διὰ τῶν δασέων through <b>the copses </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus); δ. ὕληι <b>thick </b> with copse-wood, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; rarely with <i>genitive</i>, δασὺς δένδρων (Xenophon Historicus); τὸ δασύ <b>bushy country </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)

G6786	δείδω	deidō	be in awe	G:V	1. <b>to fear </b>, <i>absolute</i>, (Homer), etc; followed by a <i>preposition</i>, δ. περί τινι <b>to be alarmed, anxious </b> about, (Iliad by Homer), attic; ἀμφί τινι, περί τινος, ὑπέρ τινος (Iliad by Homer);followed by a <i>relative</i> clause with μή, Lat. <i>vereor ne </i>, I fear it is, followed by <i>subjunctive</i>; rarely by <i>indicative</i>, δείδω μὴ νημερτέα εἶπεν (Odyssey by Homer); δ. μὴ οὐ, Lat. <i>vereor ut </i>, I fear it is not, followed by <i>subjunctive</i>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 2. with <i>infinitive</i> <b>to fear to do </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 3. with <i>accusative</i> <b>to fear, dread </b>, (Homer), etc. 4. τὸ δεδιός, <b>one's fearing </b>, = δέος, (Thucydides) (ML)
G6787	δείλαιος	deilaios	wretched		<i>lengthened</i> form of δειλός, <b>wretched, sorry, paltry </b>, mostly of persons, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; also, δ. χάρις a <b>sorry </b> kindness, (Aeschulus Tragicus); δ. σποδός <b>paltry </b> dust, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. [Penult. is often made short in attic Poets.] (ML)
G6788	δείλη	deilē	afternoon		1. <b>afternoon </b>, ἔσσεται ἢ ἠὼς ἢ δείλη ἢ μέσον ἦμαρ (Iliad by Homer); divided into <b>early </b> and <b>late </b> (πρωί̈α and ὀψία), περὶ δείλην πρωί̈ην, or δείλης ὀψίης (Herdotus Historicus); τῆς δείλης <b>in the course of the afternoon </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. <b>the late afternoon, evening </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
