G6790	δειλινός	deilinos	dusk		dusk
G6791	δεινός	deinos	awful		1. <b>fearful, terrible, dread, dire </b>, (Homer), etc; δεινὸν ἀϋτεῖν, βροντᾶν to shout, thunder <b>terribly </b>, (Iliad by Homer); δεινὸν δέρκεσθαι, παπταίνειν, ἰδεῖν to look <b>terrible </b>, (Homer); but, δεινὸς ἰδέσθαι <b>fearful </b> to behold, (Odyssey by Homer); δεινὸς μὲν ὁρᾶν, δεινὸς δὲ κλύειν (Sophocles Tragicus); τὸ δεινόν <b>danger, suffering, awe, terror </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; so, τὰ δεινά (Sophocles Tragicus), etc; οὐδὲν δεινοί, μὴ ἀποστέωσιν no <b>fear </b> of their revolting, (Herdotus Historicus); δεινὸν ποιεῖσθαι <b>to take ill, complain of, be indignant at </b> a thing, Lat. <i>aegre ferre</i>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; δεινὰ παθεῖν to suffer <b>dreadful, illegal, arbitrary </b> treatment, attic; so in <i>adverb</i>, δεινῶς φέρειν (Herdotus Historicus); δ. ἔχειν to be <b>in straits </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. with a notion of Force or Power, <b>mighty, powerful </b>, δεινὸν σάκος <b>the mighty </b> shield, (Iliad by Homer) 3. simply, <b>wondrous, marvellous, strange </b>, τὸ συγγενές τοι δεινόν kin has a <b>strange power </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus); δ. ἵμερος, ἔρως, δέος (Herdotus Historicus); δεινὸν ἂν εἴη, εἰ, it were <b>strange </b> that, (Euripides);<i>adverb</i> -νῶς, <b>marvellously, exceedingly </b>, δ. μέλας, ἄνυδρος (Herdotus Historicus) 4. the sense of <b>powerful, wondrous </b> passed into that of <b>able, clever, skilful </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), attic; especially of <b>practical ability </b>, opp. to σοφός, (Plato Philosophus): with <i>infinitive</i>, δεινὸς εὑρεῖν <b>clever </b> at inventing, (Aeschulus Tragicus); δεινὸς λέγειν (Sophocles Tragicus); δεινὸς πράγμασι χρῆσθαι (Demosthenes Orator): also with <i>accusative</i>, δεινὸς τὴν τέχνην (Plato Philosophus); δ. περί τι or τινος (Plato Philosophus) (ML)

G6927	δικάζω	dikazō	to act as judge		1. <b>to judge, to give judgment on </b> a thing, <b>decide </b> or <b>determine </b> a point, (Iliad by Homer), etc. 2. with <i>accusative</i> <i>cognate</i>, δίκας δ, <b>to adjudge </b> a penalty, (Herdotus Historicus); δ. φυγήν τινι <b>to decree </b> it <b>as </b> his punishment, (Aeschulus Tragicus); δ. φόνον ματρός <b>to ordain </b> her slaughter, (Euripides); δ. τοῦ ἐγκλήματος [i.e. δίκην] (Xenophon Historicus);Pass. <b>to be decided </b>, (Thucydides) 3. <b>to pass judgment on, condemn </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. φόνον δ. <b>to plead in </b> a case of murder, (Euripides) 5. with <i>dative</i> pers. <b>to decide between </b> persons, <b>judge </b> their <b>cause </b>, Τρωσί τε καὶ Δαναοῖσι δικαζέτω (Iliad by Homer); ἐς μέσον ἀμφοτέροισι δικάσσατε (Iliad by Homer);Pass. <b>to be judged </b> or <b>accused </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 6. <i>absolute</i> <b>to be judge, give judgment </b>, (Iliad by Homer); <b>to sit as judges </b> or <b>jurymen </b>, (Demosthenes Orator) 7. Mid. of the culprit, <b>to plead one's own case, defend one's right, have one's case tried, go to law </b>, (Odyssey by Homer), etc; δίκην δικάζεσθαί τινι <b>to go to law </b> with one, (Plato Philosophus); πρός τινα (Thucydides); τινος or περί τινος <b>for </b> a thing, (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)

G6972	δρῦς	drus	an oak		1. originally <b>a tree </b> (which indeed comes from the same Root), commonly <b>the oak </b>, Lat. <i>quercus</i>, (Homer), etc; sacred to Zeus, who gave his oracles from the oaks of Dodona, (Odyssey by Homer);hence, αἱ προσήγοροι δρύες (Aeschulus Tragicus);<i>proverbial</i>, οὐ γὰρ ἀπὸ δρυός ἐσσι οὐδ᾽ ἀπὸ πέτρης thou art no foundling from <b>tree </b> or rock, i. e. thou hast parents and a country, (Odyssey by Homer); οὐ νῦν ἐστιν ἀπὸ δρυὸς οὐδ᾽ ἀπὸ πέτρης ὀαρίζειν 'tis no time now to talk at ease from <b>tree </b> or rock, (Iliad by Homer) 2. of other trees, πίειρα δρῦς the resinous <b>wood </b> (of the pine), (Sophocles Tragicus); of the olive, (Euripides) 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>a wornout old man </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina (ML)

G7263	ἐνταῦθα	entautha	here		1. of Place, <b>here, there </b>, Lat. <i>hic</i>, illic, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; ἐνταῦθά που <b>here- </b>abouts, (Aristophanes Comicus) 2. like ἐνταυθοῖ, with sense of motion towards, <b>hither, thither </b>, Lat. <i>huc</i>, illuc, (Iliad by Homer), attic 3. with <i>genitive</i>, ἐντ. τῆς ἠπείρου (Thucydides); ἔντ. τῆς πολιτείας <b>in that department of </b> government, (Demosthenes Orator) 4. of Time, <b>at the very time, then </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus), etc. 5. with <i>genitive</i>, ἐντ. ἡλικίας, Lat. <i>ad hoc aetatis</i>, (Plato Philosophus) 6. of Sequence, = Lat. <i>deinde</i>, thereupon, then, (Herdotus Historicus) 7. generally, <b>herein </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc: <b>in this state of things, in this position </b>, (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)

G7265	ἐντείνω	enteinō	to stretch tight		1. <b>to stretch </b> or <b>strain tight </b>Pass, δίφρος ἱμᾶσιν ἐντέταται <b>is hung on tight-stretched straps </b>, (Iliad by Homer); γέφυραι ἐντεταμέναι <b>a </b> bridge <b>with the mooring-cables made taught </b>, (Herdotus Historicus); ἐντεταμένου τοῦ σώματος <b>being braced up </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 2. <b>to stretch </b> a bow <b>tight </b>, i. e. <b>string </b> it for shooting (compare ἐντανύω); (Euripides); so in Mid. <b>to string one's </b> bow, (Euripides);Pass, τόξα ἐντεταμένα bows <b>ready strung </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. ἐντείνειν ναῦν ποδί <b>to keep </b> a ship's sail <b>taught </b> by the sheet, (Euripides) 4. <b>to tie tight </b>, (Euripides) 5. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to strain, exert </b>;so in Mid, φωνὴν ἐντεινάμενος (Aeschines Orator); ἐντεινάμενοι τὴν ἁρμονίαν <b>pitching </b> the tune <b>high </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus);and in Pass, ἐντεινόμενος, <b>on the stretch, eager </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 6. <b>to carry on vigorously </b>, (Plutarch) 7. so <i>intransitive</i> in Act. <b>to exert oneself, be vehement </b>, (Euripides) 8. <b>to stretch out at </b> or <b>against </b>, πληγὴν ἐντείνειν τινί, Lat. <i>plagam intendere</i>, to lay a blow <b>on </b> him, (Xenophon Historicus) 9. <b>to put into verse </b>, (Plato Philosophus) (ML)

G7336	ἐξισόω	exisoō	to make equal		1. <b>to make equal </b> or <b>even bring to a level with </b>, Lat. <i>exaequare</i>, τινά or τί τινι (Sophocles Tragicus); Mid. <b>to make oneself equal </b>, (Babrius Fabularum Scriptor);Pass. <b>to be </b> or <b>become equal </b>, τινι (Plato Philosophus), etc; <b>to be a match for, to rival </b>, τινι (Thucydides) 2. <b>to put on a level </b>, τοὺς πολίτας (Aristophanes Comicus) 3. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to be equal </b> or <b>like </b>, μητρὶ δ᾽ οὐδὲν ἐξισοῖ <b>acts </b> in no way <b>like </b> a mother, (Sophocles Tragicus); ἐξ. τοῖς ἄλλοις (Thucydides): so in Pass, (Sophocles Tragicus) (ML)

G7350	ἐξορμάω	exormaō	to sally out		1. <b>to send forth, send to war </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus); ἐξ. τὴν ναῦν <b>to start </b> the ship, <b>set </b> it <b>agoing </b>, (Thucydides);Pass. <b>to set out, start </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; of arrows, <b>to spring from </b> the bow, (Euripides) 2. <b>to excite to action, urge on </b>, (Euripides) 3. <i>intransitive</i>, like Pass, <b>to set out, start </b>, of a ship, (Odyssey by Homer): with <i>genitive</i> <b>to set out from </b>, (Euripides);<i>metaphorically</i> <b>to break out </b>, of a disease, (Sophocles Tragicus); σφοδρὸς ἐφ᾽ ὅ τι ἐφορμήσειε eager in all that <b>he attempted </b>, (Plato Philosophus) (ML)

G7421	ἐπικρατέω	epikrateō	to prevail		1. <b>to rule over </b>, with <i>dative</i>, (Homer): <i>absolute</i> <b>to have </b> or <b>hold power </b>, (Odyssey by Homer) 2. <b>to prevail in battle, be victorious, conquer </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 3. with <i>genitive</i> <b>to prevail over, get the mastery of </b> an enemy, (Herdotus Historicus), attic;also <b>to become master of </b>, Lat. <i>potiri</i>, τῆς θαλάσσης, τῶν Ἑλλήνων (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 4. generally, <b>to be superior </b>, τῷ ναυτικῷ (Thucydides); κατὰ θάλασσαν (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)

G7425	ἐπικυλίω	epikuliō	to roll upon		to roll upon (MT)

G7427	ἐπίλεκτος	epilektos	chosen		<b>chosen, picked </b>, of soldiers, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
G7428	ἐπιληπτεύομαι	epilēpteuomai	be possessed		be possessed, convulse (MT)
G7429	ἐπίληπτος	epilēptos	convulsed		1. <b>caught </b> or <b>detected in </b> anything, (Sophocles Tragicus); with <i>participle</i>, ἐπίλαμπτος ἀφάσσουσα <b>caught </b> in the act of feeling, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. <b>suffering </b>, (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)
G7430	ἐπιμίγνυμι	epimignumi	to intermix		1. <b>to add to by mixing, mix with </b>, τί τινι (Plato Philosophus) 2. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to mingle with </b> others, <b>to have intercourse </b> or <b>dealings </b> with them, τισί (Thucydides); πρός τινας (Xenophon Historicus);so also in Pass, ἐπιμίγνυσθαι ἀλλήλοις (Xenophon Historicus); παρ᾽ ἀλλήλους (Thucydides) 3. ἐπιμίσγω,older form of ἐπιμίγνυμι 4. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to have intercourse </b>, παρ᾽ ἀλλήλους (Thucydides);so Pass. in same sense, with <i>dative</i> pers, (Odyssey by Homer), etc; αἰεὶ Τρώεσσs ἐπιμίσγομαι I have always <b>to be dealing with </b> the Trojans, am always <b>clashing with </b> them, (Iliad by Homer): <i>absolute</i> <b>to associate together </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)
G7431	ἐπίμικτος	epimiktos	intermixed		intermixed (MT)
G7432	ἐπιμύλιος	epimulios	an upper millstone		an upper millstone (MT)
G7433	ἐπινοέω	epinoeō	to think about		1. <b>to think on </b> or <b>of, contrive </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), attic;with <i>infinitive</i>, (Aristophanes Comicus);<i>absolute</i> <b>to form plans, to plan, invent </b>, (Thucydides) 2. <b>to have in one's mind, intend, purpose </b>, (Thucydides), etc: with <i>infinitive</i>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. aor1 <i>passive</i> ἐπινοήθην is used like Act, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G7438	ἐπιπολάζω	epipolazō	to float		1. <b>to come to the surface, float </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. <b>to be uppermost, to be prevalent </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 3. <b>to be forward; </b> with <i>dative</i> pers. <b>to behave insolently to </b>, (Lucian) 4. <b>to be engaged upon </b> a thing, with <i>dative</i>, (Lucian) (ML)

G7440	ἐπιρρέω	epirreō	to overflow		1. <b>to flow upon the surface, float a-top </b>, like oil on water, (Iliad by Homer) 2. <b>to flow in besides, flow fresh and fresh </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus);<i>metaphorically</i> of large bodies of men, <b>to stream on and on </b>, (Iliad by Homer); also, οὑπιρρέων χρόνος <b>onward-streaming </b> time, i. e. the future, (Aeschulus Tragicus); ὄλβου ἐπιρρυέντος if wealth <b>flows on and on, increases continually </b>, (Euripides) (ML)
G7441	ἐπίσαγμα	episagma	a saddle		<b>a load on </b> a beast's back;<i>metaphorically</i>, τοὐπίσαγμα τοῦ νοσήματος the <b>burden </b> of the disease, (Sophocles Tragicus) from ἐπισάττω (ML)

G7443	ἐπισείω	episeiō	to stir up		1. <b>to shake at </b> or <b>against </b>, with the view of scaring, τί τινι (Iliad by Homer); Πέρσας ἐπ. <b>to hold </b> them <b>out as a threat </b>, (Plutarch); but, ἐπ. τὴν χεῖρα, in token of assent, (Lucian) 2. <b>to set upon </b> one, with <i>dative</i>, (Euripides) (ML)
G7444	ἐπισημαίνω	episēmainō	to mark		1. <b>to set a mark upon </b> a person, of a disease, (Thucydides): Pass. <b>to have a mark set on one </b>, (Euripides) 2. <b>to indicate </b>, (Plutarch) 3. Mid. <b>to mark for oneself, signify, indicate </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 4. <b>to set one's seal to </b> a thing, <b>approve </b> it, (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)

G7465	ἐπιτρέχω	epitrechō	to run to		1. <b>to run upon </b> or <b>at </b>, for the purpose of attack, (Iliad by Homer); of dogs, (Odyssey by Homer); so in attic <b>to make an assault upon </b>, τινί (Thucydides) 2. <b>to run after </b>, ἐπιδραμών <b>in haste, eagerly </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. <b>to run over </b> a space, (Iliad by Homer): <b>to run over </b> or <b>graze the surface </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 4. <b>to be spread over </b>, of a mist, (Odyssey by Homer);with <i>accusative</i>, οἶδμα ὅταν ἔρεβος ἐπιδράμῃ when the billow <b>runs over </b> the deep, (Sophocles Tragicus) 5. <b>to overrun </b>, as an army does a country, (Herdotus Historicus) 6. <b>to run over, to treat lightly of </b>, Lat. <i>percurrere</i>, (Xenophon Historicus) 7. <b>to run close after </b>, (Iliad by Homer) (ML)

G7620	ἡδύς	hēdus	agreeable		1. <b>sweet </b> to the taste or smell, (Homer); to the hearing, (Homer); then of any <b>pleasant </b> feeling or state, as sleep, (Homer);with <i>infinitive</i>, ἡδὺς δρακεῖν (Aeschulus Tragicus); ἡδὺς ἀκοῦσαι λόγος (Plato Philosophus); ἡδύ ἐστι or γίγνεται it is <b>pleasant </b>, (Homer), etc;so, οὔ μοι ἥδιόν ἐστι λέγειν I had rather not say, (Herdotus Historicus);<i>neuter</i> as <i>Substantive</i>, τὰ ἡδέα <b>pleasures </b>, (Thucydides);<i>neuter</i> as <i>adverb</i>, <b>sweetly </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc. 2. after (Homer), of persons, <b>pleasant, welcome </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 3. <b>well-pleased, glad </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); in addressing a person, ὦ ἥδιστε, Horace's <b>dulcissime rerum </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 4. like εὐήθης, <b>innocent, simple </b>, ὡς ἡδὺς εἶ (Plato Philosophus) 5. <i>adverb</i> ἡδέως, <b>sweetly, pleasantly, with pleasure </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc; ἡδέως ἂν ἐροίμην I would <b>gladly </b> ask, should like to ask, (Demosthenes Orator); ἡδ. ἔχειν τι to be <b>pleased </b> or <b>content </b> with, (Euripides); ἡδ. ἔχειν πρός τινα or τινί to be <b>kind, well-disposed </b> to one, (Demosthenes Orator); <i>comparative</i> ἥδιον (Plato Philosophus), etc;Sup, ἥδιστα (Plato Philosophus) (ML)

G7626	ἤλεκτρον	ēlektron	molten bronze		<b>electron </b>, a word sometimes used to denote <b>amber </b>, as probably in (Homer) and (Herdotus Historicus);sometimes <b>pale gold </b>, a compound of 1 part of silver to 4 of gold, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc;In (Aristophanes Comicus) ἐκπιπτουσῶν τῶν ἠλέκτρων, the ἤλεκτροι are probably the pegs of the lyre <b>made of </b> or <b>inlaid with electron. </b> derivation uncertain (ML)

G7629	ἡμίονος	hēmionos	the mule		1. <b>a half-ass </b>, i. e. <b>a mule </b>, (Homer), etc; <i>proverbial</i>, ἐπεὰν ἡμίονοι τέκωσι, i. e. never, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. the ἡμ. ἀγροτέρα of (Iliad by Homer) 2. 851 is probably the <b>wild ass. </b> 3. as <i>adjective</i>, βρέφος ἡμίονον <b>a mule- </b>foal, (Iliad by Homer); ἡμ. βασιλεύς a <b>mule- </b>king, half-Mede half-Persian, (Oracle quoted in Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G7633	ἡνίοχος	hēniochos	a charioteer		1. <b>one who holds the reins, a driver, charioteer </b>, opp. to παραιβάτης <b>(the warrior by his side)</b>, (Iliad by Homer) 2. generally <b>a chariot-driver </b>, as in the games, (Pindar), attic;in (Theognis Elegiacus), <b>a rider. </b> 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>a guide, governor </b>, (Pindar) (ML)
G7634	ἧπαρ	hēpar	the liver		<b>the liver </b>, (Homer), etc; ὑφ᾽ ἥπατος φέρειν, of <b>pregnant </b> women, (Euripides);in [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota as the seat of the passions, anger, fear, etc, answering therefore to our "heart." (ML)
G7635	ἠρεμάζω	ēremazō	be calm	G:V	be calm (MT)
G7636	ἥρως	hērōs	a hero		1. a hero, in (Homer) used of the Greeks before Troy, then of <b>warriors </b> generally; and then of all free men of the heroic age, as the minstrel Demodocus, the herald Mulius, even the unwarlike Phaeacians. 2. in (Hesiod) <b>the blessed heroes </b> are the fourth age of men, who fell before Thebes and Troy, and then passed to the Islands of the Blest. 3. <b>heroes, as objects of worship, demigods </b> or men born from a god and a mortal, as Hercules, Aeneas, Memnon, (Herdotus Historicus); then of such as had done great services to mankind, as Daedalus, Triptolemus, Theseus, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina 4. later, the heroes are <b>inferior local deities </b>, patrons of tribes, cities, guilds, founders of cities, etc; as at Athens, the ἥρωες ἐπώνυμοι were <b>the heroes after whom the </b> φυλαί <b>were named </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G7638	ἠχώ	ēchō	an echo		1. <b>a sound </b>, but properly of <b>a returned sound, echo </b>, (Homeric Hymns), etc. 2. generally, <b>a ringing sound </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) (ML)

G7663	θεσμός	thesmos	a rule		1. like θέμις, <b>that which is laid down and established, a law, ordinance </b>, Lat. <i>institutum</i>, λέκτροιο θεσμὸν ἵκοντο, i. e. they fulfilled <b>the established law </b> of wedlock, (Odyssey by Homer); so in (Herdotus Historicus) and attic 2. at Athens, Draco's laws were called θεσμοί, because each began with the word θεσμός (compare θεσμοθέτης); while (Solon Lyricus)'s laws were named νόμοι. 3. <b>an institution, ordinance </b>, as the court of Areopagus, (Aeschulus Tragicus); of the great games, (Pindar) (ML)

G7725	ἱππάζομαι	hippazomai	to ride a horse		1. <b>to drive horses, drive a chariot </b>, (Iliad by Homer): later, <b>to ride </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. Pass, of the horse, <b>to be ridden </b> or <b>driven </b>, (Plato Philosophus): <b>to be broken in for riding </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 3. ἱππάζεσθαι χώραν <b>to ride over </b> a country, (Plutarch) (ML)

G7728	ἱππεύω	hippeuō	to ride horseback		1. <b>to be a horseman </b> or <b>rider, to ride </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), attic;so in Mid, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. <i>metaphorically</i> of the wind, (Euripides) 3. <b>to be a trooper, serve in the cavalry </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) 4. of a horse, as we say "the horse <b>rides </b> (i. e. <b>carries his rider </b>) well," (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)

G7733	ἱστός	histos	a mast		1. <b>anything set upright </b>: 2. <b>a ship's mast </b>, ἱστὸν στῆσαι or στήσασθαι to step <b>the mast </b>, (Homer); <b>a rod, pole </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 3. <b>the beam </b> of the loom, which <b>stood upright </b>, instead of lying horizontal as in our looms, (Homer); ἱστὸν στήσασθαι to set up <b>the beam </b> and so begin a web, (Hesiod); ἱστὸν ἐποίχεσθαι to traverse <b>the loom </b>, because the weaver was obliged to walk to and fro, (Homer) 4. <b>the warp that was fixed to the beam, the web </b>, (Homer) (ML)

G7840	καταδύω	kataduō	to descend into		1. <i>intransitive</i>, in <i>active</i> <i>present</i> καταδύνω and <i>middle</i> καταδύομαι; <b>to go down, sink, set </b>, of the sun, ἠέλιος κατέδυ (Iliad by Homer); ἐς ἠέλιον καταδύντα till sun <b>set </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); of ships, <b>to be sunk </b> or rather <b>to be disabled </b> (see. infr. II), (Herdotus Historicus);of persons, καταδεδυκώς <b>having popped down </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus) 2. <b>to go down into, plunge into </b>, with <i>accusative</i>, καταδῦναι ὅμιλον, μάχην, δόμον, πόλιν (Homer); followed by a <i>preposition</i>, καταδυσόμεθ᾽ εἰς Ἀί̈δαο δόμους <b>we will go down </b> into, (Odyssey by Homer), etc;with a notion of secresy, <b>to insinuate oneself, steal into </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 3. <b>to slink away and lie hid </b>, καταδύομαι ὑπὸ τῆς αἰσχύνης (Xenophon Historicus) 4. <b>to get into, put on </b>, τεύχεα (Homer) 5. Causal, <b>to make to sink </b>, Lat. <i>submergere</i>, ἐμὲ καταδύουσι τῷ ἄχει (Xenophon Historicus); mostly in aor1, τοὺς γαυλοὺς καταδύσας (Herdotus Historicus); καταδῦσαι ναῦν <b>to cut </b> it <b>down to the water's edge, disable </b> it, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G7914	κατάρχω	katarchō	to rule		1. <b>to make beginning of </b> a thing, with <i>genitive</i>, (Aeschulus Tragicus); ὁδοῦ κατάρχειν <b>to lead </b> the way, (Sophocles Tragicus); rarely with <i>accusative</i> <b>to begin </b> a thing, (Plato Philosophus);with <i>participle</i> <b>to begin </b> doing, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. <b>to honour </b>, (Euripides) 3. G7934	κατατείνω	katateinō	to violently strain		1. <b>to stretch </b> or <b>draw tight </b>, (Iliad by Homer); κ. τὰ ὅπλα <b>to draw the </b> cables <b>taut </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. <b>to stretch so as to torture </b>, (Demosthenes Orator), etc. 3. <b>to stretch </b> or <b>draw in a straight line </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 4. <b>to hold tight down </b>, (Plutarch) 5. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to stretch oneself </b>: hence, 6. <b>to extend </b> or <b>run straight towards </b>, Lat. <i>tendere</i>, (Herdotus Historicus): <i>absolute</i> <b>to extend </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 7. <b>to strive against, strive earnestly, be vehement </b>, (Euripides): aor1 <i>participle</i>, <b>with all one's might </b>, λέγω κατατείνας (Plato Philosophus) (ML)
G7935	κατατέμνω	katatemnō	to mutilate		1. <b>to cut in pieces, cut up </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc: so in Mid, (Euripides); Pass, τελαμῶσι κατατετμημένοις with <b>regularly </b> cut bandages, (Herdotus Historicus); σπλάγχνα κατατετμημένα (Aristophanes Comicus) 2. κ. χώρην ἐς διώρυχας <b>to cut </b> it <b>up </b> into ditches or canals, (Herdotus Historicus); κατετέτμηντο τάφροι ἐπὶ τὴν χώραν (Xenophon Historicus) 3. with <i>double</i> <i>accusative</i> κ. τινὰ καττύματα <b>to cut </b> him <b>into </b> strips, (Aristophanes Comicus);Pass, κατατμηθείην λέπαδνα <b>may I be cut up </b> into straps, (Aristophanes Comicus) 4. κ. τὸν Πειραιᾶ <b>to lay </b> it <b>out </b> for building, (Aristotle Philosopher);Pass, ἡ πόλις κατατέτμηται τὰς ὁδοὺς ἰθείας <b>has its </b> streets <b>cut </b> straight, (Herdotus Historicus) 5. <b>to cut into </b> the ground, κατετέτμηντο τάφροι <b>there were </b> trenches <b>cut </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)
G7936	κατατέρπω	kataterpō	to delight		to delight (MT)
G7937	κατατήκω	katatēkō	to dissolve		1. <i>transitive</i> <b>to melt away, to make to fall away </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. Pass, with <i>perfect</i> <i>active</i> κατατέτηκα, <b>to melt </b> or <b>be melting away </b>, (Odyssey by Homer), attic (ML)

G7939	κατατρίβω	katatribō	to wear away		1. <b>to rub down </b> or <b>away; </b> hence, 2. of clothes, <b>to wear out </b>, (Theognis Elegiacus) 3. of persons, <b>to wear out, exhaust </b>, (Thucydides);Pass. <b>to be quite worn out </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus) 4. of Time, <b>to wear it away, get rid of it </b>, Lat. <i>diem terere</i>, (Demosthenes Orator): κ. τὸν βίον <b>to employ </b> it <b>fully </b>, (Xenophon Historicus); so in <i>perfect</i> <i>passive</i> <b>to pass one's whole time </b>, κατατέτριμμαι στρατευόμενος (Xenophon Historicus) 5. of property, <b>to squander </b>, (Xenophon Historicus) (ML)

Pass, <i>future</i> -φᾶνήσομαι, <i>aorist2 </i> κατ-εφάνην [ᾶ], <b>to become visible, appear </b>, (Homeric Hymns) 3. <b>to be quite clear </b> or <b>plain </b>, (Herdotus Historicus); κατεφάνη τῷ Δαρείῳ τεχνάζειν it was apparent to Darius that he was playing tricks, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G8040	κοῖλος	koilos	hollow		1. <b>hollow, hollowed </b>, <i>epithet</i> of ships, which in early times were hollowed out of trees, (Homer); later, κοίλη ναῦς was <b>the hold </b> of the ship, (Herdotus Historicus); so, ἡ κοίλη alone, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus);of the Trojan horse, κ. λόχος, κ. δόρυ (Odyssey by Homer); κ. κάπετος, of a grave, (Iliad by Homer); κ. δέμνια, of the bed <b>when no one is in it </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 2. of Places, <b>lying in a hollow </b> or <b>forming a hollow </b>, κοίλη Λακεδαίμων <b>the vale </b> of L, (Odyssey by Homer); κ. Θεσσαλία (Herdotus Historicus); κ. Ἄργος (Sophocles Tragicus); τὰ Κοῖλα τῆς Εὐβοίας (Herdotus Historicus); ἡ Κοιλή <b>the valley </b> of the Ilissus, (Herdotus Historicus); κ. λιμήν of a harbour <b>lying between high cliffs </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); κ. αἰγιαλός an <b>embayed </b> beach, (Odyssey by Homer); κ. ὁδός <b>a hollow </b> way, (Iliad by Homer); κ. ποταμός a river <b>nearly empty </b> of water, (Thucydides) (so Virgil, <b>cava flumina) </b>: <i>metaphorically</i> of the voice, <b>hollow </b>, μυκάσατο κοῖλον (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus); φθέγγεσθαι κοῖλον (Lucian) 3. as <i>Substantive</i> κοῖλον, ου, τό, <b>a hollow, cavity, ravine </b>, (Plato Philosophus); like κοιλία, of <b>the cavities </b> in the body, τὰ κ. γαστρός (Euripides); also, ἐν τῷ κοίλῳ καὶ μυχῷ τοῦ λιμένος (Thucydides) (ML)
G8041	κοιλοσταθμέω	koilostathmeō	to vault		to vault (MT)
G8042	κοιλόσταθμος	koilostathmos	vaulted		vaulted (MT)
G8043	κοίλωμα	koilōma	a hollow		<b>a hollow, cavity </b>, (Babrius Fabularum Scriptor), etc. (ML)
G8044	κοιμίζω	koimizō	to rest		1. <b>to put to sleep </b>, (Euripides); ἄημα ἐκοίμισε πόντον, i. e. the winds <b>suffer </b> the sea <b>to rest; </b> by ceasing (cf. Virg. <b>straverunt aequora venti) </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus): <i>metaphorically</i>, μεγαληγορίαν κ. <b>to lay </b> pride <b>asleep </b>, (Euripides); so, κ. τὰς λύπας (Xenophon Historicus);Pass, παῖς κοιμίζεται (Euripides) 2. of the sleep of death, (Sophocles Tragicus); also in Mid, (Euripides) (ML)
G8045	κοιτάζω	koitazō	to lay in bed		<b>to put to bed </b>;Mid, doric aor1 ἐκοιταξάμην, <b>to go to bed, sleep </b>, (Pindar) (ML)

G8062	κονία	konia	lime		1. <b>dust, a cloud of dust </b>, stirred up by men's feet, (Iliad by Homer); also in <i>plural</i>, like Lat. <i>arenae</i>, (Homer), etc. 2. <b>sand </b> or <b>soil </b> (see. ὑπερέπτω); (Iliad by Homer) 3. <b>ashes </b>, in <i>plural</i> like Lat. <i>cineres</i>, (Odyssey by Homer) 4. <b>a fine powder </b>, sprinkled over wrestlers' bodies after being oiled, to make them more easily grasped by the opponent;this powder was also used in the bath, (Aristophanes Comicus) ι- in κονίῃσιν, in other cases ι- usually. (ML)

G8070	κόρη	korē	pupil		1. <i>feminine</i> of κόρος, κοῦρος 2. <b>a maiden, maid, damsel </b>, Lat. <i>puella</i>, (Iliad by Homer), etc. 3. <b>a bride, young wife </b>, (Homer) 4. <b>a daughter </b>, κοῦραι Διός (Iliad by Homer); κ. Διός, of Athene, (Aeschulus Tragicus);in <i>vocative</i>, κούρα <b>my daughter </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 5. <b>the pupil </b> of the eye, Lat. <i>pupula</i>, because a little image appears therein, (Euripides) 6. <b>a long sleeve </b> reaching over the hand, (Xenophon Historicus) 7. Κόρη, doric Κόρα, ionic Κούρη, ἡ, <b>Cora, the Daughter </b> (of Demeter), name under which Persephone (Proserpine) was worshipped in Attica, τῇ Μητρὶ καὶ τῇ Κούρῃ (Herdotus Historicus), etc; Δημήτηρ καὶ Κόρη (Xenophon Historicus), etc. (ML)

G8073	κορυφή	koruphē	head		1. <b>the head, top, highest point; </b> hence, 2. <b>the crown </b> or <b>top of the head </b>, (Iliad by Homer), attic 3. <b>the top </b> or <b>peak </b> of a mountain, (Iliad by Homer) 4. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>the highest point </b>, Lat. <i>summa</i>, παντὸς ἔχει κορυφάν is the <b>best of all </b>, (Pindar); κορυφὰ λόγων προτέρων <b>the sum and substance </b> of ancient legends, (Pindar) 5. <b>the height </b> or <b>excellence of </b> a thing, i. e. <b>the choicest, noblest, best </b>, (Pindar) (ML)
G8074	κορώνη	korōnē	a crowbar		1. Lat. <i>cornix</i>, the chough or <b>sea-crow </b>, a small kind with red legs and bill, (Odyssey by Homer) 2. = κόραξ, <b>the carrion-crow </b>, (Hesiod) 3. <b>anything hooked </b> or <b>curved </b>, like a crow's bill, 4. <b>the handle on a door </b>, (Odyssey by Homer) 5. <b>the tip of a bow </b>, on which the bowstring was hooked, (Homer);<i>metaphorically</i>, βιῷ κορώνην ἐπιθεῖναι to put <b>a finish </b> to life, (Lucian) (ML)

G8080	κοῦφος	kouphos	light (in weight)		1. <b>light, nimble </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; used by (Homer) only in <i>neuter</i> <i>plural</i> as. <i>adverb</i> κοῦφα προβιβάς stepping lightly on, (Iliad by Homer);<i>metaphorically</i>, κουφότεραι φρένες <b>too buoyant </b>, (Pindar) 2. <i>metaphorically</i> also <b>light, easy </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 3. <b>empty, unsubstantial, vain </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. <b>light </b> in point of weight, opp. to βαρύς, (Plato Philosophus), etc; κούφα σοι χθὼν ἐπάνωθε πέσοι may earth lie <b>lightly </b> on thee, <b>sit tibi terra levis </b>, (Euripides); of soldiers, ὡπλισμένοι κουφοτέροις ὅπλοις (Xenophon Historicus) 5. <i>adverb</i> -φως, <b>lightly, nimbly </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus); κ. ἐσκευασμένοι, of soldiers, (Thucydides) 6. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>lightly, with light heart </b>, κουφότερόν μετεφώνεε (Odyssey by Homer); κούφως φέρειν to bear <b>lightly </b>, (Euripides); ὡς κουφότατα φέρειν (Herdotus Historicus) 7. <b>lightly, with ease </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) (ML)

G8089	κρατήρ	kratēr	a basin		1. <b>a mixing vessel </b>, especially <b>a large bowl, in which the wine was mixed with water </b>, and from which the cups were filled, (Homer), etc; οἶνον δ᾽ ἐκ κρητῆρος ἀφυσσάμενοι δεπάεσσιν ἔκχεον (Iliad by Homer); πίνοντες κρητῆρας drinking <b>bowls of wine </b>, (Iliad by Homer); κρητῆρα στήσασθαι ἐλεύθερον to give <b>a bowl of wine </b> to be drunk in honour of the deliverance, (Iliad by Homer); ἐπιστέψασθαι ποτοῖο, see. ἐπιστέφω. 2. <i>metaphorically</i>, κρατῆρα πλήσας κακῶν having filled <b>a bowl </b> full of woes, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 3. <b>any cup-shaped hollow, a basin </b> in a rock, (Sophocles Tragicus) (ML)

G8114	κυβερνάω	kubernaō	to devise		1. Lat. <i>gubernare</i>, to steer, (Odyssey by Homer), etc: <i>absolute</i> <b>to act as pilot </b> or <b>helmsman </b>, (Aristophanes Comicus) 2. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to guide, govern </b>, (Pindar) (ML)
G8115	κύβος	kubos	a cube		1. Lat. <i>cubus</i>, a cube: a cubical die, marked on all 6 sides (whereas the ἀστράγαλος was marked only on four sides), in <i>plural</i>, <b>dice </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; the Greeks threw with <b>three </b> dice, so that τρὶς ἕξ, three sixes, was the highest throw, (Aeschulus Tragicus); κρίνειν τι ἐν κύβοις to decide it by <b>the dice </b>, by <b>chance </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 2. also of the single <b>pips on the dice </b>, βέβληκ᾽ Ἀχιλλεὺς δύο κύβω καὶ τέσσαρα he has thrown two <b>aces </b> and a four, (Aeschulus Tragicus) quoted in (Aristophanes Comicus) 3. <b>a cubic number </b>, i. e. a number multiplied twice into itself, as 27 is the cube of 3, (Plato Philosophus) (ML)

G8144	κώπη	kōpē	an oar		1. any handle: 2. <b>the handle of an oar </b>, and generally <b>an oar </b>, (Odyssey by Homer), attic; νερτέρᾳ προσήμενος κώπῃ, = θαλαμίτης, <i>metaphorically</i> of a man of low rank, (Aeschulus Tragicus); παραπέμπειν ἐφ᾽ ἕνδεκα κώπαις, a proverb of dubious origin, meaning "to escort with all the honours, " (Aristophanes Comicus);<i>poetry</i> to express ships, σὺν κώπᾳ χιλιοναύτᾳ, of Agamemnon's fleet, (Euripides) 3. <b>the handle of a sword, the haft, hilt </b>, Lat. <i>capulus</i>, (Homer) 4. <b>the handle of a key </b>, (Odyssey by Homer) 5. <b>the haft of a torch </b>, (Euripides) (ML)

G8240	μάλα	mala	by all means		1. <b>very, very much, exceedingly </b>, (Homer), etc. 2. strengthening the word with which it stands, μάλα πολλά <b>very </b> many, (Homer); μάλα πάντες, μ. πᾶσαι, μ. πάντα, all <b>together, every one </b>, (Homer); μάλ᾽ ἀσκηθής <b>all </b> unhurt, (Odyssey by Homer); ἀβληχρὸς μάλα τοῖος so <b>very </b> weak, (Odyssey by Homer);so in attic, μάλα δὴ πρεσβύτης <b>very </b> old, (Xenophon Historicus); μ. γέ τινες ὀλίγοι (Plato Philosophus);so with Advs, πάγχυ μάλα and μάλα πάγχυ <b>quite </b> utterly, (Iliad by Homer); εὖ μάλα <b>right </b> well, (Odyssey by Homer); μάλ᾽ αἰεί for ever and aye, (Iliad by Homer); ἄχρι μάλα κνέφαος until <b>quite </b> dark, (Odyssey by Homer); μάλα διαμπερές <b>right </b> through, (Iliad by Homer);so in attic, to express repeated action, μάλ᾽ αὖθις, μάλ᾽ αὖ (Aeschulus Tragicus), etc; with Verbs, μή με μάλ᾽ αἴνεε praise me not <b>greatly </b>, (Iliad by Homer); ἡ δὲ μάλ᾽ ἡνιόχευεν she drove <b>carefully </b>, (Odyssey by Homer), etc. 3. strengthening an assertion, εἰ μάλα μιν χόλος ἵκοι if wrath come on him <b>ever so much </b>, (Homer); so μάλα περ with a <i>participle</i>, μάλα περ μεμαώς though desiring <b>never so much </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 4. in attic in answers, <b>yes, certainly, exactly so </b>, μάλα γε (Plato Philosophus), etc; μ. τοι (Xenophon Historicus), etc; καὶ μ. δή (Xenophon Historicus) 5. <i>comparative</i> μᾶλλον, <b>more </b>, (Homer); μᾶλλον τοῦ δέοντος more than is right, (Plato Philosophus), etc; παντὸς μᾶλλον <b>more than </b> anything, i. e. most certainly, (Plato Philosophus) 6. denoting increase, <b>more and more, still more </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); μᾶλλον μᾶλλον, Lat. <i>magis magisque</i>, (Euripides) 7. sometimes joined to a second <i>comparative</i>, ῥηίτεροι μᾶλλον (Iliad by Homer); μᾶλλον ἆσσον (Sophocles Tragicus), etc. 8. μᾶλλον δέ, <b>much more </b>, but <b>rather </b>, πολλοί, μᾶλλον δὲ πάντες (Demosthenes Orator) 9. in μᾶλλον ἢ οὐ, οὐ seems redundant, ἥκει ὁ Πέρσης οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ἐπp ἡμέας ἢ οὐ ἐπp ὑμέας the Persians have come not <b>more </b> against us, than against you, (Herdotus Historicus); in this case μᾶλλον ἢ οὐ is preceded by another <i>negative</i> 10. τὸ μ. καὶ ἧττον, a form of argument, which we call <b>a fortiori </b>, (Aristotle Philosopher) 11. Sup. μάλιστα, <b>most, most of all </b>, (Homer), etc; μάλιστα μέν, ἔπειτα δέ, <b>first and above all </b>, next, (Sophocles Tragicus); τί μάλιστ; what is the <b>precise </b> thing that you want? (Plato Philosophus); ὡς or ὅτι μ, Lat. <i>quam maxime</i>, (Plato Philosophus); ὅσον μ. (Aeschulus Tragicus); ὡς μ. <b>certainly </b>, in answers, (Plato Philosophus); ὡς δύναμαι μ. (Plato Philosophus); μακρῷ μ. (Herdotus Historicus) 12. ἐς τὰ μάλιστα <b>for the most part, mostly </b>, (Herdotus Historicus); so, τὰ μάλιστα (Thucydides), etc; also, ἀνὴρ δόκιμος ὁμοῖα τῷ μ. as famous as he that is most [famous, <a href="javascript:void(0)" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 13. ἐν τοῖς μ. <b>especially, as much as any </b>, (Thucydides) 14. μάλιστα may be added to a Sup, ἔχθιστος μάλιστα, μάλιστα φίλτατος (Iliad by Homer); μ. φίλτατος (Euripides) 15. with numbers, μάλιστα means <b>about </b>, (Thucydides), etc; so, ἐς μέσον μάλιστα <b>about </b> the middle, (Herdotus Historicus); ἥμισυ μ. (Thucydides), etc. 16. καὶ μάλιστα is used in answers, <b>most certainly </b>, Lat. <i>vel maxime</i>, (Aristophanes Comicus); so, μ γε (Sophocles Tragicus); μ. πάντων (Aristophanes Comicus) (ML)

G8306	μετέρχομαι	meterchomai	to pass between the ranks		1. <b>to come </b> or <b>go among </b> others, with <i>dative</i> <i>plural</i> or <i>absolute</i>, (Homer); μετελθών <b>having gone between the ranks </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 2. <b>to go to another place </b>, (Iliad by Homer): simply <b>to come next, follow </b>, (Pindar) 3. with <i>accusative</i> <b>to go after, to go to seek, go in quest of </b> (Iliad by Homer), attic: generally, <b>to seek for, aim at </b>, (Euripides) 4. in hostile sense, <b>to pursue </b>, (Iliad by Homer), attic: with <i>accusative</i> rei, <b>to seek to avenge </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus);then with <i>double</i> <i>accusative</i> <i>of persons or things</i>, μ. τι τινά <b>to visit </b> a crime <b>upon </b> a person, (Euripides) 5. of things, <b>to go after, attend to, to pursue </b> a business, (Homer), attic 6. <b>to approach with prayers </b>, Lat. <i>adire, prosequi</i>, τινα (Herdotus Historicus): <b>to court </b> or <b>woo </b>, (Pindar) (ML)

G8326	μηχανή	mēchanē	a machine		1. = Lat. <i>machina</i>: 2. <b>an instrument, machine </b> for lifting weights and the like, (Herdotus Historicus); μ. Ποσειδῶνος, of the trident, (Aeschulus Tragicus); λαοπόροις μ, of Xerxes' bridge of boats, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 3. <b>an engine </b> of war, (Thucydides) 4. <b>a theatrical machine </b>, by which gods were made to appear in the air, (Plato Philosophus): hence <i>proverbial</i> of any sudden appearance, ὥσπερ ἀπὸ μηχανῆς (cf. Lat. deus ex machina), (Demosthenes Orator) 5. <b>any contrivance </b>, for doing a thing, (Herdotus Historicus), etc: in <i>plural</i> μηχαναί, <b>shifts, devices, arts, wiles </b>, (Hesiod), attic; μηχαναῖς Διός <b>by the arts </b> of Zeus, (Aeschulus Tragicus); <i>proverbial</i>, μηχαναὶ Σισύφου (Aristophanes Comicus);Phrases, μηχανήν or μηχανὰς προσφέρειν (Euripides); εὑρίσκειν (Aeschulus Tragicus), etc;with <i>genitive</i>, μ. κακῶν <b>a contrivance against </b> ills, (Euripides); but, μ. σωτηρίας <b>a way of providing </b> safety, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 6. οὐδεμία μηχανή [ἐστι] ὅπως οὐ, with <i>future</i>, (Herdotus Historicus); also, μὴ οὐ, with <i>infinitive</i>, (Herdotus Historicus) 7. in adverb, phrases, ἐκ μηχανῆς τινος in some <b>way </b> or other, (Herdotus Historicus); μηδεμιῆι μηχανῆι by no <b>means </b> whatsoever, (Herdotus Historicus) (ML)

G8385	νέμω	nemō	to feed		1. <b>to deal out, distribute, dispense </b>, of meat and drink, (Homer), etc; of the gods, νέμει ὄλβον Ὀλύμπιος ἀνθρώποισιν (Odyssey by Homer); μοῖραν ν. τινί <b>to pay </b> one <b>due </b> respect, (Aeschulus Tragicus), etc;Pass, ἐπὶ τοὺς Ἕλληνας νέμεται <b>is freely bestowed </b> upon them, (Herdotus Historicus); κρέα νενεμημένα <b>portions </b> of meat, (Xenophon Historicus) 2. G8468	οἴχομαι	oichomai	be undone		1. Dep. <b>to be gone, to have gone </b>, Lat. abesse (not <b>abire) </b>, in <i>perfect</i> sense, and <i>imperfect</i> ὠιχόμην in <i>pluperfect</i> sense, directly opp. to ἥκω, <b>to have come </b>, while ἔρχομαι, <b>to go </b> or <b>come </b>, serves as the <i>present</i> to both, (Homer), etc;often with <i>participle</i>, οἴχεται φεύγων is fled <b>and gone </b>, (Iliad by Homer); ὤιχετ᾽ ἀποπτάμενος he hath taken flight <b>and gone </b>, (Iliad by Homer); οἴχεται θανών (see. infr. II. 1); also with an <i>adjective</i>, οἴχεται φροῦδος <b>he's </b> clean gone, (Aristophanes Comicus);with <i>accusative</i> pers. <b>to have escaped from </b>, (Iliad by Homer) 2. Special usages, 3. euphamistic for θνήσκω, <b>to be gone hence </b>, οἴχεται εἰς Ἀί̈δαο (Iliad by Homer); in attic, οἴχεται θανών (Sophocles Tragicus), etc;<i>participle</i> οἰχόμενος for θανών, <b>departed, dead </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; but in (Homer) simply <b>absent </b> or <b>away </b>, Ὀδυσῆος πόθος οἰχομένοιο desire of <b>the absent </b> Ulysses, (Odyssey by Homer) 4. <b>to be undone, ruined </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus); especially in ὤιχωκα or οἴχωκα, Lat. <i>perii</i>, (Aeschulus Tragicus), etc. 5. of things, to denote any quick, violent motion, <b>to rush, sweep along </b>, (Iliad by Homer) (ML)

G8472	οἰωνός	oiōnos	an omen		1. <b>a large bird, bird of prey </b>, such as <b>a vulture </b> or <b>eagle </b>, and so distinguished from a common bird ὄρνις); (Homer), etc. 2. <b>a bird of omen </b> or <b>augury </b>, (Homer), etc;the flight <b>to </b> (not <b>from) </b> the right, i. e. towards the East, was fortunate, and vice versa. 3. <b>an omen, presage </b>, drawn from these birds, Lat. auspicium or <b>augurium </b>, according as taken from <b>seeing their flight </b> or <b>hearing their cry </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc; δέκομαι τὸν οἰωνόν I accept <b>the omen </b>, hail it as favourable, (Herdotus Historicus) commonly derivation from οἶος; most birds of prey being <b>solitary; </b> compare κοινωνός from κοινός (ML)

G8512	ὅμορος	homoros	adjoining		1. <b>having the same borders with, marching with, bordering on </b>, τοῖσι Δωριεῦσι, τῇ Λιβύῃ (Herdotus Historicus); <i>absolute</i> <b>bordering </b>, (Thucydides); πόλεμος ὅμορος a <b>border </b> war, (Demosthenes Orator) 2. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>bordering on, closely resembling </b>, (Aristotle Philosopher) 3. also as <i>Substantive</i>, <b>a neighbour </b>, (Herdotus Historicus); κατὰ τὸ ὅμορον because of their <b>neighbourhood </b>, (Thucydides) (ML)

G8514	ὀμφαλός	omphalos	anavel		1. <b>the navel </b>, Lat. <i>umbilicus</i>, (Iliad by Homer), etc. 2. <b>anything central (like a navel) </b>: 3. <b>the knob </b> or <b>boss in the middle </b> of the shield, Lat. <i>umbo</i>, (Iliad by Homer) 4. <b>a button </b> or <b>knob </b> on the horse's yoke to fasten the reins to, (Iliad by Homer) 5. in <i>plural</i> <b>the knobs at each end of the stick round which books were rolled </b>, Lat. <i>umbilici</i>, (Lucian) 6. <b>the centre </b> or <b>middle point </b>, as the island of Calypso is the ὀμφαλός of the sea, (Odyssey by Homer); and Delphi (or rather a round stone in the Delphic temple) was called ὀμφαλός <b>as marking the middle point of Earth </b>, (Pindar), etc. (ML)
G8515	ὄμφαξ	omphax	an unripe grape		<b>an unripe grape </b>, πάροιθε δέ τ᾽ ὄμφακές εἰσιν (Odyssey by Homer); ὅτ᾽ ὄμφακες αἰόλλονται (Hesiod); ὅταν δὲ τεύχῃ Ζεὺς ἀπp ὄμφακος οἶνον, i. e. autumn, when the unripe grapes become fit to make wine, (Aeschulus Tragicus) (ML)

Lat. <i>unguis</i>, in (Homer) only in <i>plural</i> of the eagle's <b>talons; </b> of human beings, <b>a nail </b>, (Hesiod), attic;of horses and oxen, <b>a hoof </b>, (Xenophon Historicus);Special phrases, εἰς ἄκρους τοὺς ὄνυχας ἀφίκετο (i.e. ὁ οἶνος); warmed me to <b>my fingers' ends </b>, (Euripides); ὄνυχας ἐπ᾽ ἄκρους στάς <b>on tiptoe </b>, Lat. <i>summis digitis</i>, (Euripides); ἐξ ἁπαλῶν ὀνύχων from childhood, (Horace) <b>de tenero ungui </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina; ὀδοῦσι καὶ ὄνυξι, i. e. in every possible way, (Lucian) 2. <b>a veined gem, onyx </b>, (Lucian) (ML)

G8546	ὀρθόω	orthoō	be straight up	G:V	1. <b>to set straight </b>: 2. in height, <b>to set upright, set up </b> one fallen or lying down, <b>raise up </b>, (Iliad by Homer); ὀρθοῦν κάρα, πρόσωπον (Euripides);of buildings, <b>to raise up, rebuild </b>, or, generally, <b>to erect, build up </b>, (Euripides);Pass. <b>to be set upright </b>, (Iliad by Homer), etc: simply <b>to rise from one's seat, stand up </b>, (Aeschulus Tragicus) 3. in line, <b>to make straight </b>, (Aristotle Philosopher); Pass, ἢν τόδ᾽ ὀρθωθῆι βέλος if this dart <b>go straight </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. <i>metaphorically</i> (from signf. I) <b>to raise up, restore to health, safety, happiness </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc;also <b>to exalt, honour </b>, (Pindar) 5. (from signf. G8591	πάλλω	pallō	to agitate	G:V	1. <b>to poise </b> or <b>sway </b> a missile before it is thrown, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to sway </b> other arms, not missiles, σάκος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; πέλτας [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];then, <b>to toss </b> a child, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; Νὺξ ὄχημm ἔπαλλεν <b>she drave </b> it <b>furiously </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. κλήρους ἐν κυνέηι πάλλον <b>they shook </b> the lots together in a helmet, till one leapt forth, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <i>absolute</i> <b>to cast lots </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ὅθ᾽ αὐτοὺς οἱ βραβεῖς κλήροις ἔπηλαν where the stewards <b>ranged </b> them <b>by casting </b> lots, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Mid. <b>to draw lots </b>, ἔλαχον ἅλα παλλομένων I obtained the sea <b>when we cast lots </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; so in [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. Pass. <b>to swing </b> or <b>dash oneself </b>, ἐν ἄντυγι πάλτο <b>he dashed himself </b> upon the shield-rim, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <b>to quiver, leap </b>, especially in fear, πάλλεται ἦτορ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; also of the person, παλλομένη κραδίην [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; of dying fish, <b>to quiver, leap </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. <i>intransitive</i>, like the Pass, <b>to leap, bound </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <b>to quiver </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G8653	παριστάνω	paristanō	to present		<b>παρ-ιστάνω</b>, see: παρίστημι. <b>παρ-ίστημι </b> [in LXX for עָמַד, etc;] I. Transitive verb. in present tense, imperfect, future tense, 1 aorist; 1) <b>to place beside, present, provide</b>: with accusative, Act.9:41 23:24, 2Co.4:14, Col.1:28; with accusative and dative, Mat.26:53, Luk.2:22, Act.1:3 23:33, 1Co.8:8; before accusative pred, Rom.6:13, 16 (late pres, παριστάνετε), Rom.6:19 12:1, 2Co.11:2, Eph.5:27, Col.1:22, 2Ti.2:15. 2) to present to the mind (cl.): by argument, to prove (Xen, FlJ, al.), with accusative, Act.24:13. II. Intransitive. in perfect, pluperfect, 2 aorist; 1) <b>to stand by or beside one </b>: with dative of person(s), Act.1:10 9:39 23:2 27:23; ptcp, Mrk.14:47, 69-70 15:35, 39 Jhn.18:22 19:26. 2) <b>to appear</b>: with nom. pred, before ἐνώπιον, Act.4:10; with dative of person(s), Act.27:24; so fut. mid. (of. LS, see word, B, ii, 2), Rom.14:10. 3) <b>to be at hand, be present, have come</b>: Act.4:26 (LXX); of servants in attendance, ἐνώπιον τ. θεοῦ, Luk.1:19; absol, οἱ παρεστῶτες, Luk.19:24; before αὐτῷ, Act.23:2, 4; of time, Mrk.4:29 4) <b>to stand by for help or defence </b>(Hom, Dem, Xen, al.): with dative of person(s), Rom.16:2, 2Ti.4:17. G8689	πέλτη	peltē	a small shield		1. <b>a small light shield </b> of leather <b>without a rim </b> ἴτυς); <b>a target </b>, Lat. <i>cetra</i>, originally used by the Thracians, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. <b>a body of </b> πελτασταί, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>a horse's ornament </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. = παλτόν, <b>a shaft, pole </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G8708	πεντηκοστός	pentēkostos	fiftieth		1. <b>fiftieth </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. as <i>Substantive</i>, ἡ πεντηκοστή, 3. (i.e. μερίς); at Athens <b>the duty of one-fiftieth </b>, or <b>two per century </b>, on all exports and imports, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Isaeus Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; εὕρηκε καινὴν ἱππικῆς τινὰ πεντηκοστήν he invented a new <b>two per century duty </b>, in lieu of his cavalry service, i. e. paid this instead of it, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 4. G8797	πίτυς	pitus	pine tree		<b>the pine, stone pine </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];<i>proverbial</i>, πίτυος τρόπον ἐκτρίβεσθαι to be destroyed like <b>a pine </b>, i. e. <b>utterly </b>, because the pine when cut down never grows again, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G8798	πίων	piōn	plentiful		1. <i>neuter</i> πῖον, <i>genitive</i> πίονος, <b>fat, plump </b>, Lat. <i>pinguis</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; π. δημός <b>rich </b> fat, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; of oil, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. of soil, <b>fat, rich. </b> [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; also, πίονα ἔργα <b>pingues segetes </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ὀπώρας πίων ποτός, of wine, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. of persons and places, <b>rich, wealthy </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; πίονι μέτρῳ in <b>plenteous </b> measure, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus">Refs 3rd c.BC</a>] 4. The <i>comparative</i> and Sup. are πι-ότερος, πι-ότατος, as if from πῖος. (ML)
G8799	πλαγιάζω	plagiazō	to bend	G:V	<b>to turn sideways </b> or <b>aside </b>, πλ. πρὸς τοὺς ἀντίους ἀνέμους (i.e. τὴν ναῦν); <b>to beat up </b> against adverse winds, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Lucian">Refs 2nd c.AD</a>]: <i>metaphorically</i>, πλ. ἢ φωνὴν ἢ πρᾶξιν <b>to adapt </b> them <b>to circumstances </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plutarch">1st/2nd c.AD</a>] (ML)
G8800	πλάγιος	plagios	sideways		1. <b>placed sideways, slanting, aslant </b>, Lat. <i>obliquus</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. πλάγια, ων, τά, <b>the sides </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];in military sense, τοῖς πλαγίοις ἐπιέναι to attack <b>the flanks </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; εἰς τὰ πλ. παράγειν or παραπέμπειν to make an army file off <b>right and left </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; πλαγίους λαβεῖν τοὺς πολεμίους to take the enemy <b>in flank </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. with Preps. in <i>adverbial</i> sense, εἰς πλάγιον <b>obliquely </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; εἰς τὰ πλάγια, opp. to εἰς τὸ ἀντίον, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἐκ πλαγίου <b>in flank </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; κατὰ πλάγια [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>not straightforward, crooked, treacherous </b>, φρένες [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πλάγια φρονεῖν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G8840	πολέμιος	polemios	warlike		1. <b>of </b> or <b>belonging to war </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc; τὰ πολέμια <b>whatever belongs to war, war and its business </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. <b>of </b> or <b>like an enemy, hostile </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota, etc; π. τινι <b>hostile </b> to one, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc;as <i>Substantive</i> <b>an enemy </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], attic; οἱ π. <b>the enemy </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τὸ π. <b>hostility </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. generally, <b>opposed, adverse </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. <b>of </b> or <b>from the enemy </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πολέμια, ων, τά, <b>enemy's wares, contraband </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; ἡ πολεμία (i.e. γῆ, χώρα); <b>the enemy's country </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 5. <i>adverb</i> -ίως, <b>in hostile manner </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G8862	πονέω	poneō	to suffer pain		1. in early Greek only as Dep. 2. <i>absolute</i> <b>to work hard, do work, suffer toil </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; περὶ δόρπα πονέοντο <b>were busied </b> about their supper, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; so, πεπόνητο καθ᾽ ἵππους <b>was busy </b> with the horses, of a charioteer, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to be in distress, to distress oneself </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; G8881	πρέσβυς	presbus	an ambassador		1. <b>an old man </b>, Lat. <i>senex</i>, (the prose form is πρεσβύτης); [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ὁ πρέσβυς is used much like ὁ πρεσβύτερος, <b>the elder </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>];<i>plural</i> πρέσβεις, <b>elders </b>, always implying dignity, <b>chiefs, princes </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; epic πρέσβηες [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 2. [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] uses only the <i>comparative</i> and Sup, <i>comparative</i> πρεσβύτερος, α, ον, <b>elder, older </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], attic; ἐνιαυτῷ by a year, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; βουλαὶ πρεσβύτεραι <b>the wise </b> councils <b>of age </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Sup. πρεσβύτατος, η, ον, <b>eldest </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc;the <i>comparative</i> and Sup. were used of things, πρεσβύτερόν τι (or οὐδὲν); ἔχειν = Lat. <i>aliquid (or nihil) antiquius habere<i>, to deem <b>higher, more important </b>, τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ πρεσβύτερα ποιεῖσθαι ἢ τὰ τῶν ἀνδρῶν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρεσβύτατον κρίνειν τι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρεσβυτέρως γυμναστικὴν μουσικῆς τετιμηκέναι <b>more highly than. </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];hence, merely of magnitude, πρεσβύτερον κακὸν κακοῦ one evil <b>greater than </b> another, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. like πρεσβευτής, <b>an ambassador </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];<i>plural</i> πρέσβεις is more used than πρεσβευταί, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 4. <b>a chief, president </b>: <i>comparative</i> πρεσβύτερος, <b>an elder of the Jewish Council </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="New Testament">Refs 1st c.AD</a>], etc: <b>an elder of the Church, presbyter </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="New Testament">Refs 1st c.AD</a>] (ML)
G8882	πρήθω	prēthō	to bloat		1. <b>to blow up, swell out by blowing </b>, ἔπρησεν δ᾽ ἄνεμος μέσον ἱστίον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to blow out, drive out by blowing </b>, τὸ δ᾽ [αἷμα] ἀνὰ στόμα πρῆσε he <b>blew </b> a shower of blood through his mouth, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G8883	πρίαμαι	priamai	to buy		1. <b>to have </b> a thing <b>sold to one, to buy, purchase </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], attic; with <i>dative</i> pretii, πρ. κτεάτεσσιν ἑοῖσιν <b>to buy with </b> one's money, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; with <i>genitive</i>, πρ. θανάτοιο <b>to purchase by </b> his death, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρ. τι ταλάντου [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; π. πολλοῦ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; <i>metaphorically</i>, οὐδενὸς λόγου πρίασθαι <b>to buy at </b> no price, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρ. τι παρά τινος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρ. τίμιον τοὔλαιον <b>to buy </b> it dear, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to farm </b> a tax, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

πρ. σφᾶς αὑτούς <b>gave </b> themselves <b>up as lost </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 11. <b>to desert, abandon </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; προέσθαι ἀπὸ τῶν ἰδίων [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 13. <b>to throw off </b> one's clothes, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]: and, in bad sense, <b>to throw away </b>, τὸν καιρόν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; G8911	προσβάλλω	prosballō	to strike up		1. <b>to strike </b> or <b>dash against </b>, τί τινι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ἀψῖδα πέτρῳ πρ. <b>letting </b> it <b>dash against </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τὸν πρὶν ὄλβον ἕρματι πρ. <b>to wreck </b> his happiness on a rock, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; πρ. θηρία τινί <b>to set </b> them <b>on </b> him, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; πρ. δόρυ τινί [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];without any notion of violence, <b>to put to, apply </b>, μαλακὰν χέρα πρ. Λακεδαιμονίοις Ὀλυμπιάδα <b>to give </b> them <b>the honour of </b> an Olympic victory, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρ. κακὸν τῇ πόλει [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; εὔκλειαν σαυτῇ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρ. δεῖμά τινι, Lat. <i>incutere timorem alicui</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. with <i>accusative</i> of the object struck, ἀρούρας προσβάλλειν, of the Sun, <b>to strike </b> the earth <b>with </b> his rays, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; of smells, βροτοῦ [ὀσμὴ] με προσέβαλε [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to attend to </b> a thing or <b>to add </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. μή μ᾽ ἀνάγκῃ προσβάλῃς τάδ᾽ εἰκαθεῖν <b>do </b> not <b>drive </b> me by force to give way, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 6. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to strike against, to make an attack </b> or <b>assault upon </b>, τινί [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc; πρὸς τὸ τεῖχος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>absolute</i> <b>to attack, charge </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; προσβαλὼν αἱρεῖ τὴν πόλιν <b>by assault </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 7. <b>to put in </b> with a ship, ἐς τὸν λιμένα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πρὸς Τάραντα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; with <i>dative</i>, Σικελίᾳ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 8. G8975	πτερόν	pteron	a feather		1. mostly in <i>plural</i> <b>feathers </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; in <i>singular</i> <b>a feather </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. = πτέρυξ, <b>a bird's wing </b>, in <i>plural</i> <b>wings </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; Παλλάδος ὑπὸ πτεροῖς ὄντας, <i>metaphorically</i> from chickens under the hen's wings, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; τῷ πτερὰ γίγνετο he got as it were <b>wings </b>, i. e. spirit, courage, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>the wings </b> of a bat (see. πτίλον II), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. <b>any winged creature </b>, as the Sphinx, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; a beetle, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 5. like οἰωνός, Lat. <i>avis</i>, an augury, omen, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 6. <b>anything like wings </b>: as 7. <b>a ship's wings </b>, i. e. <b>oars </b> (compare πτερόω); ἐρετμά, τά τε πτερὰ νηυσὶ πέλονται [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; νηὸς πτερά [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; hence birds are said πτεροῖς ἐρέσσειν, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 8. ἀέθλων πτερά, i. e. <b>the wings </b> of victory, which lift the Poet to heaven, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 9. <b>a feathered arrow </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 10. τοῦ πώγωνος τὰ πτερά <b>the points </b> of the beard, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Lucian">Refs 2nd c.AD</a>] 11. in Architecture, of <b>the rows of columns along the sides </b> of Greek temples, see. ἄπτερος. (ML)

G9073	σθένος	sthenos	strength (physical)		1. <b>strength, might </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];with <i>infinitive</i>, σθ. πολεμίζειν <b>strength </b> to war, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; σθ. ὥστε καθελεῖν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; σθένει <b>by force </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; λόγῳ τε καὶ σθένει both by right and <b>might </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; so, ὑπὸ σθένους [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; παντὶ σθένει with all <b>one's might </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>strength, might </b>, of all kinds moral as well as physical, σθένος τῆς ἀληθείας [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἀγγέλων σθ. their <b>might </b> or <b>authority </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>a force </b> of men, like δύναμις, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. <i>metaphorically</i>, like Lat. vis for <b>copia, a quantity, profusion </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. <i>periphrastic</i>, like βίη, ἴς, μένος, as σθένος Ἰδομενῆος, Ὠρίωνος, for Idomeneus, Orion, themselves, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9122	σκυτάλη	skutalē	a stave		1. <b>a staff, cudgel, club </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina 2. at Sparta, <b>a staff </b> or <b>baton </b>, used as a cypher for writing dispatches;a strip of leather was rolled slantwise round it, on which the dispatches were written lengthwise, so that when unrolled they were unintelligible: commanders abroad had a staff of like thickness, round which they rolled these papers, and so were able to read the dispatches;hence σκυτάλη came to mean <b>a Spartan dispatch </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; and generally <b>a message </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] derivation uncertain (ML)

G9134	σπανίζω	spanizō	be depleted	G:V	1. of things, <b>to be rare, scarce, scanty </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. of persons, <b>to lack </b> or <b>be in want of </b>, τινός [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc;so in Pass, ἐσπανίσμεθ᾽ ἀρωγῶν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]: <i>absolute</i> <b>to be in want </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9135	σπάνιος	spanios	sparingly		1. <b>rare, scarce, scanty </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; σπάνιον ἑαυτὸν παρέχειν, Lat. <i>difficiles aditus habere</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; ὕδατι σπανίῳ χρώμενοι having a <b>scanty </b> supply of water, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; with <i>infinitive</i>, σπ. ἰδεῖν <b>rare </b> to behold, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: of persons in an <i>adverb</i> sense, σπάνιος ἐπιφοιτᾷ he <b>seldom </b> visits, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; σπάνιόν ἐστι, with <i>infinitive</i>, <b>it is seldom </b> that, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; τὸ σπάνιον = σπάνις, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschines Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 2. <i>comparative</i> σπανιώτερος, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Sup. -ώτατος, attic 3. <i>adverb</i> -ίως, <b>seldom </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; so σπανίᾳ, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: <i>comparative</i> -ιώτερον, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9145	σπονδή	spondē	a libation		1. <b>a drink-offering </b>, i. e. the wine poured out to the gods before drinking, Lat. <i>libatio</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; σπονδὰς θεοῖς λείβειν, σπένδειν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. in <i>plural</i>, σπονδαί was <b>a solemn treaty </b> or <b>truce </b>, (because <b>solemn drink-offerings </b> were made on concluding them); σπονδαὶ ἄκρητοι <b>the truce </b> made by pouring unmixed wine, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; αἱ Λακεδαιμονίων σπ. <b>the truce with </b> them. G9150	σταθμός	stathmos	a doorpost		1. <b>a standing place </b> for animals, Lat. <i>stabulum</i>, a stable, fold, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <b>a stye </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: of men, <b>a dwelling, abode </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>quarters, lodgings </b> for travellers or soldiers, Lat. <i>statio</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. in Persia, σταθμοί were <b>stations </b> on the royal road, where the king rested, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: hence <b>a day's journey, day's march </b>, averaging about 5 parasangs or 15 miles, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. like Lat. <i>statio</i>, a station for ships, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>an upright post, the bearing pillar </b> of the roof, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <b>a door-post </b>, especially in <i>plural</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], attic 6. <b>the balance </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ἱστᾶν σταθμῷ τι πρός τι to weigh one thing against another, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 7. <b>weight </b>, σταθμὸν ἔχειν τάλαντον to weigh a talent, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; <i>absolute</i> in <i>accusative</i>, ἴσα σταθμόν equal <b>in weight </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἡμιπλίνθια σταθμὸν διτάλαντα two talents <b>in </b> or <b>by weight </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];in <i>plural</i> <b>weights </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. (ML)

G9228	σύγκειμαι	sugkeimai	be situated together		1. G9242	συγκροτέω	sugkroteō	to strike together		1. <b>to strike together; </b> ς. τὼ χεῖρε <b>to clap </b> the hands for joy, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; but also <b>to smite </b> them <b>together </b> in grief, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Lucian">Refs 2nd c.AD</a>];Pass. <b>to be applauded </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to hammer </b> or <b>weld together </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: hence, <b>to weld </b> a number of men into one body, i. e. <b>organise </b> them, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>], etc;<i>perfect</i> <i>passive</i> <i>participle</i> συγκεκροτημένος <b>well-trained, in good discipline </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9243	συγκυρέω	sugkureō	to fall in with		1. <b>to come together by chance </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <b>to meet with </b> an accident, συγκύρσαι τύχῃ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; εἰς ἓν μοίρας ξυνέκυρσας <b>art involved </b> in one and the same fate, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. with <i>participle</i>, like τυγχάνω, συνεκύρησε παραπεσοῦσα νηῦς fell in the way <b>by chance </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. of events and accidents, like συμβαίνω, <b>to happen, occur </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>impersonal</i>, with <i>infinitive</i>, συνεκύρησε γενέσθαι <b>it came to pass </b> that, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];so, in Pass, τὸ ἐς Λακεδαιμονίους συγκεκυρημένον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. of places, <b>to be contiguous to </b>, τινί [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Polybius Historicus">Refs 2nd c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9246	συκεών	sukeōn	a fig grove		a fig grove (MT)
G9247	συκοφάντης	sukophantēs	an extortioner		<b>a false accuser, slanderer </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc; (never used in the modern sense of <b>sycophant </b>, i. e. κόλαξ); generally, <b>a false adviser </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] (Commonly derived from σῦκον, φαίνω, <b>one who informed against persons exporting figs </b> from Attica: better perhaps <b>a fig-shewer </b>, i. e. <b>one who brings figs to light by shaking the tree </b> (the figs having been hidden in the thick foliage); and then, <i>metaphorically</i>, <b>one who makes rich men yield up their fruit by false accusations). </b> (ML)
G9248	συκοφαντία	sukophantia	extortion		1. <b>false accusation, slander, calumny </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. <b>a sophism </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9249	σύλληψις	sullēpsis	a seizing		1. <b>a taking together: a seizing, arresting </b>, ποιεῖσθαι ξύλληψιν <b>to arrest </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>conception </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plutarch">1st/2nd c.AD</a>] (ML)
G9250	συλλογή	sullogē	collection		1. <b>a gathering, collecting </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <i>metaphorically</i>, ἐν γενείου ξυλλογῇ τριχώματος in <b>the first harvest </b> of a beard, i. e. in early manhood, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>a levying </b> of soldiers, Lat. <i>conscriptio</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>a summary, recapitulation </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 4. (from Pass.) <b>an assembly, meeting </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Lysias Orator">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9257	συμβολή	sumbolē	a compact		1. <b>a coming together, meeting, joining </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: <b>the juncture </b> of two parts, <b>the end </b>, Lat. <i>commissura</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. in hostile sense, <b>an encounter, engagement, battle </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 3. = συμβόλαιον II, <b>a contract, covenant </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; in [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] Ach. there is a play on signfs. II and III, <b>encounter </b> and <b>accounts, charge </b> and <b>charges. </b> 4. in <i>plural</i>, συμβολαί were <b>contributions </b> for a common meal, πίνειν ἀπὸ συμβολῶν, like <b>de symbolis[<a href="javascript:void0" title="Terentius Grammaticus Latinus">Refs 2nd c.AD</a>] entertainment </b> itself, <b>a picnic </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9258	συμβολοκοπέω	sumbolokopeō	be fond of carousing	G:V	be fond of carousing (MT)
G9259	σύμβολον	sumbolon	a symbol		1. <b>a sign </b> or <b>token by which one infers </b> a thing, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; λαμπάδος τὸ σύμβολον <b>the token </b> of the beacon-fire, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>];often in <i>plural</i>, of <b>marks </b> on the body, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; of <b>omens </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>a pledge </b> or <b>pawn </b>, on which money was advanced, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Lysias Orator">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. in <i>plural</i> <b>tallies </b>, Lat. <i>tesserae hospitales</i>, i.e. <b>the halves </b> of a bone or coin, which two persons broke between them, each keeping one piece, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 4. at Athens, <b>a ticket, counter </b>, Lat. <i>tessera</i>, such as were given to the dicasts, on presenting which they received their fee, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>a permit </b> or <b>licence to reside, given to aliens </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; <b>a ticket </b> given by each person who joined in a picnic, to be presented for payment at the end (compare συμβολή IV), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 6. in Eccl. <b>the distinctive mark </b> of Christians, <b>a confession of faith, a creed </b>, Lat. <i>symbolum</i>. 7. in legal phrase, σύμβολα were <b>covenants between two states for protection of commerce </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>], etc; σύμβολα ποιεῖσθαι πρὸς πόλιν to make <b>a commercial treaty </b> with a state, τὰ ς. συγχέειν to violate <b>such treaty </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9264	σύμμετρος	summetros	well-proportioned		1. <b>commensurate with </b> another thing, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <b>exactly fitting </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; τῷδε τἀνδρὶ ξ. <b>being of like age with </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ποίᾳ σύμμετρος τύχ; <b>coincident with </b> what chance? i. e. in the very nick of time, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; see. infr. III. 2. 2. <b>commensurable </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>in measure with, proportionable, exactly suitable </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Isocrates Orator">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 4. <i>absolute</i> <b>in right measure, in due proportion, symmetrical </b>, opp. to ὑπερβάλλων and ἐλλείπων, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 5. generally, <b>fitting, meet, due </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; σύμμετρος ὡς κλύειν <b>within fit distance </b> for hearing, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 6. <i>adverb</i> -τρως, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Isocrates Orator">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 7. <b>in due time </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

with <i>accusative</i> only, συμμίξαντες τὰ στρατόπεδα <b>having combined </b> them, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Pass, of a river, <b>to be mingled with </b> another river, with <i>dative</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <b>to join forces </b>, of two armies, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>metaphorically</i>, οὐδείς [ἐστι] τῷ κακὸν οὐ συνεμίχθη there is none who <b>has not </b> misery <b>as an ingredient in his nature </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; G9297	συνάπτω	sunaptō	to join together		1. <b>to tie </b> or <b>bind together, to join together, unite </b>, ς. χέρα, in sign of friendship, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἰδού, ξύναψον (i.e. τὴν χέρα); [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; but, ς. χεῖρά τινος ἐν βρόχοις <b>to bind </b> it <b>fast </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ς. πόδα or ἴχνος τινί to meet him, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ς. κῶλον τάφῳ to approach the grave, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];
