ς. κακὰ κακοῖς <b>to link </b> misery with misery, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; but, ς. κακόν τινι <b>to link </b> him <b>with misery </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: ς. τινὶ δαῖτα <b>to give </b> one a meal, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <i>proverbial</i>, ς. λίνον λίνῳ <b>to join </b> thread to thread, i. e. to compare things of the same sort, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to connect in thought, to combine </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: ς. μηχανήν <b>to frame </b> a plan, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; ς. ὄναρ εἴς τινα <b>to connect </b> it <b>with </b> him, <b>refer </b> it <b>to </b> him, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ξυνῆψε πάντας ἐς μίαν βλάβην <b>involved </b> them in one loss, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. in hostile sense, ς. εἰς μάχην <b>to bring </b> into action, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἐλπὶς πόλεις ξυνῆψε <b>engaged </b> them <b>in conflict </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. ς. μάχην <b>to join </b> battle, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τινί with one, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; πρός τινα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: also (without μάχην); <b>to engage </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];Pass, νεῖκος συνῆπταί τινι πρός τινα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. in friendly sense, <b>to unite </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];Pass, συνάπτεσθαί τινι <b>to have intercourse with </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina 6. with <i>accusative</i> rei, ς. μῦθον, ὅρκους [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ς.τινὶ γάμους, λέκτρα, κῆδος <b>to form an alliance by </b> marriage, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: ξυνάπτεσθαι κῆδος τῆς θυγατρός <b>to get one's daughter </b> married, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 7. <i>intransitive</i>: 8. in local sense, <b>to border on, lie next to </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; G9410	τειχιστής	teichistēs	a stonemason		a stonemason (MT)
G9411	τεκνοποιέω	teknopoieō	to produce children		in Act, of the woman, <b>to bear children </b>, in Mid, of the man, <b>to beget them </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: in Mid. of both parents, <b>to breed children </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9412	τεκταίνομαι	tektainomai	to contrive		1. of a carpenter, <b>to make, work, frame </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];<i>absolute</i> <b>to do joiners' work </b>, opp. to smiths' work, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. of other artificers, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homeric Hymns">7th/6th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to devise, plan, contrive </b>, especially by craft, Lat. <i>machinari</i>, ἐτεκτήναντ᾽ ἀπόφθεγκτόν μ᾽ <b>they kept me </b> from speech of them, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; πᾶν ἐπ᾽ ἐμοὶ τεκταινέσθω (sc. Cleon) [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. later, Act. τεκταίνω, in same sense, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Lucian">Refs 2nd c.AD</a>]; hence <i>participle</i> <i>passive</i> τεκταινόμενος, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9413	τεκτονικός	tektonikos	a woodworker		<b>practised </b> or <b>skilled in building </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: as <i>Substantive</i> <b>a good carpenter </b> or <b>builder </b>, opp. to a smith, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; ἡ -κή (i.e. τέχνη); <b>joiners' work, carpentry </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. (ML)
G9414	τελαμών	telamōn	a ligature		1. <b>a broad strap for bearing </b> anything from Root! τλα, * τλάω, whence also the hero Telamon took his name, compare Ἄτλας 2. <b>a leathern strap </b> or <b>belt </b>, for bearing both shield or sword, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>a broad linen bandage </b> for wounds, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; for swathing mummies, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9415	τελεσιουργέω	telesiourgeō	to perfect a work		to perfect a work (MT)
G9416	τελετή	teletē	mystic rites		1. <b>initiation </b> in the mysteries, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc; ἐς χεῖρας ἄγεσθαι τὴν τελετήν to take in hand <b>the matter of initiation </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];in <i>plural</i> <b>mystic rites at initiation </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. <b>a festival accompanied by such rites </b>, in <i>plural</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; in <i>singular</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9417	τελευταῖος	teleutaios	finality		1. <b>last </b>, Lat. <i>ultimus</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τὰ τ. <b>the endings </b> or <b>terminations </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τελευταίους στῆσαι to station <b>in the rear ranks </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. of Time, ἡ τελευταία, with or without ἡμέρα, the <b>last </b> day allowed for payment, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; <b>one's last day </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>last, uttermost </b>, ὕβρις [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. τὸ τελευταῖον, as <i>adverb</i> <b>the last time, last of all </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc; or τελευταῖον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc; and τὰ τελευταῖα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>at last, in the last place </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc: but, 6. the <i>adjective</i> is often used with Verbs, where we should use the <i>adverb</i>, ὁ τελευταῖος δραμών [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; παρελθόντες τελευταῖοι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9418	τέμενος	temenos	a sacred precinct		1. <b>a piece of land cut off, assigned as a domain </b> to kings and chiefs, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>a piece of land dedicated to a god, the sacred precincts </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: in it stood the temple, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>metaphorically</i>, the <b>sacred valley </b> of the Nile is the τέμ. Νείλοιο, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; the Acropolis is the ἱερὸν τ. of Pallas, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9419	τέμνω	temnō	to prune		1. <b>to cut, hew </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; ὀδόντας οἵους τέμνειν teeth fit for <b>cutting </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to cut, wound, maim </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; πρὸς δέρην τ. <b>to wound </b> her in the neck, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 3. of a surgeon, <b>to cut </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <i>absolute</i> <b>to use the knife </b>, as opp. to cautery (κάειν), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc;Pass. <b>to be operated upon </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. <b>to cut up, cut to pieces </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; <b>to slaughter, sacrifice </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. ὅρκια τάμνειν <b>to sacrifice </b> in attestation of an oath, and so <b>to take solemn oaths </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; θάνατόν νύ τοι ὅρκι᾽ ἔταμνον <b>I made </b> a truce which was death to thee, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];Mid, of two parties, ὅρκια τάμνεσθαι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];cf. Lat. <i>foedus ferire</i>. 6. φάρμακον τέμνειν <b>to cut </b> or <b>chop up </b> a plant for purposes of medicine or witchcraft, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc; ἄκος τέμνειν <b>to contrive </b> a means or remedy, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 7. <b>to divide </b>, of a river, μέσην τ. Λιβύην <b>to cut </b> it in twain, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; δίχα τ. <b>to cut </b> in two, <b>bisect </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 8. <b>to cut asunder, cut off, sever </b>, κεφαλὴν ἀπὸ δειρῆς [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; with double <i>accusative</i>, ἐρινεὸν τάμνε ὄρπηκας <b>cut </b> the branches <b>off </b> the fig-tree, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; and in Pass, τρίχας ἐτμήθην <b>had </b> them <b>cut off </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 9. <b>to part off, mark off </b>, τέμενος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 10. <b>to cut down, fell </b> trees, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc;Mid, δοῦρα τάμνεσθαι <b>to fell oneself </b> timber, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 11. λίθον τ. <b>to hew </b> stone, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: Mid, λίθους τάμνεσθαι <b>to have </b> them <b>wrought </b> or <b>hewn </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 12. <b>to cut down </b> for purposes of destruction, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; τ. τὴν γῆν <b>to ravage </b> the country <b>by felling the trees </b> and <b>cutting the corn </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; with <i>partitive</i> <i>genitive</i>, τῆς γῆς τ. <b>to waste </b> part of it, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 13. <b>to cut </b> or <b>hew into shape </b>, δούρατα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc. 14. <b>to cut lengthwise, to plough </b>, Solon. 15. τ. ὁδόν <b>to cut </b> or <b>make </b> a road, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Pass, τέτμηνται κέλευθοι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 16. also <b>to make </b> one's way, <b>advance </b>, τ. ὁδόν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τὴν μεσόγαιαν τ. τῆς ὁδοῦ <b>to take </b> the middle road, <b>strike through </b> the interior, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; μέσον τέμνειν <b>to hold </b> a middle course, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 17. of ships, <b>to cut through </b> the waves, <b>plough the sea </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];so of birds, <b>to cleave </b> the air, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 18. <b>to bring to a decision </b>, Lat. <i>decidere</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9454	Τιτάν	Titan	titan		<b>the Titans </b>, a race of gods placed beneath Tartarus, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] (where two are named;Iapetus and Cronus), <i>accusative</i> to [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>], six sons and six daughters of Uranus and Gaia; hurled from Olympus into nether darkness, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: other names are given by later Poets, as Atlas, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; Prometheus, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; Θέμις [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; and in Lat. Poets <b>Titan </b> is the Sun-god. The oldest derivation of the name is given in [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>], <b>the stretchers, strivers; </b> others connect it with τίτας (from τίνω); <b>avengers. </b> (ML)
G9455	τιτρώσκω	titrōskō	to pierce		1. <b>to wound </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];Pass, τετρῶσθαι τὸν μηρόν <b>to have a wound </b> in the thigh, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];with <i>accusative</i> <i>cognate</i>, τιτρώσκειν φόνον <b>to inflict </b> a death <b>wound </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. generally, <b>to damage, cripple </b>, of ships, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>metaphorically</i>, of wine, <b>to do </b> one <b>a mischief </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9519	τύχη	tuchē	good luck		1. <b>the good which man obtains </b> τυγχάνει); <b>by the favour of the gods, good fortune, luck, success </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Theognis Elegiacus">Refs 6th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; σὺν τύχῃ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; θείᾳ τύχῃ, Lat. <i>divinitus</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; hence Τύχη was deified, like Lat. <i>Fortuna</i>, Τύχη Σώτειρα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; T. Σωτήρ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 2. generally, <b>fortune, chance </b>, good or bad, in <i>singular</i> and <i>plural</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], attic 3. rarely of positive <b>ill fortune </b>, ἢν χρήσωνται τύχῃ, i. e. if they are killed, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τύχῃ <b>by ill-luck </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Antipho Orator">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. especially, ἀγαθὴ τ. [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc; in <i>dative</i> ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ <b>"in God's name, " </b> [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>], etc; by crasis, τύχἀγαθῇ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];this formula was also introduced into treaties, like Lat. <i>quod felix faustumque sit</i>, Λάχης εἶπε, τύχῃ ἀγαθῇ τῶν Ἀθηναίων ποιεῖσθαι τὴν ἐκεχειρίαν Decret. in [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];so ἐπ᾽ ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 5. Adverbial usages, τύχῃ <b>by chance </b>, Lat. <i>forte</i>, forte fortuna, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; ἀπὸ τύχης [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; ἐκ τύχης [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; διὰ τύχην [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Isocrates Orator">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc; κατὰ τύχην [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 6. <b>a chance, hap, accident </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; τῆς τύχης, τὸ ἐμὲ τυχεῖν! <b>what a piece of ill-luck </b>, that! [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; mostly of <b>mishaps, misfortunes </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>], etc. (ML)

G9606	ὑφαιρέω	huphaireō	to take up		1. <b>to seize underneath </b> or <b>inwardly </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to draw </b> or <b>take away from under </b> a thing, with <i>genitive</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];also τὴν χεῖρα ὑφῄρει <b>tried to draw </b> it <b>away </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>to take away underhand, filch away </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ὑφ. τῆς ὑποψίας <b>gradually to take away </b> part of, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Pass, ὑπαραιρημένος (ionic <i>perfect</i> <i>participle</i>) <b>put secretly away, made away with </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];so in Mid. <b>to take away underhand, filch away, purloin </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 4. in Mid. also with <i>accusative</i> pers, ὑφ. τινά τινος <b>to rob </b> him of a thing, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschines Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9609	ὑφίστημι	huphistēmi	to stand		1. in these tenses Causal, <b>to place </b> or <b>set under </b>, τί τινι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; τρεῖς σταυροὺς ὑπίστησι <b>plants </b> three piles in the lake <b>to support </b> a house, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>metaphorically</i>, γνώμας ὑποστήσας σοφάς <b>having laid </b> them <b>as a foundation </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>to post secretly </b> or <b>in ambush </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 3. Causal also in <i>future</i> and aor1 <i>middle</i> <b>to substitute </b>, τί τινι one thing <b>for </b> another, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. Pass, with <i>aorist2 </i> <i>active</i> ὑπ-έστην, <i>perfect</i> ὑφ-έστηκα, ionic <i>participle</i> ὑπ-εστεώς; <b>to stand under as a support </b>, with <i>dative</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>to sink to the bottom, settle </b>, τὸ ὑφιστάμενον the milk, opp. to τὸ ἐφιστάμενον (the cream), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 6. <b>to place oneself under an engagement, engage </b> or <b>promise </b> to do, with <i>infinitive</i> <i>future</i>, ὅσς᾽ Ἀχιλῆι ὑπέστημεν δώσειν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; with <i>infinitive</i> <i>aorist</i>, οὔ τίς με ὑπέστη σαῶσαι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; with <i>infinitive</i> <i>present</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];<i>absolute</i>, <b>after promise given </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ὥσπερ ὑπέστη as <b>he promised </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];when followed by <i>accusative</i>, an <i>infinitive</i> may be supplied, τρίποδας οὕς οἱ ὑπέστη (i.e. δώσειν); [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ἐκτελέουσιν ὑπόσχεσιν ἥνπερ ὑπέσταν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 7. <b>to submit </b> to any one, τινι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 8. with <i>accusative</i> rei, <b>to submit to, consent to </b>, ὁ τὸ ἐλάχιστον ὑπιστάμενος <b>who offers to take </b> the least, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ὑφ. τὸν πλοῦν <b>to undertake </b> it <b>unwillingly </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; so, ὑφ. τὸν κίνδυνον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];rarely with <i>dative</i>, ὑφ. ξυμφοραῖς ταῖς μεγίσταις [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 9. <b>to undertake </b> an office, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 10. <b>to lie concealed </b> or <b>in ambush </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 11. <b>to support an attack, to resist, withstand </b>, with <i>dative</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; G9612	ὕω	huō	to rain		1. <b>to send rain, to rain </b>, Ζεὺς ὗε [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; ὁ θεὸς ὕει [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];then, the nom. being omitted, ὕει used <i>impersonal</i>, Lat. <i>pluit</i>, it rains, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ὕοντος <b>when it is raining </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; ὕοντος πολλῷ <b>as it was raining </b> heavily, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. with <i>accusative</i> loci, ἑπτὰ ἐτέων οὐκ ὗε τὴν Θήρην for seven years <b>it did </b> not <b>rain on </b> Thera, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];hence in Pass, with <i>future</i> <i>middle</i> <b>to be rained on </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ὕσθησαν αἱ Θῆβαι Thebes <b>was rained upon </b>, i. e. it rained there, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἡ χώρη ὕεται, i. e. <b>it rains </b> in the country, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. with <i>accusative</i> <i>cognate</i>, ὗσε χρυσόν <b>it rained </b> gold, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; καινὸν ἀεὶ Ζεὺς ὕει ὕδωρ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9713	χειρόω	cheiroō	to lay hands against		1. <b>to bring into hand, to manage, master, subdue </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. mostly in Mid, <b>to conquer, overpower, subdue </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota, etc: <b>to take prisoner </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; so, τήνδ᾽ ἐχειρούμην ἄγραν <b>became master of </b> this booty, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. without any sense of violence, <b>to master, subdue </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>], etc. 4. χειροῦμαι is also Pass. <b>to be subdued </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; <i>future</i> χειρωθήσομαι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>]; aor1 ἐχειρώθην [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; <i>perfect</i> κεχείρωμαι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9714	χελιδών	chelidōn	a swallow		1. <b>the swallow </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; the twittering of the swallow was proverbially used of barbarous tongues by the Greeks, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; χελιδόνων μουσεῖα (see. μουσεῖον); proverbs also, μία χελιδὼν ἔαρ οὐ ποιεῖ [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>the frog in a horse's foot </b>, so called from its being <b>forked like the swallow's tail </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9715	χελώνη	chelōnē	a tortoise		1. <b>a tortoise </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homeric Hymns">7th/6th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; prov. of insensibility, ἰὼ χελῶναι μακάριαι τοῦ δέρματος oh <b>ye tortoises </b>, happy in your thick skins! [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. like Roman <b>testudo, a pent-house formed of shields overlapping each other like the scales on a tortoise's back </b>, used by storming parties in approaching a city's walls: then, generally, <b>a pent-house </b> for protecting besiegers, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9716	χελώνιον	chelōnion	a lip		a lip (MT)
G9717	χερούβ	cheroub	a cherub		a cherub (MT)
G9718	χερσαῖος	chersaios	of dry land		<b>on </b> or <b>of dry land </b>, ὄρνιθες χ. <b>land- </b>birds, opp. to λιμναῖοι, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; χ. κροκόδειλος a lizard, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];also of <b>landsmen </b>, as opp. to seamen, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; κῦμα χερσαῖον στρατοῦ, an army, opp. to a fleet, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9719	χέρσος	chersos	uncultivated		1. <b>dry land, land </b>, ἐπὶ χέρσου, opp. to ἐν πόντῳ, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; κύματα κυλινδόμενα προτὶ χέρσον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; κῦμα χέρσῳ ῥηγνύμενον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; χέρσῳ <b>on </b> or <b>by land </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. as <i>adjective</i>, χέρσος, ον, <b>dry, firm </b>, of land, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἐν κονίᾳ χέρσῳ, opp. to πόντῳ, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>dry, hard, barren </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; χ. λιμήν a harbour <b>left dry </b>, [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina 4. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>barren, without children </b>, of women, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: with <i>genitive</i> <b>barren of </b>, πυρὰ χέρσος ἀγλαϊσμάτων [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] Prob. from same Root as ξηρός. (ML)
G9720	χερσόω	chersoō	to make barren		to make barren (MT)
G9721	χέω	cheō	to pour		1. Radic. sense, <b>to pour </b>: 2. properly of liquids, <b>to pour out, pour </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc; Zeus χέει ὕδωρ, i. e. he makes it rain, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; χέει χιόνα βορέας [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; <i>absolute</i>, χέει <b>it snows </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];Mid. <b>to pour for oneself </b>, especially of drink-offerings, χοὰς χεόμην νεκύεσσι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc;Pass, χέονται κρῆναι they <b>gush forth </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; χυθέντος ποτοῦ ἐς γῆν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. χ. δάκρυα <b>to shed </b> tears, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Pass, of tears, <b>to pour </b> or <b>gush forth </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; so of blood, <b>to be shed </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 4. in Pass. <b>to become liquid, melt, thaw </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 5. of solids, <b>to shed, scatter </b>, φύλλα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; πτερά [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; χ. κόνιν κὰκ κεφαλῆς [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; χ. καλάμην χθονί, of a mower or reaper (see. καλάμη), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 6. like χώννυμι, <b>to throw out </b> earth, so as to form a mound, σῆμα, τύμβον χ. [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 7. χ. δοῦρα <b>to pour </b> or <b>shower </b> spears, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; Mid, βέλεα χέοντο <b>they showered their </b> arrows, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 8. <b>to let fall </b> or <b>drop </b>, ἡνία [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; so, χέειν κρόκου βαφὰς (see. βαφή II) [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; but, καρπὸν χ, of trees, <b>to produce </b> fruit <b>abundantly </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 9. in Pass. <b>to be thrown </b> or <b>heaped up together </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 10. in Pass. also of living beings, <b>to pour </b> or <b>stream in a dense mass </b> or <b>throng </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 11. <i>metaphorically</i> of sounds, <b>to pour forth </b>, φωνήν, αὐδήν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; φθόγγον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 12. of things that obscure the sight, κατ᾽ ὀφθαλμῶν χέεν ἀχλύν <b>shed </b> a dark cloud over the eyes, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; πολλὴν ἠέρα χεῦε <b>shed </b> a mist abroad, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>];Pass, ἀμφὶ δέ οἱ θάνατος χύτο <b>was shed </b> around him, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; νόσος κέχυται [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; φρὶξ ἐπὶ πόντον ἐχεύατο (Mid. in <i>passive</i> sense), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 13. of persons, ἀμφ᾽ αὐτῶι χυμένη <b>throwing herself </b> around him, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: so in Mid, ἀμφὶ υἱὸν ἐχεύατο πήχεε [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>] 14. <i>perfect</i> <i>passive</i> κέχυμαι, <b>to be wholly engaged in </b>, Δᾶλος, ἐν ἇι κέχυμαι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9722	χηλή	chēlē	a claw		1. <b>a horse's hoof </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];also, <b>a cloven hoof </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. in <i>plural</i>, of <b>the talons </b> of a bird, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota; of a wolf's <b>claws </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus">Refs 3rd c.BC</a>] 3. <b>a sea-bank, breakwater </b>, formed of stones laid at the base of a sea-wall, to break the force of the waves (so called because it projected <b>like a hoof) </b>, Lat. <i>crepido</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. <b>the spur of a mountain </b> or <b>ridge of rocks </b> answering a like purpose, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>a cloven implement </b>, such as <b>a netting-needle; </b> compare χηλεύω. G9725	χηρεύω	chēreuō	be a widow	G:V	1. <i>intransitive</i> <b>to be bereaved </b> of a person or thing, with <i>genitive</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Theognis Elegiacus">Refs 6th c.BC</a>] 2. <i>absolute</i> <b>to be bereaved of a husband, to be widowed, live in widowhood </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>], etc;of a man, <b>to be a widower </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plutarch">1st/2nd c.AD</a>]; so, χηρεύσει λέχος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>to live in solitude </b>, of an exile, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. <i>transitive</i> <b>to bereave </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9727	χθών	chthōn	soil		1. <b>the earth, ground </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>, <i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota;to denote life upon the earth, ζῶντος καὶ ἐπὶ χθονὶ δερκομένοιο [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; χθόνα δῦναι to go beneath <b>the earth </b>, i. e. to die, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; κατὰ χθονὸς κρύπτειν τινά [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; κούφα σοι χθὼν ἐπάνω πέσοι [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. of <b>the nether world </b>, οἱ ὑπὸ χθονός, i. e. <b>those in the shades below </b>, Lat. <i>inferi</i>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; κατὰ χθονὸς θεαί, i. e. the Erinyes, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 3. <b>earth </b>, i. e. <b>the whole earth, the world </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. <b>Earth </b>, as a goddess, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>a particular land </b> or <b>country </b>, of Ithaca, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; of Libya, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; χθὼν Ἀσιᾶτις, Δωρίς, Ἀργεία, Ἑλλάς, Ἰδαία, etc, [<i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota (ML)

G9747	χορεύω	choreuō	to join in a dance		1. <b>to dance a round </b> or <b>choral dance </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; especially of the Bacchic chorus, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; <b>to take part in the chorus </b>, regarded as a matter of religion, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: <b>to be one of a chorus </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];with <i>dative</i> pers. <b>to dance to </b> him, <b>in </b> his <b>honour </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. generally, <b>to dance </b>, especially from joy, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>to practise </b> a thing, <b>be versed </b> in it, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 4. with <i>accusative</i> <i>cognate</i>, φροίμιον χορεύσομαι <b>I will dance </b> a prelude (to festivities), [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; χ. γάμους <b>to celebrate </b> them, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ὄργια Μουσῶν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];Mid, χορεύεσθαι δίνας <b>to ply the </b> eddying <b>dance </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Pass, κεχόρευται ἡμῖν (sings the Chorus) our <b>part is played </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 5. <i>transitive</i> <b>to celebrate in choral dance </b>, Ἴακχον [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];Pass. <b>to be celebrated in choral dance </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 6. Causal, <b>to set </b> one <b>a dancing, to rouse, wake to the dance </b>, τινά [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; so, πόδα χορεύειν [<i>variant</i> dates Anthology Palantina (ML)
G9748	χορηγία	chorēgia	a bestowing of expenses		1. <b>the office of a </b> χορηγός at Athens, <b>the defraying of the cost of the public choruses </b>, being the chief of the λειτουργίαι, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc. 2. <b>means for providing </b> χοροί: <b>abundance of means, fortune </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>supplies for war </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Polybius Historicus">Refs 2nd c.BC</a>] (ML)
G9749	χόριον	chorion	afterbirth		<b>the membrane that encloses the fetus, the afterbirth </b>, Lat. <i>secundae</i>: <i>plural</i> χόρια, ων, τά, <b>a dish made by stuffing it with honey and milk </b>, a kind of <b>haggis </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]: <i>proverbial</i>, χαλεπὸν χορίω (doric <i>genitive</i>) κύνα γεῦσαι "don't let a dog taste blood, " [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus">Refs 3rd c.BC</a>] (cf. Horace, <b>canis a corio nunquam absterrebitur uncto). </b> (ML)

G9756	χρέος	chreos	a debt		1. <b>that which one needs must pay, an obligation, debt </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; <b>a debt for stolen cattle </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; χρεῖος ἀποστήσασθαι to pay <b>a debt </b> in full, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ἀρᾶς τίνει χρ. pays <b>the debt demanded by </b> the curse, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; χρέος πόλει προσάπτειν to attach a further <b>debt </b>, i.e. <b>guilt </b> to the city, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; χρέος ἀποδιδόναι to repay <b>a debt </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];in <i>plural</i> <b>debts </b>, χρειῶν λύσις [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; τὴν οὐσίαν ἅπασαν χρέα κατέλιπε left all the property <b>in outstanding debts </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 2. <b>a needful business, an affair, matter </b>, ἑὸν αὐτοῦ χρεῖος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: <b>a requirement, a purpose </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: with <i>genitive</i>, like χάριν, <b>for the sake of </b>, σὸν οὐκ ἔλασσον ἢ κείνης χρέος [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. like χρῆμα, <b>a thing </b>, τί χρέο; = τί χρῆμ; <b>wherefore? </b> [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; ἐφ᾽ ὅ τι χρ. ἐμόλετ; [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. in [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], ἦλθον Τειρεσίαο κατὰ χρέος seems to be = Τειρεσίᾳ χρησόμενος, I came <b>to consult </b> him;but, κατὰ χρέος according to <b>what is due </b>, as is <b>meet </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Homeric Hymns">7th/6th c.BC</a>] 5. <b>a duty, task, charge, office </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <i>variant</i> dates Tragica Adespota 6. = χρεία, <b>want, need </b>, τί δὲ τοῦδ᾽ ἔχει πλέκους χρέο; [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristophanes Comicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G9795	ψιλός	psilos	bare		1. <b>bare </b>, 2. of land, ψιλὴ ἄροσις a <b>bare </b> corn-field, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; πεδίον μέγα τε καὶ ψιλόν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]: with <i>genitive</i>, γῆ ψιλὴ δενδρέων land <b>bare </b> of trees, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ψιλὴ γεωργία the tillage of land <b>for corn </b>, opp. to γ. πεφυτευμένη <b>(for vines </b> and <b>olives) </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 3. of animals, <b>stript of hair </b> or <b>feathers, bare, smooth </b>, δέρμα [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ἶβις ψιλὴ κεφαλήν <b>bald </b> on the head, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. generally, <b>bare, uncovered </b>, ψιλὸν ὡς ὁρᾷ νέκυν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>];with <i>genitive</i> <b>bare of, separated from </b>, ψιλὴ σώματος οὖσα [ἡ ψυχή] [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] b. <b>bare, stript of appendages </b>, ψιλὴ τρόπις the <b>bare </b> keel with the planks torn from it, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ψ. θρίδαξ a lettuce <b>with the side-leaves pulled off </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ψ. μάχαιραι swords <b>without other arms </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 5. οἱ ψιλοί (i.e. τῶν ὅπλων); <b>soldiers without heavy armour, light troops </b>, such as archers and slingers, opp. to ὁπλῖται, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>], etc; τὸ ψιλόν, opp. to τὸ ὁπλιτικόν, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; ψ. ἔχων τὴν κεφαλήν <b>bare-headed, without helmet </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 6. ψιλὸς λόγος <b>bare </b> language, i. e. <b>prose </b>, as opp. to poetry which is clothed in metre, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>]; also, ψ. λόγος is a <b>mere </b> speech, a speech <b>unsupported by evidence </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Demosthenes Orator">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 7. ψιλὴ ποίησις <b>mere </b> poetry, <b>without music </b>, i. e. <b>epic </b> poetry, as opp. to <b>lyric </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>];but, ψιλὴ μουσική <b>instrumental </b> music <b>unaccompanied by the voice </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aristotle Philosopher">Refs 4th c.BC</a>] 8. Oedipus seems to call Antigone his ψιλὸν ὄμμα, as being <b>the one poor </b> eye left him, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 9. <i>adverb</i> ψιλῶς, <b>merely, only </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Plutarch">1st/2nd c.AD</a>] (ML)
G9796	ψιλόω	psiloō	to make bear		1. <b>to strip bare </b> of hair, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; Pass. <b>to become bald </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Hesiod">8th/7th c.BC</a>]: generally, <b>to be laid bare </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Xenophon Historicus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] 2. with <i>genitive</i> <b>to strip bare of, to strip of </b> a thing, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. generally, <b>to leave naked, unarmed </b> or <b>defenceless </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 4. G20196	γίγνομαι	gignomai	gigno, gnatus.		<b>γίγνομαι</b>, see: γίνομαι. <b>γίνομαι</b>, Ion. and κοινή for Att. γίγν- (M. <i>Pr.</i>, 47; Bl, §6, 8 Mayser, 166 f.), [in LXX chiefly for היה;] 1) of persons, things occurrences, <b>to come into being, be born, arise, come on</b>: Jhn.1:15 8:58, 1Co.15:37; a first appearance in public, Mrk.1:4, Jhn.1:6, al; before ἐκ (of birth), Rom.1:3, Gal.4:4; διά, Jhn.1:3; βροντή, Jhn.12:29; σεισμός, Rev.6:12; γογγυσμός, Act.6:1; χαρά, Act.8:8, many other similar exx; ἡμέρα, Luk.22:66, al; ὀψέ, Mrk.11:19; πρωΐα, Mat.27:1; νύξ, Act.27:27. 2) Of events, <b>to come to pass, take place, happen</b>: Mat.5:18, Mrk.5:14, Luk.1:20 2:15, Act.4:21, 2Ti.2:18, al; μὴ γένοιτο [LXX for חָלִילָה, Jhn.22:29, al.], <b>far be it, God forbid</b>: Rom.3:4 (<i>ICC</i>, in l.), 1Co.6:15 and freq. in Pl; καὶ ἐγένετο, ἐγένετο δέ ([in LXX for וַיְהִי;] see Burton, 142 f; M, <i>Pr.</i>, 16f; Dalman, <i>Words</i>, 32 f; Robertson, <i>Gr.</i>, 1042 f.), with indic, Mat.7:28, Luk.1:8, al; before καί and indic, Luk.8:1, Act.5:7, al; with accusative and inf, Mrk.2:23, Luk.3:21, al; ὡς δὲ ἐγένετο, before τοῦ with inf, Act.10:25; with dative of person(s), <b>to befall one</b>: with inf, Act.20:16; with accusative and inf, Act.22:6; with adv, εὖ, Eph.6:3; τ́ ἐγένετο αὐτῷ (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 115), Act.7:40 (LXX); before εἰς, Act.28:6. 3) <b>to be made, done, performed, observed, enacted, ordained</b>, etc: Mat.6:10 19:8, Mrk.2:27 11:23, Act.19:26, al; before διά with genitive, Mrk.6:2, Act.2:43; ὑπό, Luk.13:17; ἐκ, Luk.4:23; ἐν, 1Co.9:15; ἀπογραφή, Luk.2:2; ἀνάκρισις Act.25:26; ἄφεσις, Heb.9:22; ὁ νόμος, Gal.3:17; τὸ πάσχα, Mat.26:2. 4) <b>to become, be made, come to be</b>: with pred, Mat.4:3, Luk.4:3, Jhn.2:9, 1Co.13:11, al; before ὡς, ὡσεί, Mat.10:25, Mrk.9:26; εἰς (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 71f.), Mrk.12:1 o, al; with genitive Rev.11:15; id, of age, Luk.2:42; with dative, γ. ἀνδρί ([LXX for הָיָה לְאִישׁ, Rut.1:12, al;] see Field, <i>Notes</i>, 156), Rom.7:3, 4; before ἐν, Act.22:17, Rev.1:10, al; ἐπάνω, Luk.19:19; μετά, with genitive, Mrk.16:[10], Act.9:19; before εἰς, ἐπί (Field, <i>Notes</i>, 135), κατά (ib, 62), with accusative of place, Act.20:16 21:35 27:7, al; before ἐκ, Mrk.9:7, Luk.3:22, 2Th.2:7, al. Aoristic pf. γέγονα (M, <i>Pr.</i>, 52, 145f; Field, <i>Notes</i>, 1f.), Mat.25:6, Luk.10:36, al. Aor. ἐγενήθη (for ἐγένετο, M, <i>Pr.</i>, 139f; Mayser, 379), Mat.11:23, al. (Cf. απο, δια, επι, παρα, συμ, παρα, προ.) (AS)

G20557	καρτερός	karteros	resolutely		1. <b>strong, staunch, stout, sturdy; </b> with <i>infinitive</i>, καρτερὸς ἐναίρειν <b>strong </b> to kill, (Iliad by Homer); τὰ καρτερώτατα <b>the strongest </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 2. with <i>genitive</i> <b>possessed of </b> a thing, <b>lord </b> or <b>master of </b> it, (Theognis Elegiacus) 3. like καρτερικός, <b>steadfast, patient </b>, πρὸς πάντα (Xenophon Historicus): <b>obstinate </b>, (Plato Philosophus) 4. of things, <b>strong, mighty, potent </b>, ὅρκος (Iliad by Homer); κ. ἔργα deeds <b>of might </b>, (Iliad by Homer); κ. μάχη <b>strongly contested, desperate </b>, (Herdotus Historicus); τὸ καρτερόν, τόλμης τὸ κ. <b>the extremity of </b> daring, (Euripides); κατὰ τὸ καρτερόν <b>by force </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc; so, πρὸς τὸ καρτερόν (Aeschulus Tragicus); τὸ καρτερόν, <i>absolute</i>, (Theocritus Poeta Bucolicus) 5. of place, like ὀχυρός, <b>strong </b>, (Thucydides); τὸ καρτερώτερον τοῦ χωρίου (Thucydides) 6. <i>adverb</i> -ρῶς, <b>strongly </b>, etc, κ. ὑπνοῦσθαι to sleep <b>soundly </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 7. the common <i>comparative</i> and Sup. are κρείσσων and κράτιστος (qq. see.): but the regular forms καρτερώτερος, -ώτατος, occur now and then, (Pindar), attic (ML)

G20727	μὴ οὐ	mē ou	isn't it?		1. after Verbs expressing <b>fear </b> or <b>apprehension, = </b> Lat. <i>vereor ut</i>, δέδοικα μὴ οὐ γένηταί τι I fear <b>it will not </b> be; whereas δέδοικα μὴ γένηται mean, I fear it <b>will be. </b> Here, μή and οὐ each retain their proper force. 2. with Inf, 3. after Verbs of <b>hindering, denying, avoiding, needing </b>, when μὴ οὐ resembles Lat. quin or <b>quominus </b>, οὐδὲν κωλύει μὴ οὐκ ἀληθὲς εἶναι τοῦτο <b>nihil impedit quin hoc verum sit; </b> or with the Art, οὐδὲν ἐλλείψω τὸ μὴ οὐ πυθέσθαι <b>nihil praetermittam quominus reperiam </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. after Verbs signifying <b>impossibility, impropriety, reluctance </b>, μὴ οὐ has a negative translation, δεινὸν ἐδόκεε εἶναι μὴ οὐ λαβεῖν (Herdotus Historicus); αἰσχύνη ἦν μὴ οὐ δυσπουδάζειν (Xenophon Historicus) 5. μὴ οὐ with the Partic, only after a <i>negative</i>, expressed or implied, δυσάλγητος γὰρ ἂν εἤν μὴ οὐ κατοικτείρων I should be hard-hearted <b>if </b> I did <b>not </b> pity, (Sophocles Tragicus) 6. = εἰ μή, <b>except </b> πόλεις χαλεπαὶ λαβεῖν, μὴ οὐ πολιορκία (Demosthenes Orator) (ML)

G20810	νόος	noos	point		1. <b>mind, perception </b>, (Homer), etc; νόῳ <b>heedfully </b>, (Odyssey by Homer); παρὲκ νόον <b>senselessly </b>, (Iliad by Homer); σὺν νόῳ <b>wisely </b>, (Herdotus Historicus); νόῳ λαβεῖν τι to apprehend it, (Herdotus Historicus); νόῳ ἔχειν to keep <b>in mind </b>, (Herdotus Historicus) 2. νοῦν ἔχειν means 3. to have <b>sense </b>, be <b>sensible </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus), etc; περισσὰ πράσσειν οὐκ ἔχει νοῦν οὐδένα to aim too high has no <b>sense </b>, (Sophocles Tragicus) 4. to have <b>one's mind </b> directed to something, ἄλλος᾽ ὄμμα, θἀτέρᾳ δὲ νοῦν ἔχειν (Sophocles Tragicus); δεῦρο νοῦν ἔχε (Euripides) 5. <b>the mind, heart </b>, χαῖρε νόῳ (Odyssey by Homer); so, νόος ἔμπεδος, ἀπηνής (Homer); ἐκ παντὸς νόου with all his <b>heart and soul </b>, (Herdotus Historicus), etc. 6. one's <b>mind, purpose </b>, τί σοι ἐν νόῳ ἐστὶ ποιεῖ; what do you <b>intend </b> to do? G21066	πρύτανις	prutanis	president		1. <b>a prince, ruler, lord, chief </b>, of Hiero, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; of Zeus, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>] 2. at Athens, <b>a Prytanis </b> or <b>President </b>: the πρυτάνεις were a committee of 50, chosen by lot from each of the 10 φυλαί, so that each set formed 1/10 part of the βουλή or Council of 500; out of these 50 πρυτάνεις one was chosen by lot as <b>chief-president </b> ἐπιστάτης); he chose 9 πρόεδρο; and the real business was in the hands of this smaller body, with a secretary γραμματεύς); added;The φυλή which first entered office every year was determined by lot; and their term of office πρυτανεία); was about five weeks. During this time all treaties and public acts ran in their name, in this form: Ἀκαμαντὶς φυλὴ, ἐπρυτάνευε, Φαίνιππος ἐγραμμάτευε, Νικιάδης ἐπεστάτει the Tribe Acamantis were the Presidency, Phaenippus the Secretary, Niciades the Chief-president, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Thucydides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] (ML)

G21355	ψάμμος	psammos	sabulum.		1. <b>sand </b>, so called from its loose, crumbling nature (from ψάω); [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Odyssey by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>], etc;<i>proverbial</i>, ψάμμος ἀριθμὸν περιπέφευγεν [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. ἡ ψ. <b>the sandy desert </b> of Libya, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Herdotus Historicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] Both ψάμμος and ψάμαθος sometimes drop ψ and become ἄμμος, ἄμαθος. G21365	ὠδίς	ōdis	[hudot]èbel		1. <b>the pangs </b> or <b>throes of labour, travail-pains </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Iliad by Homer">8th/7th c.BC</a>]; ἐν μόναις ὠδῖσιν at a single <b>birth </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἐν ὠδίνων ἀνάγκαις [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; in <i>singular</i> <b>travail-pain, anguish </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Pindar">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 2. in <i>singular</i>, also, <b>the fruit of travail </b> or <b>labour, a birth, child </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>]; ἄπτερον ὠδῖνα τέκνων, of young birds, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Euripides">Refs 5th c.BC</a>] 3. <i>metaphorically</i> <b>any travail, anguish </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Aeschulus Tragicus">6th/5th c.BC</a>]; also in <i>plural</i>, of love, <b>pangs </b>, [<a href="javascript:void0" title="Sophocles Tragicus">Refs 5th c.BC</a>, <a href="javascript:void0" title="Plato Philosophus">5th/4th c.BC</a>] (ML)
